Our conclusion may be as follows. There is no reason to question the external evidence which refers the Oedipus Coloneus to the latest years of Sophocles. But no corroboration of it can be derived from the internal evidence, except in one general aspect and one detail,—viz. the choice of an Attic subject, and the employment of a fourth actor. The Attic plays of Euripides, mentioned above, belong to the latter part of the Peloponnesian war, which naturally tended to a concentration of home sympathies. An Attic theme was the most interesting that a dramatist could choose; and he was doing a good work, if, by recalling the past glories of Athens, he could inspire new courage in her sons. If Attica was to furnish a subject, the author of the Oedipus Tyrannus had no need to look beyond his native Colonus; and it is conceivable that this general influence of the time should have decided the choice. In three scenes of the play, four actors are on the stage together. This innovation may be allowed as indicating the latest period of SophoclesA discussion of this point will be found below, in the note on the Dramatis Personae, p. 7..

div1.p: Scene: — At Colonus in Attica, a little more than a mile north-west of the acropolis of Athens. The back-scene shows the sacred grove of the Eumenides, luxuriant with "laurel, olive, vine" (v. 17). Near the middle of the stage is seen a rock (v. 19), affording a seat which is supposed to be just within the bounds of the grove (v. 37). The hero Colonus is perhaps represented by a statue on the stage (59 to/nde, cp. 65).

The blind OEDIPUS (conceived as coming into Attica from the W. or N.-W.) enters on the spectator's left, led by ANTIGONE. He is old and way-worn; the haggard face bears the traces of the self-inflicted wounds (duspro/sopton, v. 286): the garb of both the wanderers betokens indigence and hardship (vv. 747 ff.; duspinei=s stola/s, v. 1597). After replying to his first questions, his daughter leads him to the rocky seat (v. 19).

div2.head: 1-116: Prologue
div2.p: Prologue. Oedipus has sat down to rest, when a man of the place warns him that he is on holy ground. It is the grove of the Eumenides. At that word, Oedipus knows that he has found his destined goal; and, when the stranger has gone to summon the men of Colonus, invokes the goddesses.—Steps approach; Oedipus and his daughter hide themselves in the grove.

div3.p: ge/rontos. Sophocles marks the length of interval which he supposes between the O. T. and the O. C. by v. 395, ge/ronta d' o)rqou=n flau=ron o(\s ne/os pe/sh|. In the O. T. Oedipus cannot be imagined as much above 40,—his two sons being then about 15 and 14, his two daughters about 13 and 12 respectively. It was "long" after his fall when Creon drove him into exile (437, 441). It would satisfy the data of both plays to suppose that about 20 years in the life of Oedipus have elapsed between them.

*)antigo/nh. An anapaest can hold only the first place in a tragic trimeter, unless it is contained in a proper name, when it can hold any place except the sixth. Soph. has the name *)antigo/nh only four times in iambics. Here, in 1415, and in Ant. 11 the anapaest holds the fifth place; in O. C. 507, the 4th. But Eur. prefers the anapaest of *)antigo/nh in the 4th place: see Ph. 88, 757, 1264, 1323, 1465, 1636 (4th place) as against 58, 1476, 1588 (5th). The anapaest must be wholly in the proper name: hence Eur. I. A. 1570 e)/lece d), w)= qhrokto/n' *)/artemi pai= *dio/s was amended by Porson, e)/lece d), w)= qhrokto/n' *)/artemis *dio/s.

xw/rous, like loca, vaguely, "region" (so O.T. 798): but sing. xw=ros below (16, 37, 54), of a definite spot. Oed. already knows that they are near Athens (25), but it is time that the day's journey was ended (20); will this rural region—or town—supply their needs if they halt? The exordium has something of a Homeric tone,—due not merely to the form of the question (like that of Odysseus on awakening in Phaeacia, Od. 6.119, and in Ithaca, Od. 13.200 te/wn au)=te brotw=n ei)s gai=an i(ka/nw;), but also to the epic phrase a)ndrw=n po/lin (Il. 17.737 etc.).

planh/thn: cp. Eur. Heracl. 878 ce/noi planh/thn ei)/xet' a)/qlion bi/on. The word is not in itself opprobrious: in 123 it is merely opp. to e)/gxwros: cp. Plat. Rep. 371D kalou=men...tou\s...planh/tas e)pi\ ta\s po/leis, e)mpo/rous. In O. T. 1029 pla/nhs, said by Oed. to the Corinthian, takes its colour from the added e)pi\ qhtei/a|, "a vagrant hireling."

spanistoi=s, made scanty, given scantily: so Philostratus (circ. 235 A.D.) p. 611 a)/rwma...spanisto/n, "rare." This implies spani/zw ti as="to make a thing scanty" or rare, which occurs in Greek of the 2nd cent. B.C. (Philo Byzant. De septem mirabil. 4): cp. Shaksp. Lear 1. 1. 281 "you have obedience scanted." For a different use see Strabo 15. 727 (a land) spanisth\ karpoi=s, "poor in...," implying spani/zw tina/ as="to make one needy," whence the perf. pass. e)spani/smeq' a)rwgw=n (Aesch. Pers. 1024): and here again cp. Shaksp. Merch. 2. 1. 17 "if my father had not scanted me."
de/cetai: Xen. Anab. 5.5.24 ceni/ois... de/xesqai: Plat. Legg. 919A katalu/sesin a)gaphtai=s dexo/menos.

dwrh/masin, food, and shelter for the night: Od. 14.404 e)s klisi/hn a)/gagon kai\ cei/nia dw=ka (whereas dw=ra, or ceinh/i+a dw=ra, in Hom. usu.=special presents, as of plate or the like, Od. 24.273).

e)caitou=nta, "asking earnestly." This compound has a like force in O. T. 1255, Trach. 10; and so the midd. below, 586, 1327. Cp. e)cefi/etai, straitly enjoins, Ai. 795. In prose, the special sense of e)caitei=n was "to demand the surrender of" a person, answering to e)kdido/nai: Antiph. or. 6 § 27 ei)...qera/pontas e)caitou=si mh\ h)/qelon e)kdido/nai.

smikrou= is better than mikrou=, since the rhetorical e)panafora/ (cp. 610, O.T. 25) needs the same form in both places. mikro/s having prevailed in later Attic (as in Xen. and the orators), our MSS. in the tragic texts often drop the s. But, metre permitting, tragedy preferred smikro/s. In Soph. fr. 38 ei) mikro\s w)\n ta\ fau=la nikh/sas e)/xw, the word="of short stature," in which sense Il. 5.801 too has *tudeu/s toi mikro\s me\n e)/hn de/mas, though in 17. 757 smikrh=|si. Curtius (Etym. p. 622), comparing smukth/r and mukth/r, remarks that analogy speaks for the antiquity of the s in smikro/s, while it is possible that the m was not original, but arose from some other sound.
fe/ronta=fero/menon: O. T. 590 pa/nt' a)/neu fo/bou fe/rw: cp. 1411.

kai\ to/d). As kai\ ou)=tos (like et is, isque), or kai\ tau=ta, introduces a strengthening circumstance (Her. 6. 11 ei)=nai dou/loisi, kai\ tou/toisi w(s drhpe/th|si), so here kai\ to/de marks the last step of a climax. Some edd. point thus, fe/ronta: taking e)carkou=n as=e)carkei=, "and that suffices me": but this (a) supposes a very harsh ellipse of e)sti/, (b) maims the rhythm, (c) weakens the force of the series smikro\n—mei=on—e)carkou=n.
e)moi/ after *oi)di/poun: cp. 1329: as O.T. 535 th=s e)mh=s after tou=de ta)ndro/s (like Tr. 1073 f.): Ai. 865 muqh/somai after *ai)/as qroei=: Plat. Euthyphro 5 A ou)de/ tw| a)\n diafe/roi *eu)qu/frwn tw=n pollw=n...ei) mh\ ei)dei/hn.

ste/rgein, absol., cp. 519, Dem. De Cor. § 112 ei) de/ fhsin ou)=tos, deica/tw, ka)gw\ ste/rcw kai\ siwph/somai: usu. with accus., as Ph. 538 a)na/gkh| prou)/maqon ste/rgein kaka/. Like ste/rgein, ai)nei=n is sometimes absol. in this sense (Eur. Suppl. 388 ka)\n me\n qe/lwsin ai)ne/sai), but a)gapa=n almost always takes a clause with o(/ti, ei) or e)a/n (Od. 21.289
ou)k a)gapa=|s o(\ e(/khlos ...
dai/nusai), or an accus.

ai( pa/qai: Her. 1 207 ta\ de/ moi paqh/mata e)o/nta a)xa/rita maqh/mata ge/gone: Aesch. Ag. 177
to\n pa/qei ma/qos
qe/nta kuri/ws e)/xein.

o( xro/nos, the time (through which I live), attending on me (cunw/n) in long course (makro/s). Cp. O. T. 963 (Polybus died of disease) kai\ tw=| makrw=| ge summetrou/menos xro/nw|, "and of the long years which he had told." For cunw/n cp. O. T. 863 ei)/ moi cunei/h...moi=ra: Ai. 622 palaia=|... e)/ntrofos a(me/ra|: Pind. Pyth. 4.157
h)/dh me ghraio\n me/ros a(liki/as
a)mfipolei=.

dida/skei, verb agreeing with nearest subject: cp. Ant. 830, 1133: [Xen.] Resp. Athen. (circ. 420 B.C.) 1 § 2 dikai/ws au)to/qi kai\ oi( pe/nhtes kai\ o( dh=mos ple/on e)/xei: Plat. Symp. 190C ai( timai\ ga\r au)toi=s kai\ i(era\ ta\ para\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn h)fani/zeto: Cic. Ad Att. 9. 10, 2 "nihil libri, nihil litterae, nihil doctrina prodest."
tri/ton, as completing the lucky number: Ai. 1174 ko/mas e)ma\s kai\ th=sde kai\ sautou= tri/tou: O. T. 581 (where see n.).

qa/khsin is in itself a correct form. qa/khsis (qake/w) is (1) the act of sitting, (2) the means of sitting, as oi)/khsis (oi)ke/w) is (1) the act of dwelling, (2) the house. It is not found elsewhere, but cp. Soph. Ph. 18
h(li/ou diplh=
pa/restin e)nqa/khsis, a twofold means of sitting in the sun. With the MS. reading qa/koisin construe: — sth=so/n me h)\ pro\s qa/kois bebh/lois, ei)/ tina (qa=kon) ble/peis, etc. (We could not render ei)/ tina ble/peis "if thou seest any man," since the need for a halt did not depend on that condition.) This is a construction much less clear and simple than that with qa/khsin. bebh/lois may have induced the change of qa/khsin into qa/koisin.

bebh/lois, neut. plur. (cp. a)ba/twn a)poba/s, 167), places which may be trodden, profana, opp. to i(era/, a)/qikta: cp. fr. 86. 6
deino\s ga\r e(/rpein plou=tos e)/s te ta)/bata
kai\ pro\s be/bhla (Vater's correction of kai\ pro\s ta\ bata/): Bekker Anecd. 325. 13 a)be/bhla ta\ a)/bata xwri/a kai\ i(era\ kai\ mh\ toi=s tuxou=si ba/sima, mo/nois de\ toi=s qerapeu/ousi tou\s qeou/s. be/bhla de\ e)le/geto ta\ mh\ o(/sia mhde\ i(era/: ou(/tw *sofoklh=s. (This ignores the classical use of o(/sios as opp. to i(ero/s: in Aristoph. Lys. 743 o(/sion xwri/on = be/bhlon.) In Eur. Her. 404
kai\ be/bhla kai\ kekrumme/na
lo/gia = oracles to which access was easy, as opp. to those hidden in temple-archives.

h)\ pro\s a)/lsesin does not necessarily imply entrance on the a)/lsh. But the contrast with pro\s bebh/lois is unmeaning unless Oed. thinks of a seat on sacred ground, and not merely near it. So Antigone, who recognises the grove as sacred (16), seats him within it (19). This grove at Colonus was a)stibe/s (126) because the cult of the Eumenides so prescribed. Sacred groves were often open to visitors, as was the kuklotere\s a)/lsos of the Nymphs, with an altar "whereon all wayfarers were wont to make offerings," o(/qi pa/ntes e)pirre/zeskon o(di=tai (Od. 17.208). Hence Pausanias sometimes mentions that a particular a)/lsos was not open to the public. At Megalopolis, in the precinct of Zeus Philios, there was an a)/lsos of which he says, e)s me\n dh\ to\ e)nto\s e)/sodos ou)k e)/stin a)nqrw/pois (8. 31. 5). At Pellene, again, there was a walled a)/lsos of Artemis Soteira; e)/sodo/s te plh\n toi=s i(ereu=sin a)/llw| ge ou)deni\ e)/stin a)nqrw/pwn (7. 27. 3).

e)ci/druson, place me in a seat; cp. e)k in e)corqo/w (to render o)rqo/n). e)ci/druson, without addition, could hardly mean, seat me apart, i.e. out of the path. In Eur. fr. 877 (the only other example of e)cidru/w) it is the context which fixes this sense, thlou= ga\r oi)/kwn bi/oton e)cidrusa/mhn, "I fixed the seat of my life far apart from men's homes."

puqw/meqa. puqoi/meqa is impossible here. After a primary tense, the optative in a final clause with w(s, o(/pws, etc., occurs only:—(1) in Homeric Greek, where the case is merely imaginary: Od. 17.250
to/n pot' e)gw\n …
a)/cw th=l' *)iqa/khs, i(/na moi bi/oton polu\n a)/lfoi: "him some day I will take far from Ithaca,—so that (if I should do so) he might bring me large gain,"—implying, ei) a)/goimi, a)/lfoi a)/n. (2) After words expressing an aspiration or prayer (and not, like sth=son here, a simple order): Aesch. Eum. 297
e)/lqoi, klu/ei de\ kai\ pro/swqen w)\n qeo/s,
o(/pws ge/noito … luth/rios: "may she come—and a god hears e'en afar— that [so] she might prove my deliverer." Aesch. Suppl. 670 ff., by which Campb. defends puqoi/meqa, would come under (2), if the text were certain, but there tw/s is a v.l. for w(s. (3) More rarely, where the primary tense implies a secondary: Dem. In Androt. § 11 tou=ton e)/xei to\n tro/pon o( no/mos...i(/na mhde\ peisqh=nai mhd' e)capathqh=nai ge/noit' e)pi\ tw=| dh/mw|: "the law stands thus [=was made thus], that the people might not even have the power" etc.: i.e. e)/xei implies e)te/qh.

manqa/nein … h(/komen, we have come to learning, = are in such plight that we must learn: the infin. as after verbs of duty or fitness (o)fei/lw, prosh/kei, etc.). Cp. O. T. 1158 ei)s to/d' h(/ceis (sc. ei)s to\ o)le/sqai).

ce/noi pro\s a)stw=n: cp. the address of Oedipus the King to the Theban elders (O. T. 216ff.), esp. vv. 222 f.,
nu=n d), u(/steros ga\r a)sto\s ei)s a)stou\s telw=,
u(mi=n profwnw= k.t.l.

*oi)di/pous, the more frequent voc. (cp. O. T. 405 crit. n.): but *oi)di/pou below, 557, 1346. Athens is a little more than a mile S.E. of Colonus. The picture which Sophocles meant pu/rgoi to suggest probably included both the Acropolis—a beautiful feature in the view—and the line of city-walls with their towers. So the city-walls of Thebes are pu/rgoi, Ant. 122.
oi(\ at the end of the verse: cp. O. T. 298, El. 873, Tr. 819.

ste/gousin, the reading of all MSS., is probably right. It is true that in class. Greek ste/gw usually means either (1) "cover, conceal," as El. 1118 a)/ggos... sw=ma...ste/gon, or (2) "keep out," as Aesch. Theb. 216 pu/rgon ste/gein eu)/xesqe pole/mion do/ru. But the first sense — "cover" — might easily pass into "protect," and Xen. Cyr. 7.1.33 has ai( a)spi/des ...stega/zousi ta\ sw/mata. Wakefield's ste/fousin ("girdle") is specious; we have stefa/nwma or stefa/nh pu/rgwn (Ant. 122, Eur. Hec. 910), *babulw=na...tei/xesin e)stefa/nwse (Dionys. Periegetes 1006), o(/ploisin *mega/lh po/lis e)stefa/nwtai (Paus. 9. 15). But it does not follow that pu/rgoi po/lin ste/fousin could stand. ste/fw never occurs as = "to be set around," but either as (1) "to set around" — a)/nqh peri\ kefalh\n ste/feis, or (2) "to crown" — a)/nqesi kefalh\n ste/feis,—sometimes in the fig. sense of "honouring," as with libations or offerings (Ant. 431 etc.).

w(s a)p' o)mma/twn, sc. ei)ka/sai, to judge from sight (alone), without exact knowledge: schol. w(s e)/stin e)k proo/yews tekmh/rasqai: cp. Thuc. 1. 10 ei)ka/zesqai a)po\ th=s fanera=s o)/yews, to be estimated by the mere external aspect.

xw=ros d' o(/d' i(ro/s. Cp. Plat. Phaedr. 230B, where Socrates recognises the sacred character of the spot by the Ilissus: *numfw=n te/ tinwn kai\ *)axelw/|ou i(ero\n a)po\ tw=n korw=n te kai\ a)galma/twn (the votive dolls and images) e)/oiken ei)=nai. There, too, to\ su/skion was a feature.

w(s sa/f' ei)ka/sai, A's reading, is preferable to w(s a)peika/sai, which would imply a more diffident guess. The poet of Colonus intends that the sacred character of the grove should at once impress the Theban maiden; and sa/fa is confirmed by the emphasis of da/fnhs, e)lai/as, a)mpe/lou. It has been objected that sa/fa is inconsistent with ei)ka/sai. But it merely expresses the speaker's own belief that her guess is right; as we can say, "a certain conjecture." In L's reading, w(s a)feika/sai, it seems more likely that a second s should have been lost than that p should have become f. For the constr. with w(s, cp. Tr. 1220 w(/s g' e)peika/zein e)me/. w(s is omitted below, 152.

bru/wn takes a dat. in its literal sense of "sprouting" (bru/ei a)/nqei+ Il. 17.56), but either a dat. (as Aristoph. Nub. 45) or a gen. in its figurative sense of "being full." [Plat.] Axiochus 371 C a)/fqonoi me\n w(=rai pagka/rpou gonh=s bru/ousi (evidently pieced together from some poet).

a)mpe/lou. Cyril (Jerem. Homil. 4. 41), speaking of the later pagan practice, says, ei)s a)/lsh o(/tan futeu/wsi cu/la, futeu/ousin ou) ta\ karpofo/ra, ou) sukh=n ou)d' a)/mpelon, a)lla\ mo/non te/ryews xa/rin a)/karpa cu/la. But in earlier times, at least, ta\ karpofo/ra were not rare in sacred groves; cp. Xen. Anab. 5.3.12 (referring to the shrine of the Ephesian Artemis at Scillus) peri\ d' au)to
 to
 nao
 a)/lsos h(me/rwn de/ndrwn e)futeu/qh, o(/sa e)sti\ trwkta\ w(rai=a. Paus. 1.21.7 (in an a)/lsos of Apollo at Athens) de/ndrwn kai\ h(me/rwn kai\ o(/sa tw=n a)ka/rpwn o)smh=s pare/xetai/ tina h)\ qe/as h(donh/n.

pukno/pteroi, poet. for puknai/, the second element being equivalent to a separate epithet, pterou=ssai: cp. 717 e(katompo/dwn *nhrh|dwn, 1055 disto/lous, O. T. 846 oi)o/zwnos a)nh/r, a lonely way farer (where see n.). Such an epithet as "thickly-feathered" would be unmeaning here. The many nightingales, heard to warble from the thick covert, argue the undisturbed sanctity of the inner grove. Antigone notices an indication which her blind father can recognise.
d) is elided at the end of the verse, as O.T. 29 (n.), so also t), as ib. 1184 etc., and once tau=ta, ib. 332: cp. below, 1164.

w(s ge/ronti with makra\n: cp. Plat. Soph. 226C taxei=an, w(s e)moi/, ske/yin e)pita/tteis ("a rapid process of thought for such as I am"): Rep. 389 D swfrosu/nhs de/, w(s plh/qei, ou) ta\ toia/de me/gista; "for the mass of men, are not the cardinal points of temperance such as these?" Cp. 76.
prou)sta/lhs, hast fared forward: a compound not found elsewhere in Trag., except in Aesch. Theb. 415 *di/kh...nin proste/lletai, sends him forth as her champion.

*xro/nou … ou(/nek). O.T. 857 f.: Her. 3. 122 ei(/neke/n te xrhma/twn a)/rceis a(pa/shs th=s *(ella/dos (if it is merely a question of money): Antiphon or. 5 § 8 ka)\n a)nwmo/tois u(mi=n...e)pitre/yaimi..., e(/neka/ ge tou= pisteu/ein, "I would leave the verdict to you, though you were unsworn, if it were only a question of confidence."
o(/poi, since kaqe/stamen implies h(/komen: cp. 227, 476: on the same principle, *)olumpi/aze (not *)olumpi/asi) parei=nai, Thuc. 3. 8.
gou=n: "well (ou)=n), I know Athens (ge), but not this place." Cp. El. 233 a)ll' ou)=n eu)noi/a| g' au)dw=, "well, it is in kindness that I speak."

h(mi\n as a trochee is frequent in Soph. (Ellendt counts 26 instances), but does not occur in Eur., nor in Aesch., except in Eum. 347, where Porson's a(mi/n for a(mi=n seems necessary. Modern edd., with Dind., usu. write h(mi/n: others, as Nauck and Ellendt, would always write h(=min, for which the old grammarians afford some warrant (cp. Chandler, Accent. 2nd ed. § 673): while others, again, would distinguish an emphatic h(mi/n from a non-emphatic h)=min (cp. Hadley and Allen, Greek Gram. § 264).

a)ll' o(/stis o( to/pos. The tribrach is divided like that in Eur. Phoen. 511 e)lqo/nt|a^ su^n o^pl|ois, where su\n coheres closely with o(/plois, as o( with to/pos. But even where no such cohesion exists, a tribrach may be broken after the second syllable if it is also broken after the first: e.g. de/spoina, su\ ta/d' e)/pracas ou) gnw/mhs a)/ter is correct: cp. n. on O. T. 537.
h)= ma/qw, deliberative subjunct., of which the aor. is more frequent than the pres.: so O. T. 364 ei)/pw: see on O. T. 651.

e)coikh/simos, capable of being made into a dwelling-place, "habitable," here implying "inhabited." Adjectives with the suffix simo properly denote adaptability. They were primarily formed from substantives in -si-s, as xrh/si-mo-s, fitted for use, from xrh=sis. The noun e)coi/khsis is found only in the sense of "emigration," Plat. Legg. 704C, 850 B. But as from i(ppa/zomai was formed i(ppa/-simos, though no i(/ppasis occurs, so e)coikh/simos here is taken directly from e)coikei=n as="to make into a dwellingplace" (Thuc. 2.17 e)cw|kh/qh). oi)kh/simos as="habitable" occurs in later Greek. Just as e)coikh/simos is practically equivalent to oi)khto/s here, so Silius speaks of the Capitoline as "superis habitabile saxum," alluding to the actual shrines on it (1. 541). Cp. a(lw/simos ba/cis (Aesch. Ag. 10), tidings of an actual, not merely possible, capture. This poet. use is the converse of that by which a)/rrhtos could mean "unspeakable," or invictus, "unconquerable."

a)ll' e)sti\ mh
, "nay, but it is inhabited." Aesch. Pers. 233 (in a reply) a)lla\ mh
 i(/meir), "nay, but he was eager" (to take this very city). Especially in rejecting an alternative: Eur. Helen 1047 a)ll' ou)de\ mh
 nau=s e)/stin, "nay, but neither is there a ship."

Impatient for more light, Oed. asks, "Is he coming forth towards us,— so that it is really needless for thee to move?" deu=ro denotes the goal, pros- the direction, and e)c- the starting-point. deu=ro goes with both participles, which form a single expression,="coming towards us from the abodes" implied by oi)khto/s (28). Cp. Ai. 762 a)p' oi)/kwn... e)cormw/menos. Other explanations are:— (1) "approaching" (deu=ro being taken with prosst. only) "and setting out," as a "prothysteron" for "setting out and approaching." This is impossible. (2) "Moving, and hastening, hither": but this obliterates e)c-, and strains o(rmw/menon.
kai\ dh\, "already": Aristoph. Av. 175 *p*e*i. ble/yon ka/tw. *e*p. kai\ dh\ ble/pw.
me\n ou)=n, "nay rather" (imo); Aristoph. Eq. 13 *n*i. le/ge su/. *d*h. su\ me\n ou)=n le/ge.
w)= cei=n). The Ionic voc. occurs even without metrical necessity, Eur. I. T. 798 cei=n), ou) dikai/ws: Soph. rarely uses cei=nos except in voc.: 1014 n.

u(pe/r t' e)mou==u(pe\r e)mou= te: as O. T. 258 (where see n.), kurw= t' e)gw/=e)gw/ te kurw=: Ph. 1294. Cp. Tennyson's lines "To the Princess Frederica":
O you that were eyes and light to the King till he past away
From the darkness of life. Ant. 989 (of the blind Teiresias and his guide) du/) e)c e(no\s ble/ponte.

ou(/nex' … fra/sai: that thou hast come near, ai)/sios skopo\s w(=n (=tou/twn a(\) a)dhlou=men, an opportune inquirer into our doubts, fra/sai, so as to explain (epexegetic infin., cp. 50). skopo\s has its ordinary sense of "scout" (cp. n. on 297). Oedipus supposes that the man has been sent to make inquiry. tou/twn is objective gen. after skopo/s.
w(=n, by attract.: O. T. 788 w(=n … i(ko/mhn = (tou/twn) a(\ i(ko/mhn.

a)dhlou=men. Since a)dhle/w=to be a)/dhlos, (as a)peiqe/w to be a)peiqh/s, a)kosme/w to be a)/kosmos,) the form strictly implies that a)/dhlos could mean, "not seeing clearly": but an act. sense nowhere occurs, for in Eur. Or. 1318 xro/a| d' a)dh/lw| tw=n dedrame/nwn pe/ri means, "faces wherein the deeds cannot be read" (not, "which seem to know nought of them"). Cp. the verbs formed from the active use of verbal adjectives which were primarily passive, as a)laste/w, to be unforgetting, a)tlhte/w, to be impatient (O. T. 515). Conversely, dhlo/w, "to make dh=los," sometimes verges on the sense, "to be dh=los" (Ant. 20, 242).

As 78 shows, the man who has just entered is supposed to belong to Colonus, which, like the rest of Attica, was subject to the king of Athens (v. 67). The designation ce/nos was probably suggested merely by w)= cei=n) in 33.

ta\ plei/on), "the" details foreshadowed by the preamble. Isocr. or. 5 § 63 (in a rapid sketch of Conon's career) kai\ ti/ dei= ta\ plei/w le/gein; "and why dwell on the details?" So in Soph. Ph. 576 mh/ nu/n m' e)/rh| ta\ plei/on), Tr. 731 siga=n a)\n a(rmo/zoi se to\n plei/w lo/gon, the art. denotes "the" sequel which the previous discourse promises. In Eur. Med. 609 w(s ou) krinou=mai tw=nde/ soi ta\ plei/ona, the gen. brings this out: "Enough —I will not dispute with thee on the further aspects of this matter."

ou)x a(gno\n patei=n. The poets can use a(gno/s either like i(ero/s (e.g. Eur. Andr. 253 a(gno\n te/menos), or, as here, like o(/sios. For the infin. active, cp. Plat. Phaedo 62B lo/gos ou)...r(a/|dios dii+dei=n, 90 C lo/gou ...dunatou= katanoh=sai: Eur. Med. 316 le/geis a)kou=sai malqa/k) (auditu mollia): Soph. O. T. 792 a)/tlhton...o(ra=n, and n. on O. T. 1204.

tou= qew=n nomi/zetai; "to which of the gods is it deemed to belong?" After verbs of being thought, called, etc., the gen. expresses "belonging" (1) to a possessor, as here and Ant. 738 ou) tou= kratou=ntos h( po/lis nomi/zetai; or (2) to a class, as Eur. Andr. 12
tw=n e)leuqerwta/twn
oi)/kwn nomisqei=s). With (1) here cp. the gen. of the deity after i(ero/s (Plat. Phaedo 85B i(ero\s tou= au)tou= qeou=).

a)/qiktos ou)d' oi)khto/s, sc. e)stin, answering ti/s e)/sq' o( xw=ros; cp. 1274 a)/naudos ou)d' a(\mhni/eis fra/sas, Ph. 2 a)/steiptos ou)d' oi)koume/nh. The second question, tou= qew=n nomi/zetai; is answered by ai( ga\r e)/mfoboi k.t.l.

*gh=s te kai\ *sko/tou ko/rai: as in Aesch. Eum. 416 they call themselves *nukto\s ai)anh=s te/kna, and invoke ma=ter *nu/c (844): Aesch. does not name the other parent. In Hesiod. Theog. 184 the mother is Earth, impregnated by the blood of Uranus,—the idea being that the Erinyes were called into life by the crime of a son (Zeus) against a father. Other versions made them daughters of Euonymè (a name for Earth) and Cronus (Epimenides ap. Tzetzes on Lycophron 406), or of Earth and Phorkys (i.e. the sea): cp. Welcker Griech. Götterl. 3. 81.

ti/nwn … klu/wn; of whom hearing the august name might I make a prayer? i.e. "who may they be, whose name I am to hear, and to invoke?" The optat. with a)/n gives a reverential tone to the question: eu)cai/mhn a)/n refers to such propitiatory words of invocation as were uttered on approaching a shrine. The description has left the Theban stranger in doubt as to the particular deities meant. He might think of other "Daughters of Darkness," — as of the *kh=res (Hes. Theog. 217), or of the *moi=rai,—whom the Eumenides of Aeschylus address as matrokasignh=tai, children of the same mother, *nu/c (Eum. 961).

pa/nq' o(rw/sas, because no crime escapes their ken: Ai. 835f.
ta\s a)ei/ te parqe/nous
a)ei/ q' o(rw/sas pa/nta ta)n brotoi=s pa/qh,
semna\s *)erinu=s tanu/podas.

*eu)meni/das, the title of the Erinyes at Sicyon (Paus. 2.11.4), was not used by Aeschylus in his play of that name, unless with Herm. we assume that it was in a part of Athena's speech which has dropped out after v. 1028. When Harpocration says that the Athena of Aeschylus, prau+/nasa ta\s *)erinu/as, *eu)meni/das w)no/masen, he perh. refers to such epithets as eu)/frones (Eum. 992), i(/laoi, eu)qu/frones (1040), *semnai/ (1041). Demosthenes (or. 23 § 66) uses the name in referring to the trial of Orestes.

a)/lla d' a)llaxou= kala/: schol. a)/lla o)no/mata par' a)/llois kala\ nomi/zetai. Wunder and others quote Plut. Them. 27 w)= ce/ne, no/moi diafe/rousin a)nqrw/pwn: a)/lla d' a)/llois kala/. This is against rendering, "but otherwhere [the folk would give them] other fair names." Near Megalopolis, on the road to Messene, there was a shrine of the *mani/ai: dokei=n de/ moi, qew=n tw=n *eu)meni/dwn e)sti\n e)pi/klhsis, Paus. 8.34.1. Aeschines gives the attributes of the Erinyes to the *poinai/ (tou\s h)sebhko/tas...e)lau/nein kai\ kola/zein da=|si\n h(mme/nais, .or. 1 § 190). As at Athens they were *semnai/, at Thebes they were *po/tniai (cp. 84). Another name was *)arai/ (Eum. 417).

me\n seems right. It implies a thought answering, rather than opposed, to i(/lew| decai/ato: i.e. "gracious on their part may be the welcome, (as, on mine, the duty to remain is clear)": not, "gracious, indeed, may be their welcome, (but, even if they should be stern, I must stay)." Cp. the me/n, without a following de/, which lightly emphasises rather than contrasts: Xen. Cyr. 1.4.12 e)gw\ me\n ou)k oi)=da (as others, perhaps, may).

to
 i(ke/thn, without me (which I should at least prefer to )me\ or e)me\, if me
 were changed), is more solemn: cp. 284 a)ll' w(/sper e)/labes to
 i(ke/thn.
decai/ato, Ionic: so 921 puqoi/ato, 945 decoi/ato, O. T. 1274 o)yoi/ato, gnwsoi/ato, where see n.

w(s is clearly right. The w(/st) of the MSS. would mean, "and so" (i.e. since they are the Eumenides). It could not mean, "and in that case," i.e. "if they prove kind." w(s is best taken as simply causal, "for" (schol. e)gw\ ga\r ou)k a)nasth/somai), rather than as="know that" (Eur. Phoen. 1664 *k*r*e*w*n. w(s ou)/tis a)mfi\ tw=|d' u(gra\n qh/sei ko/nin).
>a)\n e)ce/lqoim): the optat. with a)/n calmly expresses a fixed resolve: cp. O. T. 343 ou)k a)\n pe/ra fra/saimi.
ti/ d' e)sti\ tou=to; "What means this?" (cp. ti/ d' e)/sti; "what now?" O. T. 319 n.). "What has this sudden resolve to do with the mention of the Eumenides?"

cumfora=s cu/nqhm' e)mh=s. su/nqhma=something agreed upon (sunti/qemai), as e.g. a military watchword (Her. 9.98). Apollo had told Oedipus that, when he reached a shrine of the *semnai/, then he should find rest (90). This was the su/nqhma, the sign preconcerted between them, which Oedipus has now recognised at Colonus (cp. e)/gnwka, 96). He calls his own prayer (44 f.) the su/nqhma of his fate, because it embodies the two points of the su/nqhma, — "Here are the Eumenides, — here I stay." Campbell renders, "the word that sums my destiny," and seems to regard the notion of "sign" as blended with that of "summary." But the two notions are distinct. su/nqhma is always parallel in sense with sunti/qemai as="to concert" (boulh/n, etc.), never with sunti/qhmi as="to put briefly together."
e)moi/ is indispensable, while ou)de\ me/ntoi would be weak.

tou)canista/nai: the art. with the infin. (whether subject or object) is esp. frequent in the dramatists, for the simple reason that it was often metrically convenient: 442: Ai. 114 te/ryis h(/de soi to\ dra=n: Ant. 78
to\ ga\r
bi/a| politw=n dra=n e)/fun a)mh/xanos.

di/x), like a)/neu or xwri/s, "without the sanction of": Ai. 768
kai\ di/xa
kei/nwn, "e'en without the gods' help." Nauck objects to the position: but not less bold, at least, is O.T. 1084
e)/ti
pot' a)/llos, Ai. 986
ou)x o(/son ta/xos
dh=t' au)to\n a)/ceis …;

e)ndei/cw ti/ drw=, indicate what I am doing: drw= is pres. indic.: Plat. Gorg. 488A i(kanw=s moi e)/ndeicai ti/ e)/sti tou=to. Antiphon or. 6 § 37 e)ndei=cai tw=| dikasthri/w| ta\ a)dikh/mata. The technical e)/ndeicis was an information laid against usurpers of public functions, or, in certain cases, against kakou=rgoi. Schneidewin and Wecklein take drw= as subjunct., understanding, —"report the matter (and ask) what I am to do": but the idea of asking could not be supplied.
cei=ne: 33.

mh\ m' a)tima/sh|s tou/twn (genit. as after verbs of depriving) a(/ se prostre/pw (cp. Ai. 831 tosau=ta/ se... prostre/pw),fra/sai (epexegetic infin.): deny me not the grace of the things for which I supplicate thee, that thou shouldest declare them. Cp. 35.
ti/s e)/sq), i.e. "what is it called?" In answer to the same query at v. 38 he had only learned that part of it was sacred. Cp. 26.

ka)gw/. We say: — "What I know, you also shall know" (o(/s' oi)=d' e)gw/, kai\ su\ e)pisth/sei). The Greeks could say: — "What I also (=I on my part) know, you (also) shall know." The second "also" (kai/) is absent here, since su/ is wanting. Xen. Symp. 2. 25 dokei= me/ntoi moi kai\ ta\ tw=n a)ndrw=n sumpo/sia tau)ta\ pa/sxein a(/per kai\ ta\ e)n gh=| fuo/mena. Antiphon or. 5 § 23 e)zhtei=to ou)de/n ti ma=llon u(po\ tw=n a)/llwn h)\ kai\ u(p' e)mou=. So Soph. El. 1146
ou)/te ga/r pote
mhtro\s su/ g' h)=sqa ma=llon h)\ ka)mou= fi/los. Cp. below, 870 (ka)me\): Ai. 525: Ant. 927.

*poseidw=n. Paus. 1.30.4 dei/knutai de\ kai\ xw=ros kalou/menos *kolwno\s *(/ippios...kai\ bwmo\s *poseidw=nos *(ippi/ou kai\ *)aqhna=s *(ippi/as (1069), h(rw=|on de\ *peiri/qou kai\ *qhse/ws (1593), *oi)di/podo/s te kai\ *)adra/stou. This altar of Poseidon (e)pista/ths *kolwnou= 889) lies beyond the stage-scene (888).

e)n d' (adv.), sc. e)sti/n: Prometheus did not belong to Colonus itself (as Poseidon did), but to the neighbouring Academy (see on 56): he is named as one of several divine presences in the vicinity. So e)n d' adds a new member to a group, O. T. 27 (where the same words e)n d' o( p. qeo/s refer to the plague), Ai. 675. If, instead of e)n d' we read h)d' (which Soph. sometimes used in dialogue, fr. 345 and 493), this would rather link the two deities as holding Colonus.

*promhqeu/s is a "Titan" as son of the Titan Iapetus (Hes. Theog. 510). Welcker (Griech. Götterl. 2. 254) thinks that "Titan," instead of "Titanid," is used here only because, like the Titans, Prometheus rebelled against Zeus: but this seems strained. Cp. Cic. Tusc. 2. 10.23 (from the *prom. *luo/menos of Aesch., Prometheus speaking) Titanum suboles, socia nostri sanguinis, Generata caelo. purfo/ros (55), because represented with a torch in the right hand: Eur. Phoen. 1121 (on the shield of Tydeus)
decia=| de\ lampa/da
*tita\n *promhqeu\s e)/feren w(s prh/swn po/lin. So purfo/ros of Artemis (O. T. 207), and Capaneus (Ant. 135). Cp. Philostratus p. 602 (quoting the Athenian rhetorician Apollonius, circ. 225 A.D.) i)w\ *promhqeu= da|dou=xe kai\ purfo/re. His altar was in the Academy, just S. of Colonus, and this was the starting-point of the lampadhfori/a (to the acropolis) at the three torch-festivals. Harpocrat. 184 trei=s a)/gousin *)aqhnai=oi e(orta\s lampa/das, *panaqhnai/ois kai\ *(hfaistei/ois kai\ *promhqei/ois. Schol. Aristoph. Ran. 131 lampadhfori/ai de\ gi/gontai trei=s e)n tw=| *kerameikw=|, *)aqhna=s, *(hfai/stou, *promhqe/ws. Aesch. wrote both a *pr. *purfo/ros (the 1st play of his trilogy) and a satyric *pr. *pu/rkaeu/s.
to/pon by inverse attraction: Lys. or. 19 § 47 th\n ou)si/an h(\n kate/lipe tw=| ui(ei= ou) plei/onos a)ci/a e)sti/n k.t.l.: cp. on O. T. 449.

o)do/s. Somewhere near the grove of the Eumenides, but not within the stagescene, was a spot called "the threshold" of Hades,—a steeply-descending rift or cavern in the rock, at the mouth of which some brazen steps had been made (see on 1590 f.),—in accordance with the epic notion that Hades had a xa/lkeos ou)do/s (Il. 8.15). From this spot, the immediately adjacent region (including the grove) was known as "the brazen threshold," — xalko/pous, borrowed from the literal xalka= ba/qra (1591), taking the general sense of "adamantine." As "rooted on the nether rock" (gh=qen e)rrizwme/non 1591), and also as linked by mystic sanctities with the Powers of the Under-world, this region of the "brazen threshold" is called e)/reism' *)aqhnw=n, the stay of Athens: a phrase in which the idea of physical basis is joined to that of religious safeguard.
xalko/pous, with feet of brass (El. 491 x. *)erinu/s, untiring), i.e. furnished with brazen steps: not, putting brass under the foot, as some have taken it: so a)rguro/pous, xruso/pous etc.

The name — though kolwno/s was so familiar a word — is traced in the usual Greek fashion to a hero Colonus, the e)pw/numos of the deme; and, to justify the epithet of the place, i(/ppios, he is called i(ppo/ths, horseman, or knight. In the roads about Colonus (tai=sde...a)guiai=s 715) men first learned to use Poseidon's gift of the horse. With to/nd' cp. 65 tou=de tou= qeou=. In the case of the tribes, at least, statues of eponymi were familiar to Athenians (cp. Aristoph. Pax 1183 to\n a)ndria/nta to\n *pandi/onos). A statue of the hero Colonus on the stage would be an effective device for giving greater vividness to the local legend. The speaker could point to it with dramatic fitness, since Antigone is with her blind father.

a)rxhgo/s, or a)rxhge/ths,=esp. the founder of a family or clan, or (like kti/sths, oi)kisth/s) of a city. Bekker Anecd. I. 449 a)rxhge/tai: h(gemo/nes oi( e)pw/numoi tw=n fulw=n, quoting from the *gh=ras of Ar. para\ tou\s a)rxhge/tas,=by the statues of the ten e)pw/numoi h(/rwes of the Attic tribes. Arist. fr. 85 (Berl. ed. p. 1491 a 20) a)reth\ tou= ge/nous, kai\ eu)genei=s oi( a)po\ tou/tou tou= ge/nous, ou)k e)a
 o( path eu)genh\s h)=| a)ll' e)a
 o( a)rxhgo/s. Isocr. or. 3 § 28 *teu=kros me
 o( tou= ge/nous h(mw=n a)rxhgo/s. Plat. Tim. 21E th=s po/lews qeo\s a)rxhgo/s ti/s e)stin (of Saïs in Egypt, which claimed origin from the goddess Neith).

And all (the dhmo/tai, supplied kata\ su/nesin from gu/ai as=dh=mos) bear his name in common (koino/n, in their capacity as *kolwnei=s), being designated thereby. tou)/noma, acc. of object to fe/rousi, is also cognate accus. to w)nomasme/noi, which is added to mark the fixity of the deme-name,—a title not merely ornamental (like *)erexqei=dai for Athenians), but regular.

soi, ethic dat.: El. 761
toiau=ta/ soi tau=t' e)sti/n, w(s me\n e)n lo/gw|
a)lgeina/, k.t.l.

lo/gois, "story," legend, generally, but esp. poetry, in which Colonus had not yet figured: the Iliad (23. 679) buries Oedipus at Thebes: cp. Paus. 1.30.4 (of the Oedipus-myth at Colonus) dia/fora me\n kai\ tau=ta th=| *(omh/rou poih/sei.

th=| cunousi/a|, "by the dwelling with them": i.e. those who live at Colonus feel the charm of its holy places grow upon them. So the Thucydidean Pericles describes the Athenians as th\n th=s po/lews du/namin kaq' h(me/ran e)/rgw| qewme/nous kai\ e)rasta\s gignome/nous au)th=s (2. 43): cp. the schol. here, tw=| e)/rgw| kai\ th=| pei/ra| ple/on timw/mena, ou) toi=s lo/gois.
h)= ga/r k.t.l. The eager interest of Oed. in this question depends on his knowledge, derived from the oracle, that he brought ke/rdh toi=s dedegme/nois (92).
kai\ ka/rta: cp. 301: Eur. Hipp. 89 *q*e. a)=r' a)/n ti/ mou de/caio...; *i*p kai\ ka/rta g).

qeou=, the hero Colonus. Though the distinction had lost nothing of its clearness at this date (cp. Antiphon or. 1 § 27 ou)/te qeou\s ou)/q' h(/rwas ou)/t' a)nqrw/pous dei/sasa), qeo/s is sometimes the generic term for beings who receive divine honours: so Amphion and Zethus, the Theban heroes, are tw\ siw/ (Aristoph. Ach. 905), and Eupolis says (*)astra/teutoi fr. 3) e)n eu)ski/ois dro/moisin *)akadh/mou qeou= (the e)pw/numos of the *)akadh/meia).

Elmsley reads a)/rxei ti/s au)tw=n; "Who is their king?" But Oed. rather asks, "Have they a monarchy or a democracy?" It would be a prosaic objection that the question is hardly suited to the heroic age of patrikai\ basilei=ai (Thuc. I. 13).

h)\ 'pi\ tw=| pl. lo/gos; "or does power of discussion rest with the people?" plh/qei, the popular assembly, as oft. to\ u(me/teron plh=qos in the Attic orators. Thuc. 2.40 (Pericles, on the Athenian democracy) ou) tou\s lo/gous toi=s e)/rgois bla/bhn h(gou/menoi. The schol. paraphrases, h)\ e)n tw=| pl. e)sti\n h( i)sxu/s; and kra/tos is a conject. instead of lo/gos. Elmsley and others cp. Eur. Cycl. 119 ti/nos klu/ontes; (under what king?) h)\ dedh/meutai kra/tos; There is no evidence for lo/gos as (1) the commanding word, "sway": (2) the deciding word, "arbitrament": or (3) the "principle" (ratio) of government.
e)k, of the head and fount of power: El. 264 ka)k tw=nd' a)/rxomai: Ant. 63 a)rxo/mesq' e)k kreisso/nwn.

lo/gw| te kai\ sqe/nei, word (counsel) and might (of deeds): Od. 16.242 (Odysseus) xei=ra/s t' ai)xmhth\n e)/menai kai\ e)pi/frona boulh/n: Pind. Pyth. 5.111 (may Cyrene's king be blest) e)p' e)/rgoisin a)mfi/ te boulai=s: Soph. O. T. 884 (of a tu/rannos) ei) de/ tis u(pe/ropta xersi\n h)\ lo/gw| poreu/etai. So Theseus is described by Thuc. 2.15 as geno/menos meta\ tou= cunetou= kai\ dunato/s.

Sophocles conceives the union of the Attic communes (commemorated by the annual festival of the sunoi/kia in August) as already accomplished by Theseus. Athens is the capital, all the people of Attica being reckoned as its citizens (a(pa/ntwn h)/dh cuntelou/ntwn e)s au)th/n, Thuc. 2.15). Isocr. or. 10 § 18 speaks of Theseus as o( lego/menos me\n *ai)ge/ws, geno/menos d' e)k *poseidw=nos. Aegeus, too, was said to have been king of Athens: see on 297; and was the eponymus of one of the ten Attic tribes (*ai)ghi\s fulh/, Andoc. or. 1 § 62). He gave the title to a lost play of Sophocles.

a)=r' a)/n tis … mo/loi; "I wonder if any one would go?" = I wish that some one would go. Il. 10.303
ti/s ke/n moi to/de e)/rgon u(posxo/menos tele/seie
dw/rw| e)/pi mega/lw|; Cp. infra 1100.
au)tw=|, poet. after the verb of motion: cp. Il. 12.374 e)peigome/noisi d' i(/konto: Aesch. PV 358 h)=lqen au)tw=| *zhno\s...belos: cp. O. T. 711.
pompo/s, one sent to bring a person, O.T. 288.

w(s pro\s ti/ goes with both participles, molei=n with the second only. The Chorus are uncertain whether Oedipus has merely some message for Theseus, or wishes to bring him in person to the spot (as pompo/s might imply). Our pointing is better than w(s pro\s ti/; l. h)\ k. molei=n; The query turns more on the motive of the appeal than on a sharp contrast between its possible forms. le/cwn should not be joined with molei=n ("bid him come," Blaydes).

The reading and explanation of the verse hinge on the question whether w(s (1) belongs to pro\s ti/, = "with what view?" or (2) is final, = "in order that." Now (1) is strongly supported by two other places of Soph., in each of which this formula stands, as here, at the beginning of a question: O. T. 1174 *o*i. w(s pro\s ti/ xrei/as; Tr. 1182 *u*a. w(s pro\s ti/ pi/stin th/nd' a)/gan e)pistre/feis; The simple pro\s ti/; (also freq. in Soph.) = merely "with reference to what?" while w(s pro\s ti/= "with reference to what, in your conception or intention (w(s)?": hence the latter is appropriate when the questioner cannot imagine the agent's motive.

katartu/swn molei=n, to prepare things (to work upon his mind, directly or indirectly), so that he shall come: for the inf. cp. 1286: Plat. Rep. 562C th
 politei/an... paraskeua/zei turanni/dos dehqh=nai: and for katartu/w of mental or moral influence, Plut. Mor. 38 D a)
...mh\ lo/gois xrhstoi=s a)fairw=n h)\ paratre/pwn katartu/h| th
 fu/sin.

With L's mo/loi (w(s being then final), we must render: "That Theseus might come with what view (pro\s ti/), —to say or to arrange (what)?" The opt. can stand (in spite of kerda/nh| 72), since a)=r' a)\n mo/loi; (70) puts the case hypothetically: see on 11. But: (a) the double mo/loi, at the end of two successive verses, is intolerable. Dindorf, therefore, conjecturally reads parh=|, which Wecklein and others adopt. (b) The antithesis between le/cwn and katartu/swn is hardly clear. Wecklein explains, pro\s poi=on lo/gon h)\ e)/rgon; Certainly ti/ le/cwn h)\ dra/swn could mean, "for what conceivable purpose?" (cp. O.T. 71 o(/ ti drw=n h)\ ti/ fwnw=n): but katartu/swn would be a very strange substitute for dra/swn.
mh\ ble/pontos, not ou), since the blindness is a condition: "if he has not sight."

o(rw=nta: the blind man's words will be instinct with mental vision. (Cp. O.T. 747.) The insight is ascribed to the words themselves, not to the speaker, as at 267 peponqo/ta and dedrako/ta are epithets of the e)/rga, not of the agent. Cp. Aesch. Cho. 854 fre/n)...w)mmatwme/nhn, Suppl. 467 w)mma/twsa...safe/steron (lo/gon). Milton, Par. Lost. 3. 51
So much the rather thou, Celestial Light,
Shine inward, and the mind through all her powers
Irradiate; there plant eyes.

oi)=sq' … w(s … mh\ sfalh=|s; dost thou know (how to act), — that thou mayest not come to harm? A modification of the phrase oi)=sq' w(s poi/hson, in which poi/hson is abruptly substituted for dei= se poih=sai. So, here, oi)=sqa eagerly bespeaks attention to the advice: see on O. T. 543.

w(s i)do/nti: w(s has a limiting force (as above, 20), Ant. 1161 h)=n zhlwto/s, w(s e)moi/ (cp. on O. T. 763). The dat. is that of the person interested by the perception, as in w(s me\n sunelo/nti ei)pei=n (Xen. An. 3. 1 § 38), polla\ kai\ a)/lla paralipo/nti (Thuc. 2.51), sullamba/nonti kata\ to\ o)rqo/n (for one who rightly comprehends, Her. 7.143), tw=| a(ptome/nw| ou) qermo\n h)=n (Thuc. 2.49), etc.
dai/monos, sortis: so 1337, and oft.: boldly in fr. 587 mh\ spei=re polloi=s to\n paro/nta dai/mona, sow not the rumour of thy fate abroad.

mh\ kat' a)/stu is a comforting parenthesis. mh\ is due to the preceding imperative me/n): cp. Thuc. I. 124 yhfi/sasqe to
 po/lemon, mh\ fobhqe/ntes to\ au)ti/ka deino/n: Xen. Cyr. 3.1.37 a)pa/gou th
 gunai=ka kai\ tou\s pai=das, mhde
 au)tw=n kataqei/s: but it has, in itself, almost the effect of a reassuring injunction, "do not suppose that I mean." We could not make oi( e)nqa/d' au)tou= mh\ kat' a)/stu dhmo/tai a single phrase, as=such of the folks as are not in the town, but here.

e)nqa/d' au)tou=: Solon fr. 36. 11 tou\s d' e)nqa/d' au)tou= (in Attica, as opp. to abroad): so Eupolis fr. inc. 1. 4 (where Bothe after Meineke badly points tw=n e)nqa/d', au)tou=), etc. The word dhmo/ths in Ant. 690, Ai. 1071 =a common man as opp. to a chief. Here, as in Eur. (Aesch. has not the word) and Pind. (Nem. 7. 65), dhmo/tai are the "citizens" generally; though in this place the term is tinged with the notion of "demesmen."

ei) xrh/. All our MSS. have h)\ xrh/ (which Campbell retains); but, as between h)\ and ei) in such a case, their authority is small: thus in Aesch. Cho. 994, where ei)/t) is certain, L gives the senseless h)/t). Epic usage allows h)e\ (h)\), answered by h)=e (h)=), in an indirect question: Il. 2.299
o)/fra daw=men
h)\ e)teo\n *ka/lxas manteu/etai, h)=e kai\ ou)ki/. But is there any Attic example of this construction? Three instances are indeed alleged from Aesch. (P. V. 780, Cho. 756, 890), but they are most doubtful: see Appendix. Attic usage prescribed ei) (or ei)/te) as = whether, introducing the indirect question: the correlative or was usu. ei)/te, but sometimes, as here, h)/.
h(mi\n, ethic dat.: do we find ourselves alone? Cp. 62.
e)n h(su/xw|, in quiet case, nearly= h(su/xws, as 1675 e)n puma/tw| = "at the last": cp. El. 384 nu=n ga\r e)n kalw=| fronei=n.
mo/nhs pe/las, sc. ou)/shs, a gen. absol. (we could not understand w(s o)/nti pe/las e)mou= mo/nhs): cp. 1588: O. T. 966 w(=n u(fhghtw=n, sc. o)/ntwn.
po/tniai, fitting in his mouth, as being esp. their name at Thebes (43).

deinw=pes: as looking sternly on sin (42). The face of the Avengers is still terrible to his inner eye. Sophocles nowhere portrays the lineaments of the Furies, as Aesch. does (Eum. 46-54), but he leaves on the mind an impression not less awful.

eu)=te: nu=n e)/kamya e)pi\ e(/dras (gen. sing.) u(mw=n prw/twn (possess. gen.) th=sde gh=s (partitive gen.). e)pi/ can be so placed since u(mw=n is possessive gen. (=u(mete/ras): cp. 126, O. T. 177 a)kta\n pro\s e(spe/rou qeou=.
e)/kamya (sc. go/nu) absol., as Eur. Hec. 1079 pa= bw=, pa= stw=, pa= ka/myw;

a)gnw/mones, without gnw/mh, hence, inconsiderate; and so, unfeeling: Tr. 473 fronou=san qnhta\ kou)k a)gnw/mona, i.e. not refusing to make allowance for human frailty. Xen. Mem. 2.8.5 a)gnw/moni krith=| perituxei=n, to fall in with a judge who makes no allowance. But a)gnw/s = "undiscerning," O. T. 677.

e)ce/xrh, since in Attic xra/w contracts in h: Tyrtaeus 3. 3
*)apo/llwn
xrusoko/mhs e)/xrh pi/onos e)c a)du/tou: Pind. Ol. 7.92 e)/xreon (v.l. e)/xraon): Lucian Alex. 22 e)/xra kai\ e)qe/spize (common dialect). ta\ po/ll), cp. El. 564 ta\ polla\ pneu/mat), those frequent winds. The prophecy was made to Oedipus at Delphi when he went thither in his youth from Corinth, to ask whether he was indeed the son of Polybus, the Corinthian king, and Meropè. The god did not solve his doubt,—a)/lla d' a)/qlia kai\ deina\ kai\ du/sthna prou)/fhnen le/gwn (O. T. 789). Eur. makes Oedipus, while still at Thebes, tell Antigone of a xrhsmo/s which doomed him to die at i(ero\s *kolwno/s (Phoen. 1705 ff.). Far more poetical is the conception of Sophocles, that Apollo had appointed the sign, but not named the place.

tau/thn e)/lece pau=lan: spoke of this as a rest. The pronominal object of the verb, instead of being tou=to, is assimilated to the gender of the predicate pau=lan: cp. Plat. Crat. 433E le/gei... ei)=nai tau/thn o)rqo/thta o)no/matos, cunqh/khn, he says that in this consists the correctness of a word,—convention: Lysias or. 12 § 37 tau/thn ga\r e)sxa/thn di/khn duna/meqa par' au)tw=n labei=n, this (death) is the extreme penalty which we can exact from them.

e)n xro/nw| makrw=|: so El. 330: Ant. 422, Ph. 235, etc.: but 1648 xro/nw| braxei= (without e)n). The general Attic rule was to use e)n in such phrases as e)n pollw=|, makrw=|, o)li/gw|, braxei= xro/nw|, e)n o)li/gais h(me/rais, e)n polloi=s e)/tesin. The instances in which e)n is omitted are comparatively rare in poetry, and very rare (usu. doubtful) in prose, with the exception of the phrase u(ste/rw| xro/nw| which in prose usu. lacks e)n: it takes it, however, below at 614 and Tr. 18.

e)lqo/nti … bi/on. Apollo said: au(/th pau=la/ soi e)/stai, e)lqo/nti xw/ran termi/an, o(/pou a)
 la/bh|s q. s. e(/dran kai\ ceno/stasin: e)ntau=qa ka/myeis k.t.l. In the orat. obliqua, if the tense of the principal verb were primary (as le/gei), o(/pou a)
 la/bh|s would become o(/pou a)
 la/bw: since it is secondary (e)/lece), we have o(/pou la/boimi. The part. e)lqo/nti expresses the first condition to be fulfilled before the pau=la can be attained. tau/thn is explained by e)ntau=qa ka/myein. termi/an is proleptic: in whatever land he should find the Semnae, that land was to be for him termi/a, i.e. was to contain the goal of his wanderings. The word occurs elsewhere only in Ant. 1331, termi/an a(me/ran, one's last day. It fits the metaphor of ka/myein, from rounding the post in the di/aulos (ka/myai diau/lou qa/teron kw=lon pa/lin, Aesch. Ag. 344), since te/rma oft.=nu/ssa or kampth/r, the turning-post (Il. 23.466 eu)= sxeqe/ein peri\ te/rma).
semnw=n: see on 43.

ceno/stasin, quarters for strangers. Pollux 9. 50 me/rh| de\ kai\ po/lews kai\ pandokei=on kai\ cenw\n kai\ w(s e)n *)ina/xw| *sofokle/ous (a satyric drama, fr. 253), pando/kos ceno/stasis. The word occurs only in these two places of Soph.: so i(ppo/stasis, bou/stasis.

ke/rdh me/n k.t.l.: with advantages, through my having settled there (oi)kh/santa), for my entertainers, and ruin for the Thebans. The conjecture oi)ki/santa, "having founded," deserves to be carefully weighed. Cp. the poet. use of kti/sas below (715) in regard to the invention of the curb: also Aesch. PV 250 tufla\s e)n au)toi=s e)lpi/das katw/|kisa. On the other hand, the blessing to Attica turned on the personal residence of Oed. therein at the close of his life: cp. 626
kou)/pot' *oi)di/poun e)rei=s
a)xrei=on oi)khth=ra de/casqai. This favours oi)kh/santa. ke/rdh and a)/thn, accusatives in appos. with the sentence e)ntau=qa ka/myein to\n bi/on: the participle oi)kh/santa (in antithesis with dedegme/nois, cp. 13 ce/noi pro\s a)stw=n) serves to bring out the point on which the ke/rdh and a)/th depend. For the plur. acc. in appos. cp. Eur. Alc. 6
kai/ me qhteu/ein path\r
...tw=nd' a)/poin' h)na/gkasen. This is better than to refer ke/rdh and a)/thn to the person of Oed. ("having dwelt there as a blessing" etc.), which would suit a)/thn, but hardly the plur. ke/rdh,—used here instead of ke/rdos (cp. 579) because the "blessings" were to be felt in many ways and on many occasions (see 1524 ff.).
toi=s pe/myasin is supplemented by a)ph/lasan, since pe/mpein can be said of those who "speed the parting guest": Od. 15.74 xrh\ cei=non pareo/nta filei=n e)qe/lonta de\ pe/mpein.

parhggu/a cannot mean "pledged,""promised" (h)ggua=to), but only "passed the watchword to me," i.e. "told me, as a sign." Xen. Cyr. 3.3.58 parhggu/a o( *ku=ros su/nqhma, *zeu\s su/mmaxos kai\ h(gemw/n, "C. proceeded to pass the watchword, 'Zeus'", etc. pareggua/w regularly has this sense (which sometimes passes into that of "exhorting," "encouraging" one another); or else that of "putting something into another's hand," "entrusting" it to him. The omission of the temporal augment in L and other MSS. is not a sufficient ground for adopting Herwerden's fere/ggua ("trusty").

h)\ seismo/n, h)\ bronth/n tin), some such sign as earthquake or thunder (tina/ with both): thunder is the sign given at 1606. tin) suggests that the god spoke merely of "signs": Oed. interprets. Cp. schol. Aristoph. Ach. 171 dioshmi/a de/ e)stin o( para\ kairo\n xeimw/n. Plut. Mor. 419 F su/gxusin mega/lhn peri\ to\n a)e/ra kai\ dioshmi/as polla\s gene/sqai.
e)/gnwka me\n is answered (101) by a)lla/ moi...do/te. nun, "then," seems better than nu=n, (though this could stand,) since the oracle is the basis of his belief.
th/nde th\n o(do\n: acc. of extension in space (with e)ch/gage), denoting the ground traversed: cp. 1686: Ph. 1223 ke/leuqon e(/rpeis.

ou)k e)/sq' o(/pws ou), which in grammatical order immediately follows w(s, can be thus placed because felt as one adverbial expression="assuredly": so often e)/stin o(/te (="sometimes"), ou)k e)/stin h(=| ("in no wise"), ou)dei\s o(/stis ou) ("everybody"), etc.

ptero\n: no outward sign had been given. The "omen" was in the leading of his will. Cp. the feeling in the Odyssey (more spiritual here than the Iliad) that the gods sometimes act directly on the human mind by inspiring a thought at a crisis. Od. 16.282 (Odysseus to his son, when planning to slay the suitors)
o(ppo/te ken polu/boulos e)ni\ fresi\ qh/sei *)aqh/nh,
neu/sw me/n toi e)gw\ kefalh=|: which anticipates such a ptero/n as is meant here. For ptero/n as=oi)wno/s or o)/rnis (= pa/nq' o(/saper peri\ mantei/as diakri/nei Aristoph. Av. 719), Schneidewin cp. Callimachus Lav. Pall. 124 poi/wn (o)rni/qwn) ou)k a)gaqai\ pte/ruges, Propert. 4. 10. 11 felicibus edita pennis (with happy auguries).
e)ch/gag), i.e. "to my goal" (e)c-), not, "aside from the highway." Plat. Phaedo 66B kinduneu/ei toi w(/sper a)trapo/s tis e)kfe/rein h(ma=s (and so Soph. Ai. 7).
ou) ga\r a)/n, "for else," etc., the suppressed protasis being ei) mh\ e)ch/gage: so 125: O. T. 82, and Appendix to O. T. p. 221.

nh/fwn a)oi/nois; the austere wanderer lights first on the shrine of the austere goddesses (w(s ai)ei\ to\n o(moi=on a)/gei qeo\s w(s to\n o(moi=on); nh/fwn implying the thought that he has been in a manner consecrated to suffering. Water, and honey mixed with milk (meli/kraton), formed the xoa\s a)oi/nous, nhfa/lia meili/gmata (Aesch. Eum. 107) of the Furies. Pollux 6. 26 to\ ga\r nhfalieu/ein to\ nhfa/lia qu/ein e)/legon, o(/per e)sti\ to\ xrh=sqai qusi/ais a)oi/nois, w(=n ta\s e)nanti/as qusi/as oi)nospo/ndous e)/legon. Photius s. v. nhfa/lioi qusi/ai, e)n ai(=s oi)=nos ou) spe/ndetai, a)lla\ u(/dwr kai\ meli/kraton.
a)ske/parnon (cp. 19), not shaped by the adze (ske/parnos, fr. 724): so Soph. is quoted by Hesychius (1. 90) for a)dre/panon (from drepa/nh).

bi/ou … pe/rasin … kai\ katastrofh/n tina, some ending of life,—some close to my course. bi/ou pe/rasis is to\ pera=n to
 bi/on, a passing through life to its end, a concluding of it (Eur. Andr. 101 th
 teleutai/an...pera/sas h(me/ran): katastrofh/ adds the notion of a career which approaches its goal. Thuc. 2.42 (of those who had fallen in the war) dokei= de/ moi dhlou=n a)ndro\s a)reth
 prw/th te mhnu/ousa kai\ teleutai/a bebaiou=sa h( nu=n tw=nde katastrofh/ (the closing scene of their lives). Polyb. 5. 54 th
 au)th
 e)poih/santo tou= bi/ou katastrofh/n.
o)mfa\s: see on 550.

meio/nws e)/xein=mei/wn ei)=nai. This euphemistic mode of expression with the comparative adverb is often found where censure or disparagement is to be conveyed less bluntly. Plat. Phaedo 75A o)re/getai me
 pa/nta tau=ta ei)=nai oi(=on to\ i)/son, e)/xei de\ e)ndeeste/rws (repeated just afterwards thus, au)tou= e)ndee/stera/ e)stin): Apol. 34 C ta/x' a)
 ou)=n tis tau=ta e)nnoh/sas au)qade/steron a)
 pro/s me sxoi/h, = au)qade/steros a)
 ei)/h: Legg. 932 A e)a/n tis e)n th=|de th=| po/lei gone/wn a)mele/steron e)/xh| tou= de/ontos = a)mele/steros h)=|. Oedipus says to the Furies: "Grant me rest, unless haply (ti, adv., as O. T. 969, here with bitter irony) I seem to be beneath such grace,—I, who have suffered so much and so long." meio/nws e)/xein means here to be mei/wn in the sense of "too insignificant," "of too little account," in respect of suffering: i.e., one who has not yet suffered enough. Thus we arrive at the same sense which the scholiast extorts by a method which seems impossible. He explains meio/nws e)/xein as = e)latto/nws e)/xein ta\ kaka/, "to have ills in too small a degree." But (1) as Herm. said, this would be mei=on or mei/w e)/xein, and (2) it is impossible to understand ta\ kaka/. Campbell thinks that meio/nws e)/xein latreu/wn = meio/nws e)/xein latreuma/twn: which is open to objection (1), and also to this, that the partic. latreu/wn could not do duty for a partitive gen. after e)/xein. Wecklein (who follows the schol.) suggests meio/nws e)/xein kakw=n, and a)ei/ for brotw=n in 105.
mo/xqois latreu/wn: Aesch. Ag. 217 a)na/gkas e)/du le/padnon: Eur. Suppl. 877 xrhma/twn zeuxqei\s u(/po (in bonds to lucre). Tr. 357 po/nwn latreu/mata (servitude in toils) is not similar.
i)/t', in urgent petition, as 248, O. T. 46 i)/q'...a)no/rqwson: 1413 i)/t', a)ciw/sat.

glukei=ai, with blandishment, as Tr. 1040 w)= gluku\s *(/aidas. No other poet of the class. age (I think) ventures on this use of gluku/s in addressing deities, which, indeed, is somewhat apt to recall the Aristophanic w)= glu/kwn, w)= gluku/tate.
*sko/tou: on 40.

*palla/dos, possessive gen. with kalou/menai: Athens, thou that art said to belong to Pallas, of all cities most honoured: Eur. Ion 8
e)/stin ga\r ou)k a)/shmos *(ellh/nwn po/lis,
th=s xrusolo/gxou *palla/dos keklhme/nh: ib. 311 *loci/ou keklh/meqa, I am called (the servant) of Apollo.

ei)/dwlon (cp. 393), a mere wraith, with the semblance and speech of the man, a)ta\r fre/nes ou)k e)/ni pa/mpan, but the living heart is not therein (as Achilles says of the ei)/dwlon of Patroclus, Il. 23.104). So the wraith of Helen is ei)/dwlon e)/mpnoun, Eur. Helen 34.

ou) ga\r dh\ to/ g). After to/d' in 109 a second to/d' here would be very awkward: and the article, if not necessary, is at least desirable. ou) ga\r dh/ is esp. used in rejecting an alternative to something already stated, and ge is often added with the force of "at any rate"; below, 265
ou) ga\r dh\ to/ ge
sw=m': El. 1020 ou) ga\r dh\ keno/n g' a)fh/somen: Ph. 246 ou) ga\r dh\ su/ g' h)=sqa nauba/ths. On the other hand ou) ga\r dh/ without ge occurs O. T. 576, Ant. 46.
The grove being close to the village, the man of the place has done his errand quickly, and the elders of Colonus are already heard approaching (cp. 78).

xro/nw|, dat. of circumstance with palaioi/, old in respect of their years, i.e. "aged." The phrase (an unusual one) does not seem to be intensive, as Campbell makes it, "very old" (gonh=| gennai=e in O. T. 1469 is not similar), but simply pleonastic, as in Od. 13.432 palaiou=... ge/rontos, an old man of many years.
e)pi/skopoi here=speculatores, explorers, but in Ant. 217 overseers, watchers, and ib. 1148 of Dionysus, "master" (of mystic rites).

kai\ su/ m' e)c o(dou= po/da kru/yon all MSS. (1) This is usu. explained by partitive apposition (sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros), the part po/da being in appos. with the whole me: "Hide me,—that is, my foot,—apart from the road." The construction is common (Ph. 1301 me/qes me...xei=ra, Hom. Il. 11.240 to\n d' a)/ori plh=c' au)xe/na): the question here is as to the sense. a)/gage/ me po/da could bear such a sense: but kru/yon me po/da cannot do so, unless we grant that kru/ptein po/da could mean "to guide another's steps to a hiding place." Wholly different is Eur. Hec. 812 poi= m' u(peca/geis po/da; "whither art thou withdrawing thy steps from me?" =poi= me feu/geis; (2) Paley thinks that po/da is "quite redundantly used," as if a)/gousa had been part of the sentence. The evidence cited for a "redundant" use of po/da consists in (a) the phrase bai/nw po/da, Eur. El. 1173 etc., where bai/nw is trans.: (b) one place, Eur. Alc. 1153 a)ll' eu)tuxoi/hs, no/stimon d' e)/lqois po/da: where, if right, p. is a bold cognate acc., come with returning foot: but o(do/n and do/mon are vv. ll. (3) Campbell takes me as governed, pro\s to\ shmaino/menon, by kru/yon po/da as=u(pe/cage: but this involves the difficulty noticed under (1). I regard as probable H. Keck's e)kpodw\n o(dou=. Cp. Eur. Phoen. 978 xqono\s th=sd' e)kpodw/n. No substitute for po/da is satisfactory: among the conjectures are ko/ra, me/ poi, pa/lin, pe/las, pe/ra, pro/sw, ta/xa, to/de, to/d' a)/y.

tw=nd' … e)kma/qw ti/nas lo/gous e)rou=sin, learn in regard to these men what they will say; not, learn from them (by speaking to them), since his present object is only to overhear them, unseen. This gen. of connection often goes thus with verbs of perceiving, etc.: Xen. Mem. 3.6.17 e)nqumou= tw=n ei)do/twn o(/ti le/gousi. Plat. Gorg. 517C a)gnoou=ntes a)llh/lwn o(/ti le/gomen. Distinguish 593 o(/tan ma/qh|s mou nouqe/tei, when thou hast learnt from me.

e)n ga\r tw=| maqei=n: i.e. "for in learning (how the people of the place are disposed) consists the caution of (proper for) all that we are doing": we are poor strangers, who must be prepared to shape our course according to the mood of the a)stoi/ (13). The spondee can stand in the 5th place, since e)n, to which ga/r adheres, itself coheres closely with tw=| maqei=n: so El. 376 ei) ga\r tw=nde/ moi (where, as here, Elms. proposed de\ instead of ga\r): ib. 409 tw=| tou=t' h)/resen; cp. 664.

tw=n poioume/nwn: so El. 84 (just before an exit, as here):
tau=ta ga\r fe/rei
ni/khn t' e)f' h(mi=n kai\ kra/tos tw=n drwme/nwn. The gnw/mh here, though perhaps meant to mark the caution taught by bitter experience (cp. 273), has the tone of Periclean Athens: cp. Thuc. 2.40 (it is a mischief) mh\ prodidaxqh=nai...lo/gw| pro/teron h)\ e)pi\ a(\ dei= e)/rgw| e)lqei=n: 3. 42 (Diodotus answering Cleon) tou\s...lo/gous... didaska/lous tw=n pragma/twn.

div2.head: 117-253: Parodos
div2.p: Parodos, passing at v. 138 into a lyric dialogue (kommo/s) between the Chorus and Oedipus (see preliminary n. on the structure of the play). For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

The framework is as follows. (1) first strophe, 117 ti/s a)/r' h)=n to 137 nai/ei, = first antistrophe, 149 e)h/ to 169 a)peru/kou. (2) second strophe, 176 ou)/toi to 187 se/besqai, = second antistr., 192 au)tou= to 206 e)kpuqoi/man. Between the 1st strophe and the 1st antistrophe is interposed an anapaestic "system" (su/sthma) of 11 verses, 138 o(/d' e)kei=nos to 148 w(/rmoun (Oed. and Ch.). Between the 1st antistr. and the 2nd strophe, a second system of 6 verses, 170 qu/gater to 175 metanasta/s (Oed. and Ant.). Between the 2nd strophe and the 2nd antistr., a third system of 4 verses, 188 a)/ge nun to 191 polemw=men (Oed.). From v. 207 to the end (253), the verses are without strophic correspondence (a)nomoio/strofa). A doubt exists as to the genuineness of vv. 237-253 (w)= ce/noi—du/naito), and of the 4 trimeters which follow (254-257): see on 237.

The Chorus induce Oed. to leave the grove by promising that no one shall remove him from Colonus by force (176), but, on learning who he is (222), revoke the promise, and command him to leave Attica. Antigone appeals to them.

div3.p:
o(/ra: cp. Aesch. Eum. 255 (the Furies hunting Orestes):
o(/ra, o(/ra ma/l' au)= leu=sse/ te pa/nta, mh\
la/qh| fu/gda ba\s matrofo/nos a)ti/tas: cp. also the scene in which the Chorus of the Ajax are seeking the hero (867
pa= pa=
pa= ga\r ou)k e)/ban e)gw/;).

ti/s a)/r' h)=n; imperf. of previous mention (not implying that he is not still trespassing): who was he of whom our informant spoke? Plat. Crito 47D o(\ tw=| me\n dikai/w| be/ltion e)gi/gneto (is, as we agreed, made better), tw=| de\ a)di/kw| a)pw/lluto. Slightly different is the imperf. of a truth newly seen: Ph. 978
o(/d' h)=n a)/ra
o( cullabw/n me, "so (all the time) this was he who has seized me."
nai/ei, of mere situation (not habitation), as Il. 2.626 nh/swn ai(\ nai/ousi pe/rhn a(lo/s: so Ai. 597 (of Salamis), and Tr. 99 (of a wanderer).

e)kto/pios instead of e)k to/pou: 716 a(li/a...pla/ta qrw/skei: O. T. 1340 a)pa/get' e)kto/pion: 1411 qala/ssion e)kri/yat): Ant. 785 foita=|s d' u(perpo/ntios: El. 419 e)fe/stion ph=cai: Eur. I. T. 1424 para/ktioi dramei=sqe. Plut. Dion 25 pela/gioi pro\s th\n *sikeli/an e)/feugon.

a)kore/statos, "most insatiate" (ko/ros); hence, reckless of due limit,— shameless: cp.
improbus annis
atque mero fervens (Iuv. 3. 282). Eur. Her. 926 (deprecating u(/bris),
mh/pot' e)mo\n fro/nhma
yuxa/ t' a)ko/restos ei)/h. A positive a)korh/s is found in later Greek (Themistius, or. 90 D, 4th cent. A.D.): and as diakorh/s and katakorh/s are classical (Plato, etc.), it may be a mere accident that a)korh/s has no earlier warrant. If referred to a)ko/restos, the superl. would be a poet. form like ne/atos, me/satos.

This verse is corrupt in the MSS., but two things seem clear: (1) there is no reason to suspect prosde/rkou: (2) the singular leu=sse must be restored, and placed after prosde/rkou. The antistrophic verse (153) is a)ll' ou) ma
 e)/n g' e)moi/. A long syllable is then wanted to complete the verse prosde/rkou, leu=sse. Hermann's nin has been generally adopted. But leu=sse nin could only mean "see him": not, "look for him": leu/ssein tina/ could not stand for zhtei=n tina. The MS. au)to
 was prob. a gloss which came in after prosde/rkou and leu=sse had been transposed; and the plur. leu/ssete may have arisen from leu=sse dh/. In 135 o(/n is governed by gnw=nai, not by leu/sswn: and in Aesch. Eum. 255 o(/ra, o(/ra ma/l' au)=, leu=sse/ te pa/nta (v.l. panta=), the sense is, "scan all the ground." Cp. Ai. 890 ("'tis cruel," the Chorus say, baffled in their quest) amenhno
 a)/ndra mh\ leu/ssein o(/pou.

prospeu/qou (only here) ought to mean "ask, or learn, further" (the reg. sense of prospunqa/nesqai, proserwta=n), but this is weak: here, it seems rather to mean, "press the inquiry," inquire assiduously: cp. prosaitei=n, prosliparei=n. prosfqe/ggou ("speak to him"), a v.l. for prospeu/qou, is plainly unsuitable. Hermann transposed prosde/rkou and prospeu/qou: but the "looking" naturally precedes the "asking," and pantaxh=| suits both. The conjectures
leu=ss' au)to/n, prosdrakou=,
prospeu/qou (or
prospuqou=,
prosde/rkou) are open not only to the objection from the sense of leu/ssein (121), but also to this, that the aor. is less fitting here. As to prosdrakou=, e)drako/mhn in Anth. Pal. 7. 224 is a very rare example of that form.
plana/tas, one who has wandered hither from beyond our borders, and so =ce/nos: cp. on 3.
prose/ba ga\r ou)k a)/n: cp. 98: for the place of ou)k, Ant. 96.
a)/lsos e)s: see on 84.

a)maimaketa=n: used by the poets of any violent force, divine or elemental, with which men cannot cope (as the Chimaera, Il. 6.179; Artemis in her wrath, Pind. Pyth. 3.33; the sea, ib. 1.14; fire, O. T. 177), and probably associated with a)/maxos. But the reduplication recalls mai-ma/-w (cp. por-fu/r-w, poi-pnu/-w), —the a) being intensive: and if we suppose a secondary development of √MA as mak (Fennell on Pind. P. 1. 14), the proper sense of a)maima/ketos would be "very furious." The word being of epic coinage, it is conceivable that associations with ma/xomai may have influenced the formation as well as the usage.

kai\ parameibo/mesq' k.t.l. In approaching or passing a shrine, it was usual to salute (proskunei=n), and to invoke the deity audibly. But in passing the grove of the Eumenides the people of Colonus avoid looking towards it. No sound, no articulate word, escapes them. Their lips only move in sign of the prayer which the mind conceives. Cp. on 489.

to\ ta=s e)fa/mou sto/ma fronti/dos i(e/ntes = "moving the lips of (in) reverently-mute thought"; i(e/nai (instead of oi)/gein, lu/ein, diai/rein) sto/ma has been suggested by the phrases fwnh\n (or glw=ssan) i(e/nai: cp. fr. 844. 3 pollh\n glw=ssan e)kxe/as ma/thn. This is better than to make sto/ma purely figurative (like "the still, small voice"), when the sense would be, "giving a (still) voice to our reverent thought," eu)fa/mou (=silent) qualifying the metaphor as when discord is called pu=r a)nh/faiston, Eur. Or. 621.

a)fw/nws. The ancient custom was to pray aloud, partly from a feeling that one ought not to make any prayer which might not be heard by all mortals. Pythagoras in Clemens Alex. Strom. 4. 26 § 173 (it is usual meta\ fwnh=s eu)/xesqai) e)moi\ dokei=, ou)x o(/ti to\ qei=on w)/|onto mh\ du/nasqai tw=n h(suxh=| fqeggome/nwn e)pai+/ein, a)ll' o(/ti dikai/as e)bou/lonto ei)=nai ta\s eu)xa/s, a(\s ou)k a)/n tis ai)desqei/h poiei=sqai pollw=n suneido/twn. Persius 2. 6
Haud cuivis promptum est murmurque humilesque susurros
Tollere de templis et aperto vivere voto. Lucan 5. 104 tacito mala vota susurro Concipiunt.
After i(e/ntes we may place either (1) a point,—making ta\ de\ nu=n begin a new sentence: or (2) merely a comma,— taking a(\s (129) as still the object to a(/zonq': (1) is best.

ou)de
 (adverb) a(/zonq', sc. au)ta/s: ou)de
 a(/zonq' as="reverencing nothing" would be at least unusual. The act. of a(/zomai occurs only here; but that fact scarcely seems to warrant a change. If any were made, the simplest would be ou)de
 a)/gonq' (in the sense of qeou\s a)/gein), with e)/xeis in 166.
o(\n with gnw=nai only: leu/sswn absol.: see on 121.
moi ethic dat. (62, 81)
nai/ei 117.
e)kei=nos, of whom ye were speaking: Ant. 384: Aristoph. Ach. 41 tou=t' e)kei=n' ou(gw\ )legon: Nub. 1167 o(/d' e)kei=nos a)nh/r: El. 665.

fwnh=| ga\r o(rw|: (I appear to you), for in sound is my sight (i.e. I know your presence by your voices). To this announcement of his blindness a certain gentle pathos is added by to\ fatizo/m. (acc. in appos.), "as they say of us the blind": alluding generally, perh., to the fig. use of o(ra=n, ble/pein in ref. to mental sight (as O. T. 747, of the blind seer, de/doika mh\ ble/pwn o( ma/ntis h)=|), rather than to any special proverb. So Thuc. 7.87 panwleqri/a| dh/, to\ lego/menon,...ou)de\n o(/ti ou)k a)pw/leto, referring merely to the phrase. [Dem.] or. 25 § 89 w(/sper to\ th=s paroimi/as, o(rw=ntas mh\ o(ra=n kai\ a)kou/ontas mh\ a)kou/ein. We must not render (1) with the schol., "I understand by sound what ye mean," to\ lego/menon par' u(mw=n, nor (2) with Ellendt, "I perceive what is uttered by your voice." The pause saves the short final of fatizo/menon from being a breach of synaphea: cp. 143 (pre/sbus;): Ant. 932 (u(/per).

o(ra=n, klu/ein, epexegetic inf., like xalepo\s suzh=n (Plat. Polit. 302B). The cry which bursts from the Chorus merely utters their horror at first seeing and hearing the wretch who has dared so great an impiety;—they have not yet had time to scan the traces of misery which the blind man's form exhibits (cp. 286).

prosi/dht' a)/nomon, regard as lawless: schol. lei/pei to\ w(s. The omission is remarkable. Doederlein cp. Thuc. 2.72 de/xesqe de\ a)mfote/rous fi/lous, which is less bold: so, too, is O. T. 412 tuflo/n m' w)nei/disas (where see n.). In modern Greek, however, (and the use doubtless goes far back,) qewrei=n regularly="to consider as" (without w(s).
The hiatus allows *zeu= to be short.
a)lech=tor: Aristoph. Vesp. 161 *)/apollon a)potro/paie, tou= manteu/matos.

ou) pa/nu moi/ras prw/ths not wholly of the best fortune, eu)daimoni/sai (epexeg. inf., ei)s to\ eu)daimoni/sai schol.) so that men should call him happy. The gen. is a poet. form of the possessive, "belonging to" the best fortune (as to a category); cp. Pind. Pyth. 3.60 oi(/as ei)me\n ai)/sas, of what estate we (mortals) are: Plut. Num. 2 krei/ttonos h)=n moi/ras. The place of eu)daim. has been influenced by its common constr. with a causal gen.: but we could not say, ou)k ei)mi\ eu)daimoni/sai, I am not to be congratulated.

prw/ths, not "from his birth," but "best": Ant. 1347
to\ fronei=n
eu)daimoni/as prw=ton u(pa/rxei: a sense associated with the idea of first prize (Il. 23.275 ta\ prw=ta labw/n), ta\ prwtei=a: cp. 1313; and so 1228 polu\ deu/teron.
ou) pa/nu oft means "not at all," but prob. as a result of the primary ironical sense, "not altogether."
e)/foroi: since the stranger had said krinou=si (79).

dhlw= d' (like shmei=on de/, tekmh/rion de/), i.e., and this is plain from my being guided by yonder maiden: cp. 1145: O. T. 1294 dei/cei de\ kai\ soi/ (sc. *oi)di/pous): Aristoph. Eccl. 936 dei/cei ta/x' au)to/s: Lys. or. 10 § 20 dhlw/sei de/: oi)xh/setai ga\r a)piw/n.

a)llotri/ois o)/mm. (instrumental dat.): Ant. 989
toi=s tufloi=si ga\r
au(/th ke/leuqos e)k prohghtou= pe/lei: Eur. Phoen. 834
h(gou= pa/roiqe, qu/gater, w(s tuflw=| podi\
o)fqalmo\s ei)= su/. (In Plat. Phaedo 99B, quoted by Blaydes, read a)llotri/w| o)no/mati, not o)/mmati.)

Oedipus is indeed old and worn (110): but me/gas contrasts the man of mature age with the girl, his defenceless guide (752). Cp. Od. 2.313 (Telemachus)
e)gw\ d' e)/ti nh/pios h)=a:
nu=n d', o(/te dh\ me/gas ei)mi/ (full-grown).

smikroi=s: for the allusive (masc.) plur., instead of smikra=|, cp. O. T. 366 su\n toi=s filta/tois (with Iocasta): for the sense, below, 957 e)rhmi/a me … smikro\n ti/qhsi. The antithesis of persons suggests that smikroi=s is masc. rather than neut.: so below 880: Ai. 158 smikroi\...mega/lwn xwri/s, 160
meta\ ga\r mega/lwn baio\s a)/rist' a)\n
kai\ me/gas o)rqoi=q' u(po\ mikrote/rwn. If smikroi=s were neut., it could mean: (a) like the masc., weak persons: cp. 1 Cor. i. 27 ta\ mwra\ tou= ko/smou e)cele/cato o( qeo/s, i(/na kataisxu/nh| tou\s sofou/s: (b) fig., "weak things," frail supports. But the neut. plur. smikra/ in such antitheses usu.="lowly fortunes": Pind. P. 3. 107
smikro\s e)n smikroi=s, me/gas e)n mega/lois
e)/ssomai: Eur. El. 406
ei)/per ei)si\n eu)genei=s
ou)k e)/n te mikroi=s e)/n te mh\ ste/rcous' o(mw=s;

w(/rmoun: usu. e)pi/ tinos: Dem. De Cor. § 281 ou)k e)pi\ th=s au)th=s (a)gku/ras) o(rmei= toi=s polloi=s: but also e)pi/ tini: Plut. Solon 19 (he added the *boulh/ to the Areopagus) oi)o/menos e)pi\ dusi\ boulai=s w(/sper a)gku/rais o(rmou=san h(=tton e)n sa/lw| th\n po/lin e)/sesqai. For the metaphor cp. Soph. fr. 619 a)ll' ei)si\ mhtri\ pai=des a)/gkurai bi/ou. Eur. fr. 858
h(/de moi trofo/s,
mh/thr, a)delfh/, dmwi/s, a)/gkura, ste/gh. Or. 68
w(s ta/ g' a)/ll' e)p' a)sqenou=s
r(w/mhs o)xou/meq': Med. 770 e)k tou=d' a)napto/mesqa prumnh/thn ka/lwn. Campbell understands — "Nor, being a prince (me/gas), as I am, should I have taken up my rest here to crave a small boon." But (1) me/gas in this sense ill suits the present tone of Oed.: cp. 110, 393. (2) This version of e)pi\ smikroi=s w(/rmoun is impossible: the scholium e)pi\ eu)tele/sin ai)th/masin ou)k a)\n sfo/dra i(ke/teuon evades the point.

e)h/. L has e)\ e)\: which should metrically answer to o(/ra (117). It is possible that in an exclamation, followed by a momentary pause, the second e)/ should stand here: but it is more prob. that, as in Aesch. Theb. 966 etc., we should write e)h/.

a)law=n o)mma/twn. Oedipus has spoken of his own ill fortune as if it consisted primarily in his blindness. The Chorus then ask: — "Ah! and wast thou blind from thy birth? Thy life has been long, as well as unhappy, one may judge." The gen. could depend on e)h/, as oft. on feu=, w)=, oi)/moi, etc., but is better taken with futa/lmios, of which the sense (with au)tw=n understood) would else be obscure.

futa/lmios="generator": i.e. didst thou bring them with thee into life? e)/fusas tufla\ o)/mmata;=h)=sqa tuflo\s e)k geneth=s; Ai. 1077 ka)\n sw=ma gennh/sh| me/ga though one grow a great body (=though his frame wax mighty).

=120 o( pa/ntwn a)kore/statos. In regard to L's reading, makrai/wn te/ q' (sic) w(s e)peika/sai, note these points: (1) w(s is wrong, as the metre shows, (2) t) is certainly right. We should not read, with Campb., dusai/wn; makrai/wn tis, e)peika/sai, because the thought turns on the linking of dusai/wn with makrai/wn, the chief stress falling (as oft. in Greek) on the second: thou art old as well as hapless: i.e. thou hast borne thy woes long. (3) e)/q' may, I think, be rejected, as too weak. (4) How, then, is the short syllable to be supplied? (a) We might read;— makrai/wn q', o(/s) e)peika/sai: cp. Thuc. 6.25 o(/sa...h)/dh dokei=n au)tw=|, "so far as he could now judge." (b) makrai/wn te/ tis, ei)ka/sai: cp. O. T. 82 a)ll), ei)ka/sai me/n, h(du/s. I prefer (a), since all MSS. have e)peika/sai.
("Thou hast already suffered;) but verily, within my power (e)/n g' e)moi/, =if I can help it), thou shalt not add these curses (to thy woes)."

ma/n strengthens the adversative force of a)lla/ (as in a)lla\ mh/n, a)ll' ou)de\ mh/n): e)/n g' e)moi/ = e)n e)moi/ ge. Cp. 247: O. T. 314 (n.): Xen. Oec. 7.14 ti/s h( e)mh\ du/namis; a)ll' e)n soi\ pa/nta e)sti/n. The thought is like that of Ant. 556 a)ll' ou)k e)p' a)rrh/tois ge toi=s e)moi=s lo/gois (sc. qanei=).

prosqh/sei, make thine own, bring on thyself: Aesch. Pers. 531 mh\ kai/ ti pro\s kakoi=si prosqh=tai kako/n: Eur. Her. 146 i)/dia prosqe/sqai kaka/: Andr. 394
ti/ de/ me kai\ tekei=n e)xrh=n
a)/xqos t' e)p' a)/xqei tw=|de prosqe/sqai diplou=n; The MSS. have prosqh/seis: but the active word would require either (a) the reflexive pronoun, as in fr. 323
tau=t' e)sti\n a)/lgist', h)\n paro\n qe/sqai kalw=s
au)to/s tis au(tw=| th\n bla/bhn prosqh=| fe/rwn: O. T. 819
ou)/tis a)/llos h)=n
h)\ )gw\ )p' e)mautw=| ta/sd' a)ra\s o( prostiqei/s: or (b) some dat. such as toi=s soi=s kakoi=s: and we cannot legitimately supply either. So, again, the version "thou shalt not bring on us" (ou)k e)moi\ prosqh/seis th\n sh\n a)ra/n schol.) could stand only if e)moi/ or h(mi=n were expressed.
pera=|s, absol.: "thou art going too far" (into the grove): Oed., not reassured by their cry (141), has moved some steps back.
a)ll' i(/na … mh\ prope/sh|s is answered by meta/staq' 162.

prope/sh|s e)n na/pei, advance blindly in the grove, till he stumble (so to say) on its inmost mystery. Cp. Arist. Eth. 3.7.12 oi( me
 qrasei=s propetei=s. Isocr. or. 5 § 90 (the Greeks, when conquering the Persians at Cunaxa, 401 B.C.a, were worsted)dia\ th
 *ku/rou prope/teian, his precipitancy in rushing at his brother Artaxerxes (Xen. Anab. 1.8.26 ei)pw/n, *(orw= to
 a)/ndra, i(/eto e)p' au)to/n).
a)fqe/gktw|: see on 130 ff.

ou(= ka/qudros krath\r suntre/xei r(eu/mati meilixi/wn potw=n, where the bowl filled with water is used along with the stream of sweetened drink-offering: i.e. where libations are poured, first, of water alone, and then of water mingled with honey; see on vv. 472-479.
meilixi/wn p.: schol. gluke/wn potw=n, o(/ e)sti, me/litos, oi(=s meili/ssousi ta\s qea/s (see on 100).

suntre/xei, is combined with: Tr. 295 pollh/ )st' a)na/gkh th=|de ( sc. th=| pra/cei )tou=to suntre/xein, this joy of mine must needs attend on this good fortune of my husband. While krath/r points to the figurative use of suntre/xei, r(eu/mati suggests its literal sense. Others understand:— "where the basin (krath/r") runs together in a stream (r(eu/mati modal dat.) of sweetened waters, i.e. "is filled by the confluence of sweetened waters"; but (a) krath/r is the bowl from which the xoai/ are poured, not a basin which receives them: (b) such an inversion is impossible.

The tw=n of L and most MSS. cannot be right. To be on one's guard against a thing is always fula/ssomai/ ti, never tinos. In Thuc. 4.11 fulassome/nous tw=n new=n mh\ cuntri/ywsin = acting cautiously on account of the ships (where Classen cp. xalepw=s fe/rein tino/s, 1. 77): in Aesch. PV 390 tou/tou fula/ssou mh/pot' a)xqesqh=| ke/ar, join tou/tou ke/ar. The v.l. to\n points to to/, which in this parenthetic warning=tou=to (to\ propesei=n) rather than o(/. to/n (referring to krath/r) is less good; and tw=| ("wherefore") would be weak.

e)ratu^/ei, arcet, keeps (thee) off (from us), separates: Eur. Phoen. 1260 e)rh/tuson te/kna | deinh=s a(mi/llhs. This is said to themselves rather than to Oed.: they are not sure that he has heard their cry, a)po/baqi. To Musgrave's e)ratu/oi the objections are:—(1) the opt. where we should expect the imperat. The opt. is sometimes joined with the imper. in good wishes or counsels (Pind. O. 13.25 a)fqo/nhtos ge/noio...kai\ to/nde lao\n eu)/qune): but here, where peremptory command is given (162 meta/staq', a)po/baqi — 169 fw/nei), the opt. is quite out of place. (2) The sense would be weak, after 161.
