oi)/seis, written in L over the vulgate e)/xeis, cannot be a correction of the latter, but must represent a distinct reading (whether conjectural or not). i)/sxeis would suit the metre (=a(/zonq' 134, where see n.) equally well: but the language slightly favours oi)/seis.

fe/rein lo/gon pro\s e)ma\n le/sxan=to bring forward something to be discussed with us (cp. Ant. 159
su/gklhton
th/nde gero/ntwn prou)/qeto le/sxhn), not, "in answer to our address," a sense which le/sxh never has. For fe/rein cp. Tr. 122 w(=n e)pimemfome/na s' a(dei=a (ai)doi=a Musgrave) me\n a)nti/a d' oi)/sw: for fut. indic. with ei) of immediate purpose, with an imperat. in apodosis, Aristoph. Av. 759 ai)=re plh=ktron ei) maxei=.
a)ba/twn: see on 10.
i(/na pa=si no/mos, where use suffers all (to speak): for the omission of e)sti/ cp. Her. 1.90 e)peirwta=n...ei) a)xari/stoisi no/mos ei)=nai toi=s *(ellhnikoi=si qeoi=si.
a)peru/kou, a)pe/xou tou= fwnei=n: schol. pro/teron de\ mh\ diale/gou.

poi= tis fronti/dos e)/lqh|; Such phrases present thought, speech, or the mind itself, as a region in which the wanderer is bewildered; cp. 310: El. 922 ou)k oi)=sq' o(/poi gh=s ou)d' o(/poi gnw/mhs fe/rei: "thou knowest not whither or into what fancies thou art roaming": ib. 1174 poi= lo/gwn … e)/lqw; ib. 390 pou= pot' ei)= frenw=n; Tr. 705 ou)k e)/xw...poi= gnw/mhs pe/sw.

e)/lqh|, delib. subjunct., in third pers., as Dem. De Cor. § 124 po/tero/n se/ tis, *ai)sxi/nh, th=s po/lews e)xqro\n h)\ e)mo\n ei)=nai fh=|; L has e)/lqoi, which might be defended as = "whither can one possibly turn?" — a more despairing form of e)/lqh|. Mr. A. Sidgwick has pointed out (Aesch. Cho. Append. p. 122) that the Attic examples of such an optat. without a)/n are always directly or indirectly interrogative (as Ant. 604 ti/s...kata/sxoi;), and are akin to the interrogative or "deliberative" subjunctive, not to the conditional optat. with a)/n. The principle is (I think) true. But here, at least, the genuinely "deliberative" e)/lqh| seems best. See Appendix.

a)stoi=s i)/sa xrh\ meleta=n, we must practise the same customs which they practise. Eur. Bacch. 890
ou)
ga\r krei=sso/n pote tw=n no/mwn
gignw/skein xrh\ kai\ meleta=n: we must never set our theory, or practice, above the laws.

Since ka)kou/ontas suits both metre and sense, it seems more likely that this was the reading from which, by a scribe's mistake, kou)k a)kou/ontas arose, than that a)kou/ontas conceals some other participle (such as katoknou=ntas or a)piqou=ntas). It is hard to see why Herm. thought the "negatio contrarii" to be necessary here,—common though it is (see on O. T. 58 gnwta\ kou)k a)/gnwta). After xrh\ meleta=n, too, we should expect mhde/, not kai\ ou)k; the latter supposes that ou) and its partic. form one word. kou)k a)/kontas (B and Campbell) would mean, "and that, too, not unwillingly"—surely a weak sense. The existence of this as the only v.l. confirms ka)kou/ontas.
kai\ dh/: see on 31.

mh\ … a)dikhqw=. The prohibitive subjunct. (esp. aor.) is freq. in the 1st pers. plur., but the 1st pers. sing. is very rare: Tr. 802 mhd' au)tou= qa/nw: Il. 1.26 mh/ se kixei/w: 21. 475 mh/ seu a)kou/sw.

soi\ (the coryphaeus) after w)= cei=noi (the Chorus): cp. 208 w)= ce/noi,...mh/ m' a)ne/rh|: 242 ff. w)= ce/noi, oi)ktei/rat', followed by o)/mma so/n. Cp. O. T. 1111 pre/sbeis, 1115 su/. kai\ was omitted by Herm., to make a paroemiac (when the sound and rhythm become extremely unpleasing); soi\ was omitted, with the same object, by Brunck and Elmsley. Both words are genuine. A paroemiac is neither needful nor desirable here, when another follows so closely (177).

tw=nd' e(dra/nwn, "these seats," the resting-place, generally, in front of the grove, rather than the particular rocky seat pointed out at 192 f.: cp. 233 f. (Hardly "abodes," i.e. Colonus, as Aesch. Pers. 4.)

a)/cei was altered to a)/rh| by Elmsley on the ground that ou) mh/ with the fut. indic. forbids; with the subjunctive, denies. But, besides the passages in which ou) mh/ stands with the 2nd pers. fut. ind., and forbids (as Aristoph. Ran. 462 ou) mh\ diatri/yeis, "don't dawdle"), there are others in which it stands with the 1st or 3rd pers. fut. ind., and denies. In some of these our MSS. are doubtless corrupt; but there are others in which the correction, if any, must be bold. Thus: (1) with 1st pers.: Soph. El. 1052 ou)/ soi mh\ meqe/yomai/ pote: Aristoph. Ran. 508 ou) mh/ s) e)gw\ | perio/yoma)pelqo/nt'. (2) with 3rd pers.: Xen. Hellen. 1.6.32 ei)=pen o(/ti h( *spa/rth ou)de\n mh\ ka/kion oi)kiei=tai au)tou= a)poqano/ntos: Eur. Phoen. 1590
safw=s ga\r ei)=pe *teiresi/as ou) mh/pote
sou= th/nde gh=n oi)kou=ntos eu)= pra/cein po/lin (oblique of ou) mh\ pra/cei). On the whole the evidence points to the conclusion that ou) mh/ could be used with the 1st or 3rd pers. fut. indic., as with the aor. or pres. subjunct., in giving a strong assurance.

L's e)/t' ou)=n e)/ti probw=; metrically answers to ou(/tws in 194. The choice seems to lie between e)/t' ou)=n; and probw=; The latter might easily have been added to explain the former: and e)/t' ou)=n is not too abrupt, since pro/sqige/ nu/n mou (173) has already marked the beginning of his forward movement. e)/ti bai=ne seems better than e)pi/baine in the case of a blind man advancing step by step, and asking at each step whether he has come far enough. This is well expressed by e)/t) ou)=n;—e)/ti bai=ne.—e)/ti; For e)/ti_ before prob., cp. Ant. 612 to_ pri/n.

After a)i+/eis three verses have been lost (the 1st and 3rd for Ant., the 2nd for Oed.), answering to 197 pa/ter — 199 a(/rmosai: and after a(=| s' a)/gw (183) a verse for Oed. answering to 202 w)/moi … a)/tas. See Metrical Analysis.

ma/n (a stronger me/n, "verily") may here be simply hortative ("come!") as it oft. is with the imperat.: Il. 1.302 ei) d' a)/ge mh\n pei/rhsai: 5. 765 a)/grei ma/n: Aesch. Suppl. 1018 i)/te ma/n. If the lost words of Oed. uttered a complaint, then ma/n may have had an adversative force, "yet": but this is more oft. ge mh/n than mh/n alone: cp. 587.
w(=d', in this direction: see on O. T. 7.

a)maurw=| kw/lw| = tuflw=| podi/ (Eur. Hec. 1050): cp. 1639 a)maurai=s xersi/n. In Eur. Herc. Fur. 123, however, podo\s a)mauro\n i)/xnos = merely "my feeble steps" (for Amphitryon is not blind). That might be the meaning here too. But in choosing between the literal sense of a)mauro/s, "dim," and the fig. sense, "feeble," we must be guided by the context of each passage; and the context here favours the former. Cp. 1018.
to/lma … se/besqai. These four vv. are wrongly given by the MSS. to Antigone. Her gentle counsel in 171 ff. may have prompted the attribution.

w)= tla/mwn: the nom. can thus stand for the voc. even in direct address, as Eur. Med. 1133 mh\ spe/rxou, fi/los: but is sometimes rather a comment, as ib. 61 w)= mw=ros, ei) xrh\ despo/tas ei)pei=n to/de. Cp. 753, 1471.

te/trofen a)/filon, holds in settled dislike:—the perfect tense marking how the sentiment which forbids impiety towards the Eumenides has interwoven itself with the life of the place. tre/fw ti/ a)/filon=to hold a thing (in one's thoughts) as unloveable: cp. e)n e)lpi/sin tre/fw ti (Ant. 897). For the perfect, denoting a fixed view, cp. Her. 3.38 ou(/tw nenomi/kasi ta\ peri\ tou\s no/mous (and so 7. 153, 8. 79): Plat. Legg. 8. 837 C o(...e)rwn th=| yuxh=|...u(/brin h(/ghtai th\n peri\ to\ sw=ma tou= sw/matos plhsmonh/n: Prot. 348 E ou(/tw pepi/steukas sautw=|. The perf. act. of tre/fw occurs in Anthol. Append. 111. 2 (Jacobs vol. II. p. 795) a)/ndras a)gakleitou\s te/trofe *kekropi/h: in Polybius (12. 25 h in the later form te/trafa), etc.: but in older Greek only in the Homeric use, as Od. 23.237 peri\ xroi+\ te/trofen a(/lmh (the brine has hardened on their flesh): whence Nauck here, po/lei te/trofen (as=pe/fuken) a)/filon, (whate'er) hath grown unpleasing to the city.

a)/n with the optat. verbs, not with i(/na: "(to a place) where I may speak on the one hand, and hear on the other": to\ me\n … to\ de/ are adverbial: cp. Xen. Anab. 4.1.14 ta\ me/n ti maxo/menoi, ta\ de\ kai\ a)napauo/menoi.

ei)/poimen … a)kou/saimen, i.e. "arrive at a mutual understanding," — a regular phrase: Thuc. 4.22 cune/drous de\ sfi/sin e)ke/leuon e(le/sqai oi(/tines le/gontes kai\ a)kou/ontes peri\ e(ka/stou cumbh/sontai: Theocr. 25. 48
ai)sumnh/ths
w(=| ke to\ me\n ei)/poimi, to\ d' e)k fame/noio puqoi/mhn (a head-man, "who to shrewd questions shrewdly can reply," Calverley).

a)/n with the optat. in the relative clause just as in apodosis; so Theocr. 25. 61
e)gw\ de/ toi h(gemoneu/sw
… i(/na ken te/tmoimen a)/nakta (to a place where we are likely to find him): Xen. Anab. 3.1.40 ou)k oi)=da o(/ ti a)/n tis xrh/saito au)toi=s (I know not what use one could make of them).

eu)sebi/as e)pibai/nontes, entering on piety, placing ourselves within its pale: but this figurative sense is here tinged with the notion of "entering on lawful ground" (schol. eu)sebw=s patou=ntes). For the fig. sense cp. Od. 23.52
o)/fra sfw=i+n e)u+frosu/nhs e)pibh=ton
a)mfote/rw fi/lon h)=tor, "that ye may both enter into your heart's delight" (Butcher and Lang): Ph. 1463 do/chs ou)/pote th=sd' e)piba/ntes, though we had never entered on that hope (dared to entertain it).
kai\ mh\ xr. pol.: Ant. 1106 a)na/gkh| d' ou)xi\ dusmaxhte/on. Simonides fr. 5. 21 a)na/gka| d' ou)de\ qeoi\ ma/xontai. Eur. fr. 709 xrei/a dida/skei, ka)\n bradu/s tis h)=|, sofo/n.
au)tou=. Oed. has now advanced to the verge of the grove. Here a low ledge of natural rock forms a sort of threshold, on which his feet are now set.

au)tope/trou bh/matos, a "step," i.e. ledge, of natural rock, not shaped by man (as was the ordinary bh=ma or raised place for speakers, etc.), distinct, of course, from the a)/cestos pe/tros of 19, which was within the grove. So au)to/culos (of rough wood, Ph. 35), au)topo/rfuros (of natural purple), au)to/pokos (of simple wool), au)to/pu_ros (of unbolted wheaten flour), au)to/komos (with natural hair, Aristoph. Ran. 822), au)to/rofoi pe/trai (rocks forming a natural roof, Oppian Halieut. 1. 22). The a)ntipe/trou of the MSS. could mean:—(1) "A ledge like rock"; cp. a)nti/pais (Aesch. Eum. 38)= "weak as a child": and so the schol. in L, i)sope/trou, xalkou=,—i.e. "a ledge of material firm as rock," "of brass," meaning the xalko/pous o)do/s understood literally: see, however, on 57. (2) "A ledge serving as a rock": cp. (o)nei/dh) a)nti/kentra (Aesch. Eum. 136), li/qos a)ntiqu/retros (Nonnus 11. 140), a)nti/purgos pe/tra (Eur. Bacch. 1097). (3) "A seat of rock fronting thee": cp. a)nti/prw|ros, with prw/|ra facing one. This does not fit the data. (4) Bellermann: "a (stone) seat over against a rock," i.e. "behind which the stone wall rises" (?).—Campb. renders first by "rocky," then by "rock-like," and refers it to "some peculiarity in the basement of the low seats."

po/da kli/nh|s (aor.) like po/da tre/pein (Eur. Suppl. 718), since, the seat being now at his side, he turns away from it if he moves forward. Wecklein explains it as =go/nu ka/myh|s ("sit down"), but (1) po/da could not here stand for go/nu, and (2) the question is now of halting, not yet of sitting down (see 195).

h)= e(sqw=; "am I to sit down?" deliberative aor. subj. of e(/zomai. This aor. of the simple verb occurs nowhere else: but e)kaqe/sqhn is used in later Greek (as kaqesqe/nta Paus. 3.22.1). Since e( is the radical vowel, it seems better to suppose a synizesis (h)= e(sqw=;) than an aphaeresis (h)= )sqw=;): the h)=, though not necessary, is prob. genuine. I have left this questionable e(sqw= in the text, on the strength of e)kaqe/sqhn: but the v.l. h)= stw= ("am I to halt?"), preferred by the schol. in L, seems more defensible than it has been thought by recent edd. The answer of the Chorus, no doubt, refers to sitting down. So, however, it could do after h)= stw=; He has already been told to go no further (191 f.): but, in his anxiety to avoid further offence, it is conceivable that he should repeat his question in the clearest form. (Cp. Eur. Hec. 1079 pa= bw=, pa= stw=, pa= ka/myw...;)

le/xrio/s g' … o)kla/sas, "yes, moving sideways," — the rocky seat being near his side — "(sit down), crouching low on the top of the rock." o)-kla/zw (cp. o)-da/c, from √dak), from kla/-w, to bend the hams in crouching down; Xen. Anab. 6.1.10 to\ *persiko\n w)rxei=to,...kai\ w)/klaze kai\ e)cani/stato, "he danced the Persian dance, sinking down and rising again by turns" (there was a dance called o)/klasma): so o)kladi/as=a folding campstool.
braxu\s, "low," (as me/gas="tall,") because the seat is near the ground.
a)/krou, on the outer edge of the rocky platform (bh=ma 192).

la=os, gen. of la=as, as Od. 8.192 la=os u(po\ r(iph=s. No part of la=as occurs in trag., except here and Eur. Phoen. 1157 acc. la=an. The MSS. have la/ou, and the schol. in L quotes Herodian (160 A.D.), e)n tw=| e_ th=s kaqo/lou (=bk 5 of his lost work h( kaqo/lou prosw|di/a), as taking it from a nom. la/os: but Herodian had perhaps no warrant besides this passage, and no other trace of such a form occurs.

e)mo\n to/d): i.e. the office of placing him in his seat (cp. 21ka/qize/... me). Hermann changes the e)n h(suxi/a| of the MSS. to e)n a(suxai/a|, joining it with ba/sei. The corresponding strophic verse is lost (see on 181): but the metre confirms the emendation (see Metrical Analysis). The words e)n h(suxai/a| … e)ma/n are said as she helps him to sit down. He has to make one step sideways (195) to the seat. Taking his arm, she says: "Lean on me, and join step to quiet step" (a(/rmosai aor. imper. midd.): i.e. "advance one foot to the resting-place, bring the other up beside it, and then (supported by my arm) sit down." Cp. Eur. Or. 233 h)= ka)pi\ gai/as a(rmo/sai po/das qe/leis; "wouldest thou set thy feet together (plant thy feet) on the ground?" Pseudo-Simonides 182
o(/pa| podo\s i)/xnia pra=ton
a(rmo/samen, where we first planted our feet (on the battlefield,—there we fell). Campbell takes ba/sin as the foot of Oed., and ba/sei as a "stone support for the foot attached to the seat," rendering, "fit thy foot into its quiet resting place." This seems improbable. "Time thy step to my quiet step" is unsuitable, since they are close to the seat already. The interjection i)w/ moi/ moi, given by the MSS. to Antigone, but by Herm. (rightly) to Oed., need not, with Herm., be placed after a(/rmosai.
du/sfronos, as the work of a mind clouded by the gods: Ant. 1261 i)w\ frenw=n dusfro/nwn a(marth/mata. The gen. after the exclamation w)/moi: cp. on 149.
tla/mwn, see on 185.
xala=|s, hast ease (alluding to his words betokening pain and exhaustion): not, ei)/keis kai\ ou)k a)ntitei/neis tw=| e)celqei=n (from the grove), as the schol.
ti/s o( pol.: cp. on 68.

ti/n' a)\n … patri/d'. For the twofold question, cp. Ph. 220 

ti/nes pot' e)s gh=n th/nde kate/sxet'; …

poi/as pa/tras a)\n h)\ ge/nous u(ma=s pote

tu/xoim' a)\n ei)pw/n; Eur. Helen 86 a)ta\r ti/s ei)=; po/qen; ti/n' e)cauda=n se xrh/; (Dind. ti/nos s' au)da=n xre/wn;) Od. 1.170  (and in five other places) ti/s po/qen ei)=s a)ndrw=n; po/qi toi po/lis h)de\ tokh=es;

Oed. replies to their second question by a)po/ptolis, which is almost an exclamation; — "I have no patri/s now": he deprecates their first question (ti/s a)/gei;) altogether. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 1410 (the Argive elders to Clytaemnestra) a)po/polis d' e)/sei, | mi=sos o)/brimon a)stoi=s. Soph. has a)po/ptolis in O. T. 1000 (dialogue) and Tr. 647 (lyr.). Cp. 1357.

mh/, mh/ m' a)ne/rh|. As the verses from 207 onwards are a)nomoio/strofa (see on 117), the strophic test is absent, but mh/, mh/ m) is metrically preferable to mh\ mh\ mh/ m) here (see Metr. Analysis). And, after the preceding a)lla\ mh/, a threefold iteration would rather weaken than strengthen.
Wunder's correction of the MS. deina\ to ai)na\ is required by the Ionic measure (uu | - uu): see Metr. Analysis.
fu/sis=origin, birth: 270: Tr. 379 (Iolè) lampra\ … fu/sin, | patro\s me\n ou)=sa ge/nesin *eu)ru/tou, k.t.l.

gegw/nw, delib. perf. subjunct. from ge/gwna: whence, too, the imper. ge/gwne, Ph. 238. Both these could, indeed, be referred to a pres. gegw/nw, which is implied by other forms, as e)ge/gwne (Il. 14.469): cp. Monro Hom. Gr. § 27. Poetry recognised, in fact, three forms,—a perf. ge/gwna, a pres. gegw/nw, and a pres. gegwne/w (gegwnei=n, Il. 12.337). Cp. a)/nwga with impf. h)/nwgon.

ti/nos ei)= spe/rmatos; possessive gen., denoting the stock, country, etc., to which one belongs: cp. on 144: Plat. Symp. 203A patro\s ti/nos e)sti\ kai\ mhtro/s; Meno 94 D oi)ki/as mega/lhs h)=n: Dem. or. 57 § 57 o(/soi tw=n mega/lwn dh/mwn e)ste/.

patro/qen with ei)=: the Chorus, whose uneasy curiosity is now thoroughly roused, presses for an explicit answer, and first (as usual) for the father's name. Plat. Legg. 753C ei)s pina/kion gra/yanta tou)/noma patro/qen kai\ fulh=s kai\ dh/mou. Ai. 547 e)mo\s ta\ patro/qen.
ti/ pa/qw … ; "what is to become of me?" Tr. 973 (Hyllus, in his wild grief for his father) ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ mh/somai; oi)/moi.

e)p' e)/sxata bai/neis, "thou art coming to the verge" (not, "thou treadest on the verge," which would require gen. or dat.), since, after the hint ai)na\ fu/sis (212), the full truth cannot long be withheld. Cp. fr. 658 (Orithyia was carried) e)p' e)/sxata xqono/s: Ant. 853 proba=s' e)p' e)/sxaton qra/sous: Her. 8.52 e)s to\ e)/sxaton kakou= a)pigme/noi.

Hermann's me/lleton (for the MS. me/llet)) is fitting, since Oed. and Ant. have just been speaking together; and is clearly better than me/llete/ g) (Triclinius) or me/llomen (suggested by Elms.). The sing. ta/xune rightly follows, since it is from Oed. alone that a reply is sought.
makra\, neut. plur. as adv.: O. T. 883 u(pe/ropta (n.): Aristoph. Lys. 550 ou)/ria qei=te: Eur. Or. 152 xro/nia...pesw\n...eu)na/zetai.

*lai+/ou i)/ste tin'; The word a)po/gonon, seemingly a gloss, which follows tin' in the MSS., is against the metre, which requires -uuu- after tin': it also injures the dramatic force. Each word is wrung from Oed.; the gen. *lai+/ou tells all. The long syll. after tin' could be,—(1) w)/, which Herm. supplies,—giving it, however, to the Chorus,—whereas the rhythm will be better if it is an interjection by Oed.: (2) o)/nt); (Dindorf): or (3) ou)=n; (Elmsley). The two latter are somewhat tame.
The family patronymic was taken from Labdacus (the father of Laïus), though the line was traced directly up to Cadmus, father of Polydorus and grandfather of Labdacus (O. T. 267; Her. 5.59).

The relat. clause o(/s' au)dw= is most simply taken as representing an accus., governed by de/os i)/sxete mhde\n as=mh\ deimai/nete (rather than a genitive depending on de/os): Tr. 996 oi(/an m' a)/r' e)/qou lw/ban: Dem. De Fals. Legat. § 81 o(/ ge dh=mos o( tw=n *fwke/wn ou(/tw kakw=s...dia/keitai, w(/ste...teqna/nai tw=| fo/bw|...tou\s *fili/ppou ce/nous: Aesch. Theb. 289
me/rimnai zwpurou=si ta/rbos (=poiou=si/ me tarbei=n)
to\n a)mfiteixh= lew/n: Eur. Ion 572 tou=to ka)/m' e)/xei po/qos. Cp. below, 583, 1120. In such instances the acc. might also, however, be taken as one of "respect."

The MSS. give the one word dusmoros to Oed., as uttered by him between the exclamations of the Chorus. It thus marks his despair at their refusal to hear him. There is dramatic force in the sentence of expulsion (226) being the first articulate utterance of the Chorus after the disclosure which has appalled them.

poi= kataqh/seis; fig. from the payment of a debt in money. If you will not pay it here and now, to what place will you bring the payment for it? i.e. when, and in what form, can your promise of a safe refuge (176 f.) be redeemed, if I am driven from Colonus? poi= with a verb pregnantly used, as 476 to\ d' e)/nqen poi= teleuth=sai/ me xrh/; to what end am I to bring it? Cp. 383. For kataqh/seis cp. Dem. In Mid. § 99 ou) ga/r e)stin o)/flhma o(/ ti xrh\ kataqe/nta e)pi/timon gene/sqai toutoni/, there is no debt (to the Treasury), by paying which he can recover the franchise. Pind. Nem. 7.75 nikw=nti/ ge xa/rin … ou) traxu/s ei)mi kataqe/men.

ou)deni\ moiridi/a ti/sis e)/rxetai, to no one comes punishment from fate, w(=n (=tou/twn a(\) propa/qh|, for things (caus. gen.) which he has already suffered, to\ ti/nein (acc.), in respect of his requiting them. suggnwsto/n e)stin e)a\n ti/nh| tis a(\ a)\n propa/qh|. <"Thou didst deceive us by getting our promise before telling thy name; we may requite thy deceit by deeming our promise void." ti/nein (with to\ added, see on 47) further explains the causal gen. w(=n: "no one is punished for deeds which have first been done to him—that is, for repaying them to the aggressor." Cp. 1203 pa/sxein, paqo/nta d' ou)k e)pi/stasqai ti/nein: Eur. Or. 109 ti/noi...trofa/s, repay care.
w(=n for w(=n a)/n, as 395, O. T. 1231 (n.).

With Wunder's a(\n some construe:— ou)deni\ to\ ti/nein a(\ a)\n propa/qh| e)/rxetai moiridi/a ti/sis, "for no one retaliation becomes (=gi/gnetai) a fate-doomed punishment": but could the ti/sis itself thus stand for the cause of the ti/sis? The w(=n of the MSS. is confirmed by other passages where, instead of an acc. governed by the infin., we have a gen. depending on another word, and then the infin. added epexegetically: El. 542 i(/meron te/knwn … e)/sxe dai/sasqai: Plat. Crito 52B ou)d' e)piqumi/a se a)/llhs po/lews ou)d' a)/llwn no/mwn e)/laben ei)de/nai: Rep. 443 B a)rxo/menoi th=s po/lews oi)ki/zein.

a)pa/ta d): guile on the one part (e(te/ra), matching itself against deeds of guile on the other (e(te/rais), makes a recompense of woe, not of grace (as in return for good deeds): e)/xein, epexeg. "(for the deceiver) to enjoy" (cp. Il. 1.347 dw=ke d' a)/gein).
a)pa/ta e(te/ra, not another kind of guile, but another instance of it, as Ph. 138 te/xna (a king's skill) te/xnas e(te/ras prou)/xei, excels skill in another man.

paraball., as Eur. I. T. 1094 e)gw/ soi paraba/llomai qrh/nous, vie with thee in dirges: Andr. 290 paraballo/menai, abs., "in rivalry." For the sentiment cp. Plat. Crito 49B ou)de\ (dei=) a)dikou/menon a)/ra a)ntadikei=n, w(s oi( polloi\ oi)/ontai: Archil. fr. 67
e(\n d' e)pi/stamai me/ga,
to\n kakw=s me drw=nta deinoi=s a)ntamei/besqai kakoi=s. Pind. Pyth. 2.83
fi/lon ei)/h filei=n:
poti\ d' e)xqro\n a(/t' e)xqro\s e)w\n lu/koio di/kan u(poqeu/somai,
a)/ll' a)/llote pate/wn o(doi=s skoliai=s.

e(dra/nwn with e)/ktopos (cp. on 119), xqono\s with a)/formos, which adds force to e)/kqore; cp. O. T. 430
ou)k ei)s o)/leqron; ou)xi\ qa=sson; ou) pa/lin
a)/yorros oi)/kwn tw=nd' a)postrafei\s a)/pei; Eur. Hipp. 155 hasnauba/tas tis e)/pleusen | *krh/tas e)/cormos, "from an anchorage in Crete," cp. e)cormei=n to be (or go) out of port: but a)/formos belongs to a)forma=n (there is no a)formei=n), "rushing from" (a)formhqei/s, schol.).
xre/os … prosa/yh|s (like ku=dos, tima/s, ai)ti/an prosa/ptein), fix a debt or obligation on the city, i.e. make it liable to expiate a pollution. But xre/os = simply "matter" in O. T. 155, n.

ai)do/frones: as ye have ai)dw/s for the Eumenides, so have ai)dw/s for the suppliant. Cp. Dem. or. 37 § 59 a)\n e(lw/n tis a)kousi/ou fo/nou...meta\ tau=t' ai)de/shtai kai\ a)fh=| (with ref. to the kinsman of a slain man pardoning the involuntary slayer).
a)ll', "Nay," opening the appeal: cp. O. T. 14. The second a)ll' in 241 = "at least."

This whole me/los a)po\ skhnh=s of Antigone (237 — 253), with the tetrastichon of the Chorus (254 — 257), was rejected by some of the ancient critics, acc. to the schol. on L: "for they say it is better that Oed. should forthwith address his justification to them." But, as the schol. rightly adds, it is natural and graceful that an appeal to pity (e)leeinologi/a),— which the daughter makes,—should precede the father's appeal to reason (to\ dikaiologiko/n). The schol. further remarks that Didymus (circ. 30 B.C.) had not obelized any part of the passage. This is important, as making it most improbable that the a)qe/thsis rested on the absence of these verses from the older Alexandrian copies. Though the text is doubtful in some points, the internal evidence cannot be said to afford any good ground for suspicion.

gerao
 … e)mo
: the text of this verse is doubtful, and there is no strophic test, but it seems most likely that a)lao
 was an interpolation: see crit. n.
a)ko/ntwn, epithet of the agent, instead of that proper to the act (a)kousi/wn): 977: O. T. 1229 kaka\ e(ko/nta kou)k a)/konta. Cp. 74, 267.

a)i+/ontes au)da/n, "perceiving," i.e. "being aware of,""having heard," the report of his involuntary deeds. Cp. 792 klu/w: Thuc. 6.20 w(s e)gw\ a)koh=| ai)sqa/nomai.—Not: (1) "on hearing (from him) the mention of his deeds" — as implied in his name: nor (2) "on hearing his first utterance," as if a)ko/nt.
e)/rgwn could be caus. gen. with ou)k a)ne/tlate.
a)ll', "at least," cp. 1276: fr. 24 ka)\n a)/llo mhde/n, a)lla\ tou)kei/nhs ka/ra.

Hermann's tou)mou= mo/nou (for the MS. tou= mo/nou) is metrically right, but mo/nou can hardly be sound. It must mean (1) "for my father alone" (and not for my own sake): not (2) "lonely, as he is": nor (3) "for my own father" (Campbell's view, which I do not comprehend). *t*o*u*m*o*n*o*u may have come from *t*o*u*d*a*q*l*i*o*u (Mekler), but to\n a)/qlion in 246 is against this (see, however, on 554). Perhaps tou=d' a)mmo/rou.
ou)k a)laoi=s, as his are.
prosorwme/na: for the midd. cp. El. 1059 e)sorw/menoi. The midd. of the simple o(ra/w is poet. only (Ant. 594): but the midd. of proora/w and periora/w occurs in Attic prose.

w(/s tis k.t.l.: as if I were a young kinswoman of your own, appealing to you, the eldest of my house, for protection. The words are hardly so strong as "like daughter to father"; and though so\n is addressed to the coryphaeus (cp. on 175), this sense would be less fitting. So Creon imagines his niece Antigone appealing to the sacred ties of kinship (Ant. 487 *zhno\s e(rkei/ou; 658 e)fumnei/tw *di/a | cu/naimon).

e)n u)/mmi kei/meqa, "we are situated" (not, "prostrate") "in your power": e)n u)/mmi, penes vos, cp. 392, 422, 1443, O. T. 314 (n.), Dem. De Cor. § 193 e)n ga\r tw=| qew=| tou=to to\ te/los h)=n, ou)k e)n e)moi/. The epic forms u)/mmes (nom.), u)/mmi (dat.), u)/mme (acc.), freq. in Hom., belonged esp. to the Lesbian Aeolic: the acc. occurs in Aesch. Eum. 620 boulh=| pifau/skw d' u)/mm' e)pispe/sqai patro/s: Soph. Ant. 846 cumma/rturas u)/mm' e)piktw=mai. e)n u(mi=n ga\r (MSS.) is unmetrical: and if ga\r is omitted, u(mi=n still mars the metre, which requires a dactyl.

kei/meqa, of a critical situation, as Tr. 82
e)n ou)=n r(oph=| toia=|de keime/nw|, te/knon,
ou)k ei)= cune/rcwn; (when his fate is thus trembling in the balance). Cp. 1510.
neu/sate with acc. of the boon, as Hom. Hymn. 5.445, Eur. Alc. 978 *zeu\s o(/ ti neu/sh| (more oft. e)pi- or kataneu/ein).

ta\n a)do/khton xa/rin, the unlooked-for grace, i.e. for which, after your stern words (226), we can scarcely dare to hope,—but which, for that very reason, will be the more gracious. Eur. Med. 1417
kai\ ta\ dokhqe/nt' ou)k e)tele/sqh,
tw=n d' a)dokh/twn po/ron eu(=re qeo/s.

pro/s s): in supplications the poets often insert the enclitic se between pro/s and the gen. of that by which one adjures: 1333: Tr. 436 mh/, pro/s se tou= kat' a)/kron k.t.l.: Ph. 468
pro/s nu/n se patro/s, pro/s te mhtro/s, w)= te/knon,
pro/s t' ei)/ ti/ soi kat' oi)=ko/n e)sti prosfile/s,
i(ke/ths i(knou=mai. e)k se/qen could go with a)/ntomai only if pro/s s) were pro/s t) or pro\s d) and even then would be harsh. Join, then, o(/ ti soi fi/lon e)k se/qen, "whatever, sprung from thyself, is dear to thee"; the next words repeat this thought, and add to it: "yea, by child—or wife, or possession, or god." Cp. 530 e)c e)mou=. e)k se/qen could not mean simply, "on thy part," as = "in thy home." Against Elmsley's tempting oi)/koqen (cp. Eur. Med. 506 toi=s oi)/koqen fi/lois) it may be remarked that the alliteration pro/s s' … soi — e)k se/qen seems intentional (cp. O. T. 370 n.).

h)\ xre/os h)\ qeo/s: a designed assonance (paromoi/wsis): cp. Isocr. or. 5 § 134 kai\ th\n fh/mhn kai\ th\n mnh/mhn: or. 4 § 45 a)gw=nas...mh\ mo/non ta/xous: kai\ r(w/mhs a)lla\ kai\ lo/gou kai\ gnw/mhs. xre/os here=xrh=ma, "thing," any cherished possession (cp. Il. 23.618 kai/ soi tou=to, ge/ron, keimh/lion e)/stw), rather than "business," "office."
a)qrw=n, if thou look closely. Plat. Rep. 577C th\n o(moio/thta a)namimnhsko/menos th=s te po/lews kai\ tou= a)ndro\s ou(/tw kaq' e(/kaston e)n me/rei a)qrw=n ta\ paqh/mata e(kate/rou le/ge.

a)/goi, i.e. draw on to evil: Ant. 623 o(/tw| fre/nas | qeo\s a)/gei pro\s a)/tan. Oedipus was led on to his unwitting deeds by a god. Cp. fr. 615
ou)d' a)\n ei(=s fu/goi
brotw=n poq', w(=| kai\ *zeu\s e)formh/sh| kaka/: so, too, El. 696. For the hiatus after a)/goi, cp. O. T. 1202 f. kalei= | e)mo/s.

div3.head: 254-667: First episode
div3.p: First e)peiso/dion. Oedipus appeals to the Chorus, who resolve that Theseus shall decide (295). Ismene arrives from Thebes (324), with news of the war between her two brothers, and presently goes to perform the prescribed rites in the grove of the Eumenides (509). After a kommo/s (510—548) between Oedipus and the Chorus, Theseus enters, and assures Oedipus of protection.

ta\ d' e)k qew=n, euphemistic: cp. Aesch. Pers. 373 ou) ga\r to\ me/llon e)k qew=n h)pi/stato. For e)k cp. also Ph. 1316 ta\s … e)k qew=n | tu/xas: Eur. Phoen. 1763 ta\s e)k qew=n a)na/gkas. Similarly I. A. 1610 ta\ tw=n qew=n (=their dispensations).
For tw=n as 1st syll. of 3rd foot cp. Ant. 95 a)ll' e)/a me kai\ th\n e)c e)mou= dusbouli/an.

r(eou/shs, when it flows away, perishes, ma/thn, "vainly," without result: i.e. issues in no corresponding deeds. Tr. 698 r(ei=pa=n a)/dhlon: El. 1000 (our fortune) a)porrei= ka\pi\ mhde\n e)/rxetai: Ai. 1267 xa/ris diarrei=. Cp. Lat. futilis, fluere (Cic. Fin. 2. 32. 106 fluit voluptas corporis et prima quaeque avolat). For ma/thn cp. Aesch. Ch. 845
lo/goi
... qnh/skontes ma/thn. (Not, "when the fame is current without good ground.")

ei) with ind. fasi/ (siquidem dicunt) introduces the actual case which has suggested the general question, ti/ dh=ta k.t.l.: cp. El. 823
pou= pote keraunoi\ *dio/s, h)\ pou= fae/qwn
*(/alios, ei) tau=t' e)forw=ntes
kru/ptousin e(/khloi; ge oft. follows ei) (and ei)/per) in such cases, but here is better taken with ta/s: it slightly emphasises the name of Athens.

qeosebesta/tas. Athens is pre-eminently (1) religious, (2) compassionate towards the oppressed. Paus. 1.17.1 *)aqhnai/ois de\ e)n th=| a)gora=| kai\ a)/lla e)sti\n ou)k e)s a/pantas e)pi/shma kai\ *)ele/ou bwmo/s, w(=| ma/lista qew=n e)s a)nqrw/pinon bi/on kai\ metabola\s pragma/twn o(/ti w)fe/limos, mo/noi tima\s *(ellh/nwn ne/mousin *)aqhnai=oi. tou/tois de\ ou) ta\ e)s filanqrwpi/an mo/non kaqe/sthken, a)lla\ kai\ e)s qeou\s eu)sebou=sin a)/llwn ple/on: kai\ *ai)dou=s sfi/si bwmo/s e)sti kai\ *fh/mhs kai\ *(ormh=s.
mo/nas, not strictly "alone," but "more than all others": cp. O. T. 299 n.

to\n kakou/menon ce/non. The two standard instances were subsequent, in mythical date, to the time of Oedipus. (1) Theseus, at the prayer of Adrastus king of Argos, compels Creon and his Thebans to permit the burial of the Argive warriors who had fallen in the war of Eteocles and Polynices. This is the subject of the Supplices of Eur., which continues the story of the Antigone and the Phoenissae. (2) Demophon, the son of Theseus, protects the children of Hercules against the Argive Eurystheus. This is the subject of the Heracleidae of Eur.

These two examples are cited in Her. 9.27; in the spurious e)pita/fios ascribed to Lysias (or. 2 §§ 4-16); and in that ascribed to Demosthenes (or. 60 §§ 7, 8). Isocrates quotes them in the Panegyricus, as showing how the Athenians diete/lesan th\n po/lin koinh\n pare/xontes kai\ toi=s a)dikoume/nois a)ei\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn e)pamu/nousan (§ 52); also in his Encomium Helenae § 31; and again in his Panathenaicus, where he remarks that Tragedy has made them familiar to all (§ 168 ti/s ou)k a)kh/koe tw=n tragw|dodidaska/lwn *dionusi/ois;). They figure, too, in the Platonic Menexenus, with the comment that Athens might justly be accused of too great compassion, and too much zeal for "the weaker cause": w(s a)ei\ li/an filoikti/rmwn e)sti\ kai\ tou= h(/ttonos qerapi/s, 244 E. Cp. Her. 8.142 ai)ei\ kai\ to\ pa/lai fai/nesqe pollou\s e)leuqerw/santes a)nqrw/pwn. Andocides or. 3 § 28 tou\s krei/ttous fi/lous a)fie/ntes a)ei\ tou\s h(/ttous ai(rou/meqa.
sw/|zein, to give him a safe refuge: a)rkei=n, to come to his rescue (El. 322 e)sqlo/s, w(/st' a)rkei=n fi/lois), if anyone seeks to take him thence by force.
oi(/as te, sc. ei)=nai, here synonymous with e)/xein. After oi(=o/s te this ellipse of ei)mi/ is frequent.

ka)/moige pou=. The thought of the whole passage is,—ti/ do/ca ma/thn r(e/ousa w)felei=, ei) ta\s *)aqh/nas fasi\ ( me\n ) qeosebesta/tas ei)=nai, e)moi\ de\ tau=ta mhdamou= e)stin; Instead however, of a clause e)moi\ de\...k.t.l., thus depending on ei), a new sentence is opened by the direct question,— kai\ e)/moige pou= tau=ta/ e)stin;

kai/, prefixed to interrogative words (as pou=, pw=s, poi=os, ti/s), makes the query an indignant comment on a preceding statement: El. 236: Dem. De Fals. Legat. § 232 kai\ ti/s, w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi, tou=t' i)dw\n to\ para/deigma di/kaion au(to\n parasxei=n e)qelh/sei;

oi(/tines, causal, as if par' u(mi=n had preceded: hence=e)pei\ u(mei=s. Cp. 427, 866. Thuc. 4.26 a)qumi/an te plei/sthn o( xro/nos parei=xe para\ lo/gon e)pigigno/menos, ou(\s ( o(/ti au)tou\s ) w)/|onto h(merw=n o)li/gwn e)kpoliorkh/sein, since they had thought to reduce them in a few days. 1. 68 nu=n de\ ti/ dei= makrhgorei=n, w(=n ( = e)pei\ h(mw=n ) tou\s me
 dedoulwme/nous o(ra=te...; 6. 68 pollh=| me
 paraine/sei...ti/ dei= xrh=sqai, oi(\ pa/resmen e)pi\ to
 au)to
 a)gw=na; 8. 76 § 6 (oi(/ ge). Aristoph. Nub. 1225
i(/ppon; ou)k a)kou/ete
o(
 ( = o(/ti e)me\ ) pa/ntes u(mei=s i)/ste misou=nq' i(ppikh/n. Ai. 457 ti/ xrh\ dra=n; o(/stis e)mfanw=s qeoi=s | e)xqai/romai. Cp. O. T. 1228 n.: Ph. 1364.

As 276 shows, e)ca/rantes refers to his first seat, in the grove. They had induced him to leave that seat (174 ff.), on a pledge that no one should remove him from the resting-place outside of the grove. Yet now they command him to quit Attica (e)lau/nete: 226 e)/cw...bai/nete xw/ras).
ta/de ba/qra denote, generally, the seats afforded by the natural rock in or near the grove: here he is thinking specially of the ba/qron a)ske/parnon (101) within its precincts.

ou) ga\r dh\ to/ ge: see on 110. For the art. to/, followed only by ge at the end of the v., with its noun sw=ma in the next v., cp. Ant. 67 to\ ga\r | … pra/ssein, ib. 78 to\ de\ | … dra=n: Tr. 92, 742.

e)pei\ … e)/coida. I am "a man more sinned against than sinning" (Lear 3. 2. 60),—as would appear, could I unfold to you my relations with my parents (ta\ mhtro\s kai\ patro/s), on account of which relations (the parricide and the incest— w(=n neuter) ye dread me. Of that I am sure. (For those relations began with their casting out their new-born son to perish. That first wrong led to the rest: hence it was that I knew not the face of my assailant in the pass, or of my bride at Thebes.)

peponqo/t' … dedrako/ta. The agent's activities (ta\ e)/rga mou) here stand for the agent himself; and so, instead of toi=s e)/rgois peponqw/s ei)mi (cp. 873), we have ta\ e)/rga mou peponqo/t' e)sti/. (Cp. 74, 1604.) O. T. 1214 ga/mos: teknw=n kai\ teknou/menos = one in which the son has become the spouse. So a particular activity of a person's mind is sometimes expressed by the active participle (neut.) of a verb to which the person himself would properly be subject: to\ boulo/menon, to\ o)rgizo/menon th=s gnw/mhs (Thuc. 1.90, 2. 59): to\ dedio/s, to\ qarsou=n au)tou= (1. 36).

"Ye shrink from me as from a guilty man. And yet (kai/toi),— evil as were my acts (in themselves),— how have I shown an evil disposition (fu/sin), or incurred moral guilt? Before I struck my father, he had struck me (paqw\n a)nte/drwn: see O. T. 809). Even if I had been aware (fronw=n) who he was, I might plead this in my defence: but, in fact, I did not know. Nor did I recognise my mother. They, on the other hand, had deliberately tried to kill their babe." — Note that the clause w(/st' ei) fronw=n … kako/s, which could not apply to the incest, limits the reference of a)nte/drwn to the parricide; while i(ko/mhn (273) refers to both stains.

He has two distinct pleas, (1) provocation, and (2) ignorance. These could have been expressed by a)nte/drwn (1) paqw
 me/n, (2) ei)dw\s d' ou)de/n. But (2) is forestalled by the thought that, if he had known, (1) would have excused him. This hypothesis is then contrasted with the fact (273); and the fact on his side is next contrasted with the fact on the other (274). Hence paqw
 me/n has no clause really answering to it; for nu=n d) answers to ei) fronw=n, and u(f' w(=n d) to ou)de
 ei)dw/s. The impf. (a)nte/drwn) expresses the situation ("I was retaliating"): the aor. (273), an act accomplished at a definite moment.
i(ko/mhn i(/n' i(ko/mhn: cp. 336, 974; O. T. 1376 (n.) blastou=s' o(/pws e)/blaste.
u(f' w(=n d' e)/pasxon (u(po\ tou/twn) ei)do/twn (predicate) a)pwllu/mhn, impf. of attempted act, cp. O. T. 1454 oi(/ m' a)pwllu/thn.
e)/pasxon: when the iron pin was driven through the babe's feet and he was exposed on Cithaeron, O. T. 718.

w(/sper me ka)nesth/s.: as ye caused me to leave my seat in the grove, so give me the safety which ye then promised: see on 264: for kai/, on 53. For a)nista/nai, of causing i(ke/tai to leave sanctuary, cp. Thuc. 1.126 (Cylon and his adherents) kaqi/zousin e)pi\ to
 bwmo
 i(ke/tai to
 e)n th=| a)kropo/lei. a)nasth/santes de\ au)tou\s oi( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn e)pitetramme/noi,... e)f' w(=| mhde
 kako
 poih/sousin, a)pagago/ntes a)pe/kteinan.
qeou\s … tou\s qeou\s: the art. with the repeated word, as 5, Ph. 992 qeou\s protei/nwn tou\s qeou\s yeudei=s ti/qhs.

moi/rais poei=sqe could not stand for e)n moi/rais poiei=sqe. The prep. e)n is indispensable. See the discussion of this passage in the Appendix. The gentlest remedy would be moi/ras (as gen. sing.), which two MSS. have. As e)n ou)deni\ lo/gw| poiei=sqai (Her. 3.50) and e)n ou)demia=| moi/ra| a)/gein (2. 172) are parallel phrases, so ou)deno\s lo/gou poiei=sqai (1. 33) might suggest ou)demia=s moi/ras poiei=sqai. For the two negatives cp. El. 336 kai\ mh\ dokei=n me\n dra=n ti phmai/nein de\ mh/, "and not to seem active yet do no harm." It is hollow, Oed. says, to insist so strictly on the sanctity of a grove (qeou\s timw=ntes), and then to refuse the gods their moi=ra, their due tribute of practical piety. You treat the gods as if they were not, when at their shrines you do a)no/sia e)/rga (283) by violating your pledge to a suppliant.

poei=sqe. Numerous Attic inscriptions of the 5th and 4th cent. B.C. show that in this verb i was regularly omitted before ei or h (poei=, poh/sei), though never before ou, oi, or w (e)poi/oun, poioi/h, poiw=n: Meisterhans, p. 27). L generally, but not always, omits the i before ei or h if the syll. is short. Forms from poiw=, with the 1st syll. short, occur below in 459, 584, 652, 1018, 1033, 1037, 1144. In 584 and 652, as here, L keeps the i: in the other five places it omits it. In 1517, where the quantity is different, L has poei=n.

The place of tou before fwto/s (cp. Ai. 29 kai/ moi/ tis o)pth/r, Ph. 519 mh\ nu=n me/n tis eu)xerh\s parh=|s) would be less awkward if fugh\n and mh/pw changed places: but the latter is reserved for the emphatic place at the beginning of the verse.

mh/pw, not ou)/pw, because of the imperat. h(gei=sqe (278). After verbs of thinking, the negative with the inf. is ordinarily ou) (Plat. Prot. 317A h(gou=mai ga au)tou\s ou)/ ti diapra/casqai): though mh/ is used in asseveration (as with o)/mnumi), and sometimes in strong expressions of personal conviction: O. T. 1455 oi)=da mh/te m' a)
 no/son | mh/t' a)/llo pe/rsai mhde/n, where see n. Thuc. 6.102 ad fin. nomi/santes mh\ a)
...i(kanoi\ gene/sqai (and id. 4. 18): Xen. Cyr. 7.5.59 e)no/mise de\ mh\ a)
 gene/sqai pote\ pisto/n.

fwto\s … brotw=n, no wight among mortals, no one in the world. In Ai. 1358 toioi/de me/ntoi fw=tes e)/mplhktoi brotw=n, though brotoi=s is a specious variant, brotw=n has the better authority: cp. Od. 17.587
ou) ga/r pou/ tines w(=de kataqnhtw=n a)nqrw/pwn
a)ne/res u(bri/zontes: 23. 187 a)ndrw=n d' ou)/ ke/n tis zwo\s broto/s.
cu\n oi(=s, su\n toi=s qeoi=s (schol.), "with whose help," since the gods strengthen men to refrain from evil, as well as to do good.

mh\ ka/lupte, as with a veil (ka/lumma) of dishonour cast over her bright fame: cp. Il. 17.591 to\n d' a(/xeos nefe/lh e)ka/luye me/laina. Thuc. 7.69 a)ciw=n...ta\s patrika\s a)reta/s, w)=n e)pifanei=s h)=san oi( pro/gonoi, mh\ a)fani/zein. Plut. Cor. 31 h)maurwme/nos th=| do/ch|.
ta\s eu)dai/monas: Her. 8.111 le/gontes w(s kata\ lo/gon h)=san a)/ra ai( *)aqh=nai mega/lai te kai\ eu)dai/mones.
e)/labes, since Oed. put himself into their hands when he left sanctuary (174 f.).
to\n i(ke/thn, cp. 44, 487.

e)xe/gguon, having received your e)ggu/h, pledge, that I should not be wronged (176). Elsewhere e)xe/gg. = "having a good e)ggu/h to give," trustworthy (like fere/gguos); Eur. Med. 388 gh=n a)/sulon kai\ do/mous e)xeggu/ous (=pu/rgos a)sfalh/s ib. 389). But Oed. could call himself e)xe/gguos in this sense only as coming with credentials from Apollo; and that is not the point here. Cp. Her. 5.71 a)nista=si ( tou\s i(ke/tas ) … oi( pruta/nies, … u(peggu/ous plh\n qana/tou, under a pledge that they should stand their trial, but not suffer death.
e)kfu/lasse, till I am out of peril: only here, and twice in Eur. as = "to watch well" (Or. 1259, Ion 741).
duspro/sopton, since the sightless orbs bore traces of his dreadful act (O. T. 1268): cp. 577. Continue me with a)tima/sh|s.
i(ero/s, as now formally the i(ke/ths of the Eumenides (44)
eu)sebh/s, since he has come thither kat' o)mfa\s ta\s *)apo/llwnos (102).
fe/rwn | o)/nhsin: the first hint, to the Chorus, of the ke/rdh mentioned in the prayer which only his daughter witnessed (92). Cp. 72.

o( ku/rios … tis: the master— whoever he be. O. T. 107 tou\s au)toe/ntas ...timwrei=n tinas the murderers—whoever they be. Plat. Legg. 716A o( me\n eu)daimonh/sein me/llwn...o( de/ tis e)carqei/s k.t.l. The art. implies that the person exists; the indef. pron., that his name is unknown.
ta\ de\ metacu\ tou/tou, in the space between (the present time) and that event (sc. tou= parei=nai au)to/n)

ta\ as in ta\ nu=n, to\ au)ti/ka, to\ e)k tou=de, etc. Dem. De Cor. § 26 to\n metacu\ xro/non...tw=n o(/rkwn, the interval between (that time, and) the oaths: Aristoph. Av. 187 e)n me/sw|...a)h/r e)sti gh=s, between (heaven and) earth: Ach. 433
a)/nwqen tw=n *questei/wn r(akw=n,
metacu\ tw=n *)inou=s, between (them and) Ino's.
ta)po\ sou=, coming from thee, urged on thy part: Tr. 844 ta\ d' a)p' a)llo/qrou | gnw/mas molo/nt): Ant. 95 th\n e)c e)mou= dusbouli/an.

w)no/mastai, "expressed" (rather than "mentioned"): cp. Dem. De Cor. § 35 ou) ga\r ta\ r(h/mata ta\s oi)keio/thtas e)/fh bebaiou=n, ma/la semnw=s o)noma/zwn (expressing himself in very stately language).
braxe/si, not "short," but "light," "trivial": Thuc. 1.78 bouleu/esqe ou)=n brade/ws w(s ou) peri\ braxe/wn.
a)/naktas, i.e. Theseus: Aesch. Cho. 53 despotw=n qana/toisi (Agamemnon's death). Cp. 146, 814, 970.
dieide/nai, here, diiudicare: usu.=dignoscere; Plat. Phaedr. 262 A th\n o(moio/thta...kai\ a)nomoio/thta a)kribw=s dieide/nai. Cp. O. T. 394 dieipei=n (ai)/nigma), to solve it.
The ce/nos had spoken of Theseus as o( kat' a)/stu basileu/s (67), but had not said where he then was.

patrw=|on a)/stu gh=s, not for patrw/|as gh=s a)/stu, but simply "his father's city in the land" (the gen. gh=s as 45), i.e. the city from which Aegeus (69) had swayed Attica. The poets can use patrw=|os as=pa/trios; but in the mouth of Oed. (O. T. 1450) patrw=|on a)/stu means the city of Laïus, and in that of Ant. (Ant. 937) the city of Oedipus: on the other hand, ta\ pa/tria...dw/mata (O. T. 1394), his "ancestral" home.

e)/xei = "is in," cp. 37. Isocrates conceives the line of hereditary Attic kings as having been unbroken from Erichthonius down to Theseus (Panath. § 126). The greatness of Athens as the centre of government was reputed to date from Theseus; but the royal seat of his predecessors was supposed to have been a lesser Athens (the acropolis and the part south of it. Thuc. 2.15), from which they swayed Attica while its communes were still independent (spora/dhn kai\ kata\ kw/mas oi)kou=san, Isocr. Encom. Helen. § 35).

skopo\s refers to the quality in which the man of Colonus had presented himself to Oed. (35), and so helps him at once to know who is meant. The word can mean "messenger" only in the sense of "one sent to obtain news"; but we need not change it, as Wecklein does, to pompo/s.
ka)me\: see on 53.
e)/pemyen is better here than e)/pempen, which could only mean, "was our summoner."
stelw=n, to make him set forth, to fetch him: O. T. 860 pe/myon tina\ stelou=nta.

Wecklein brackets these nine verses, thinking that they arose from a misunderstanding of 551-554. Theseus divined the name of Oedipus from the description of his person; but these vv. were inserted by one who thought it necessary to explain how Theseus knew the name. I hold the verses to be genuine. The ce/nos must have been sent to Athens by the Chorus before they came to the grove (117), and could not, therefore, know the name of Oedipus (first disclosed at 222). He could only tell Theseus that there was a blind stranger at Colonus, who hinted at his own power to confer benefits (72), and who looked noble (76). Theseus, on entering (551), at once greets Oedipus by name, though he had never seen him before (68). He had divined the identity through a knowledge of the history (553) — i.e. he started from Athens on the strength of what the ce/nos could tell. And on the way to Colonus (adds Theseus) he has been made certain of the fact (554) — i.e. he had heard the name. Now, it was precisely for such certainty that the dramatist meant this passage to provide. He felt that otherwise there might have been too great improbability in the instant confidence of the recognition by Theseus.

Join au)to\n with e)lqei=n, not with e(/cein: cp. O. T. 6
a(gw\ dikaiw=n mh\ par' a)gge/lwn, te/kna,
a)/llwn a)kou/ein au)to\s w(=d' e)lh/luqa.
kai\ ka/rq': cp. 65.

ke/leuqos: cp. 164. Some wayfarers, passing by Colonus towards Athens, may have heard the prolonged tumult of horror which greeted the name of Oedipus (222). As the distance to the city is more than a mile, there will be many chances for the news to be caught up from their lips, and carried to Theseus.
plana=sqai: cp. Cic. Rep. 1. 17 speremus nostrum nomen volitare et vagari latissime.
tw=n refers to e)/ph. a)i+/w and like verbs can take a gen. either of the person, or (as 1187) of the thing, heard: though the latter is more often in the acc. (as 240).
qa/rsei, pare/stai: the same words (in another context) 726.

polu\, with strong rumour: O. T. 786 u(fei=rpe ga\r polu/. Aeschin. or. 1 § 166 polu\s me\n ga\r o( *fi/lippos e)/stai (we shall hear a great deal of him), a)namixqh/setai de\ kai\ to\ tou= paido\s o)/noma *)aleca/ndrou.
kei) bradu\s eu(/dei, even if he is reposing (from affairs), and is unwilling to move.

eu(/dw, in the fig. sense (O. T. 65), is more often said of things (as eu(/dei po/ntos, etc., cp. 621) than of men: but kaqeu/dw, at least, was often thus used: Plut. Pomp. 15 w(/ra me/ntoi soi mh\ kaqeu/dein a)lla\ prose/xein toi=s pra/gmasin. The conjectures e(/rpei and speu/dei (the latter referring, not happily, to speu=de brade/ws) both suppose that Theseus lingers by the way. But, if he started, he would scarcely loiter.
bradu/s here=indisposed to exertion (as bradu/s is joined with malako/s in Plat. Polit. 307A, and bradu/ths with h(suxio/ths in Charm. 160 B).
klu/wn sou= (gen. of connection), hearing about thee, El. 317 tou= kasignh/tou ti/ fh/s; Ph. 439 a)naci/ou me\n fwto\s e)cerh/somai: Od. 11.174 ei)pe\ de/ moi patro/s te kai\ vi(e/os. Cp. 355.

ti/s ga\r e)sqlo/s. Oedipus has hinted to the Chorus that he brings o)/nhsin a)stoi=s toi=sde, but has reserved all explanation of his meaning until Theseus shall arrive (288). His exclamation here again touches on his secret; but, instead of interpreting eu)tuxh/s, he turns it off, for the present, by a quickly-added commonplace. "Does not experience, indeed, teach us that the benefactor of others is often his own?" The generous man, though he acts from no calculation of self-interest, actually serves himself by making zealous friends. Like thoughts are found in many popular shapes elsewhere: Il. 13.734 (of the man with no/os e)sqlo/s) kai/ te pole/as e)sa/wse, ma/lista/ te/ k' au)to\s a)ne/gnw, "he saveth many, yea, and he himself best recognises (the worth of wisdom)": Menander Sentent. 141 e)sqlw=| ga\r a)ndri/ [ g' ] e)sqla\ kai\ didoi= qeo/s: ib. 391 ce/nois e)parkw=n tw=n i)/swn teu/ch| pote/: Hortat. 23 o( xrhsto/s, w(s e)/oike, kai\ xrhstou\s poiei=: pseudo - Philem. ap. Boissonad. Anecd. 1. 147 mete/rxetai to\ di/kaion ei)s pleoneci/an. Conversely, oi(= au)tw=| kaka\ teu/xei a)nh\r a)/llw| kaka\ teu/xwn (Hes. Opp. 265), li/an filw=n seauto\n ou)d' e(/ceis fi/lon (Men. Sent. 310). We should not suppose a suppressed clause: ("I do not say, to himself,") "for what good man is not a friend to himself?" The interest of the king is identified with that of his realm. To distinguish them so sharply is unfitting here. Cp. 1124, 1496, 1553. The conjecture e)/sq' o(\s (for e)sqlo\s) makes Oed. apologise for the selfishness of e)moi/ te: "for who is not his own friend?" (!)

ti/le/cw, here prob. fut. ind. rather than aor. subj. (though 315 ti/ fw=;): cp. O. T. 1419 oi)/moi, ti/ dh=ta le/comen pro\s to/nd' e)/pos; Ph. 1233 w)= *zeu=, ti/ le/ceis; For fut. ind. combined with aor. subj., cp. Eur. Ion 758 ei)/pwmen h)\ sigw=men h)\ ti/ dra/somen;
poi= frenw=n: see on 170.
ti/ d' e)/sti; (cp. 46) marking surprise, as O. T. 319 (n.), 1144 etc.

*ai)tnai/as … pw/lou, not seen, of course, by the spectators: Ismene leaves it with her servant (334), and enters on foot (320). Sicily having a reputation both for its horses (Oppian Cyneg. 1. 170) and for its mules (Photius 366. 12), some understand a mule here, as that animal (with an easy saddle, a)stra/bh) was much used for such journeys. But though pw=los, with a defining word (as tw=n kamh/lwn Arist. Hist. An. 1.1.47, ku/neoi Anthol. 12. 238) could denote the young of animals other than the horse, pw=los alone would always mean a young horse.

*ai)tnai/as implies some choice breed, as in Theophr. Char. XXI (=VII in my 1st ed.) the mikrofilo/timos buys *lakwnika\s ku/nas, *sikelika\s peristera/s, etc. In Aristoph. Pax 73 the *ai)tnai=os me/gistos ka/nqaros is not a mere joke on the Etna breed of horses, but alludes to a species of beetle actually found there (cp. Aesch. fr. 229, Plato Com. e(ort. fr. 13, quoted by schol. ad loc.).

krati\: locative dat., "on her head," rather than dat. of interest with h(liosterh\s, "for her head." The h(liosterh/s of the MSS. is a very strange word. It ought to mean "deprived of the sun": cp. biosterh/s 747, o)mmatosterh/s 1260. Even with an active sense, "depriving of the sun," it is awkward. It could not mean "sun-averting." In Aesch. Suppl. 1063 *zeu\s...a)posteroi/h ga/mon is not, "may he avert from us," but "may he take away (from our foes)": Hartung would read a)postre/foi moi. (1) h(lioskeph\s (Nauck) is supported by Il. 16.224 xlaina/wn a)nemoskepe/wn, and (2) h(liostegh\s (Coraes) by the use of ste/gw as "to keep out." The latter seems most applicable to rain: cp. Pind. P. 4. 81 a)mfi\ de\ pardale/a| ste/geto fri/ssontas o)/mbrous, Anthol. P. 6. 90 pi=lon...u(dasistegh=: the former, to heat, cold, or wind: cp. Anthol. P. 6. 335, on a kausi/a (a broad-brimmed felt hat, used in Macedonia—from kau=sis), kai\ ske/pas e)n nifetw=|, kai\ ko/rus e)n pole/mw|.

*qessali\s kunh=, a form of the Thessalian pe/tasos, a felt hat (somewhat like our "wide-awake") with brim, worn esp. by travellers: cp. schol. on Aristoph. Av. 1203 (where Iris enters with a kunh=), kunh= de/, o(/ti e)/xei perikefalai/an to\ pe/tason. In the Inachus Soph. made Iris wear an *)arka\s kunh= (fr. 251).
pro/swpa (acc. of respect) … nin: Aristoph. Lys. 542 ou)de\ go/nat' a\n ko/pos e(/loi me.
Elms. cp. Eur. I. T. 577 a)=r' ei)si/n; a)=r' ou)k ei)si/; ti/s fra/seien a)/n;
plana=|, misleads (me): the act. never="to wander." Plat. Prot. 356D au(/th me\n (sc. h( tou= fainome/nou du/namis) h(ma=s e)pla/na. Hor. Carm. 3. 4. 5 an me ludit amabilis Insania?

cit.quote: a)du/naton a(/ma katafa/nai kai\ a)pofa/nai a)lhqw=s.

div3.p: ti/ fw=, the delib. subj. in a dependent clause (ti/ might be o(/ ti): cp. O. T. 71 n.
faidra\, neut. acc. plur. as adverb: cp. 1695: O. T. 883 u(pe/ropta...poreu/etai (n.).

sai/nei me, greets me: cp. Aesch. Agam. 725 (the young lion) faidrwpo\s poti\ xei=ra sai/nwn ("fawning"): Soph. Ant. 1214 paido/s me sai/nei fqo/ggos, "greets mine ear." [Eur.] Rhes. 55 sai/nei m' e)/nnuxos fruktwri/a, the beacon flashes on my sight.

The dh=lon of the MSS. can mean only "manifest to me" (a very weak sense): for it could not bear the emphatic sense, "in living presence" (as opp. to "in my fancy"). Nor, again, can it well be taken as a parenthetic adv., "'tis clear" (like Ai. 906 au)to\s pro\s au(tou=: dh=lon:). The conjecture a)delfo\n (cp. Ant. 1 w)= koino\n au)ta/delfon *)ismh/nhs ka/ra) may be right.

Ismene has come from Thebes, where she has hitherto continued to live, in order to bring her father important tidings. The Thebans will shortly make an attempt to fix his home, not within, but near their borders. A war has already broken out between his sons.

There is no contrast in this play, as in the early part of the Antigone, between the spirit of the sisters. But the contrast between their circumstances indirectly exalts Antigone. She is wandering barefooted, enduring heat and cold (349 f.), — Creon is struck by the suffering shown in her aspect (748), — while Ismene has at least the ordinary comforts of life.

w)= dissa\ patro\s kai\ kasign. k.t.l. = w)= pa/ter kai\ kasignh/th, dissa\ e)moi\ h(/dista prosfwnh/mata, two names most sweet for me to use: cp. Or. 1049
w)= ste/rn' a)delfh=s …
ta/d' a)nti\ pai/dwn kai\ gamhli/ou le/xous
prosfqe/gmat' a)mfi\ toi=s talaipw/rois pa/ra. Suppl. 802
w)= pai=des, w)= pikro\n fi/lwn
proshgo/rhma mate/rwn ("sons," a name bitter for your mothers to utter).
deu/teron, when I have found you.
lu/ph|, caus. dat.: Archilochus fr. 101 (strong emotion) pollh\n kat' a)xlu\n o)mma/twn e)/xeuen.
o(ra=n, epexeg. inf.: so a)/tlhton … o(ra=n, O. T. 792. The form du/smoiros only here.

In the MSS. the verse h)= th=sde ka)mou=; etc. stands immediately after the verse pro/syauson, w)= pai=, etc. Musgrave has been followed by nearly all subsequent editors, in separating these two verses by the insertion between them of the verse w)= spe/rm' o(/maimon etc. This transposition is plainly necessary: else Ismene will say that she touches not only her father and sister, but herself. Campbell defends qigga/nw … dusmo/rou … e)mou= tri/ths as meaning, "I too am linked in this unhappy circle": adding that "the construction of a reply, in this sort of dialogue, is not to be pressed too closely." The source of the confusion in the MSS. was obviously that the gen. h)= th=sde ka)mou= etc. could depend, in grammar, either on qigga/nw or on trofai/, though the sense leaves no choice. Nauck further places v. 327 (w)= te/knon, h(/keis) after v. 329 (pro/syauson). Wecklein places v. 328 (te/knon, pe/fhnas) after v. 329. Neither of these changes is hurtful; but neither appears necessary.

w)= dusa/qliai trofai/, wretched mode of life (338), — referring to the outward signs of suffering and destitution on which Creon dwells, 745 ff.: cp. 1250 ff. By his reply, h)= th=sde ka)mou=; Oed. seems to hint that she separates herself from those whom she pities. Ismene with quick sensibility rejoins, dusmo/rou t' e)mou= tri/ths, the life is to be mine, too, in your company (for tri/ths cp. 8). Dindorf's conjecture, w)= du/) a)qli/w trofa/, makes the subsequent question of Oedipus appear needless.

o(/maimon expresses the sisters' relation to each other only ("my children and my sisters" would be du/sfhmon here). In Soph. o(/maimos, o(mai/mwn always refer to brother or sister: 323, 979, 1275, 1405, 1772: Ant. 486, 512 f.: El. 12, 325, 531: O. T. 639.
sh=| (caus. dat.)=an objective gen. sou=: O. T. 969 tw)mw=| po/qw| (n.).
po/tera, instead of po/teron, to avoid an anapaest: Ai. 265 n.
po/qoisi; (causal:) was it because thou wast fain to see me after so long a time? (or was there some further special cause?) Cp. Ai. 531 fo/boisi/ g' au)to\n e)celusa/mhn.
lo/gwn au)ta/gg. object.gen., au)th\lo/gousa)gge/llousa. Aesch. Ag. 646 pragma/twn eu)a/ggelon. lo/gois would be a dat. of circumstance ("with"), but very harsh.

cu
 w(=|per … mo/nw|=cu
 (tou/tw|) oi)ketw=n o(/nper ei)=xon pisto
 mo/non, the attrac tion of the relative extending to the predicative adj.: Dem. De Cor. § 298 ou)/te fo/bos ou)/t' a)/llo ou)de
 e)ph=ren...w(=n e)/krina dikai/wn kai\ sumfero/ntwn th=| po/lei ou)de
 prodou=nai.

ponei=n, epexeg. infin. with pou= (ei)si): so as to do their part. The infin. was thus used in affirmative clauses (esp. after o(/de), as Il. 9.688 ei)si\ kai\ oi(/de ta/d' ei)pe/men, oi(/ moi e(/ponto, here are these also to tell the tale, who went with me: Eur. Hipp. 294 gunai=kes ai)/de sugkaqista/nai no/son, here are women to help in soothing thy trouble. So on the affirmative oi(/de ei)si\ ponei=n ("here they are to serve") is modelled the interrogative pou= ei)si\ ponei=n; "where are they, that they may serve (as they are bound to do)?" So Eur. Or. 1473 pou= dh=t' a)mu/nein oi( kata\ ste/gas *fru/ges;
pou= (the scholiast's reading) is right. poi= supposes a very harsh ellipse of h(/kousin or the like, and agrees less well with the reply.
ou(=pe/r ei)si: on 273. Schaerer's ta)n is better than the MS. d' e)n because the hint is made more impressive by the abruptness.
tanu=n is adv.

*ai)gu/ptw|. Her. 2.35 ta\ polla\ pa/nta e)/mpalin toi=si a)/lloisi a)nqrw/poisi e)sth/santo h)/qea/ te kai\ no/mous: e)n toi=si ai( me\n gunai=kes a)gora/zousi kai\ kaphleu/ousi, oi( de\ a)/ndres kat oi)/kous e)o/ntes u(fa)i/nousi. Soph. certainly seems to have had this passage of his friend's work in view: else it would be strange that v. 341 should correspond so exactly with the special tasks ascribed to the women by Her. So the reference in El. 62 to the (supposed) dead returning recalls the Thracian Salmoxis in Her. 4.95, and the disputed passage Ant. 905 ff. recalls the wife of Intaphernes in Her. 3.119. Nymphodorus of Syracuse (275 B.C.?), in the 3rd book (read g' for ig' in the schol. here, Müller fr. Hist. 2. 380) of his *no/mima *barbarika/, repeated the statement of Her., adding (prob. of himself) that Sesostris had thus sought to tame the men of Egypt to his sway. Anaxandrides, of the Middle Comedy (circ. 340 B.C.), in his *po/leis, represented the Athenians as rejecting an Egyptian alliance on the ground of the opposition between the manners of Greece and Egypt: — ou)/q' oi( tro/poi ga\r o(monoou=s), ou)/q' oi( no/moi | h(mw=n (Fragm. Com. Bothe p. 426).
fu/sin, 270
trofa/s, 330.

i(stourgou=ntes: Il. 6.490
(Hector to Andromache) a)ll' ei)s oi)=kon i)ou=sa ta\ s' au)th=s e)/rga ko/mize,
i(sto/n t' h)laka/thn te, kai\ a)mfipo/loisi ke/leue
e)/rgon e)poi/xesqai: po/lemos d' a)/ndressi melh/sei.

ta)/cw bi/ou trofei=a, those means of supporting life which are sought outside of the home,—paraphrasing the a)gora/zousi kai\ kaphleu/ousi of Her. 2.35. Elsewhere trofei=a always = "reward for rearing" (Plat. Rep. 520B, etc.).

sfw=|n d), dat. of interest, "for you two" (Ant. and Ism.), in your case. Some take it as partitive gen.: then it would mean, "of you two pairs," — the pair of brothers being one unit, and the pair of sisters another. But I know no parallel for such an use of a dual pronoun. It is different when a)/mfw is said of two "sides" or armies, considered as units (Il. 2.123 ei)/per ga/r k' e)qe/loimen *)axaioi/ te *trw=e/s te | … a)riqmhqh/menai a)/mfw): or when a dual verb has a twofold dual subject, Il. 8.185
*ca/nqe te kai\ su/, *po/darge, kai\ *ai)/qwn *la/mpe te di=e
nu=n moi th\n komidh\n a)poti/neton.
Not noticing Ismene's hint (336), Oedipus imagines his sons in repose at Thebes. He is soon to learn that one of them, an exile, is levying war against the other (374).

oi)kourou=sin, not oi)kourei=ton, though a dual follows (345): O. T. 1511f. ei)xe/thn...eu)/xesqe: Xen. Cyr. 6.1.47 w(s ei)de/thn...h)spa/santo a)llh/lous: Plat. Prot. 330C ei)/peton dh/ moi...o(\ w)noma/sate a)/rti.
w(/ste=w(s, an epic use freq. in Aesch. and Soph.

parqe/noi. [Dem.] In Neaer. (or. 59) § 86 i(kano\n fo/bon tai=s gunaici\ paraskeua/zwn tou= swfronei=n kai\ mhde\n a(marta/nein a)lla\ dikai/ws oi)kourei=n. Eur. Or. 928
ei) ta)/ndon oi)kourh/maq' oi( leleimme/noi
fqei/rousin.

ta)ma\ dusth/nou: Ph. 1126 ta\n e)ma\n mele/ou trofa/n: so nostros vidisti flentis ocellos Ov. Her. 5. 43. ta)ma\ … kaka\: cognate acc. to u(perponei=ton (like ponei=n po/nous), "ye bear the woes of me hapless for me" (dusth/nou, placed between art. and noun, must not be taken with u(perpponei=ton). Cp. Plat. Legg. 717C (a son must cherish his aged parents) a)poti/nonta danei/smata e)pimelei/as te kai\ u(perponountwn w)di=nas palaia\s e)pi\ ne/ois daneisqei/sas, requiting...their pangs of old, when they suffered for him.

ne/as trofh=s e)/lhce, ceased to need the tender care which is given to children. ne/a trofh/, here, "the nurture (not "growth") of the young": so Ai. 510 ne/as | trofh=s sterhqei/s, bereft of the tendance which childhood needs: El. 1143 (speaking of her brother's infancy) trofh=s | … th\n … a)mfi\ soi\ | pare/sxon. But in O. T. 1 ne/a trofh/ = "last-born nurslings."

kati/sxusen, became strong (ingressive aor.), de/mas, "in body" (acc. of respect). This compound verb, though metrically convenient, seems not to occur elsewhere before the 2nd cent. B.C.: it was usu. intrans., as Polyb. 11. 13 kati/sxuon kai\ tw=| plh/qei kai\ tai=s eu)xeiri/ais (began to prevail in the battle). Evang. Matth. xvi. 18 pu/lai a(/|dou ou) katisxu/ousin au)th=s.
gerontagwgei=, on the analogy of paidagwgei=n (so, in late Greek, cenagwgei=n for cenagei=n): Aristoph. Eq. 1098 ("I give myself to thee," says Demus) gerontagwgei=n ka)napaideu/ein pa/lin.

nhli/pous: schol. a:nupo/dhtos. Apoll. Rhod. 3. 646 nh/lipos, oi)e/anos (shoeless, with only a tunic): Theocr. 4. 56 ei)s o)/ros o(/kx' e(/rph|s, mh\ a)na/lipos e)/rxeo, *ba/tte: where schol. h)=liy ga\r to\ u(po/dhma. If the word really comes from an h)=liy (of which there is no other trace), then nhli/pous (used also by Lycophron 635, who, however, may have followed Soph.) is less correct than nh/lipos, which Blomfield (Aesch. PV 248) wished to restore here. Eustathius 787. 52 derives nh/lipos from li/pos (fat, unguent), explaining it by au)xmhro\s kai\ a)liph/s ("unkempt").

h(gei=tai. The sentence gerontagwgei=, polla\ me
 ... a)lwme/nh, polloi=si d' o)/mbr. moxqou=sa, is so far regular and complete: then we should have expected h(goume/nh, introducing a comment on the whole sentence. Instead, we have h(gei=tai, which draws moxqou=sa to itself, and thus breaks the symmetry of the antithesis. The substitution of a finite verb for a second participial clause is freq. in Greek; but is usu. managed as if here we had polla\ me
...a)lwme/nh, polloi=s d' o)/mbr. moxqei=, h(goume/nh etc. Cp. El. 190
oi)konomw= qala/mous patro/s, w)=de me

a)eikei= su
 stola=|,
kenai=s d' a)mfi/stamai trape/zais (instead of a)mfistame/nh): Ph. 213 ff. ou) molpa
...e)/xwn,—...a)lla\...boa=| (instead of bow=n): Lys. or. 12 § 15 e)do/kei moi tau/th| peira=sqai swqh=
ai, e)nqumoume/nw| o(/ti, e)a
 me
 la/qw, swqh/somai:, e)a
 de\ lhfqw=, h(gou/mhn etc.: and O. T. 1134 n. See also Ai. 806 (n. on zhtei=t)).

ta\ th=s. There are only three other instances in Soph. of the art. so placed: Ph. 263 *filokth/ths o(\n oi( | dissoi\ strathgoi/: Ant. 409 ko/nin sh/rantes h)\ katei=xe to\n | ne/kun: El. 879 ka)pi\ toi=s | sauth=s kakoi=si. Close cohesion in thought and utterance is the excuse for this, as for the elision of d', t', tau=t' at the end of a v. (O. T. 29 n.).

ei) … e)/xoi is an abstract statement of the condition: — "Supposing him to have tendance, she is content." For optat. in protasis, with pres. ind. in apodosis, cp. Antiphanes fr. incert. 51 (Bothe p. 412)
ei) ga\r a)fe/loi tis tou= bi/ou ta\s h(dona/s,
katalei/pet' ou)de\n e(/teron h)\ teqnhke/nai, "supposing one takes away...then nothing is left."
trofh\n, "tendance": see on 345: cp. 1614.

mantei=a pa/nta implies several oracles, given to the Thebans about Oedipus after he had left Thebes. There is no clue to their purport, and we need not ask: they are invented merely to create a pious office for Ismene. It would not have seemed well that she should have stayed at Thebes all these years without showing any active interest in his fate: on the other hand, the poetic legend required that Antigone should be the sole guide of his wanderings. The oracle about final rest had been given to Oed. in his youth (see on 87); the oracle about his grave has only just been received at Thebes (389). Between these two, the only oracle suggested by the Sophoclean version of the story is a response to the question which Creon had proposed to ask at Delphi (O. T. 1438), as to whether Oed. should remain at Thebes. But the story of the expulsion (768 ff.) implies that no such response had then been obtained.
tou=de sw/matos (without peri/), gen. of connection; see on 307.

fu/lac de/ moi k.t.l., a general description of her part, subjoined to the special instance just given: "and you constituted yourself a trusty watcher (at Thebes) in my interest, when I was being driven from the land," i.e. from the moment when the decision to expel me had been taken, and the act was in contemplation.

moi for mou seems necessary: and I suspect that mou first arose from inattention to the exact sense. A gen. after fu/lac always denotes the object guarded: thus fu/lac mou ought to mean (not, "a watcher in my interest," but) "a guardian of my person"; this, however, was Antigone's part (21): Ismene had never roamed with him. So in Eur. Bacch. 612 ti/s moi fu/lac h)=n; (say the Bacchants to Dionysus), "what overseer, master (of our rites, like e)pi/skopos of Dionysus, Ant. 1148) had we?" — not, "what guardian of our persons was there?" Yet there L2 (cod. Laur. 32. 2) has mou.
sto/los, a journey with a purpose, a "mission": Ph. 243 ti/ni | sto/lw| prose/sxes; on what mission hast thou touched here?

mh\ ou)xi\ … fe/rousa explains the special sense of kenh/. "You have not come empty-handed—i.e. without bringing some terror for me." mh\ ou) properly stands with a partic. in a negative statement only when mh/ could stand with it in the corresponding affirmative statement: thus (a) affirmative: bradu\s e)/rxei mh\ fe/rwn, you (always) come slowly, if you are not bringing: (b) negative: ou) bradu\s e)/rxei, mh\ ou) fe/rwn, you never come slowly, unless you are bringing. Here mh\ ou) is irregular, because the affirmative form would be h(/keis ou) (not mh\) fe/rousa, a simple statement of fact; and so the negative should be ou)x h(/keis ou) fe/rousa. But bringing bad news is felt here as a condition of her coming. Hence mh\ ou) is used as if the sentence were formally conditional: ou)k a)\n h)=lqes mh\ ou) fe/rousa.

From Thebes to Athens is a short day's journey; but Ismene has sought her father far and wide. This could not well have been if, as Campbell supposes (on 355), the oracles which she herself had formerly brought to him had directed his course towards Attica.
zhtou=sa th\n sh\n trofh/n, "enquiring as to your way of life" is supplemented by pou= katoikoi/hs, i.e., "where you were living." Cp. Thuc. 4.42 e)peth/roun tou\s *)aqhnai/ous oi(= katasxh/sousin.

a)mfi\ … pai/doin (dat.), "about": oft. of encompassing tenderness, as 1614; here, of besetting trouble: unless we take it as merely = "in the case of": cp. Tr. 727 a)ll' a)mfi\ toi=s sfalei=si mh\ )c e(kousi/as | o)rgh\ pe/peira.

Eteocles and Polyneices were young boys at the fall of Oedipus (see on 1), and their uncle Creon (brother of Iocasta) became regent (O. T. 1418). As the two brothers grew up, they agreed, at first, in wishing to resign the throne, of which they were joint heirs, to Creon, lest Thebes should be tainted by their own rule; but afterwards they fell to striving with each other for the sole power.

e)/rws, desire (436), is a necessary and a certain correction. The MS. e)/ris would have to mean "emulous desire," either (a) between the two brothers, if te … mhde/ = "both" … "and not": or (b) between the brothers and (te) Creon. Now, there is no objection to using e)ri/zw, e)/ris of noble rivalry. The fatal objection is that the idea of rivalry at all is here completely,—almost ludicrously,—out of place. The notion that Soph. was thinking of the a)gaqh\ e)/ris, which rouses men to effort, as opp. to the kakh\ e)/ris (Hes. Opp. 11 ff.), is surely very frigid. It is possible, however, that it was this notion which first brought e)/ris into 367.

*kre/onti/ te. The te = "both," answering to mhde/ "and not." So te is answered by ou)de/ (instead of ou)/te) Eur. I. T. 697, or by de/ Soph. Ph. 1312. So, too, ou)/te by de/, Eur. Suppl. 223, etc. Such irregularity is natural when the second thought is opposed to the first. The objection to reading mh/te in 368 is that, while ou)/te (or mh/te)... te is common enough, there is no example of te...ou)/te (or mh/te).

Paley's *kre/onti dh\ is, however, highly probable. It would mean, "to Creon in the next resort." So dh\ is used of succession in Ant. 173, where Creon says e)gw\ kra/th dh\ pa/nta kai\ qro/nous e)/xw, I next (the sons of Oed. being dead); and Aesch. Eum. 3 h(\ dh\ to\ mhtro\s deute/ra to/d' e(/zeto | mantei=on.
e)a=sqai, pass., as Tr. 329 h( d' ou)=n e)a/sqw: Thuc. 1.142 ( e)aso/menoi ): Eur. I. A. 331 ( e)a/somai ) : I. T. 1344 ( e)w/menos ) : etc. The midd. of e)a/w is not classical.
po/lin: so in Ant. 776 o(/pws mi/asma pa=s' u(pekfu/gh| po/lis, it is implied that the whole State may be polluted by an act of the king.

lo/gw|, in the light of reason, with calm reflection (in contrast to the blind passion for power which afterwards seized them), a dat. of manner, cp. 381, O. T. 405 o)rgh=| lele/xqai, Ant. 621 sofi/a|...e)/pos pe/fantai.

th\n pa/lai … fqora/n, beginning with the curse called down on Laïus by Pelops, for robbing him of his son Chrysippus. Cp. Ant. 596 (of this Labdacid house) ou)d' a)palla/ssei genea\n ge/nos, a)ll' e)rei/pei | qew=n tis etc.: one generation doth not free another, but some god brings ruin.

ka)lithri/ou. The MS. reading, ka)c a)l&ibreve;throu=, is against metre, and gives a form of the adj. which occurs nowhere else; though, had it existed, it would have been most convenient for epic verse. a)lith/rios, and the poet. a)l&ibreve;tro/s, alone are found. The preceding e)k may have led the scribe into an erroneous repetition, as in Ai. 205 L has o( deino\s o( me/gas instead of o( deino\s me/gas (cp. Wecklein, Ars Soph. emend. XVI. pp. 69 ff.). This seems, on the whole, more likely than that the Homeric a)lei/ths ("sinner," a)loito/s in Lycophr. 579) should have suggested a form a)leithro/s or a)loithro/s, of which there is no other trace. Hesychius (I. 236), s.v. a)litrosu/nh, says that in the *ai)xmalwti/des Soph. used the subst. a)litri/a (Aristoph. Ach. 907 w(/sper pi/qakon a)litri/as polla=s ple/wn), whence Dindorf ka)c a)litri/as freno/s, "from a sin of the mind." The objection to this is the unexampled lengthening of the second syllable.

The dat. after ei)sh=lqe is strictly a dat. of the person interested, but was perh. influenced by the analogy of the dat. in pare/sth moi, "it occurred to me," and the like; cp. Tr. 298 e)moi\ ga\r oi)=ktos... ei)se/bh: Her. 1.86 ) le/getai ( tw=| *kroi/sw| … e)selqei=n...to\ tou= *so/lwnos: but 6. 125 to\n *kroi=son ge/lws e)sh=lqe: and so Eur. Med. 931 ei)sh=lqe/ m' oi)=ktos.

tri\s a)qli/oin for trisaqli/oin was first given by Porson, since otherwise there would be no caesura either in the 3rd or in the 4th foot. He compares Od. 5.306 tri\s ma/kares *danaoi\ kai\ tetra/kis: Ar. Plut. 851 kai\ tri\s kakodai/mwn kai\ tetra/kis, k.t.l. To Hermann's argument, that in any case tri\s and a)qli/oin cohere, the answer is that, for the metre, the degree of coherence makes all the difference. Blaydes, keeping trisaqli/oin, quotes five such cases as "free from suspicion." They are the same five which Porson had discussed and proposed to amend in connection with this passage (praef. p. xxviii): viz. Aesch. Pers. 501 (transpose krustalloph=ga), Eur. I. A. 1586 (transpose o(rwme/nou), Soph. Ai. 969 (not strictly similar,—e)peggelw=|en), Aesch. Ag. 1261 (=1252 Dind. paresko/peis, doubtful), Suppl. 252 (=244 D. e)peika/sai, doubtful). Of these, paresko/peis is the only exact parallel to trisaqli/oin, as being a single word coincident with the dipodia, and not preceded by elision.

If nea/zwn merely=new/teros w)/n, the pleonasm would be too weak: perh., then, it is tinged with the notion of neanieuo/menos (as in Eur. Phoen. 713: poi=; mw=n nea/zwn ou)x o(ra=|s a(\ xrh=n s' o(ra=n; — said by Creon to Eteocles). Cp. Aesch. Ag. 763
filei= de\ ti/ktein u(/bris me\n palaia\ nea/-
zousan u(/brin.

to\n pro/sqe: Polyneices alludes to his right as the firstborn, 1294, 1422: Eur. (Phoen. 71) followed the common account in making Eteocles the elder. The change adopted by Soph. is here a twofold dramatic gain; for (a) Polyneices, who is to come on the scene, can be treated as the foremost ofiender; (b) Eteocles has now a special fault, and so the curse on both sons is further justified (421).
a)posteri/skei, historic pres., "deprives of" (rather than a true pres., "is excluding from"). The simple steri/skw (Thuc., Plat., Eur., etc.) was commoner in Attic than this compound.
plhqu/wn, lit., becoming full (of the Nile rising, Her. 2.19): Aesch. Ag. 869 w(s e)plh/quon lo/goi.

*)/argos, the territory, not only the city; called koi=lon because the Argive plain is bounded on W., N. and E. by hills, as on S. by the sea. This epithet had already been given to it, acc. to the schol., in the epic called the *)epi/gonoi, popularly ascribed to Homer (Her. 4.32, who expresses doubt), and was again used by Soph. in his Thamyras (fr. 222). Cp. Strabo 8. 370 th=s te xw/ras (the Argive plain) koi/lhs ou)/shs kai\ potamoi=s diarreome/nhs (the Inachus and the Erasînus) kai\ e(/lh kai\ li/mnas parexome/nhs. So Her. 7.129 to\ me/son de\ tou/twn tw=n lexqe/ntwn o)re/wn h( *qessali/h e)sti/, e)ou=sa koi/lh: Od. 4.1 *lakedai/mona koi/lhn (the valley of the Eurotas); Polyb. 1. 3. 1 *koi/lh *suri/a (as lying between Lebanon and Anti-Lebanon). The epith. koi=lon has an epic tone, as suggesting a distinction from the Homeric *pelasgiko\n *)/argos (perh. Thessaly), *)axai+ko\n and *)/iason *)/argos (Peloponnesus).
kh=dos, affinitatem, with Adrastus, by marrying his daughter Argeia (kh=dos *)adra/stou labw/n, Eur. Phoen. 77).

kaino/n, in a new quarter (as opp. to his native land). Perhaps Statius, whom Schneid. quotes, was translating this:
iamque ille novis, scit fama, superbit
Conubiis, viresque parat, queis regna capessat (Theb. 2. 108).
w(s k.t.l.: "as purposing that Argos should either possess the Theban land in honour, or exalt Thebes to the skies" (by the glory of having defeated Argos).

w(s … *)/argos … kaqe/con h)\ … bibw=n, acc. absol. in the personal constr., as O. T. 101 w(s to/d' ai(=ma xeima/zon po/lin: Thuc. 6.24 e)/rws e)ne/pese toi=s pa=sin...e)kpleu=sai...w(s h)\ katastreyome/nois e)f' a(\ e)/pleon, h)\ ou)de
 a)
 sfalei=san mega/lhn du/namin, in the belief that they would reduce Sicily, or that at all events a great armament could suffer no disaster. Eur. Ion 964 *p*a*i*d. soi\ d' e)s ti/ do/c' ei)/sh=lqen e)kbalei=n te/knon;—*k*r*e*o*u*s*a. w(s to
 qeo
 sw/sonta to/n g' au(tou= go/non.
timh=|, dat. of manner: cp. 369.
kaqe/con, occupy as conquerors: Dem. or. 18 § 96 ta\ ku/klw| th=s *)attikh=s katexo/ntwn a(rmostai=s kai\ frourai=s.

pro\s ou)r. bibw=n: cp. kle/os ou)rano\n i(/kei (Od. 9.20), kle/os ou)rano/mhkes (Aristoph. Nub. 459): Eur. Bacch. 972 w(/st' ou)ranw=| sthri/zon eu(rh/seis kle/os (thou wilt find thy fame towering in the sky). But the best illustration is Isocr. or. 15 § 134 ta\ me\n a(martano/mena paro/yontai, to\ de\ katorqwqe\n ou)rano/mhkes poih/sousin, they will overlook your failures, and exalt your success to the skies. So Lucr. 1. 78
religio pedibus subiecta vicissim
Opteritur, nos exaequat victoria caelo. Wecklein strangely understands: — "or will make Thebes rise to the sky" (in smoke, by burning the city), comparing Eur. Tro. 1298
pte/rugi de\ kapno\s w(/s tis ou)-
ra/nia pesou=sa dori\ katafqi/nei ga=, which means simply: "our land hath fallen like smoke that hath sunk down on its wing from the sky, and is perishing by the spear."

a)riqmo/s: Eur. Tro. 475
ka)ntau=q' a)risteu/ont' e)geina/mhn te/kna,
ou)k a)riqmo\n a)/llws, a)ll' u(perta/tous *frugw=n. Hor. Epp. 1. 2. 27 Nos numerus sumus et fruges consumere nati.

If the MS. o(/poi (Vat. o(/ph) is right, the phrase is harsh beyond example. poi=, o(/poi, instead of pou=, o(/pou, are often boldly used, when the verb implies either (a) motion, as 227 kataqh/seis, 476 teleuth=sai, Eur. Bacch. 184 kaqista/nai, etc.; or (b) patience up to a point, as Aristoph. Lys. 526 poi= ga\r kai\ xrh=n a)namei=nai; But it is hard to see how o(/poi katoiktiou=sin could mean "how far they will prolong (thy woes) before they pity them." To supply proelqo/ntas or proagago/ntes is to cut the knot. If the phrase meant anything, it ought rather to mean, "up to what point they will pity them." As in 335 poi= is a MS. error for pou=, so here o(/poi for o(/pou (Wecklein prefers o(/ph|, "in what way"). Note that, in this context, po/nous = the woes of Oed. generally (mental and physical), not merely his toils in wandering: this is against the emend. katoikiou=sin.

w(s … e(/cein. Against the tempting conjecture qeoi\ … e(/cous', remark that in some other passages, where our MSS. give this mixed construction, the acc. and inf. could not be eliminated without strong measures: thus Xen. Hellen. 6.5.42 e)lpi/zein de\ xrh\ w(s a)/ndras a)gaqou\s ma=llon h)\ kakou\s au)tou\s genh/sesqai: Cyr. 8. 1. 25 pro\s de\ tou/tois e)logi/zeto w(s ei) pa/ntes oi( koinw=nes qeosebei=s ei)=en, h(=tton a)\n au)tou\s e)qe/lein: where the least violent remedy would be to delete w(s—a course not possible here. In some other such places, indeed, the inf. can be very easily corrected (as Hellen. 3. 4. 27 ei)/h for ei)=nai, 7. 4. 39 dei= for dei=n).

w(s … qeou\s e(/cein may be sound. Harsh as it seems to us, usage had perhaps accustomed the ear to hearing the speaker's own view introduced by w(s, even when the corresponding construction did not follow. w(=d' e)mou= would be weak. But w(/st' e)mou= (against which the presence of w(/ste in 386 is not conclusive, cp. on 544) is worth weighing: cp. Eur. Or. 52 e)lpi/da de\ dh/ tin' e)/xomen w(/ste mh\ qanei=n.

Since e)/gwge is virtually one word, this v. cannot be regarded as an instance of ge used twice in the same sentence. Such repetition is allowable when more than one word is to be emphasised, as Eur. Phoen. 554 e)pei\ ta/ g' a)rkou=nq' i(kana\ toi=s ge sw/frosin, but no certain example happens to occur in Soph.: see on O. T. 1030.
