The purport of this new oracle seems to have been: — "The welfare of Thebes depends on Oed., alive or dead." Ismene paraphrases it: — "It shows that you will be in request with the Thebans some day (pote/, i.e. some day soon, 397), — not merely after your death, but while you live." She knows that Creon is coming in the hope of carrying Oed. back — not to Thebes, but to some place just beyond the Theban border, where his person, and afterwards his grave, should be under Theban control. Cp. on 1331.

eu)soi/as, used by Soph. also in the Amphitryon (fr. 119)
e)pei\ de\ bla/stoi, tw=n triw=n mi/an labei=n
eu)/soian a)rkei=, quoted by the schol., who describes it as the reading e)n toi=s a)nagkaiote/rois tw=n a)ntigra/fwn (the better copies) … o(\ kai\ oi( u(pomnhmatisa/menoi a)ciou=sin (the Alexan drian commentators). It does not occur except in Soph.: but Theocr. 24. 8 has eu)/soa te/kna ("safe and sound").

A and other MSS. have toiou=d' u(p', which gives a clear constr. It seems arbitrary to assume that in L's reading ti/s d' a)\n toiou=d' a)ndro\s eu)= pra/ceien a)/n the syllable lost was rather ti after ti/s d' a)\n, the gen. being one of source. Herm. supports the latter view by O. T. 1006 sou= pro\s do/mous e)lqo/ntos eu)= pra/caimi/ ti, but there the gen. is absolute. Wecklein gives ti/s d' a)nti\ toiou=d' a)ndro\s eu)= pra/ceien a)/n; comparing a)nq' ou(=, a)nti\ tou=; but in such phrases a)nti/="in recompense for," not "through the agency of."
e)n soi\: 247.
gi/gnesqai is never merely ei)=nai. e)n soi\ gi/gnetai ta\ kei/nwn kra/th=their power comes to be in thy hand: i.e. the new oracle so appoints.
fasi/ with indef. subject, "people say," report says (we cannot supply "the qewroi/" from 413).
kra/th, political predominance generally, but with esp. ref. to prevalence in war against Athens (1332): the plur. as of royal power (Ant. 173 kra/th...kai\ qro/nous).
a)nh/r, emphatic, as oft.: Aristoph. Nub. 823 o(\ su\ maqw\n a)nh\r e)/sei: Xen. Cyr. 4.2.25 ou)ke/t' a)nh/r e)stin, a)lla\ skeuofo/ros.
w)/llusan, imperf. of intention; see on 274. This was their design up to the moment of his fall. From that moment dates the period meant by nu=n.
see on 1.
d\s pe/sh| without a)/n, as oft. in poetry, seldom in prose (O. T. 1231 n.).
kai\ mh\n here = "Well, however that may be" (even if it is flau=ron).
ge throws back a light stress on *kre/onta: "Creon thinks the matter important." For a slightly different use of kai\ mh/n... ge cp. O. T. 345 n.

baiou= … xro/nou. The gen. of the "time within which" expresses the period to which the act belongs, and might so be viewed as possessive: Plat. Gorg. 448A ou)dei/s me/ pw h)rw/thke kaino\n ou)de\n pollw=n e)tw=n, i.e. non-questioning of me has now been the attribute of many years. e)nto/s is sometimes added (Isocr. or. 6 § 46 e)nto\s triw=n mhnw=n kate/sxen a(/pasan *makedoni/an).
kou)xi\ m., with warning emphasis: O. T. 58 gnwta\ kou)k a)/gnwta (n.). Cp. 617.

sth/swsi, sc. oi( *qhbai=oi: Creon himself lays stress on his mission to speak for all (737). Schol. katoiki/swsi. The word has a certain harsh fitness for to\n planh/thn (3). Against w(s a)/gxi gh=s sth/sh| se speaks the plural strain of the whole passage (392 kei/nwn, 400 kratw=si, 402 kei/nois, 405 qe/lousi, etc.).

o(/rwn. e)mbai/nw usu. takes either dat., or prep. with gen. or accus.: the simple gen. could be explained as partitive, but prob. is rather on the analogy of the gen. with e)pibai/nw: cp. O. T. 825 e)mbateu/ein patri/dos. The gen. with e)pembai/nw (924) is warranted by the first preposition.
The tenor of this fine passage should be observed.

Oedipus took e)n soi/ (392) to mean that the welfare of Thebes depended on his presence there. He is thinking of a restoration to his Theban home (395). He asks, therefore, —"Of what use can I be to them if I am left at their doors, and not received within their land?" "They will suffer," she replies, "if your tomb is neglected." Oedipus does not see the force of this answer: he still infers (from qano/nta in 390) that, whatever may be his doom in life, he is at least to be buried at Thebes. "Why, of course they will," he replies (403). "So" — pursues the daughter (404) — "they mean to keep you within their grasp." A new suspicion flashes on him. "They will bury me at Thebes?" "It cannot be." That is enough. He will never give himself into their hands. — Remark that he was supposing Apollo's former decree (91) to have been cancelled by this later one (389). He now sees that the new oracle does not cancel the former, but merely confirms it in one aspect, viz. in the promise of a)/thn toi=s pe/myasin (93).

qu/rasi, foris, as Eur. El. 2074 ou)de\n ga\r au)th\n dei= qu/rasin eu)prepe\s | fai/nein pro/swpon (she ought not to show her beauty abroad), where, as here, Elms. restored it from the MS. qu/raisi. Campbell retains the latter. But, while in qu/rasi, qu/raze, qu/raqen, qurai=os the notion of "external" is uppermost, the figurative uses of the plural qu/rai always speak of approaching the house: as e)pi\ ta\s qu/ras foita=n, e)pi\ tai=s qu/rais diatri/bein, e)pi\ tai=s qu/rais th=s *(ella/dos e)sme/n (Xen. Anab. 6.5.23). So here qu/raisi would mean, not, "outside of their doors," but "at their very doors."
keime/nou: schol. oi)kou=ntos.
kei/nois with baru/s only.

dustuxw=n=if it does not receive due honours: cp. a)/moiros...ne/kus of a corpse denied due rites (Ant. 1071). Eur. Hec. 319
tu/mbon de\ bouloi/mhn a)
 a)ciou/menon
to
 e)mo
 o(ra=sqai. Since in death (390) he was still to sway their destiny, they wished his grave to be where they could make the due offerings (e)nagi/zein) at it: cp. Her. 2.44 tw=| me
 w(s a)qana/tw|...qu/ousi, tw=| de\...w(s h(/rwi e)nagi/zousi. Such e)nagismo/s would be at least annual (cp. Isae. or. 2 § 46). The schol. takes dustuxw=n as = "if not on Theban soil": but this is excluded by 407.
Cp. O. T. 398 gnw/mh| kurh/sas ou)d' a)p' oi)wnw=n maqw/n. It needed no oracle to tell one that they would incur divine anger for neglecting the first duties of piety towards their late king.

se prosqe/sqai, "to associate you with them (as a prospective ally) in the neighbourhood of their land, and not (to leave you) in a place where you will be your own master." Cp. Her. 1.69 xrh/santos tou= qeou= to\n *(/ellhna fi/lon prosqe/sqai,...u(me/as...proskale/omai fi/los te qe/lwn gene/sqai kai\ su/mmaxos. With mhd), etc., a verbal notion such as e)a=sai oi)kei=n must be supplied from prosqe/sqai: cp. El. 71
kai\ mh/ m' a)/timon th=sd' a)postei/lhte gh=s,
a)ll' a)rxe/plouton (sc. katasth/sate).
a)\n … kratoi=s, nearly = krath/seis. See on i(/n' a)\n...ei)/poimen, 189. With the MS. krath=|s, a)/n belongs to i(/na: "wherever you may be your own master": which is evidently less suitable here.

kai\ with kataskiw=si (not with h(=, which would imply that he did not expect it, O. T. 368): "Having settled me near their land, will they further bury me within it?" For kataskia/zein cp. Epigrammata Graeca 493 (Kaibel, Berl. 1878) qano/nta...gai=a kateski/asen.

tou)/mfulon ai(=ma, thy blood-guilt for the death of a kinsman: so e)mfu/lion ai(=ma (Pind. Pyth. 2.32), ai(=ma suggene/s (Eur. Suppl. 148), ai(=ma gene/qlion (Or. 89): but in O. T. 1406 ai(=m' e)mfu/lion merely="a blood-kinship." Oed. was doomed to a)eifugi/a (601). Even to bury him in Theban ground would seem impious towards Laïus. So, when Antigone has given the burial-rite to Polyneices, Creon asks, (Ant. 514) pw=s dh=t' e)kei/nw| dussebh= tima=|s xa/rin; "How, then, canst thou render a grace which is impious towards that other?" (Eteocles).

sunallagh=s, strictly, a bringing together (by the gods) of persons and circumstances, a "conjuncture": rarely without the defining gen. (as no/sou c., O. T. 960); for in Tr. 845 o)leqri/aisi cunallagai=s prob.= "at the fatal meeting" (of Deianeira with Nessus).

soi=s … ta/fois, poetical locative dat. (O. T. 381 n.), freq. in Homer, as Il. 21.389 h(/menos *ou)lu/mpw|. Some day the Thebans will invade Attica, and will be defeated by the Athenians near the grave of Oedipus. Cp. Aristeides u(pe\r tw=n tetta/rwn p. 284 (the great men of the Greek past are guardian spirits), kai\ r(u/esqai/ ge th\n xw/ran ou) xei=ron h)\ to\n e)n *kolwnw=| kei/menon *oi)di/poun: where the schol. records a vague legend of his epiphany in some fight with Theban invaders. When the Persians (480 B.C.) were repulsed from Delphi, two gigantic warriors pursued them; tou/tous de\ tou\s du/o *delfoi\ le/gousi ei(=nai tou\s e)pixwri/ous h(/rwas, *fu/lako/n te kai\ *au)to/noon, tw=n ta\ teme/nea/ e)sti peri\ to\ i(ro/n (Her. 8.39). So Theseus was seen at Marathon (Plut. Thes. 35); Athene appeared, and the Aeacidae helped, at Salamis (Her. 9.83 f.).
qewrw=n, sent from Thebes to Delphi, to consult the oracle in solemn form (O. T. 114): cp. on 354.
e(sti/as, the "hearth of the Pythian seer" (O. T. 965), "at earth's centre" (meso/mfalos, Eur. Ion 462).
e)f' h(mi=n, "in my case" (n. on O.T. 829).
oi( molo/ntes: schol. oi( qewroi/.
pai/dwn tis (there being only two sons) virtually strengthens the question, as if he asked —"Had my sons any knowledge whatever of this?"
kai\ ei)=ta, "and after that," is explained by tw=nd' a)kou/santes.
tw=nd': see on 304.

pa/ros … prou)/qento: Eur. Hipp. 382 oi( d' h(donh\n proqe/ntes a)nti\ tou= kalou= | a)/llhn tin): Isocr. Ep. 9 § 17 a)/llous a)nq' h(mwn prokriqh=nai: and so Plat. protima=n ti a)nti/ tinos (Lys. 219 D), pro/ tinos (Legg. 727 D), ple/on tino/s (ib. 777 D), ma=llon h)/ ti (887 B). What is the complaint of Oed. against his sons? This: — Apollo had made him the arbiter, in life and death, of Theban welfare (389). His sons might have pleaded with the Thebans: — "Apollo has now virtually condoned the e)/mfulon ai(=ma (407). Restore our father to the throne." But they desired the throne for themselves. Here, as in regard to his expulsion, they neglected an opportunity which natural piety should have seized (441).
tou)mou= po/qou: the possess. pron. =object. gen. of pers. pron.: see on 332.

fe/rw d' o(/mws is usually taken, "but such are my tidings" (cp. 360). This would be fitting if, with Wecklein, we might read fe/rousa for klu/ousa: but the latter is in all MSS., and naturally refers to the words just heard by Ismene from Oed., not to a report heard by her at Thebes. The indignant question of Oed. invited a defence. She replies, "I am pained to hear my brothers charged with such conduct, but I must bear it" — i.e. I cannot deny the charge. The contrast between a)lgw= and fe/rw has thus more point.

a)ll'. "Nay, then" — opening the imprecation, as Ph. 1040
a)ll', w)= patrw/|a gh= qeoi/ t' e)gxw/rioi,
tei/sasqe, tei/sasq'.

sfin, not sfi, was prob. always the form used by Attic tragedy. It is required by metre below, 444, 451, 1490: Ai. 570: El. 1070: Aesch. PV 252, 457: Pers. 759, 807: fr. 157 (ap. Plat. Rep. 391E). Eur. has the dat. in two places where, as here, sfi is possible, but in both sfin has MS. authority, and should probably be read, Med. 398 (v.l. sfi), Suppl. 769. On the other hand there is no place in trag. where metre excludes sfin.
th\n peprwme/nhn, by the curse in the house of Laïus (369).

e)n d' after mh/te is harsh, and Elmsley's e)/n t' may be right. There is, however, a good deal of MS. evidence for te...de/ in trag.: see on 367. Cp. Ant. 1096 to/ t' ei)kaqei=n ga\r deino/n, a)ntista/nta de\ k.t.l., n.
e)n e)moi/ (cp. 247), may the issue for them come to be (392) in my hands, i.e. may the gods allow me to be the final arbiter, and to doom them both by a father's curse.

ka)panai/rontai. The words kai\ e)panai/rontai do/ru do not form a second relative clause,—as if, from the h(=s before e)/xontai, we had to supply the relat. pron. in a different case (e)f' h(=|, or ei)s h(/n) with e)panai/rontai. They form an independent sentence, which is co-ordinated with the relative clause, h(=s e)/xontai. This is the normal Greek construction. See note in Appendix. Cp. 467, 731.

e)panairou=ntai do/ru, the MS. reading, would mean, "are taking a spear upon them," the verb being used figuratively (like in se suscipere) of obligations or responsibilities (fili/an, po/lemon, te/xnhn, latrei/an etc.); but e)panai/resqai, in its literal sense of "uplifting against," is more natural and more poetical with do/ru: cp. Eur. Her. 313 kai\ mh/pot' e)s gh=n e)xqro\n ai)/resqai do/ru.
w(s, "for" (if I were to have the decision). Blomfield's conjecture w(=d' is unnecessary.
oi(/ ge, causal: see on oi(/tines 263.
a)ti/mws: cp. 440 bi/a|: 770 e)cew/qeis. Soph. has this adv. thrice elsewhere of ignominious or ruthless treatment, El. 1181, Ant. 1069, fr. 593. 7.

ou)k e)/sxon, did not stop me (from being expelled). We find such phrases as e)/xw tina\ poiou=nta/ ti, to check one in the act of doing something (O. C. 888 bouqutou=nta/ m)...e)/sxet)), but not e)/xw tina\ a)dikou/menon, to stop one from being wronged (like pau/w). Here, then, it is better to supply to\ (or w(/ste) mh\ e)cwqei=sqai than to take e)/sxon with e)cwqou/menon. Cp. Xen. Anab. 3.5.11 pa=s...a)sko\s du/o a)/ndras e(/cei to\ (v.l. tou=) mh\ katadu=nai: w(/ste de\ mh\ o)lisqa/nein, h( u(/lh kai\ h( gh= sxh/sei.
h)/munan, sc. e)moi/.

a)na/statos, made to rise up and quit one's abode, "driven from house and home," implying a)eifugi/a (601), Tr. 39
e)n *traxi=ni th=|d' a)na/statoi
ce/nw| par' a)ndri\ nai/omen (driven from our home at Argos). Thuc. 1.8 oi(...e)k tw=n nh/swn kakou=rgoi a)ne/sthsan u(p' au)tou= (were expelled).

au)toi=n, not dat. of the agent (very rare except with perf., plpf., or fut. pf. pass.), but dat. of interest ("so far as they were concerned"): cp. Ph. 1030 te/qnhx' u(mi=n pa/lai: Aesch. PV 12 sfw=|n me\n e)ntolh\ *dio\s | e)/xei te/los dh/.

e)cekhru/xqhn, by a proclamation of Creon (as regent) to the citizens—like that which Oed. himself had made (O. T. 216 ff.). kh/rugma is used of the royal edict, Ant. 8, 161, etc. Cp. Lys. or. 12 § 95 (of those banished by the Thirty) e)cekhru/xqhte...e)k th=s po/lews.

ei)/pois a)\n: the figure called u(pofora/ (Lat. subiectio, Cornificius 4. 23. 33), the "suggestion" of an objection, with the reply; Tiberius peri\ sxhma/twn § 36 (Spengel Rhet. III. 77) u(pofora\ de/ e)stin o(/tan mh\ e(ch=s probai/nh| o( lo/gos, a)ll' u(poqei/s ti h)\ w(s para\ tou= a)ntidi/kou h)\ w(s e)k tou= pra/gmatos a)pokri/nhtai pro\s au(to/n, w(/sper du/o a)ntilego/mena pro/swpa mimou/menos. Oed. here speaks chiefly to Ism., whose pain for her brothers (420) might suggest the excuse; though in 445, 457 he addresses the Chorus. Wecklein conceives Oed. as speaking directly to the spectators, who might recollect the close of the O. T. Need we charge the poet with this dramatic impropriety?

qe/lonti, "desiring" (not merely "consenting"): cp. 767: O. T. 1356 qe/lonti ka)moi\ tou=t' a)\n h)=n. The desire of Oed. to be sent away from Thebes is passionately expressed in the O. T. (1410 ff., 1449 ff.). At the end of that play he repeats the request (1518), and Creon replies that it must be referred to Delphi.
to/te with kath/|nesen, i.e. "when I was banished"; so Ai. 650 to/te="in those old days."

The i in L's kathi/nusen speaks for kath/|nesen,— clearly much fitter here than kath/nusen. Cp. 1633 katai/neson, 1637 kath/|nesen. The contrast is between exile imposed as a doom or granted as a boon,—not merely between a wish fulfilled or unfulfilled.

h(me/ran: the acc. of duration (cp. O. T. 1138) is strictly warrantable, as in Xen. Cyr. 6.3.11 kai\ e)xqe\s de\ kai\ tri/thn h(me/ran (the day before yesterday) to\ au)to\ tou=to e)/pratton: though in a negative sentence we might have rather expected the gen. (cp. An. 3. 3. 11 th=s h(me/ras o(/lhs dih=lqon ou) ple/on pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi stadi/wn).
th\n au)ti/x): Thuc. 2.64 e)/s te to\ me/llon...e)/s te to\ au)ti/ka: 3. 112 e)n tw=| au)ti/ka fo/bw|.

leusqh=nai pe/trois, the typical form of summary vengeance on one who has incurred public execration: Il. 3.56 h)e/ ken h)/dh | la/i+non e(/sso xitw=na: Aesch. Ag. 1616 dhmorrifei=s...leusi/mous a)ra/s: Ai. 254 liqo/leuston *)/arh (on the part of the infuriated army): Eur. Or. 442 qanei=n u(p' a)stw=n leusi/mw| petrw/mati (the pleonasm as here). Her. 9.5 (the "lynching" of the Athenian who advised his fellowcitizens to accept the Persian terms, 479 B.C.)perista/ntes *luki/dhn kate/leusan ba/llontes. The redundant pe/trois adds emphasis: so Ant. 200 puri\ | prh=sai kata/kras. Cp. O. T. 1255 foita=| ga\r h(ma=s e)/gxos e)caitw=n porei=n: 1411 foneu/sat' h)\ qala/ssion | e)kri/yat).

e)/rwt' e)s to/nd), the conjecture of Papageorgius (see cr. n.), is, I think, almost certain. The MS. change supposed is of the slightest kind, and such as continually occurs in our MSS.: while e)/rwtos tou=d) cannot be defended as either (a) gen. of connection, "helping in regard to this desire," or (b) possessive gen. with w)felw=n as=eu)erge/ths, "helper of this desire." See Appendix.

pe/pwn. The metaphor is not directly from the mellowing of fruit, but from the medical use of the word in ref. to the subsiding of inflammation (as in angry tumours, etc.). Cp. the fig. sense of w)mo/s. So pepai/nesqai Hippocr. 1170 B: Arist. Meteor. 4.3 h( fuma/twn (tumours) kai\ fle/gmatos...pe/pansis: Anthol. Pal. 12. 80
ti/ soi to\ pepanqe\n *)/erwtos
trau=ma dia\ spla/gxnwn au)=qis a)nafle/getai; Hence, too, Tr. 728 o)rgh\ pe/peira.

e)kdramo/nta, had rushed out, run to excess (not, run e)/cw dro/mou, out of the course): 08: cp. Ant. 752 h)= ka)papeilw=n w(=d' e)pece/rxei qrasu/s; dost thou e'en go to the length of threatening so boldly?

The gen. might be taken with mei/zw, "a chastiser greater than the sins," i.e. "severer than they merited" (h)\ kata\ ta\ h(mart.); but it is simpler to take it with kolasth/n, "too great a chastiser of the sins." As me/gas qumo/s is "violent anger," so qumo/s which is over-violent can be called mei/zwn kolasth/s. The rhythm of the verse will not permit us to disjoin mei/zw (as by a comma) from kolasth/n.

to\ thni/k' h)/dh, just when that time had come (the art. as in to\ au)ti/ka, "at the moment," Thuc. 2.41). While thnika/de ("at this time of day") was common, the simple thni/ka occurs nowhere else in elass. Attic; it is found, however, in the Alexandrian poets, and in later Greek.
tou=to me/n is answered by de/ (441) instead of tou=to de/, as by e)/peita de/ (Ant. 63), tou=t' au)=qis (ib. 165), ei)=ta (Ph. 1345), tou=t' a)/llo (O. T. 605).

xro/nion, "after all that time,"— repeating the thought with which he had begun (xro/nw| 437). Thuc. 1.141 xro/nioi...cunio/ntes, meeting only at long intervals: 3. 29 sxolai=oi komisqe/ntes, having made a leisurely voyage: 8. 14 a)fiknou=ntai ai)fni/dioi.
e)pwfelei=n with dat. (like e)parkei=n) as Eur. Andr. 677, elsewhere usu. with acc. (Ph. 905, etc.): cp. the poet. dat. with the simple verb, Ant. 560 toi=s qanou=sin w)felei=n.

oi( tou= patro\s tw=| patri/ blends two forms of antithesis,—(1) oi( pai=des tw=| patri/, and (2) oi( tou= *oi)di/podos tw=| *oi)di/podi. The gen. of "origin," tou= patro/s, really a possessive gen., comes in with peculiar force here, as suggesting that the sons belong to the sire. For pa^tro\s...pa_tri/ cp. 883, Ph. 296 a)ll' e)n pe/troisi pe/tron, Ant. 1310 n.
to\ dra=n, on 47.

e)/pous smikrou= xa/rin, for lack of a few words in his defence (a)ntilogi/as braxei/as, schol.). As if one said, "They incurred all this loss for the sake of a petty sum" (i.e. to save it). This is a slight deviation from the ordinary use of e(/neka, ou(/neka (22), e(/kati, xa/rin, in such phrases. Cp. fr. 510. 6
ka)moi\ ga\r a)\n path/r ge dakru/wn xa/rin
a)nh=kt' a)\n ei)s fw=s, would have been brought up, if tears could bring him: Aesch. Pers. 337 plh/qous...e(/kati, if numbers could give victory.

sfin, i.e. they looked on and did nothing: see on au)toi=n 430. The question between a)ei/ (L) and e)gw/ (A) turns on these points. With a)ei/, h)lw/mhn = "continued to wander." He can scarcely mean that, after his expulsion, they might at any time have recalled him, since he regards the new oracle as having given them an opportunity which did not exist before (418). But he may mean that their silence at the moment of his expulsion was the cause of the whole sequel. With e)gw/, h)lw/mhn might mean, "proceeded to wander forth," referring to the moment of expulsion (cp. e)chlauno/mhn 356). But (a) the tense is somewhat awkward here, and (b) e)gw/ is weak unless taken as= "I—their father."

toi=nde, not tai=nde, is the form of the fem. du. as found in Attic inscrr. of c. 450—320 B.C.: cp. Ant. 769 n. But as to the partic., the dual forms in -a, -ain, and those in -e, -oin, seem to have been used concurrently (cp. 1676 n.): I have not, therefore, changed ou)/sain to o)/ntoin with Nauck.
trofa/s: cp. 330, 341.

gh=s a)/deian, a strange phrase (perh. corrupt), must mean, security in regard to the land (where I find myself at any given time), a secure resting-place. Cp. Thuc. 8.64 labou=sai ai( po/leis...a)/deian tw=n prassome/nwn, security in regard to their proceedings. His daughters, so far as they can, give him in exile all that his sons should have given him at Thebes,—(1) maintenance, (2) safety in his movements, (3) generally, the support due from kinsfolk.

Nauck's ste/ghs t) a)/deian seems too suggestive of a fixed home to suit to\n planh/thn (3): Wecklein's koi/ths t' a)/deian makes a detail too prominent in this general acknowledgment. With regard to bla/bhs t) or ka)/ths a)/deian (Blaydes), remark that a)/deia never occurs with a gen. of that against which one is safe. The kai\ before gh=s seems genuine: were it absent, the kai\ before trofa\s must answer to that before ge/nous. And, for a rhetorical passage, gh=s is in some degree confirmed by the assonance with ge/nous.

ge/nous (subjective gen.) e)pa/rkesin=h(\n to\ ge/nos pare/xei. Thuc. 7.34 dia\ th\n tou= a)ne/mou (subject.) a)/pwsin tw=n nauagi/wn (object.)=o(/ti o( a)/nemos a)pwqei= ta\ naua/gia (Thompson, Synt. § 98).
The constr. is, ei(le/sqhn qro/nous, kai\ krai/nein skh=ptra, etc.
krai/nein=(1) to bring a thing to pass, (2) to exercise power, to reign, sometimes with a gen. of the persons ruled (296, 862, etc.).

skh=ptra goes with krai/nein as an almost adverbial cognate accus., "to rule with sceptre": as Ph. 140 skh=ptron a)na/ssetai (pass.) implies a similar skh=ptron a)na/ssw. Rhythm forbids to take skh=ptra with ei(le/sqhn, making krai/nein epexegetic ("so as to rule").
As most editors since Elmsley have allowed, the MS. ou)/ ti ... ou)/te cannot be right. And ou)/ ti ... ou)de/ is clearly more forcible than ou)/te ... ou)/te.

la/xwsi: this verb with gen. is less common than with accus., but is well attested not only in poetry but in prose, as Plat. Legg. 775E timh=s e)a\n th=s proshkou/shs...lagxa/nh| (Krüger 1. 47. 14). It is surely needless, then, to adopt Brunck's tu/xwsi.
tou=de, very rare for tou=d' a)ndro/s as =e)mou=: so th=sde = e)mou= Tr. 305, tw=|de =e)moi/ ib. 1012.
summa/xou predicate; cp. 1482 e)naisi/ou de\ sou= tu/xoimi, and 1486.

The oracle newly brought by Ismene is distinguished from the oracle given to Oedipus himself at Delphi in former years (see on 87). He calls the former her oracle, because she brings it. Both oracles alike concern him. We must not, then, change ta)c to ta)p' ("concerning me").
ta\ e)c e)mou= palai/fata=the earlier predictions which I, on my side, can produce: those which the resources of my knowledge furnish forth.
e)c is appropriate, since they have been so long treasured in his inmost soul. Cp. on 293.

h)/nusen, by bringing him to the grove (cp. 87), in earnest that the requital predicted for the authors of his exile (93) will also come to pass. If h)/nusen were referred to the involuntary crimes of Oed., the connection of thought would be less close.

o(mou= | prosta/tisi (predicative), along with them as your protectors or champions against Theban violence. Oed. is already under the guard of the Eumenides as their i(ke/ths (284): if the Coloniates are loyal to the Eumenides, Attica and he will alike be saved.

In the reading
qe/lhte/ mou
pro\s tai=si tai=s, note these points: (1) a)lkh/n mou poiei=sqai would not mean, "defend me," but rather "defend against me" (cp. on 1524): we must at least have moi. (2) pro/s yields no tolerable sense. u(mei=s, pro\s tai=s qeai=s, "ye, in addition to the goddesses," ranks the Coloniates with, or above, their deities. The gloss su/n, written in L over pro/s (whence it came into other MSS.), was a palliative. Nor could pro/s mean here, "close to their shrine."

For Dindorf's
o(mou=
prosta/tisi it may be urged:—(1) tai=si tai=s is in all MSS., which would be strange if tai=sde tai=s were genuine; while pro\s tai=si tai=s is simply explained by prosta/(t)isi tai=s. (2) A change of prosta/tisi into pro\s tai=si might have produced the change of -q' o(mou= into -te/ mou. (3) After e)mou= in 455 it is easy to dispense with the pronoun.—Cp. O. T. 882 qeo\n ou) lh/cw pote\ prosta/tan i)/sxwn: Tr. 209 *)apo/llwna prosta/tan: Porphyry Antr. Nymph. 12 nu/mfais u(da/twn prosta/tisin.

dhmou/xois, holding, reigning among, your people: cp. O. T. 160 gaia/oxon … | *)/artemin: Aristoph. Eq. 581 *palla\s poliou=xos: Aesch. Th. 69 polissou=xoi qeoi/. But below, 1087 ga=s...damou/xois = the Athenians, 1348 dhmou=xos xqono/s = the king. The word is tinged here with the notion of "deme": cp. 78.

a)lkh
 poei=sqai (for the spelling see 278 n.), a simple periphrasis,= a)lkaqei=n: Thuc. 1.124 poei=sqai timwri/an =timwrei=n (to succour), 2. 94 fulakh
... e)poiou=nto = e)fu/lasson, etc. Distinguish a)lkh
 tiqe/nai tino/s (1524), to create a defence against a thing. A gen. after a)lkh/ as = "succour" must denote (a) the defender, as in *dio\s a)lkh/, or (b) the danger;— not the interest defended.
a)rei=sqe: Ai. 75 n.

The e)mh=s in L (where th=sd' perh. preceded toi=sd') gives some colour to the conjecture th=s (or toi=s) de\ gh=s: yet toi=s d' e)moi=s seems right. Oedipus is following the train of thought in which benefits to Attica are bound up with retribution for his own wrongs (92); and he thus gives the Chorus another pledge that their interest is one with his. With e)moi=s, th=|de me\n is best in 459: with gh=s, th=|de th=| would have been fitter.

e)pa/cios, sc. ei)=. When the verb is thus omitted, the pron. is usu. added: here, the absence of su/ is excused by *oi)di/pous. This form of the voc. has the best MS. authority in some 12 places of Soph., as against 3 which support *oi)di/pou (more often gen.), viz. below, 557, 1346, and O. T. 405 (where see n.).
katoikti/sai: Thuc. 1.138 a)/cios qauma/sai. The pass. inf. is rarer in this constr., as ti/esqai d' a)ciw/tatos Aesch. Ag. 531. Cp. 37.

e)pemba/lleis, you insert yourself in this plea as a deliverer: i.e. to his protest against a breach of their promise (258—291), and his appeal to pity, he adds a promise of benefit to Attica (287, 459). Cp. Her. 2.4 dia\ tri/tou e)/teos e)mbo/limon e)pemba/llousi, they insert an intercalary month every other year: Plat. Crat. 399A polla/kis e)pemba/llomen gra/mmata, ta\ d' e)cairou=men, we insert letters (in words), or remove them.
tw=|de lo/gw| is not instrum. dat., but goes with the verb. Not, "further pledge yourself to be the deliverer": in Ph. 813 e)mba/llw menei=n follows e)/mballe xeiro\s pi/stin.
Editors usu. give either w(s nu=n, qou= nu=n (with L), or w(/s nun...qou= nun (as Elms.). But nun seems best in 465, nu=n in 466.
proce/nei, grant me thy kindly offices (of advice and direction), as a man does in his own State to the foreigners who have made him their pro/cenos (see n. on O. T. 1483).
w(s … telou=nti, in the assurance that I will perform anything required of me: cp. 13.
kaqarmo\n tw=nde daimo/nwn (poss. gen.), such a lustration as belongs to them, is due to them: not object. gen., since kaqai/rein could not stand for i(la/skesqai.

The libation is due (1) as a greeting to the qeoi\ e)gxw/rioi of Attica, (2) as an atonement for trespass on the grove. The words kai\ kate/steiyas pe/don form an independent sentence, and not a second relative clause (as if w(=n were supplied from e)f' a(/s): see on 424.

kate/steiyas: Sappho fr. 95
oi(/an ta\n u(a/kinqon e)n ou)/resi poime/nes a)/ndres
possi\ katastei/boisi, "trample on": here the word suggests the rash violation of the xw=ron ou)x a(gno\n patei=n (37). The v.l. kate/steyas was explained figuratively: "came to the ground as a suppliant," who lays his branch (i(kethri/a), twined with festoons of wool (ste/fh), on an altar: see n. on O. T. 3. Schol.: kaqike/teusas, meta\ i(kethri/wn a)fi/kou: justly adding that the other reading is piqanw/teron. kata/steyon (marg. of L) was a grammarian's attempt to improve on kate/steyas: it would refer to the twigs (483); but a secondary detail of the rite should not be thus forestalled and emphasised.

a)eiru/tou. The rule is that r is doubled when, by inflection or composition, a simple vowel precedes it, but remains single when a diphthong precedes it: hence neo/rrutos, but a)ei/rutos. Through overlooking this distinction, Blaydes follows our MSS. in writing a)eirru/tou. Metre often led the poets to use r instead of rr, as a)mfi^ru/tou (Ai. 134), xrusoru/tous (Ant. 950), au)to/rizos (Babrius fab. 69); and prore/w, not prorre/w, was the regular form, as euphony plainly required. But there is no classical instance of the opposite anomaly.

di' o(si/wn xeirw=n, i.e. after duly washing the hands before entering the sacred precinct. Blood-guilt is not thought of here: if that was in question, kaqarmoi\ xoirokto/noi (Aesch. Eum. 283) would first be needed for Oed. himself: but the Chorus assume that, as he said, he is now eu)sebh/s (287). Washings, or sprinklings, were required before approaching shrines, and for this purpose perirranth/ria were set at the entrances of sacred places. Cp. Hippocr. Morb. Sacr. 2 o(/rous toi=si qeoi=si tw=n i(erw=n kai\ tw=n temene/wn a)podeiknu/menoi, w(s a)\n mhdei\s u(perbai/noi ei) mh\ a(gneu/oi, ei)sio/ntes de\ perirraino/meqa, ou)x w(s miaino/menoi, a)ll' ei)/ ti kai\ pro/teron e)/xomen mu/sos, tou=to a)fagniou/menoi. Lucian Sacrific. 13 to\ me\n pro/gramma/ fhsi mh\ parie/nai ei)/sw tw=n perirranthri/wn o(/stis mh\ kaqaro/s e)sti ta\s xei=ras. So Od. 4.750
a)ll' u(drhname/nh, kaqara\ xroi\+ ei(/mat' e)/xousa, …
eu)/xe' *)aqhnai/h|.
tou=to, adject., but without art. (cp. 1177), an epic use sometimes allowed by the Attic poets, and not rare in Sophocles.
a)kh/raton: Chrysippus ap. Plut. Stoic. repugn. 22 commends Hesiod for enjoining on men that they should respect the purity of rivers and springs, since thence the gods were served (Hes. Opp. 755).

krath=re/s ei)sin: i.e. the priest in charge of the shrine keeps them ready for the use of the worshippers, near the spring in the inner part of the grove (505), from which they were to be filled. The libations to the Eumenides were wineless (100), but they are associated with the mixing-bowl which was regularly used in libations (of wine) to other deities. Bekker Anecd. 274. 3 krathri/zwn: h)/toi to\n oi)=non e)n krath=ri kirnw=n, h)\ a)po\ krath/rwn spe/ndwn. Dem. De Fals. Legat. § 280 spondw=n kai\ krath/rwn koinwnou/s. In Mid. § 53 (in a spurious oracle)i(era\ telei=n kai\ krath=ra kera/sai.
eu)/xeiros: schol. eu)pala/mou. Pind. Ol. 9.111 eu)/xeira, decio/guion, "deft-handed, nimble-limbed," of a wrestler. Lucian Amor. 11 th=s *pracite/lous eu)xeiri/as (v.l. eu)xerei/as).

te/xnh: fr. 161 o(/plois a)rrw=cin, *(hfai/stou te/xnh| (the work of Hephaestus): a common use of the word in later Greek. Cp. Verg. Aen. 5. 359 clipeum...Didymaonis artes. Mixing-bowls were made not only of earthenware, but oft. of gold, silver, or bronze: Achilles had an a)rgu/reon krhth=ra tetugme/non:
...au)ta\r ka/llei e)ni/ka pa=san e)p' ai)=an
pollo/n: e)pei\ *sido/nes poludai/daloi eu)= h)/skhsan (Il. 23.741).

The crater had various forms, some of them local (thus Her. 4.61 speaks of a *le/sbios krhth/r, and 4. 152 of an *)argoliko/s): but the general type was that of a large bowl, supported by a foot with a broad base, and having a handle at each side (cp. Guhl and Koner, p. 150).

kra=t), acc. sing., the "top," i.e. rim, of each krath/r. In Il. 19.93 kra/ata is acc. plur., and Pindar is quoted by Eustath. (Od. 12.1715. 63) as having said tri/a kra=ta (for kra/ata). But in Od. 8.92 kra=ta is sing., and so always in Attic: Soph. has (to\) kra=ta several times as acc., and once as nom. An acc. plur. masc. kra=tas occurs twice in Eur. (Ph. 1149, H. F. 526).

laba\s a)mfisto/mous, handles on each side of the sto/ma, or mouth. The festoon of wool, which was to be wreathed round the rim of the bowl, could be secured to these. Wecklein understands handles which also served as spouts.

qalloi=sin, of olive. kro/kh, from kre/kw, to strike the web, in weaving, with the kerki/s, or rod, is the woof, the warp being sth/mwn: in Pind. Nem. 10.43 malakai=si kro/kais are cloaks of soft woollen texture. So here kro/kai are woollen cloths.

The MS. neara=s seems the right word: with Bellermann, I insert su\, though Wecklein's te is also possible. For the iterated neo- cp. Ant. 157
neoxmo\s nearai=si qew=n
e)pi\ suntuxi/ais. The objection to ge is that it supposes kro/kaisin to be the genus of which mallw=| is a species. mallo/s, however, means, not a woollen texture, but a fleece of wool, flocks of which were to be made into a festoon (ste/fos) for the brim of the krath/r, like that which the suppliant put on his i(kethri/a (O. T. 3). new/rous is tempting, but elsewhere means "recent," "fresh" (730, El. 901), not "young." The drawback to Dindorf's nealou=s is the sense. nealh/s in class. Attic meant not young, but fresh as opp. to exhausted: Xen. Cyr. 8.6.17 paralamba/nein tou\s a)peirhko/tas i(/ppous kai\ a)nqrw/pous kai\ a)/llous pe/mpein nealei=s. Plat. Polit. 265B neale/steroi o)/ntes (we shall travel better) while we are fresh. Aristoph. fr. 330 e(/ws nealh/s e)stin au)th\n th\n a)kmh/n is an isolated line, but the word seems to have the same sense there. Nicander Alexipharmaca 358 (circ. 150 B.C.) is the first writer quoted for nealh/s as = "young."

labw/n, sc. au)to/n: cp. Tr. 1216 ( didou/s ): Aristoph. Av. 56 su\ d' ou)=n li/qw| ko/yon labw/n (in O. T. 607 labw/n is not similar): Il. 7.303 dw=ke ci/fos a)rguro/hlon—su\n kolew=| te fe/rwn kai\ e)u+tmh/tw| telamw=ni. The guardian of the grove (506) would supply the mallo/s.

to\ d' e)/nqen, rare for to\ e)nqe/nde, to\ e)nteu=qen, but cp. Aesch. Ag. 247 ta\ d' e)/nqen ou)/t' ei)=don ou)/t' e)nne/pw. Here prob. adverbial: cp. Ph. 895 ti/ dh=t' a)\n drw=|m' e)gw\ tou)nqe/nde ge;
poi= tel., to what conclusion am I to bring the rite? Thus far it has been all preparation. see on 227.

xoa\s xe/asqai. xoai/ were offered to the gods of the under-world (cp. 1599), or to the dead (Ant. 431), as spondai/ to the gods above. loibai/ usu.=spondai/, but=xoai/ in El. 52 (to the dead). So Aesch. Eum. 107 xoa\s a)oi/nous, of the Eumenides. The midd. verb as Od. 10.518 ( xoh\n xei=sqai ), and Aesch. Pers. 219 xrh\ xoa\s | gh=| te kai\ fqitoi=s xe/asqai. The verb with cogn. acc. gives solemnity, as in qusi/an qu/ein, sponda\s spe/ndein, etc.

pro\s prw/thn e(/w, not meaning, of course, that the time must be dawn. On the contrary it was an ancient custom that sacrifices to the xqo/nioi and to the dead should not be offered till after midday: Etym. M. 468 a)po\ de\ meshmbri/as e)/quon toi=s kataxqoni/ois, and in Aesch. Eum. 109 Clytaemnestra speaks of sacrificing to the Eum. by night, w(/ran ou)deno\s koinh\n qew=n.

The schol. here says that persons performing expiatory rites (e)kqu/seis) or purifications (kaqarmoi/) faced the East (as the region of light and purity), quoting El. 424 f., where Electra h(li/w| | dei/knusi tou)/nar, and Cratinus e)n *xei/rwni (the title of the comedy was *xei/rwnes, Bothe, Frag. Com. p. 47): a)/ge dh\ pro\s e(/w prw=ton a(pa/ntwn i(/stw kai\ la/mbane xersi\ | sxi=non mega/lhn,—the squill being used in purifications.

Statues of gods were oft. set to face the East (Paus. 5.23.1, etc.): also, victims about to be sacrificed (Sen. Oed. 338). Cp. the precept of Zoroaster "to face some luminous object while worshipping god" (Max Müller, Chips 1. 175). Conversely, in pronouncing solemn curses the priests faced the West,—waving red banners: [Lys.] In Andoc. § 51 sta/ntes kathra/santo pro\s e(spe/ran kai\ foiniki/das a)ne/seisan.

krwssoi=s here=krath=rsin. The word is fitting, since the krwsso/s was more esp. used for water (Eur. Ion 1173, Cycl. 89), though also sometimes for wine (Aesch. fr. 91 krwssou\s | mh/t' oi)nhrou\s mh/t' u(dathrou/s), also for oil,—or as a cinerary urn. Guhl and Koner (p. 149) think that the krossos resembled the u(dri/a, which, like the ka/lpis, was a bulky, shortnecked vessel, oft. seen in the vase-paintings as borne by maidens on their heads when fetching water.
oi(=s by attract. for ou(/s.
xe/w delib. aor. (rather than pres.) subjunct.

phga/s: here, strictly the gushing of the water from the bowl. From each of the three bowls he is to pour a xoh/. The first and second bowls are to be filled with the spring water only; and from each of these he is to make a libation without emptying the bowl. The third bowl is to contain water sweetened with honey; and, in making the libation from this, he is to empty it.

trissa/s might be distributive, "three from each bowl" (as the number nine recurs in 483); but in the xoh/ to the dead in Od. 10.519, at least, there are only three pourings, viz. of (1) hydromel, (2) wine, (3) water.
to\n teleut. (krwsso/n) as if e)/kxeon, not xe/on, were understood: cp. Menander fr. 461 to\n xoa= | e)kke/xukas, you have emptied the pitcher.

qw= has raised needless doubts. The operator is to fetch water from the spring in the grove (469), fill the bowls which he will find ready, and place them in a convenient position for the rite. From the distinction just drawn between the first two bowls and the third, Oed. surmises that the contents of the latter are not to be of precisely the same nature as those of the others. He asks, then,— "With what shall I fill it, before placing it beside the other two,—preparatory to beginning the rite?"

meli/sshs=me/litos: schol. a)po\ ga\r tou= poiou=ntos to\ poiou/menon, quoting the Erastae (fr. 160) glw/sshs meli/sshs tw=| katerruhko/ti. So porfu/ra (the purple-fish)=purple, e)le/fas=ivory, xelw/nh =tortoise-shell.
prosfe/rein infin. for imper., as esp. in precepts or maxims: cp. 490, O. T. 1466 ai(=n moi me/lesqai, 1529 mhde/n' o)lbi/zein.
mela/mfullos, overshadowed by dense foliage. Pind. P. 1. 27 *ai)/tnas e)n melamfu/llois...korufai=s, Ar. Th. 997 m. t' o)/rh da/skia.
au)th=|, sc. e)n th=| gh=|, locative dat. (411).

e)c a)mfoi=n xeroi=n, perh. laying them with each hand alternately, beginning and ending with the right, or lucky, hand. The olive-branches symbolise the fruits of the earth and of the womb, for the increase of which the Eumenides were esp. prayed, since they could blight it: Aesch. Eum. 907
karpo/n te gai/as kai\ botw=n e)pi/rruton
a)stoi=sin eu)qenou=nta mh\ ka/mnein xro/nw|,
kai\ tw=n brotei/wn sperma/twn swthri/an.
e)peu/xesqai, "over" the rite, to complete it: the prayer was to be said while the twigs were being laid; hence tiqei/s, not qei/s.
tou/twn (for the gen. cp. 418), sc. tw=n litw=n:

me/gista, neut. pl. without subject, instead of me/giston (cp. 495): Ai. 1126 di/kaia ga\r to/nd' eu)tuxei=n...; Thuc. 5.14 a)du/nata ei)=nai e)fai/neto...polemei=n: Eur. Or. 413 ou) deina\ pa/sxein deina\ tou\s ei)grasme/nous.
*eu)meni/das: see on 42.

e)c, properly with ref. to the inner spring of the feeling, but here almost="with": cp. O. T. 528 e)c o)mma/twn d' o)rqw=n te ka)c o)rqh=s freno/s. Slightly different is e)k qumou=,="from my heart" (Il. 9.343).
to\n i(ke/thn: cp. 44, 284.

swth/rion="with a view to swthri/a",—leaving the hearer to think of that which Oed. gives, and also of that which he receives. swth/rios is nowhere definitely pass., as=sw=s, "saved"; for in Aesch. Cho. 236 spe/rmatos swthri/ou is the seed which is to continue the race. Hence it is usu. taken here as="fraught with good for us," with ref. to his promise, swth=r' a)rei=sqe (460). That idea is present, but does not exclude the other.

su/ t), not su/ g), is right. The constr. is su/ te au)to\s ai)tou=, kai\ (ai)tei/sqw) ei)/ tis a)/llos a)nti\ sou= (ai)tei=tai). This is to be the prayer, both if thou thyself prayest, and if another prays for thee. In such statements the conjunctive te... kai/ is equally admissible with the disjunctive ei)/te...ei)/te. Cp. 1444: Eur. Hec. 751 tolma=n a)na/gkh ka)\n tu/xw ka)\n mh\ tu/xw.

a)/pusta: schol. a)nh/kousta (cp. on 130). Hence, he adds (quoting Polemon of Illium, circ. 180 B.C.), the hereditary priests of the Eumenides were called *(hsuxi/dai. Their eponymous hero, *(/hsuxos, had an h(rw=|on between the Areiopagus and the W. foot of the acropolis, and to him, before a sacrifice, they offered a ram. Priestesses of a like name, serving the Eumenides, are mentioned by Callimachus fr. 123
nhfa/liai kai\ th=|sin a)ei\ melihde/as o)/mpnas (barley cakes)
lh/|teirai kai/ein e)/llaxon *(hsuxi/des.

mhku/nwn, "making loud": a sense found only here (cp. 1609). In makro\n a)u+tei=n (Hom.), h)xei=n (Plat.), etc., the idea of "loud" comes through that of "heard afar." The schol. perh. understood here, "loud and long," for on a)/pusta he says, a)nti\ tou=, h)re/ma kai\ sunto/mws.
a)fe/rpein=imperat. (481).

a)/strofos: so in Aesch. Cho. 98 Electra debates whether, after pouring her mother's offering at Agamemnon's grave, she shall turn away,—
kaqa/rmaq' w(/s tis e)kpe/myas, pa/lin
dikou=sa teu=xos, a)stro/foisin o)/mmasin. In Theoc. 24. 92 Teiresias directs that the ashes of the serpents which would have strangled the infant Heracles shall be cast beyond the borders by one of Alcmena's handmaids: a)\y de\ ne/esqai | a)/streptos. Verg. Ecl. 8. 101
Fer cineres, Amarylli, foras, rivoque fluenti
Transque caput iace, neu respexeris. Ov. Fasti 6. 164 Quique sacris adsunt respicere illa vetat.
parastai/hn, as thy friend and helper: cp. Ai. 1383 tou/tw| ga\r … | mo/nos pare/sths xersi/n.
prosxw/rwn, who therefore can judge best (cp. 12).

o(dwta/, plur., as Ant. 677
ou(/tws a)munte/' e)sti toi=s kosmoume/nois,
kou)/toi gunaiko\s ou)damw=s h(sshte/a: Thuc. 1. 118 e)pixeirhte/a e)do/kei ei)=nai: cp. 485, 1360.
lei/pomai, pass., "I am at a disadvantage"; usu. with gen. of thing, as El. 474 gnw/mas leipome/na sofa=s, or person, Tr. 266 tw=n w(=n te/knwn lei/poito.
e)n: O. T. 1112 e)/n te ga\r makrw=| | gh/ra| cuna/|dei: Ph. 185 e)/n t' o)du/nais ...limw=| t' oi)ktro/s. Only here at the end of a verse: cp. on 265 to/ ge | sw=m).

du/nasqai (without sw/mati), of bodily strength: cp. the speech of Lysias *(upe tou= a)duna/tou ("For the Invalid"), or. 24 § 13 ou) ga dh/pou to
 au)to
 u(mei=s me
 w(s duna/menon (as being able-bodied) a)fairh/sesqe to\ dido/menon, oi( de\ w(s a)du/naton o)/nta klhrou=sqai kwlu/sousin: so ib. § 12 w(s ei)mi\ tw=n duname/nwn. mhd' for mh/q' is a necessary correction here. Cp. 421.

a)rkei=n … parh=|. The thought is: "I have trespassed on the grove of the Eumenides, and it might be doubted whether such deities would accept the atonement from any hand but my own. Nay, I believe that they regard the intention rather than the outward details. If my deputy approaches the shrine in a loyal spirit, the offering will be accepted—yes, would be accepted, not on behalf of one man alone, but of many." Clemens Alex. Strom. 5. 258, after quoting Isaiah i. 16, "Wash you, make you clean," cites verses ascribed (though wrongly) to Menander, among which are,
qew=| de\ qu=e dia\ te/lous di/kaios w)/n,
mh\ lampro\s w)\n tai=s xlamu/sin w(s th=| kardi/a|. Porphyry De Abstin. 2. 19 quotes an inscription from a temple at Epidaurus,
a(gno\n xrh\ nhoi=o quwde/os e)nto\s i)o/nta
e)/mmenai: a(gnei/h d' e)sti\ fronei=n o(/sia. Cp. the frequent sentiment that the poor man's offering, if pious, is welcome (Eur. fr. 940, Hor. Carm. 3. 23. 17, etc.).

a)ll' e)n ta/xei ti. Bornemann's toi for the MS. ti has been adopted by some of the best critics; but it seems scarcely appropriate here. For ti cp. Ant. 1334
me/llonta tau=ta: tw=n prokeime/nwn ti xrh\ | pra/ssein.
di/xa. With g' a)/neu the g' is intolerable, and L's d' a)/neu points to a confusion between an original di/xa and a gloss a)/neu.
telou=sa, in its ceremonial sense: cp. O.T. 1448 o)rqw=s tw=n ge sw=n telei=s u(/per (perform the funeral rites).
to\n to/pon: bou/lomai de\ maqei=n tou=to— i(/na xrh/sei me e)feurei=n to\n to/pon. The position of the krh/nh (470) had not been indicated.

xrh=stai by crasis from xrh\ e)/stai, xrh/ being a subst., "need." This is the view of H. L. Ahrens. If it can hardly be considered certain, it is at least highly probable; and therefore I do not now place in the text (as in the 1st ed.) my conjecture xrh/sei, a fut. of xrh/ which occurs in Her. 7.8 pa/nta tina\ u(me/wn xrh/sei parei=nai, and Plat. Legg. 809B poi=a kai\ ti/na metaxeiri/zesqai xrh/soi tro/pon (v.l. xrh/sei). See Appendix.—
tou=to, resuming the object (to\n to/pon), with emphasis: Tr. 457 n.
a)/lsous, gen. after to\ e)kei=qen, as after to\ (or ta\) e)p' e)kei=na, ta\ e)pi\ qa/tera, ta\ pro\s borra=n, etc.

e)/poikos, here, "one who dwells close to" the grove, — hardly, on the xw=ros ou)k oi)khto/s (39); though the guardians of sacred a)/lsh sometimes dwelt within them, as Maron in Apollo's grove (Od. 9.200), and the priest in Athena Kranaa's grove at Elatea (Paus. 10.34.7). Elsewhere e)/poikos usu. = "immigrant": so El. 189 (as = "alien"). In Aesch. PV 410 e)/poikon … *)asi/as e(/dos means the Greek settlers in Asia.
*)antigo/nh, su\ d): El. 150 *nio/ba, se\ d' e)/gwge ne/mw qeo/n. Cp. 1459.
ou)d) ei) ponei= tis, dei==ei) kai\ p. t., ou) dei=. When A and nearly all other MSS. have ponei=, L's ponh= (sic) surely does not warrant ponh=|. Cp. on 1443.

div2.head: 510-548: Commos
div2.p: A kommo/s, which divides the first e)peiso/dion into two parts (254— 509, 549—667). For the metres, see Metrical Analysis. (1) 1st strophe, 510—520 =1st antistrophe, 521—532. (2) 2nd strophe, 533—541=2nd antistrophe, 542 —550.

div3.p:
kei/menon … e)pegei/rein. Eur. El. 41
eu(/dont' a)\n e)ch/geire to\n
*)agame/mnonos
fo/non, he would have aroused the slumbering memory of Agamemnon's murder. Plat. Phileb. 15C mh\ kinei=n kako\n eu)= kei/menon ("Let sleeping dogs lie").
Mekler's w(/ra me (for e)/ramai) would give a closer correspondence between strophe and antistrophe: see on 523.

ti/ tou=to; "What means this?" Cp. 46 ti/ d' e)sti\ tou=to; He is startled and disquieted. He shrinks from all cross-questioning on the past, as from a torture (cp. 210). We lose this dramatic touch if we construe ti/ tou=to (e)/rasai puqe/sqai) as a calm query,—"What is this that thou wouldst learn?"
ta=s: for the gen. ("concerning"), cp. on 355.

a)po/rou fanei/sas: because the horror of the discovery consisted in relationships which could not be changed: O. T. 1184 f.
fu/s t' a)f' w(=n ou) xrh=n, cu\n oi(=s t'
ou) xrh=n o(milw=n, ou(/s te/ m' ou)k e)/dei ktanw/n.
a(=| cune/stas, with which you were brought into conflict,—with which you became involved: Her. 9.89 limw=| susta/ntas kai\ kama/tw|. Thuc. 4.55 cunestw=tes...nautikw=| a)gw=ni.

ta=s sa=s a(\ pe/ponq'. The objection to pointing at sa=s and understanding e)sti/ with a)naidh= (as Herm. proposed) is that a)noi/ch|s requires an object. We should then have to understand a)lghdo/na. The conject. ta=s sa=s, pe/pon, e)/rg' a)naidh= has found undeserved favour. The address pe/pon occurs about 18 times in Homer and the hymns, and always marks familiarity: there is a touch of household intimacy in it, as when Polyphemus says to his ram, krie\ pe/pon (Od. 9.447). It is absurdly out of place here (cp. 521 w)= ce/noi, 530 w)= cei=n)): w)= fi/ltate, at 465, is different.
e)/rg' was inserted in the MSS. to explain that a)naidh= referred to his own acts.
to\ polu\ kai\ mhdama\ lh=gon a)/kousma xrh/|cw a)kou=sai o)rqo/n (predic.):
polu\, on 305.
mhdama\ (neut. plur. adv.) with causal force, being such as does not cease.
lh=gon, of rumour: O. T. 731 hu)da=to ga\r tau=t), ou)de/ pw lh/cant' e)/xei.
a)/kousma, anything heard,—sometimes (unlike a)kro/ama) in a bad sense, Arist. Pol. 7.17 a)pelau/nein a)po\ tw=n a)kousma/twn kai\ tw=n o(rama/twn a)neleuqeri/as.
ste/rcon, be patient of my request, yield to it: cp. 7.

ka)gw\ (for kai/ cp. 53) ga\r (pei/qo- mai soi/), for I comply with thee as to all that thou cravest (by allowing him to await the coming of Theseus, and by instructing him in the rites of the grove: cp. 465).

I read h)/negk' ou)=n kako/tat),... h)/negk' a)e/kwn. h)/negkon was, indeed, the ordinary form of the aor. in the older Attic, as inscriptions show, in which h)/negka occurs first about 360 B.C. (Meisterhans, p. 88); but h)/negka is proved by metre in El. 13 and Eur. Ion 38. ou)=n is suitable, when he is reluctantly proceeding to unfold his story in answer to their pressing demand.
h)/negk) emphasises his ruling thought, his great plea— that he has been a sufferer, not a doer (267).

kako/tat), the misery of his two involuntary crimes. h)/negkon ... h)/negk) might possibly stand, but would be harsh. There is nothing to offend in a)e/kwn me\n... tou/twn de/, meaning—"The agent was not free—the acts were not voluntary."

In the MS. reading, h)/negkon—h)/negkon a)/kwn me/n, a)/kwn is wrong, since metre requires u- (cp. 510). With Bothe's e(kw\n the sense would be:—"I have endured misery through acts which were my own, indeed: but not one of them was done knowingly." The objections to this are insuperable. (1)

qeo\s i)/stw must clearly have been preceded by the mention of some point to which he could appeal in an extenuation of his deed,—not by an admission, such as e(kw/n expresses. (2) h)/negkon e(kw/n, in the supposed sense, is utterly at variance with the language and the whole tone of the play. Cp. 239 e)/rgwn | a)ko/ntwn: 964 h)/negkon a)/kwn: 977 pw=s a)\n to/ g' a)=kon pra=gm' a)\n ei)ko/tws ye/gois; he asks, speaking of his own deeds.

It would be a subtlety foreign to Sophocles to make Oedipus say that he had acted e(kw\n when he did not act fronw=n (271), ei)dw/s (273), cuniei/s (976). Il. 4.43 kai\ ga\r e)gw\ soi\ dw=ka e(kw\n a)e/konti/ ge qumw=| is irrelevant:— Zeus there says to Hera "I have given thee this (thy pleasure touching Troy) of my free will" (since neither god nor man could compel Zeus), "yet against mine own wish."

au)qai/reton. Heinrich Schmidt keeps this reading (Compositionslehre lxxx), which is not metrically irreconcileable with 512 o(/mws d' e)/ramai puqe/sqai (see Metrical Analysis). It is possible, indeed, that au)qai/reton is, as Hermann thought, corrupt: but no probable correction of it has been suggested. We cannot regard as such e)qelhto/n (not found), e)qelhmo/n (used in masc. by Hes.), or e)qe/lhmon (used in masc. by Plut.): e(ko\n e)/rgon: or pro/dhlon. Note, on the other hand, O. T. 1231 au)qai/retoi (phmonai/).
kaka=| eu)na=|, instr. dat., rather than dat. in appos. with a)/ta|. ga/mwn a)/ta, ruin coming from a marriage, like do/khsis lo/gwn, suspicion resting on mere assertions, O. T. 681.
h)= matro/qen … e)plh/sw; Didst thou fill thy bed with a mother, dusw/= numa (prolept.) so as to make it infamous? (I should not take matro/qen with dusw/n. only, "infamous from a mother.")

matro/qen is substituted for matro/s by a kind of euphemism: that was the quarter from which the bride was taken. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 840 ou)d' a)pei=pen | patro/qen eu)ktai/a fa/tis (the curse of Oed. on his children). The aor. midd. e)plhsa/mhn is used by Hom., Her., etc., and (in comp. with e)n) by Attic writers: it seems needless then to write e)/plhso (from epic aor. e)plh/mhn) with Bergk. The notion of "filling" is perh. tinged with that of "defiling" (a)napimpla/nai, a)na/plews). The tone of the passage is against rendering "satisfied," as if le/ktra=le/ktrwn e)piqumi/an. Nauck's e)pa/sw rests on Hesychius I. 1316 e)pa/sw: e)kth/sw: *ai)sxu/los *prwtei= saturikw=|. The aor. of pa/omai "to acquire" occurs elsewhere only in part. pasa/menos (Theogn., Theocr., etc.).
a)kou/ein: cp. 141.
The constr. is au(=tai de\ e)c e)mou= du/o me\n pai=de, du/o d' a)/ta … a)pe/blaston etc.

e)c e)mou=, sprung from me: no partic. need be supplied, since the verb a)pe/bl. follows: cp. 250 o(/ ti soi fi/lon e)k se/qen (sc. e)sti/). The cry with which the Chorus interrupts him (pw=s fh/s;) marks their perception (from his first words au(=tai de/ etc.) that the children of that marriage were before them.
au(=tai … pai=de: cp. Plat. Laches p. 187 A au)toi\ eu(retai\ gegono/te.
Poetical Greek idiom would join koina=s with w)di=nos rather than with matro/s. Cp. Aesch. Eum. 325 matrw=|on a(/gnisma ku/rion fo/nou: Ant. 793 nei=kos a)ndrw=n cu/naimon.
koina=s = which bore me also.

sai/ t' ei)/s' a)/r). The Chorus have known all along that Oed. had married Iocasta, and also that he was the father of the girls (cp. 170, 322); but they are supposed to learn now for the first time that Iocasta was their mother. In the earlier versions of the Oedipus-myth (as in the Odyssey) Iocasta bears no issue to Oed.; his children are borne by a second wife, Euryganeia. The Attic poets seem first to have changed this (see Introd. to O. T. p. xv). The Chorus would say: "Thine, then, they are by a double tie, at once as children and...as sisters?" but Oed. takes out of their mouths the second name which they shrink from uttering, and utters it himself with terrible emphasis.
koinai/, by the same mother: cp. O. T. 261 n.: so Ant. 1 koino\n au)ta/delfon … ka/ra.
patro\s with a)delfeai/ only.
i)w/ — i)w\ dh=ta: cp. El. 842 *h*l. feu=. *x*o. feu= dh=t'.
ge after muri/wn marks assent.

e)pistrofai/ refers to the revival of the pangs in his soul by this questioning. His troubles are likened to foemen who, when they seem to have been repulsed and to be vanishing in the distance, suddenly wheel about and renew their onset. Cp. 1044 dai+/wn | a)ndrw=n e)pistrofai/. Philopoemen made his cavalry o)cei=s pro/s te ta\s kat' ou)lamo\n e)pistrofa\s kai\ perispasmou\s (wheeling sharply in troops) kai\ ta\s kaq' i(/ppon e)pistrofa\s kai\ kli/seis (wheeling and changing direction singly), Plut. Ph. 7.

a)/last' e)/xein, unforgettable (dreadful) to endure: e)/xein epexeg.: see on 231. Trag. borrowed the word from the epic pe/nqos a)/laston (Il. 24.105), a)/laston o)du/romai (Od. 14.174): so Aesch. Pers. 990 ( kaka\ ) a)/lasta stugna\ pro/kaka. Cp. 1482. Wecklein's o)xei=n (Od. 7.211 o)xe/ontas o)i+zu/n) is perh. right: cp. Aesch. P.V. 143 froura\n a)/zhlon o)xh/sw.
ou)k e)/reca: cp. 267, 521.
ti/ ga/r; "Why, what else?" if not e)/reca. Cp. 542.
dw=ron. The turanni/s was dwrhto/n, ou)k ai)thto/n (O. T. 384),—the reward pressed on him by Thebes for worsting the Sphinx; and with the throne he received the hand of Iocasta.

The MS. e)pwfe/lhsa, "I benefited," or "succoured" (cp. 441), cannot be right. The sense required is mh/pote w)/felon e)cele/sqai, "would that I had never won!" cp. Ph. 969 mh/pot' w)/felon lipei=n | th\n *sku=ron: Od. 11.548 w(s dh\ mh\ o)/felon nika=n: where mh/, though thus placed, belongs to the infinitives. See Appendix for the attempted explanations of e)pwfe/lhsa, and for some proposed emendations.

I would read the partic. e)pwfelh/sas (which the iambic metre allows), and take e)cele/sqai as the absol. infin. expressing a wish:—"and would that I had never received that choice gift from the city, for having served her." For this absol. infin., with the subject in the nominative, cp. Aesch. Cho. 363:
*h*l. mhd' u(po\ *trwi+/as
tei/xesi fqi/menos, pa/ter,
met' a)/llwn dourikmh=ti law=|
para\ *skama/ndrou po/ron teqa/fqai,
pa/ros d' oi( ktano/ntes nin ou(/tws damh=nai. Orestes had uttered the wish that Agamemnon had fallen in war at Troy: ei) ga\r u(p' *)ili/w| | … kathnari/sqhs (345 ff.). Electra modifies it: "I would not have had thee to perish e'en beneath Troy's walls, and to be buried by Scamander's stream; would rather that the murderers (Aegisthus and Clytaemnestra) had first been slain as they slew thee!" Here the MSS. have te/qayai and damh=nai. On the latter the schol. has lei/pei to\ o)/felon, and on the former lei/pei to\ w)/feles, thus indicating the certain correction of H. L. Ahrens, teqa/fqai. Cp. also Od. 24.376
ai)\ ga/r, *zeu= te pa/ter kai\ *)aqhnai/h kai\ *)/apollon,
oi(=os *nh/rikon ei(=lon, …
toi=os e)w/n toi xqizo\s e)n h(mete/roisi do/moisin,
teu/xe' e)/xwn w)/moisin, e)festa/menai kai\ a)mu/nein, "Ah, would to father Zeus,...that, such as I was when I took Nericus,...in such might, and with armour on my shoulders, I had stood by thee, and had been aiding thee, yesterday in our house!" A criticism by Wecklein is discussed in the Appendix.

e)cele/sqai, ironical as if the bride were a ge/ras e)cai/reton. The act. aor. is used of the army choosing a prize (out of the booty) for a chief, Il. 16.56 kou/rhn h)\n a)/ra moi ge/ras e)/celon ui(=es *)axaiw=n: the midd. aor., of the victor choosing his own prize, as Tr. 244 tau/tas | … e)cei/leq' au(tw=| kth=ma. Here po/leos e)cele/sqai is not "to choose for myself out of the city," but "to receive as a choice gift from the city."

ti/ ga/r; "how then?"—marking the transition from the topic of the marriage to that of the parricide. (Cp. Quid vero?) Others refer the words merely to du/stane, i.e. "for what else art thou?" This seems tame. Cp. 538.

deute/ran, sc. plhgh/n: Her. 3.64 kairi/h|...tetu/fqai: Ant. 1307 ti/ m' ou)k a)ntai/an | e)/paise/n tis; Xen. Anab. 5.8.12 a)ne/kragon...w(s o)li/gas pai/seien. no/son, accus. in apposition: of mental anguish, as O. T. 1061 a(/lis nosou=s' e)gw/.

e)/xei de/ moi … pro\s di/kas ti: but (the deed) has for me (dat. of interest) something from the quarter of justice; i.e. it has a quality which tends to place it on the side of justice,—to rank it among justifiable deeds. Cp. O. T. 1014 pro\s di/khs ou)de\n tre/mwn (n.). The subj. to e)/xei is to\ e)/rgon, easily supplied from e)/kanon.— This is better than to take e)/xei as impers. with pro\s di/kas as=e)ndi/kws, ti being then adv.: "my case is in some sort just."
ti/ ga/r; sc. e)/xei: "why, what justification has it?"

The MSS. give kai\ ga\r a)/llous e)fo/neusa k.t.l. Hermann's a(lou\s (for a)/llous) must mean either (1) "caught," as in a net, by fate, or (2) "caught" by Laïus and his men, in the sense of, "driven to fight for life." Neither sense is tolerable. Campbell suggests, "I murdered, and was convicted of the murder," saying that a(lou\s e)fo/neusa=e(a/lwn foneu/sas. This is as if one said in English, "Having been hanged, he did the murder." To a)gnw/s the short a^ would be a grave objection: Soph. has the first a long thrice in a)/gnoia, twice in a)gnoei=n, once in a)gnw/s (O. T. 681), and short never: even in au)to/gnwtos (Ant. 875) the o is long. Porson's a)/nous could hardly mean, "without understanding" merely in the sense of "unwittingly." The word means "silly," "foolish" (Ant. 281), and should here mean, "in folly," which is not an apt sense.

And all these corrections, confined to a)/llous, leave a blot. After e)fo/neusa, kai\ w)/lesa is intolerably weak. Mekler's kai\ ga\r a)/n, ou(\s e)fo/neus), e)/m' a)pw/lesan brings out the point on which Oed. insists, and to which the words no/mw| kaqaro/s (548) refer,—viz. that, in slaying, he was defending his own life. Cp. 271. After he had returned the blow of Laïus, the attendants set on him (see on O. T. 804—812). The change of e)fo/neus' e)/m' a)pw/lesan into e)fo/neusa kai\ a)pw/lesa (or ka)pw/lesa) would have been easy if e)fo/neusa/ m' a)pw/lesa had once been written. In Ai. 794 L has w(/ste k' w)di/nein instead of w(/ste m' w)di/nein. Cp. Her. 1.11 (Gyges was forced) h)\ to\n despo/tea a)pollu/nai h)\ au)to\n u(p' a)/llwn a)po/llusqai.

no/mw| … kaqaro/s, because he had been first struck by Laïus, and was acting in self-defence. Plat. Legg. 869C a)delfo\s d' e)a
 a)delfo
 ktei/nh| e)n sta/shsi ma/xhs genome/nhs h)/ tini tro/pw| toiou/tw|, a)muno/menos a)/rxonta xeirw=n pro/teron, kaqa/per pole/mion a)poktei/nas e)/stw kaqaro/s: kai\ e)a
 poli/ths poli/thn w(sau/tws, h)\ ce/nos ce/non. Rhadamanthus himself was cited as the author of this rule (Apollod. 2. 4. 9).
e)s to/d' h)=lqon, to this plight: cp. on 273.
kai\ mh\n introducing the new person: cp. 1249: so Ant. 526, 1180, 1257: Ai. 1168, 1223: El. 78, 1422.
o)mfh/n, his message. Usu. of a divine or oracular voice (102), but see 1351: Pind. fr. 53 o)mfai\ mele/wn su\n au)loi=s: Eur. Med. 174 mu/qwn t' au)daqe/ntwn | … o)mfa/n (the words of the Chorus).
e)f' a(sta/lh=e)pi\ (tau=ta) e)f' a(\ e)sta/lh (cp. 274); "that by a small service he might win a great gain" (72).

The skopo/s, who did not know the name of Oed., could describe the traces of wounds about the sightless eyes, and brought the mysterious message (72). Theseus then set out, surmising who it was. Meanwhile the name of Oed. had become known at Colonus (222), and wayfarers who met Theseus raised his surmise into certain knowledge. Cp. on 299 ff.

e)/n te, answered by tanu=n q'. The simplest statement would have been e)/gnwka/ se, a)kou/wn e)/n te tw=| pa/ros xro/nw| tanu=n te. Then, by repetition of the partic., we get e)/gnwka, a)kou/wn te e)n t. p. xr., a)kou/wn te tanu=n. And then, by insertion of a new verb, e)/gnwka/ te/ se, a)kou/wn e)n t. p. xr., e)cepi/stamai/ te a)kou/wn tanu=n. Cp. the insertion of h(gei=tai in 351, and n.
e)/gnwka/ s), "I have recognised thee"—explaining how he is able to greet him by name: not merely, "I recognise thee."

e)/gnwka is used (1) with a distinctly perfect sense: Lys. or. 17 § 6 tau=ta...pro/teron e)gnw/kate h(me/tera ei)=nai: Dem. or. 3 § 10 o(/ti...dei= bohqei=n...pa/ntes e)gnw/kamen. (2) More like a present, yet always with a certain emphasis, "I have come to know": Aristoph. Eq. 871 e)/gnwkas ou)=n dh=t' au)to\n oi(=o/s e)stin; "have you found out what sort of man he is?" Her. 1.207 ei) d' e)/gnwkas o(/ti a)/nqrwpos ei)=s (if you have realised that you are a mortal): Plat. Rep. 366C i(kanw=s...e)/gnwken o(/ti a)/riston dikaiosu/nh (he has thoroughly apprehended). So Pind. P. 4. 287, Aesch. PV 51, o(doi=s, the coming of Theseus from Athens (Campb. understands the coming of Oed. to Attica): the plur. of one journey, as Ant. 226 o(doi=s kuklw=n e)mauto\n ei)s a)nastrofh/n, and so El. 68: otherwise below, 1397.

a)kou/wn, after the same word in 551, is awkward. The ga/r in 555 might also suggest that the partic. here referred to the evidence of his own eyes, not to further hearsay by the way. leu/sswn is intrinsically the best substitute that has been proposed: but it has no palaeographic probability. I had thought of i(ka/nwn (cp. 576). Doubtless it is possible that a)kou/wn was not a corruption of a similar form, but merely an inadvertent repetition from 551.

For a)kou/wn it may be pleaded that the sense is at least quite intelligible, and that ancient writers, even the most artistic, were less careful than moderns in avoiding such repetitions of single words. Cp. 631 e)kba/loi, 636 e)kbalw=: 638, 640 h(du/: 966, 969 e)pei/: 1000, 1003 kalo/n, 1004 kalw=s: 1123, 1129: 1451, 1459: 1487 f.: O. T. 517 fe/ron, 519 fe/ronti, 520 fe/rei: ib. 1276, 1278 o(mou=: Ant. 73, 76 kei/somai: Ai. 1201, 1204 (te/ryin).

skeuh/: cp. 1597 ei)=t' e)/luse duspinei=s stola/s. The misery of his aspect impresses Creon (747), as it had impressed the Chorus (150). His garb, then, can hardly have announced a prince, though it may have indicated a Theban. Probably the reference is simply to the tale of long and destitute wanderings which his wretched apparel told (cp. 3 ff.).
du/sthnon, as showing how he had blinded himself: cp. 286.

o)/nq' o(\s ei)=, i.e. *oi)di/pous. Cp. O. T. 1036 w)noma/sqhs...o)\s ei)= (Oedipus). Od. 24.159 ou)de/ tis h(mei/wn du/nato gnw=nai to\n e)o/nta, "and not one of us could tell that he was the man" (Odysseus).
)pere/sqai aor. (used by Thuc., Plat., etc.); the fut. e)perh/somai was also Attic; but the Attic pres. was e)perwta/w, e)pei/romai being only Ionic.

e)pe/sths, hast presented thyself. Plat. Symp. 212D e)pisth=nai e)pi\ ta\s qu/ras. Esp. of a sudden and unlooked-for appearance before a place (as in war): Isocr. or. 9 § 58 mikrou= dei=n e)/laqen au)to\n e)pi\ to\ basi/leion e)pista/s.
po/lews … e)mou= t;, obj. gen.: ti/ prostre/pwn po/lin e)me/ te (cp. on 49).

a)
 … tu/xois … e)cafistai/mhn: "strange would be the fortune which (=I cannot imagine what fortune) you could succeed in mentioning, from which I would hold aloof": another way of saying ou)k a)
 tu/xois l. toiau/thn, o(poi/as e)cafistai/mhn. When the optat. with a)/n stands in the antecedent clause (as a)
 tu/xois here), the optative without a)/n stands in the relative clause: cp. Il. 13.343
ma/la ken qrasuka/rdios ei)/h,
o(\s to/te ghqh/seien: he would be right bold of heart, who should then rejoice. Aristoph. Nub. 1250
ou)k a)
 a)podoi/hn ou)d' a)
 o)bolo
 ou)deni/,
o(/stis kale/seie ka/rdopon th
 kardo/phn. Such a relative clause is equivalent to a protasis with ei) and optat.: as here to ei) au)th=s a)fistai/mhn. Cp. Goodwin, Moods and Tenses, § 62. 4. Carefully distinguish the opt. o(
...ye/caimi at 1172, where see n.

pra=cin, "fortune," not "action." The sing. pra=cis in Soph. usu. means "fortune," Ai. 790, Tr. 152, 294: while the sense of "action" usu. belongs to the plur. pra/ceis, as below, 958, O. T. 895, Ant. 435. There is only one Sophoclean exception each way: in Tr. 879 pra=cis = "mode of doing," and in Ant. 1305 pra/ceis="fortunes." Cp. Aesch. PV 695 pe/frik' e)sidou=sa pra=cin *)iou=s. Her. 3.65 a)pe/klaie th\n e(wutou= prh=cin.

ce/nos. Aethra, the mother of Theseus, was daughter of Pittheus, king of Troezen, where Theseus was brought up, in ignorance that his father was Aegeus, king of Athens. On arriving at manhood, he received from his mother the tokens of his birth (su/mbola, gnwri/smata) —the sword and sandals left at Troezen by Aegeus—and set out for Attica. There he slew the sons of his uncle Pallas, who were plotting against his father, and was acknowledged by Aegeus as his heir (Plut. Thes. 4-13).

kai\ w(s h)/qlhsa plei=sta ei(=s a)nh/r. With plei=stos the strengthening ei(=s or ei(=s a)nh/r is esp. freq.: Tr. 460 plei/stas a)nh\r ei(=s: Eur. Her. 8 plei/stwn mete/sxon ei(=s a)nh/r: Xen. Cyr. 8.2.15 qhsaurou\s...plei/stous e(ni\ a)ndri/: Thuc. 8.40 mia=| ge po/lei...plei=stoi. Cp. O. T. 1380 n. With the MS. xw)/s tis the w(s before e)paideu/qhn must be repeated before h)/qlhsa, the constr. being, kai\ (w(s) h)/qlhsa, w(s a)nh/r tis plei=sta h)/qlhse. This has been compared with Xen. Anab. 1.3.15 a)/rxesqai e)pi/stamai w(/s tis kai\ a)/llos ma/list' a)nqrw/pwn (where some would omit the last two words),—a passage not properly similar: and here a)nh/r becomes very weak. Elmsley, adopting xw)/ti, took a)nh/r as=ei(=s a)nh/r, quoting [Eur.] Rhes. 500 kai\ plei=sta xw/ran th/nd' a)nh\r kaqubri/sas (where, for kai\, read ei(=s with Hermann): and Eur. Hec. 310 qanw\n u(pe\r gh=s *(ella/dos ka/llist' a)nh/r, where we should perh. read ka/llist' a)nh\r ei(=s *ella/dos qanw\n u(/per.
e)pi\ ce/nhs: 184

kinduneu/mat) (acc. of cognate notion), his encounters, on his way overland from Troezen to Attica, with various foes,—the robbers Periphetes, Sinis, Sciron, Procrustes,—the sow of Crommyon, —etc.; his slaying of the Minotaur in Crete;—his fighting on the side of the Lapithae against the Centaurs, etc. In all his aqloi Theseus was depicted by the Attic legend as the champion of the oppressed,—a)dikh/swn me\n ou)de/na, tou\s de\ u(pa/rxontas bi/as a)munou/menos (Plut. Thes. 7).

e)n tw)mw=| ka/ra|, at the risk of my own life, e)n denoting the stake: Eur. Cycl. 654 e)n tw=| *kari\ kinduneu/somen: Plat. Lach. 187 B mh\ ou)k e)n tw=| *kari\ u(mi=n o( ki/ndunos kinduneu/htai, a)ll' e)n toi=s ui(e/si. Cp. Od. 2.237 parqe/menoi kefala/s, at the risk of their lives (as 3. 74 yuxa\s parqe/menoi): Il. 9.322 ai)e
 e)mh
 yuxh
 paraballo/menos polemi/zein. The irreg. dat. ka/ra| from nom. ka/ra again Ant. 1272, El. 445 (v.l. ka/ra), fr. 141. 2: it occurs first in Theogn. 1018, the Homeric dat. being ka/rhti or krati/.

ce/non with u(pektrapoi/mhn as well as suneksw/|zein: cp. Plat. Phaedo 108B th\n a)ka/qarton (yuxh\n)...a(/pas feu/gei te kai\ u(pektre/petai. The notion is that of retiring (u(po-) out of the path to avoid meeting a person. Soph. has the act. with gen., Tr. 549 tw=n d' u(pektre/pei po/da.
suneksw/|zein, to help in extricating: Antiph. or. 5 § 93 to\ sw=ma a)peirhko\s h( yuxh\ sunece/swsen.
a)nh\r=qnhto/s: Ant. 768 fronei/tw mei=zon h)\ kat' a)/ndr' i)w/n. Cp. 393.
dou==h)\ soi/: Ant. 74 plei/wn xro/nos | o(\n dei= m' a)re/skein toi=s e)kei= tw=n e)nqa/de: Thuc. 1.85 e)/cesti d' h(mi=n ma=llon e(te/rwn.
to\ so\n gennai=on: shown in sparing Oed. the painful task of introducing himself and telling his story.

parh=ken (aor. of pari/hmi) closely with w(/ste … dei=sqai: "has graciously permitted that there should be," etc. Cp. 591: El. 1482 a)lla/ moi pa/res | ka)\n smikro\n ei)pei=n: Ant. 1043 ( ou)d' w(\s ) qa/ptein parh/sw kei=non. (Not, "has so passed the matter on,""so left it.") For w(/ste cp. Her. 6.5 ou) ga\r e)/peiqe tou\s *xi/ous w(/ste e(wutw=| dou=nai ne/as: and see on 970.
w(/ste e)moi\ dei=sqai, so that there is need for me, braxe/a fra/sai, to say but little.

dei=sqai midd., impersonal,=dei=n. (It could not be pass., with braxe/a for subject.) Bekker Anecd. p. 88. 21 dei=tai: a)nti\ tou= dei=: a)pelqei=n me dei=tai. The only example (so far as I know), besides our passage, is Plat. Meno. 79C dei=tai ou)=n soi pa/lin...th=s au)th=s e)rwth/sews. And presently: h)\ ou) dokei= soi pa/lin dei=sqai th=s au)th=s e)rwth/sews; In the former place, while the best MSS. have dei=tai, some have dei=. (I do not add deh/sesqai, ib. E, since that may be personal.) If, however, the text can be trusted, these are clear instances, for it would be very forced to supply o( lo/gos. In Her. 4.11 deo/menon (as if=de/on) is plainly corrupt: Buttmann's de/oi me/nontas may be right. If we altered e)moi\ to e)mou=, the subject to dei=sqai would be to\ so\n gennai=on. But then dei=sqai would mean "requests," rather than "requires," of me.

For the dat. e)moi/ with dei=sqai (instead of e)me/ as subj. to fra/sai) cp. Eur. Hipp. 940 qeoi=si prosbalei=n xqoni\ | a)/llhn deh/sei gai=an: and see on 721. Wecklein takes e)moi/ with parh=ken, permisit mihi, but the interposed w(/ste forbids this. The conject. soi (for e)moi/), "to say little to thee," would be very weak.

Theseus has named Oed. (557) and Laïus (553), but not Thebes. A knowledge of the stranger's country was implied by the rest. Cp. on 205. gh=s could stand with h)=lqon (cp. O. T. 152 *puqw=nos e)/bas, Ph. 630 new\s a)/gonta), but is more simply governed by a)po\.

xw( lo/gos dioi/xetai, and the statement is at an end. o( lo/gos is the explanation due from Oedipus after sending for Theseus. Cp. Eur. Suppl. 528
(Theseus to the Thebans) ei) ga/r ti kai\ pepo/nqat' *)argei/wn u(/po,
teqna=sin, h)mu/nasqe polemi/ous kalw=s,
ai)sxrw=s d' e)kei/nois, xh( di/kh dioi/xetai: i.e., if you have been wronged, you have had satisfaction, "and the cause is closed."

die/rxetai (L) is certainly corrupt. It ought to mean, "the discussion is being carried through," rather than, "our conference draws to an end" (as Campbell, comparing diecelh/luqa pa/nta, diech=lqon dia\ makrou= lo/gou, which are not similar). And if o( lo/gos means "our comerence," then Oedipus is assuming that his petition has only to be stated in order to be granted.
tou=t' au)to\ marks eagerness: O. T. 545 *o*i. ...baru/n s' eu(/rhk' e)moi/. *k*r. tou=t au)to\ nu=n mou prw=t' a)/kouson w(s e)rw=.

ta\ de\ | ke/rdh: cp. 265. Doederlein understands, ta\ de\ ke/rdh ma=llon a)gaqa/ e)stin h)\ kalh/ e)stin h( morfh/. Schneidewin and Wecklein adopt this forced explanation, which is condemned both by par' au)tou= and by the absence of the art. with morfh/.

pou, i.e. so far as Oed. can conjecture the purpose of Apollo. He could not be sure that the close of his life would immediately follow on his arrival at the grove. The promised sign of the end had not yet been given (94).

poi/w|, sc. xro/nw|, asks with surprise for some further definition of the vague xro/nw| ma/qois a)/n. Theseus naturally assumes that the blessings are to come in the lifetime of Oedipus. And if not now, he asks, then in what contingency? The answer startles him.

prosfora\, offering, present. Theophrast. Char. XXX (=XXVI in my 1st ed.) it is like the ai)sxrokerdh/s, gamou=nto/s tinos tw=n fi/lwn kai\ e)kdidome/nou qugate/ra pro\ xro/nou tino\s a)podhmh=sai, i(/na mh\ pe/myh| prosfora/n (a wedding-present). Cp. 1270.
dhlw/setai, pass.: see O. T. 672 n.

i.e. "You ask for the last offices which piety can render: you do not ask me for protection during your lifetime." Through the oracle (389), of which Theseus knows nothing, a grave in Attica had become the supreme concern of Oedipus.
ta\ d' e)n me/sw| is governed by lh=stin i)/sxeis as=e)pilanqa/nei (see on 223), no less than by poei=. To make ta\ d' e)n m. an accus. of respect would suit the first verb, but not the second.
di' ou)deno\s poei=, a solitary instance of this phrase (instead of ou)deno\s or par' ou)de\n poei=sqai), perh. suggested by the use of the prep. in such phrases as dia\ fulakh=s e)/xw ti, etc.

e)ntau=qa ga/r, "yes" for there,— in that boon (e)n tw=| qa/ptesqai),—those other things (ta\ e)n me/sw|) are brought together for me: i.e. if you promise that I shall eventually be buried in Attica, you cannot meanwhile allow me to be forcibly removed to the Theban frontier. He is thinking of protection against Creon's imminent attempt (399). sugkomi/zomai, to collect or store up for oneself, was, like sugkomidh/, esp. said of harvesting (Xen. Anab. 6.6.37), and that notion perhaps tinges the word here.

e)n braxei= in sense=braxei=an: "this grace which you ask of me lies in a small compass" (not, "you ask me this favour in brief speech"). The adverbial e)n braxei= does not go with the verb, but is equiv. to a predicative adj. agreeing with xa/rin. Such phrases imply the omission of the partic. w)/n: so 29 pe/las ga\r a)/ndra to/nd' o(rw=: Ph. 26 tou)/rgon ou) makra\n le/geis (the task which you set is not distant): El. 899 w(s d' e)n galh/nh| pa/nt' e)derko/mhn to/pon. For braxei= cp. 293, Plat. Legg. 641B braxu/ ti...o)/felos.

ge mh/n, however: Aesch. Ag. 1378 h)=lqe, su
 xro/nw| ge mh/n. The only ground for a(gw
 rather than a)gw
 is the trace of x from the first hand in L: neither reading is intrinsically better than the other. Cp. El. 1491 lo/gwn ga ou) | nu=n e)stin a(gw/n, a)lla\ sh=s yuxh=s pe/ri. The word a)gw/n is so far ambiguous that it does not necessarily mean a physical contest, but can mean an issue or crisis (Lat. discrimen, momentum). Plat. Rep. 608B me/gas...o( a)gw
...to\ xrhsto
 h)\ kako
 gene/sqai.

po/tera. Oed. has said, "If you pledge yourself to keep me in Attica, a serious issue will be raised." Theseus:— "Do you speak of the relations between your sons and me?" You mean that they will contest my right to retain you?

e)ggenw=n (Hartung) may be right; but the MS. e)kgo/nwn is not condemned by the evident fact that Theseus does not yet know of the quarrel between the father and the sons (599). It is enough if he knows the sons to exist: they would represent the claim of the e)ggenei=s.

ka)mou=: the MS. h)\ )mou= is certainly wrong. Theseus does not ask—"Will the issue be serious for your kinsmen, or for me?" but, "In what quarter will the issue arise?" Cp. 606 ta)ma\ ka)kei/nwn. The conject. h)\ tou= (=ti/nos) is tame: and ka)mou= has the advantage in clearness, by indicating the second party to the a)gw/n.

Kayser's a)/nac, xrh/|zousi (for a)nagka/zousi) is exactly what the sense requires, and is fairly near to the MS. reading, while the latter is (I think) certainly corrupt. The verse must not be considered alone, but in close connection with 590, and with the whole context. It has been rendered:—(1) "They are for compelling (my protectors) to convey me to Thebes." But the ellipse of tina/ before komi/zein is intolerable. And the protectors could not be required to do more than surrender him. Therefore it is no cure to propose ei)/ s) (for kei=s)) a)nagka/sousi/ me. To read se for me merely shifts the first difficulty, and leaves the second. (2) "They are for putting constraint on me, so as to carry (me) to Thebes." Such an epexegesis by the act. infin. is impossible here. Who could write a)nagka/zei se a)/gein e)kei=se, meaning, "he is forcing thee, so as to take (thee) thither"? (3) komi/zein has been taken as="to return,"=komi/zesqai. This needs no comment. We want either: (1) instead of komi/zein, a word="to return"; but katelqei=n is very unlikely, and no other substitute is obvious: or (2) instead of a)nagka/zousi, a word = "they wish, seek." That the fault lies in a)nagka/zousi is very strongly suggested by 590, where L has a)ll' ei) qe/lont' a)/n g), evidently corrupted, by dittographia of g), from a)ll' ei) qe/lonta/ g), which L2 has. This gives a clear and fitting sense, if in 589 we read a)/nac, xrh/|zousi/ me. All the trouble, for the MSS. and for the edd., has arisen from a)nagka/zousi. Hence (1) Goebel, a)ll' ou) qelo/ntwn, "but if they do not wish thee" (feu/gein): (2) Reisig, a)ll' ei) qe/lonta/s g), "but what if it be not seemly for thee to shun them when willing (to receive thee)?" Both these are forced. Campbell supplies ei) bou/lointo komi/zein to explain qe/lonta, keeping L's qe/lont' a)/n: but a)/n can stand with a partic. only when the latter is equiv. to an apodosis, as it is in 761. So far as the tense of a)nagka/zousi is concerned, a change to the fut. is no gain: it is the pres. of tendency or intention. But the whole mention of compulsion or violence is premature in 589. Oed. leads very gently up to the disclosure of his sons' unnatural conduct (599).
ou)de\ soi\: while they, on their part, call you home, for you, on yours, exile is not desirable,—if, indeed, their offer is agreeable to you (i.e. if you have no repugnance to Thebes).

ou)de/ is here the negative counterpart of de/ in apodosis: i.e. as we can say, ei) qe/lonta/ se e)kei=noi kata/gousi, soi\ de\ katelqei=n kalo/n, so also ou)de\ soi\ feu/gein kalo/n. The same resoluble quality of ou)de/ is seen in its use for a)ll' ou) (Il. 24.25). Cp. on 591.
feu/gein=fuga/di ei)=nai, rather than "to shun them."
a)ll' ou)d) presupposes his refusal, and justifies it: "Nay, neither did they consider my wishes."

pari/esan, "concede," sc. e)moi\ katelqei=n, cp. 570: not e)me\ ei)s th\n po/lin, "admit" (in which sense usu. of allowing armies to enter territory, or the like: Eur. Suppl. 468 *)/adraston e)s gh=n th/nde mh\ parie/nai).
qumo\s d). de/ sometimes corrects or objects: O. T. 379 (n.) *kre/wn de/ soi ph=m' ou)de/n ("Nay").
cu/mforon: the neut. as often in maxims, when the masc. or fem. subj. is viewed in its most general aspect: Eur. Or. 232 dusa/reston oi( nosou=ntes: cp. O. T. 542 n.

ma/qh|s mou, heard (the matter) from me. Distinguish the gen. with e)kma/qw in 114, where see n. Cp. El. 889
a)/kouson w(s maqou=sa/ mou
to\ loipo\n h)\ fronou=san h)\ mw/ran le/gh|s. O. T. 545 manqa/nein d' e)gw\ kako\s | sou=.

cumfora\n euphemistic (O. T. 99 n.): cp. 369 th\n pa/lai ge/nous fqora/n. Here, as there, ge/nous="race," not "birth." Theseus supposes Oed. to mean that the hereditary curse has fallen on him with especial weight.
e)rei=s, "will you mention," i.e. "do you allude to": cp. Ph. 439 ff. *f*i. a)naci/ou me\n fwto\s e)cerh/somai... *n*e. poi/ou ge tou/tou plh\n *)odusse/ws e)rei=s; *f*i. ou) tou=ton ei(=pon.
