mei=zon h)\ kat' a)/nqr., gravius quam pro mortali: Xen. Mem. 4.4.24 belti/onos h)\ kat' a)/nqrwpon nomoqe/tou: Thuc. 7.75 mei/zw h)\ kata\ da/krua e)pepo/nqesan. If the woe to which he alludes is something greater than the calamity of his house, then it must be superhuman.
nosei=s: see on 544.
Instead of ou)k e)/sti moi katelqei=n pote, we have e)/sti moi katelqei=n mh/pote, since e)/sti moi="my doom is," zhmi/a kei=tai/ moi.—Cp. on 407.
pemyai/aq' (cp. on 44), summon to themselves: Eur. Hec. 977 ti/ xrh=m' e)pe/myw to\n e)mo\n e)k do/mwn po/da;
w(/st' oi)kei=n di/xa, if it is understood that you cannot live with them in Thebes.

w(/ste introduces the condition: Thuc. 1.28 e(toi=moi de\ ei(=nai kai\ w(/ste a)mfote/rous me/nein kata\ xw/ran, the Corcyreans said that they were also ready (to make an armistice) under the condition that each party should remain where they were.
e)canagka/sei. There is no reason for changing fut. to pres. here. The oracle had been given (388), but its effect was to come. Cp. 1179.

o(/ti, as if poi=on xrhsmo\n a)kou/santas had preceded. Not with dei/santas: verbs of fearing are sometimes followed by w(s or o(/pws with indic. (instead of mh/ with subj.), as in El. 1309; but by o(/ti only as="because."
th=|de … xqoni/, locative dat., not instrum. (as schol. u(po\ tau/ths th=s xqono/s). Oed. interprets Ismene's less explicit statement (411).

ta)ma\ ka)kei/nwn=ta\ e)ma\ kai\ (ta\) e)kei/nwn: cp. 588: Tr. 1068: Eur. El. 301 tu/xas barei/as ta\s e)ma\s ka)mou= patro/s: Phoen. 474 tou)mo/n te kai\ tou=d). Poetry tolerated such omission of the second art. even when the subjects were sharply opposed: El. 991: Aesch. Ag. 324 kai\ tw=n a(lo/ntwn kai\ krathsa/ntwn. Theseus cannot foresee any cause which should trouble the ancient amity between Athens and Thebes (619, 632).

gh=ras … katqanei=n: for the inf. without art. co-ordinated with another noun cp. Il. 10.173
e)pi\ curou= i(/statai a)kmh=s
h)\ ma/la lugro\s o)/leqros *)axaioi=s h)e\ biw=nai.

sugxei=, confounds, ruins, effaces: Tr. 1229: Her. 7.136 sugxe/ai ta\ pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn no/mima: esp. fitting here, since applicable to breach of treaties, Il. 4.269 su/n g' o(/rki' e)/xeuan | *trw=es.
pagkrath\s, epithet of sleep in Ai. 675, and of fire in Ph. 986. Cp. Shaksp. Sonnets 63, 64 "With Time's injurious hand crush'd and o'erworn":..."by Time's fell hand defaced."

fqi/nei me
 … fqi/nei de\, epanaphora, as 5, O. T. 25 fqi/nousa me
 … | fqi/nousa d', 259 e)/xwn me
...e)/xwn de/.

gh=s has been needlessly suspected: here, as in the great speech of Ajax (Ai. 669—677), human destiny is viewed in relation to the whole order of nature. Cp. Tennyson, Tithonus 1 "The woods decay, the woods decay and fall, The vapours weep their burthen to the ground, Man comes and tills the field and lies beneath, And after many a summer dies the swan."
blasta/nei, comes into existence, —like the other natural growths which wax and wane: fig. of customs and institutions in Ant. 296 no/mism' e)/blaste, El. 1095 e)/blaste no/mima.

pneu=ma is not here the wind of fortune (as Eur. H. F. 216 o(/tan qeo/s soi pneu=ma metabalw\n tu/xh|), but the spirit which man breathes towards man, and city towards city; the spirit of friendship or enmity. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 705
(where, though fortune is meant, the dai/mwn is a person), dai/mwn
lh/matos e)n tropai/a| xroni/a| metal-
lakto\s i)/sws a)\n e)/lqoi
qalerwte/rw|
pneu/mati. Ant. 136 (Capaneus menacing Thebes) bakxeu/wn e)pe/pnei | r(ipai=s e)xqi/stwn a)ne/mwn. Eur. Suppl. 1029 au)/rais a)do/lois | gennai/as … yuxa=s. So pnei=n me/nos, ko/ton, e)/rwta etc.

be/bhken, is set (cp. 1052). Though (e.g.) pneu=ma fi/lion be/bhken e)n a)ndra/sin could not mean, "a friendly spirit is steady among men," yet pneu=ma tau)to\n be/bhken can mean, "the same spirit is set," i.e. blows steadily. Cp. Aristoph. Ran. 1003
h(ni/k' a)\n to\ pneu=ma lei=on
kai\ kaqesthko\s la/bh|s.
po/lei ethic dat., on the part of.
toi=s me\n ga\r h)/dh, for some men at once (i.e., after but a brief friendship), for others, later.

h)/dh is here used as au)ti/ka more often is: cp. Aesch. Cho. 1020 mo/xqos d' o( me\n au)ti/x), o( d' h(/cei. No relationship between men or states is permanent, for the feelings with which they regard each other are liable to change,—from liking to dislike, yes, and back again to liking.

kau)=qis fi/la, by completing the circle, completes the picture of inconstancy. Nauck has quite needlessly suspected these two vv. The maxim ascribed to Bias of Priene (c. 550 B.C.), filei=n w(s mish/sontas kai\ misei=n w(s filh/sontas (Arist. Rhet. 2.13, Cic. De Amic. 16. 59 ita amare oportere ut si aliquando esset osurus), is paraphrased in Ai. 679 ff., with the comment, toi=s polloi=si ga\r | brotw=n a)/pisto/s e)sq' e(tairei/as limh/n: cp. ib. 1359 h)= ka/rta polloi\ nu=n fi/loi kau)=qis pikroi/.

*qh/bais dat. of interest, if she has her relations with you in a peaceful state. eu)hmerei=. eu)hmeri/a=either (1) "fine weather," eu)di/a, as Arist. Hist. An. 6. 15 o(/tan eu)hmeri/as genome/nhs a)naqermai/nhtai h( gh=, or (2) "prosperity." The verb is always figurative. Arist. Pol. 6.8. 22 tai=s sxolastikwte/rais kai\ ma=llon eu)hmerou/sais po/lesin.

kalw=s has been censured as faulty after the eu)= in eu)hmerei=: its defenders might have quoted Eur. fr. 886 to\n kalw=s eu)dai/mona. It means, "satisfactorily," "as we could wish," and is represented by the word "all" in the version above.
ta\ is better than to\ for the MS. te (or te\).

to\ pro\s se/ would be rather, "so far as her relation to you is concerned" (acc. of respect),—when ta\ nu=n should be read in 616. This would make the welfare of Thebes more prominent than the mutual amity.
o( muri/os: cp. Ai. 646 o( makro\s ka)nari/qmhtos xro/nos.

teknou=tai. The midd. was more commonly used of the mother, the act. of the father (though converse instances occur); the midd. is used figuratively, as here, in Aesch. Ag. 754 (o)/lbos), Eur. I. T. 1262 (xqw/n).

i)w/n, as it proceeds. Cp. El. 1365
pollai\ kuklou=ntai nu/ktes h(me/rai t' i)/sai
ai(\ tau=ta/ soi dei/cousin.

e)n ai(=s, in the course of which: i.e. at some moment in them. So Ant. 1064
ka/tisqi mh\ pollou\s e)/ti
tro/xous a(millhth=ras h(li/ou telw=n
e)n oi)=si … a)moibo\n a)ntidou\s e)/sei.

deciw/mata, pledges given by placing one's right hand in another's: the word occurs only here, and in Athen. 159 B (poet. anonym.) w)= xruse/, deci/wma ka/lliston brotoi=s, gift most welcome to men. deciou=sqai is only "to greet" or "welcome": but decia\s dido/nai kai\ lamba/nein, etc., suggested the phrase here. Cp. Il. 2.341 spondai/ t' a)/krhtoi kai\ deciai/, h(=|s e)pe/piqmen. In Eur. Suppl. 930 Theseus says of Polyneices, ce/nos ga\r h)=n moi, as if alluding to hereditary ceni/a between the royal houses. Cp. 632.
do/rei diaskedw=sin, they will "throw their pledges to the winds" by an armed invasion of Attica. Cp. Ant. 287 no/mous diaskedw=n, to make havoc of laws.

do/rei (instead of the more freq. dori/) is required by metre also in 1314, 1386, Aristoph. Pax 357 su
 do/rei su
 a)spi/di, Vesp. 1081 (where MSS. cu
 dori\ cu
 a)spi/di),—all iambic or trochaic. The phrase in Ar. came from Soph. *mw=mos, acc. to Choeroboscus 376. 19. Cp. [Eur.] Rhes. 274 ma/xas pro\ xeirw=n kai\ do/rh basta/zomen,—a plur. on the analogy of this dat. sing.

i(/n) could mean, "at a place where," at the grave (see on 411), but is better taken as="in which case," "when," since the moment of rupture (diaskedw=sin) would not be the battle at Colonus, but the preceding declaration of war.
eu(/dwn (cp. on 307), in contrast with the fierce combatants on the ground above him.

yuxro\s … qermo
, here of the physical contrast between death and life; but in Ant. 88 qermh
 e)pi\ yuxroi=si kardi/an e)/xeis, "thy heart is hot on chilling deeds" (krueroi=s). Simonides 120. 5 nu=n d' o( me
 e)n po/ntw| kruero\s ne/kus. For the idea of the buried dead draining the lifeblood of their foes cp. El. 1420 pali/rruton ga ai(=m' u(pecairou=si tw=n | ktano/ntwn oi( pa/lai qano/ntes.
safh/s, true (as a prophet): 792: O.T. 1011 tarbw= ge mh/ moi *foi=bos e)ce/lqh| safh/s. So fi/los safh/s, a proved friend (Eur. Or. 1155), grammateu\s safh/s an accurate scribe (Aesch. fr. 348).

ta)ki/nhta,=a(\ mh\ dei= lo/gw| kinei=sqai (see 1526), secrets which should be allowed to rest beyond the veil: so Ant. 1060 o)/rseis me ta)ki/nhta dia\ frenw=n fra/sai, the secrets locked in my soul. (Cp. Gray: "No farther seek his merits to disclose, Or draw his frailties from their dread abode.")

e)/a me ( e)n tou/tois ) a(\ ( le/gwn ) h)rca/mhn, leave me (permit me to cease) at the point where I began (the prayer for an Attic home). Cp. Il. 9.97 e)n soi\ me\n lh/cw, se/o d' a)/rcomai. Here we cannot well evolve a)f) or e)c w(=n from e)n oi(=sin: nor, again, would e)n oi(=s h)rca/mhn be idiomatic.

to\ so
 … pisto
 fula/sswn, taking care that thy part is loyally done: cp. O. T. 320 to\ so/n te su\ | ka)gw\ dioi/sw tou)mo/n (thy part): Ai. 1313 o(/ra mh\ tou)mo
 a)lla\ kai\ to\ so/n (thine interest): ib. 99 w(s to\ so
 cunh=k' e)gw/ (thy saying). Both idiom and rhythm are against joining to\ so
 pisto/n as "thy good faith."
ei)/per mh\ yeu/sousi, you will find me helpful,—that is to say, if the gods do not disappoint me.

ei)/per marks the point which must be taken for granted, in order that e)rei=s (626) should hold good: cp. Eur. H. F. 1345
dei=tai ga\r o( qeo/s, ei)/per e)/st' o)/ntws qeo/s (assuming him to be so),
ou)deno/s. Lys. or. 12 § 48 ei)/per h)=n a)nh\r a)gaqo/s, e)xrh=n a)/n, etc. (Cp. Thompson Syntax § 225. 4.)
pa/lai: 287, 459. The Chorus, tempering caution with good-nature, testify that the promise of Oedipus is, at least, not merely a device inspired by the arrival of the King.

e)fai/neto telw=n (without w(s)= "was manifestly intending to perform": e)fai/neto w(s telw=n="appeared as one intending to perform," w(s marking the aspect in which he presented himself to their minds. Ai. 326 kai\ dh=lo/s e)stin w(/s ti drasei/wn kako/n. For the imperf., cp. Aesch. Ag. 593 lo/gois toiou/tois plagkto\s ou)=s' e)faino/mhn, by such reasonings I appeared (was made out to be) in error.
dh=t), "then," a comment on the speech of Oed. rather than on the words of the Chorus, as oft in questions (cp. 602).

e)kba/loi: properly, "cast out of doors," as a worthless thing: hence, "reject," "repudiate": Eur. fr. 362. 45 progo/nwn palaia\ qe/smi' o(/stis e)kbalei=: Plat. Crito 46B tou\s de\ lo/gous, ou(\s e)n tw=| e)/mprosqen e)/legon, ou) du/namai nu=n e)kbalei=n. Others take it literally, "cast out of the land," so that a)ndro\s eu)me/neian toiou=de=a)/ndra eu)menh= toio/nde. But the notion of rashly scorning what is really precious gives more point both here and in 636.
o(/tw|, not o(/tou, is right. Con strue: o(/tw| h( doru/cenos e(sti/a ai)e\n koinh/ e)sti par' h(mi=n, lit., "to whom the hearth of an ally is always common among us":
koinh/, "common," = "giving reciprocal hospitality," which Theseus could claim at Thebes, as Oedipus at Athens.

ai)e/n, i.e. "even if he had not this special claim." This seems better than to take koinh/ as (1) "common to him with other Thebans," (2) "provided by our State," (3) "common to him with us," or (4) "accessible," as Andoc. or. 2 § 147 oi)ki/a koinota/th tw=| deome/nw|. With o(/tou the above version could not stand (since "belongs to him" could not replace "exists for him"), and so we should have to understand, o(/tou h( doru/cenos e(sti/a ai)e\n koinh/ e)sti par' h(mi=n, whose allied hearth (at Thebes) is always regarded among us as open to us ("as a common possession," Campb.): but this seems very forced.

doru/cenos, "spear-friend," is one with whom one has the tie of ceni/a in respect of war: i.e., who will make common cause with one in war. It is applied by Aesch., Soph., and Eur. only to princes or chiefs, with an armed force at their command. Cp. Aesch. Cho. 562 ce/nos te kai\ doru/cenos do/mwn, said by Orestes when he presents himself pantelh= sagh\n e)/xwn: i.e. he comes not merely as the personal ce/nos of the royal house, but as a chief in armed alliance with it. Plut. (Mor. 295 B, Quaest. Gr. 17) asks, ti/s o( doru/cenos; He conjectures that it meant, a ransomed prisoner of war, in his subsequent friendly relation to the ransomer (e)k dorialw/tou doru/cenos prosagoreuo/menos). This is against the usage of the poets, our only witnesses. And the source of the guess is clear. Plutarch was thinking of the verbal compounds, doria/lwtos, dori/kthtos, dori/lhptos, etc. From these he inferred that doru/cenos would mean primarily, "a friend gained through the spear."

Wecklein brackets the whole passage from 632 o(/tw| down to 637 th\n tou=de as "a later addition," because (1) there could be no ceni/a when Oedipus did not even know the name of Theseus (68), and (2) sebisqei\s in 636 is suspicious. On this, see ad loc. As to (1), the ceni/a to which Theseus refers is not a personal friendship, but a hereditary alliance between the royal houses, as in Eur. Suppl. 930 Polyneices (whom he had not seen before) is his ce/nos. Cp. on 619. After Wecklein's excision, we have
ti/s dh=t' a)\n a)ndro\s eu)me/neian e)kba/loi
toiou=de; xw/ra| d' e)/mpalin katoikiw=. This is incoherent.

a)figme/nos, not, "because," but, "while," he has come. Besides his public claim (632), Oed. has two personal claims, (1) as the suppliant of the Eumenides, (2) as a visitor who can make a valuable return to Athens for protecting him.
dasmo/s, usu. "tribute" (O. T. 36, and so in Xen.); here fig., "recompense."

The aor. sebisqei\s only here: sebi/zein 1007, sebi/sasa Ant. 943, sebi/zomai (midd.) Aesch. Suppl. 922. In later Gk. the pass. aor. of seba/zomai was deponent, as Anth. P. 7. 122 ai)/, ai)\ *puqago/rhs ti/ to/son kua/mous e)seba/sqh; It appears rash to deny that e)sebi/sqhn could be so used. The deponent use of e)se/fqhn is attested only by Plat. Phaedr. 254 B ( sefqei=sa ), and Hesych. 1. 1456 e)se/fqhn: e)seba/sqhn, h(su/xasa, h)|sxu/nqhn. *sofoklh=s *daida/lw| (fr. 168 Nauck).
e)kbalw=: cp. 631.

e)/mpolin is Musgrave's certain correction of the MS. e)/mpalin: cp. 1156 soi\ me\n e)/mpolin | ou)k o)/nta, suggenh= de/, not thy fellow-citizen, indeed, but thy kinsman. The word does not occur elsewhere. "I will establish him in the land," says Theseus, "as a member of our State": he who now is a)/polis (cp. 208) shall in Attica have the full protection of our laws.

e)/mpalin has been rendered (1) "on the contrary," i.e. "so far from rejecting him": so the schol., and this version is alone correct: (2) "once more," i.e. renewing the alliance between the states,— Paley: (3) "in return" for his benefits,— Ellendt. Campbell objects that with e)/mpolin "the opposition of the clauses would not be sufficiently marked by de/": but for
de/=a)lla/ cp. Antiph. or. 5 §§ 4, 5 ai)th/somai u(ma=s ou)x a(/per oi( polloi/..., ta/de de\ de/omai u(mw=n: Thuc. 4.86 ou)k e)pi\ kakw=|, e)p' e)leuqerw/sei de\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn parelh/luqa.

se/, the Coryphaeus. Cp. Aesch. Suppl. 955ff., where the king gives the Danaïdes their choice between Argos and a private home apart;
stei/xet' eu)erkh= po/lin
… ei) de/ tis mei/zwn xa/ris,
pa/restin oi)kei=n kai\ monorru/qmous do/mous.
tou/twn ta\ lw=|sta kai\ ta\ qumhde/stata
pa/resti, lwti/sasqe.

ei) de\ to/de — stei/xein met' e)mou=, — h(du/ e)sti — di/dwmi/ soi, tou/twn kri/nanti ( o(po/teron bou/lei ), xrh=sqai ( au)tw=|). For to/d) in appos. with stei/xein cp. Xen. Cyr. 8.4.4 safhni/zesqai de/, w(s e(/kaston e)ti/ma, tou=to e)do/kei au)tw=| a)gaqo\n ei)=nai: Aeschin. or. 2 § 106 to\ mh\ polupragmonei=n h(ma=s tou\s pre/sbeis mhde/n, tou=t' a)gaqo\n u(polamba/nwn ei)=nai. Here to/de similarly follows the word with which it is in appos., though it should properly precede it, as Eur. Phoen. 550 me/g' h(/ghsai to/de, | perible/pesqai ti/mion;

tou/twn partitive gen. with kri/nanti, "having chosen (one) of these things"; cp. O. T. 640
duoi=n dikaioi= dra=n a)pokri/nas kakoi=n,
h)\ gh=s a)pw=sai...h)\ ktei=nai.
di/dwmi … xrh=sqai: cp. Xen. Anab. 3. 4 §§ 41 f. ei) bou/lei, me/ne..., ei) de\ xrh/|zeis, poreu/ou...*)alla\ di/dwmi/ soi, e)/fh o( *xeiri/sofos, o(po/teron bou/lei e(le/sqai.

With ei)/t) e)mou=, the constr. would be, ei)/te met' e)mou= stei/xein (h(du\ au)tw=| e)sti, stei/xein pa/restin), a word expressing consent being evolved from ta/cw. But (1) this is harsher than O. T. 91
ei) tw=nde xrh/|zeis plhsiazo/ntwn klu/ein
e(/toimos ei)pei=n, ei)/te kai\ stei/xein e)/sw (xrh/|zeis), where e(/toimos is more easily fitted to the second clause; though somewhat similar is Eur. Ion 1120
pepusme/nai ga/r, ei) qanei=n h(ma=s (ei)/te katqanei=n Badham) xrew/n,
h(/dion a)\n qa/noimen, ei)/q' o(ra=n fa/os (xrew/n), sc. h(/dion a)\n o(rw=|men. And (2) in proposing the second alternative,—that Oed. should accompany him,—it is more suitable that he should address Oed. himself.
th=|de, "in that sense," i.e. in whichever course you may prefer, h(=| a)\n su\ bou/lh|: cp. 1444: Ant. 1111 do/ca th=|d' e)pestra/fh: El. 1301 o(/pws kai\ soi\ fi/lon | kai\ tou)mo\n e)/stai th=|d'.
cunoi/somai, agree: Antiph. or. 5 § 42 toi=s me\n prw/tois ( lo/gois ) sunefe/reto,... tou/tois de\ diefe/reto.
didoi/hs … eu)=: 1435: O. T. 1081 (tu/xhs) th=s eu)= didou/shs.
do/mous stei/xein: 1769 *qh/bas … | pe/myon: O. T. 1178 a)/llhn xqo/na | dokw=n a)poi/sein.
ei) … h)=n, sc. e)/xrh|zon a)\n do/mous stei/xein.

e)n w(=| ti/ pra/ceis; Cp. O. T. 558
*o*i. po/son tin' h)/dh dh=q' o( *la/i+os xro/non
*k*p. de/drake poi=on e)/rgon; ou) ga\r e)nnow=.
*o*i. a)/fantos e)/rrei … etc.; Ph. 210 *x*o. a)ll' e)/xe, te/knon, *n*e. le/g' o(/ti *x*o. fronti/das ne/as: El. 854 ff. An interruption of this kind serves to bespeak the attention of the audience for a point which the dramatist desires to emphasize.
krath/sw: near the shrine he was to close his life (91), and at his grave the Thebans were to be defeated (411, 621).
me/g' a)\n le/gois dw/rhma,=me/ga a)\n ei)/h dw/rhma o(\ le/geis, it would be a great benefit of which you speak (sc. ei) kratoi=s). Cp. Ant. 218.

th=s sunousi/as, "from your abiding with the people here (at Colonus)": i.e. "You have suggested a strong reason for your staying here, rather than for going with me to Athens." Cp. th=| cunousi/a| in 63. It would be tame, at this stage, to take cunousi/a merely of his presence in Attica. The belief of Theseus in Theban amity (606) has now been shaken by his visitor (620).
th=s s., gen. of source (ultimately possessive): O. T. 170 fronti/dos e)/gxos, a weapon furnished by thought.

ei) soi/ g' | a(/per fh\s e)mmenei=, "yes, if on your part (ethic dat.) the promise (of protection and burial) shall be observed, telou=nti" by your performing it moi for me (dat. of interest). e)mmenei= alone might have meant merely, "if you abstain from withdrawing your promise": telou=nti supplements it, marking that good faith must be shown by deeds. We can say either e)mme/neis oi(=s le/geis or e)mme/nei soi a(\ le/geis: cp. Thuc. 2.2 te/ssara me\n ga\r kai\ de/ka e)/th e)ne/meinan ai( triakontou/teis spondai/: Plat. Phaedr. 258 B e)a\n...e)mme/nh|, if (his proposal) stand good.

to\ tou=de/ g' a)ndr. might be acc. of respect ("as to"), but is more simply taken with qa/rsei: cp. Dem. or. 3 § 7 ou)/te *fi/lippos e)qa/rrei tou/tous ou)/q' ou(=toi *fi/lippon: Xen. Cyr. 5.5.42 eu)w/xei au)tou/s, i(/na se kai\ qarrh/swsin. (Distinguish this acc. with qarsei=n, of confidence in, from the more freq. acc. of confidence against, as qarsei=n ma/xas.) Cp. to\ so/n, 625 n.

w(s kako\n: cp. Eur. Med. 731 ff., where Medea asks Aegeus to clinch his promise with an oath, and he asks, mw=n ou) pe/poiqas; Shaks. Jul. Caes. 2. 1. 129 ff.
Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous,—
...unto bad causes swear
Such creatures as men doubt. pistw/somai. pisto/w is "to make pisto/s": Thuc. 4.88 pistw/santes au)to\n toi=s o(/rkois, when they had bound him by the oaths (iureiurando obstrinxerant): so the pass., Od. 15.435 ei)/ moi e)qe/loite/ ge, nau=tai, | o(/rkw| pistwqh=nai. The midd. expresses "in one's own interest," as here; or reciprocity, as Il. 21.286 xeiri\ de\ xei=ra labo/ntes e)pistw/sant' e)pe/essin.

h)\ lo/gw|, than by word (without my oath). Dem. or. 27 § 54 kai\ marturi/an me\n ou)demi/an e)neba/leto tou/twn o( tau=t' ei)pei=n a)ciw/sas, yilw=| de\ lo/gw| xrhsa/menos [rather e)xrh/sato] w(s pisteuqhso/menos di' e)kei/nwn. Cp. Antiphon or. 5 § 8 quoted on 22. Shaksp., G. of Verona 2. 7. 75 "His words are bonds." —Not, "than in name," i.e. "form," as opp. to e)/rgw|.

tou= ma/list' o)/knos s' e)/xei; not, "what do you fear most?" but, "What, exactly, do you fear?"—a polite way of asking the question. Plat. Gorg. 448D *s*w. a)lla\ ga\r o(\ u(pe/sxeto *xairefw=nti ou) poiei=. *g*o*r. ti/ ma/lista, w)= *sw/krates;

o(/ra me lei/pwn, like his utterances in 653 and 656, is left unfinished, —Theseus striking in: sc. mh\ e)kei/nois prodw=|s. Taken as a sentence, the words could mean only "see that" (not "how") "you are leaving me." The conj. o(ra=n (for dra=n), adopted by Nauck and Wecklein, would be an echo of o(/ra: it is not only quite needless, but bad, because here it would give an angry tone, as such echoes usually do in trag.; see on O. T. 548 f. The case of oi)=sqa...oi)=da 656 is different.

o)knou=nt' a)na/gkh: i.e., o)knou=nta/ me a)na/gkh dida/skein se,—feeling such fear as I do, I am constrained to be thus urgent with you. (Not, "I must thus urge you, since you are slack.") Wecklein's change to o)knei=n g) is unnecessary.
ou)k oi)=sq': Oed. had said nothing of Creon's threatened visit (396).
mh/, not ou), in strong assurance, as with inf. after o)/mnumi, etc.: cp. 281, 797: Ant. 1092 e)pista/mesqa … | mh/pw pot' au)to\n yeu=dos … lakei=n

—660 Many emendations of 658 f. have been proposed, and Wecklein would reject the three verses altogether. To me they seem not only authentic but textually sound. They picture a tumult of passions in the soul, presently quelled by reason. The angry threats and the sobering reason are alike personified. The genuineness of the nominative pollai\ d' a)peilai\ is confirmed by the imagery of the second clause, a)ll' o( nou=s o(/tan. For this animated personification of speech or passion, cp. Aesch. Cho. 845
h)\ pro\s gunaikw=n deimatou/menoi lo/goi
peda/rsioi qrw/skousi, qnh/|skontes ma/thn: Eur. Hipp. 1416
ou)de\ gh=s u(po\ zo/fw|
qea=s a)/timoi *ku/pridos e)k proqumi/as
o)rgai\ kataskh/yousin e)s to\ so\n de/mas. The cognate verb kathpei/lhsan (gnomic aorist), instead of the simple e)/lecan, gives an emphasis like that which the cogn. accus. would give in polloi\ a)peila\s kathpei/lhsan.
qumw=| modal dat., "in wrath-" (not locative, "in the soul"): cp. Plat. Legg. 866D ( e)a\n ) qumw=| … h)=| to\ pepragme/non e)kpraxqe/n: O. T. 405 o)rgh=| lele/xqai.

au(tou= (possessive) ge/nhtai, become its own master, regain its control over passion: cp. Dem. or, 4 § 7 h(\n u(mw=n au)tw=n e)qelh/shte gene/sqai: Plat. Phaedr. 250 A e)kplh/ttontai kai\ ou)ke/q' au(tw=n gi/gnontai. So Her. 1.119 ou)/te e)cepla/gh e)nto/s te e(wutou= gi/netai, "was not dismayed, but mastered his feelings": Dem. or. 34 § 35 ou)k e)nto\s w)\n au(tou=: or. 19 § 198 e)/cw d' au(th=s ou)=sa u(po\ tou= kakou=. Elmsley strangely preferred au)tou=, taking it as adv., "there."
frou=da, there is an end of them: Eur. Tro. 1071 (to Zeus) frou=dai/ soi qusi/ai.
kei/nois (referring to a)/ndres in 653) goes both with e)perr. and with fanh/setai.

kai\ ei) e)perrw/sqh (impersonal) even if courage has come to them deina\ le/gein to say dread things th=s sh=s a)gwgh=s about your removal (for the gen. see on 355: for th=s sh=s as=an objective sou, on 332). The normal phrase would be kei=noi e)perrw/sqhsan, and the use of the impersonal form here is bolder than in the ordinary passive examples (usu. with perf.) such as i(kana\ toi=s...polemi/ois eu)tu/xhtai (Thuc. 7.77). Possibly the common impers. use e)ph=lqe/ moi le/gein ("it occurred to me to say") may have helped to suggest the impers. e)perrw/sqh.

le/gein. An inf., which here depends on the notion e)to/lmhsan, does not elsewhere occur with e)pirrw/nnusqai, but stands with the simple pf. e)/rrwmai as="to be bent on doing" (Lys. or. 13. 31 e)/rrwto...kako/n ti e)rga/zesqai). Whitelaw: "though terrible things were emboldened to the utterance,"—comparing 658 a)peilai\...kathpei/lhsan. But, if the deina/ are personified, do we not then want a stronger word than le/gein?
We cannot read kei=nos, since the pl. is needed. The best solution would be kei/nois de/, kei)/ tis, from which i)/sws kei) might have come through a transposition. But the sarcastic
i)/sws is fitting: cp. Ai. 962 i)/sws toi, kei) ble/ponta mh\ )po/qoun | qano/nt' a)\n oi)mw/ceian.
kei) here where ei) kai\ would be natural (as granting the fact); whereas in 306 the kei) is normal: see O. T. Append. Note 8, p. 296.

to\ deu=ro, instead of to\ metacu/, since pe/lagos suggests plou=s: cp. 1165. If the Thebans attempt an armed invasion, they will find "a sea of troubles" interposed. Eur. Hipp. 822
kakw=n d', w)= ta/las, pe/lagos ei)sorw=
tosou=ton w(/ste mh/pot' e)kneu=sai pa/lin,
mh/t' e)kpera=sai ku=ma th=sde sumfora=s. So of prosperity, O. T. 423 eu)ploi/as tuxw/n. The form plw/simon only here: Attic writers elsewhere use plw/i+mos (oft. plo/i+mos in our MSS.), Her. plwto/s: pleu/simos is not found.

qarsei=n me
 ou)=n. "Now (ou)=n") you are safe indeed (me
), even without my protection,—Phoebus being with you; but (de\ 666) that protection,—superfluous though it be,—will be afforded by my name just as well as by my presence. For me
 ou)=n with this distributed force cp. O. T. 483, Ant. 65; for its composite force, O. T. 705.

ka)/neu th=s e)mh=s gnw/mhs, even apart from my resolve (636) to protect you. Though th=s e)mh=s form a cretic, the spondee ka)/neu can stand because the prep. coheres closely with its case. Cp. 115. In 1022 ou)de\n dei= ponei=n, and 1543 w(/sper sfw\ patri/, the monosyllable excuses the spondee.
e)painw= with inf., advise: El. 1322 siga=n e)ph/|nes).
*foi=bos: Theseus infers this from 623.

o(/mws with mh\ paro/ntos: it usu. follows the partic. (as 851, 1529), but sometimes precedes it, as Eur. Ion 734 de/spoin' o(/mws ou)=s). It would be possible, however, to take o(/mws with oi)=da: "but nevertheless (though my protection is needless)." Possibly it should be o(mw=s, "equally" (Ai. 1372 ka)kei= ka)nqa/d' w)\n... o(mw=s).

div2.head: 668-719: First stasimon
div2.p: The first strophe and antistrophe (668—680=681 —693) praise Colonus: the second (694 —706=707—719) praise Attica. But the local theme is skilfully knitted to the national theme. The narcissus and crocus of Colonus introduce the Attic olive (second strophe). The equestrian fame of Colonus suggests the Attic breed of horses, and this, in turn, suggests Poseidon's other gift to Athens,—the empire of the sea (second antistrophe). For the metres see Metrical Analysis.
Cicero (Cato 7) is the earliest extant authority for the story of Sophocles reciting this ode before his judges.

div3.p: The first word eu)i/ppou strikes a note which connects Colonus i(/ppios with the fame of Attica. Take ga=s with kra/tista. You have come to earth's best abodes (Colonus), belonging to this eu)/ippos xw/ra (Attica). The gen. eu)i/p. t. xw/ras is most simply taken as possessive, denoting the country to which the e)/paula belong, though it might also be partitive. It precedes e)/paula as the territorial gen. regularly precedes the local name, Her. 3.136 a)pi/konto th=s *)itali/hs e)s *ta/ranta.

ga=s is partitive gen. with the superl., as Lys. or. 21 § 6 h( nau=s a)/rista... e)/plei panto\s tou= stratope/dou. When gh= stands alone it usu.="the earth," as O. T. 480 ta\ meso/mfala ga=s...mantei=a. Some understand, less well, "the best abodes in Attica (ga=s"), belonging to (or consisting in) Colonus (xw/ras).

e)/paula, prop. a fold for cattle, as in O. T. 1138, where staqma/ is its synonym. So e)/pauloi in Od. 23.358, and e)/paulis in Her. 1.111. Then, just like staqma/ in poetry, "homesteads," "dwellings": Aesch. Pers. 869 pa/roikoi | *qrh|ki/wn e)pau/lwn. The form e)/paulis was similarly used in late prose.
to\n: the antistrophic syll. (na/rk- 683), is long, but it is needless to write to/nd), since the anacrusis is common.

a)rgh=ta, "white," contrasting with xlwrai=s (673). See Tozer, Geography of Greece p. 242: "The site of Colonus is distinguished by two bare knolls of lightcoloured earth, the a)rgh=ta *kolwno/n" of the poet,—not chalky, as the expositors of that passage often describe it to be. Schol. to\n leuko/gewn. From √ARG, denoting "brightness," come (a) the group of words for "bright" or white, a)rgo/s, a)rgh/s, a)rgino/eis, a)rgenno/s, a)/rgufos: (b) a)/rguros: (c) a)/rgilos, argilla, white clay. Thus the notion of a light-coloured soil was specially associated with this root. And this was certainly one reason why places were called "white,"—whether the soil was merely light-coloured, as at Colonus, or chalky. Pindar puts Cyrene e)n a)rgino/enti mastw=| (P. 4. 8), and it is known to have stood on a chalk cliff (F. B. Goddard in Amer. Journ. Philol. v. 31 ap. Gildersleeve ad loc.). Soil is suggested by a)rgei/lofon pa\r *zefuri/wn kolw/nan (the town *lokroi\ *)epizefu/rioi on the S.E. coast of Italy, Pind. fr. 200); and soil or light-coloured rocks by *)arginou=sai, the three islets off the coast of Aeolis (Strabo 617). Cp. "Albion." But a town on a hill might also owe the epithet to its buildings. We cannot now decide between soil and buildings in the cases of to\n a)rgino/enta *lu/kaston and *ka/meiron (Il. 2.647, 656) in central Crete (?), nor always in the case of the name "Alba."

minu/retai qami/zousa inverts the usual constr.; cp. Od. 8.450
o( d' a)/r' a)spasi/ws i)/de qumw=|
qerma\ loe/tr), e)pei\ ou)/ti komizo/meno/s ge qa/mizen, "since he was not often so cared for"; Plat. Rep. 328C w)= *sw/krates, ou)de\ qami/zeis h(mi=n katabai/nwn ei)s to\n *peiraia=. Here, however, qami/zousa may be taken separately, "frequenting" (the place): Il. 18.386 pa/ros ge me\n ou)/ti qami/zeis, "hitherto thou comest not oft." The midd. in fr. 460 tw=|de (v.l. th=|de) qami/zetai, (the fish) haunts those waters.

xlw. u(po\ ba/ssais, "under" (screened by) green glades,—in the sacred grove (cp. 17) and in the neighbouring Academy. Cp. Ai. 198 e)n eu)ane/mois ba/ssais (Ida's glens). If the word could be referred, like busso/s, to the rt. of baqu/s, it would be peculiarly appropriate here to the haunts of the bird that "sings darkling."

The reading a)ne/xousa is usually justified by Ai. 212 ( se ) ste/rcas a)ne/xei, "having conceived a love for thee, he upholds thee"; and Eur. Hec. 123 ba/kxhs a)ne/xwn le/ktr' *)agame/mnwn, "upholding," i.e. "refusing to forsake," "remaining constant to." But how could the bird be said to "uphold" the ivy in that sense? In Thuc. 2.18 and 7. 48 a)nei=xen is intrans., "he held back" cautiously. Of the two MS. readings, oi)nwpa\n e)/xousa and oi)nw=p' a)ne/xousa, the latter seems to have come from the former, not vice versa. oi)nwpo/s is a good Attic form (used four times by Eur.), and oi)nwpo\n e)/xousa is nearer to the MSS. than Dindorf's oi)nw=pa ne/mousa. The latter word would mean, "having for her domain."

The ivy and the vine (17) being sacred to Dionysus (qeou=), the foliage of the place generally is called his. qeou= is certainly not the hero Colonus (65). We might desire qea=n (the Eumenides), but the fulla/s meant is not only that of the sacred grove; it includes the Academy.
murio/karpon refers to the berries of the laurel (pagka/rpou da/fnhs O. T. 83), the fruit of the olive and of the vine. Cp. on 17.

a)nh/nemon … xeimw/nwn, cp. 786, 1519: El. 36 a)/skeuon a)spi/dwn: ib. 1002 a)/lupos a)/ths: Tr. 691 a)lampe\s h(li/ou: Od. 6.250 e)dhtu/os...a)/pastos: Eur. Phoen. 324 a)/peplos fare/wn. In these poet. phrases, the gen. might be viewed either as (1) simply a gen. of want, as after kaqaro/s, etc.: (2) an attrib. gen. depending on the implied noun (here, a)/nemoi).
bakxiw/tas (only here)=bakxeuth/s, ba/kxos, reveller. Cp. O. T. 1105 o( *bakxei=os qeo/s.
e)mbateu/ei, haunts the ground, Aesch. Pers. 449 *pa\n e)mbateu/ei ponti/as a)kth=s e)/pi.

a)mfipolw=n, properly, "moving around," so, "attending on," "roaming in company with." The bold use seems to have been suggested by the noun a)mfi/polos as="follower" (Pind., etc.), a)mfipolei=n being here to that noun as o)padei=n to o)pado/s.

tiqh/nais, the nymphs of the mythical Nysa, who nurtured the infant god, and were afterwards the companions of his wanderings: Il. 6.132 (Lycurgus, king of Thrace) *diwnu/soio tiqh/nas | seu=e kat' h)ga/qeon *nush/i+on.

qa/llei d). After the mention of Dionysus, the narcissus now serves to introduce a mention of Demeter and Persephone (Cora). Under the name of *)/iakxos, represented as the son of Cora (or sometimes of Demeter), Dionysus was associated in the Eleusinian mysteries with the "two goddesses" (tw\ qew/): thus Ant. 1119 he reigns pagkoi/nois *)eleusini/as | *dhou=s e)n ko/lpois. A relief found at Eleusis in 1859, and referable to the period between Pheidias and Praxiteles, shows Persephone with her right hand on the head of the young Iacchos (a boy of some fifteen years), who is facing Demeter. It is reproduced in Baumeister's Denkmäler des klass. Alterth., s.v. "Eleusinia," p. 471. There was a shrine of Demeter near Colonus, 1600.

na/rkissos. As the epithet shows, some thickly-flowering variety is meant: cp. Vergil's "comantem Narcissum," Geo. 4. 122. Wieseler (Narkissos, pp. 114 ff., Gött. 1856) thinks that a lily is meant here. Bentham (British Flora, 4th ed., p. 473) says that the narcissus poeticus of the Mediterranean region "has usually a solitary flower of a pure white, except the crown, which is yellow, often edged with orange or crimson." This does not suit kalli/botrus. There is a like doubt about the classical u(a/kinqos, variously taken as iris, gladiolus, or larkspur—at any rate, not our hyacinth. But, whatever the true identification here may be, the symbolism of na/rkissos in Greek mythology is clear. It is the flower of imminent death, being associated, through its narcotic fragrance, with na/rkh,—the pale beauty of the flower helping the thought. It is the last flower for which Persephone is stretching forth her hand when Pluto seizes her,—Earth having put forth a wondrous narcissus, with a hundred flowers, on purpose to tempt her: Hom. Hymn. 5.15
h( d' a)/ra qambh/sas' w)re/cato xersi
 a(/m' a)/mfw
kalo
 a)/qurma labei=n: xa/ne de\ xqw
 eu)rua/guia. Paus. 9.31.9 (quoting an ancient hymn by the legendary poet Pamphos) says that Cora was seized ou)k i)/ois a)pathqei=san a)lla\ narki/ssois. So Euphorion (220 B.C.) fr. 52 *eu)meni/des narki/ssou e)pistefe/es plokami=das. Artemidorus (160 A.D.), interpreting dreams of crowning the head, says, ste/fanoi narki/sswn pepoihme/noi pa=si kakoi/ (Oneirocr. I. 77). Narcissus is the fair youth cold to love, whose face seen by himself in the water was the prelude of death (cp. Artemid. 2. 7).

mega/lain qeai=n: Paus. 8.31.1 (at Megalopolis) qew=n i(ero\n tw=n mega/lwn: ai( de/ ei)sin ai( mega/lai qeai\ *dhmh/thr kai\ *ko/rh. In Attic usu. tw\ qew/, and so Andoc. or. 1 § 32 (of these goddesses) pro\s toi=n qeoi=n is now read (v.l. tai=n qeai=n). Indeed qea/ is rare in Attic prose except in such phrases as qeou\s kai\ qea/s. But here, in a lyric passage, and with an epithet added, the poet may have preferred the less familiar qeai=n. The schol. was wrong in desiring ta=n megala=n qea=n (meaning the Eumenides).

a)rxai=on stefa/nwm). The narcissus does not figure specially as an attribute of the goddesses—as the corn-ears and poppy of Demeter, the pomegranate of Cora, and the myrtle of Iacchos. But, as the flower which Cora was plucking when seized, it was associated with their cult from the first (a)rxai=on), and was one of the flowers which would be most fitly woven into those floral wreaths which, on the wall-paintings, sometimes replace Demeter's more usual crown of corn-ears (see Baumeister, Denkm. p. 417). Hesych. says that in Crete the narcissus was called dama/trion. In Rhodes Cora was crowned with asphodel (Bekker Anecd. I. 457. 9). At Hermione a flower like the u(a/kinqos, locally called kosmosa/ndalon, was worn by the worshippers of Demeter Chthonia (Paus. 2.35.5). Schneidewin's explanation, "original crown,"— before they changed it for others,—is against the myth itself, which makes the narcissus a new joy to Cora's eyes (Hom. Hymn. 5.15).

xrusaugh\s kro/kos. Tozer, Geogr. of Greece p. 162: "when Sophocles... speaks of the crocus with its golden sheen," we would fain regard this as the same with the splendid flower that displays its golden blossoms close to the snow on Parnassus and the mountains of Arcadia. But, in reality, there can be little doubt that it was the cultivated crocus, from which the saffron was obtained, and which was introduced into Greece from the East, where it was prized as a dye for robes and slippers,— the kroko/bapton podo\s eu)/marin of the Persae [660]—the sign of royalty and majesty. Cp. Hom. Hymn. 4.177
(of fair maidens) a)mfi\ de\ xai=tai
w)/mois a)i+/ssonto krokhi+/w| a)/nqei o(moi=ai. Along with roses, violets, "hyacinth," "narcissus," and "agallis" (iris?), the "crocus" is gathered by Cora (ib. 6 ff.). Schol. ka)n th=| *niobh| o( *sofoklh=s to\n kro/kon a)/ntikrus th=| *dh/mhtri a)nati/qetai. At the Thesmophoria (the festival of Demeter qesmofo/ros), when wreaths of flowers were not worn (schol.), the women appeared in krokwtoi/, saffroncoloured robes (Ar. Thesm. 138). The crocus was planted on graves (Juv. Sat. 7. 208).

krh=nai, the "founts." "The most distant sources of the river are on the w. side of Mt. Pentelicus and the s. side of Mt. Parnes, and in the intermediate ridge which unites them" (Leake): in particular, a broad stream descends from the steepest part of Parnes. The Cephisus has a course of about 20 miles to the bay of Phalerum.

minu/qousin. Soph. has seized a distinctive point. Even at this day, when the plain has much less shade than of old, the Cephisus "never fails," while in the long droughts of summer the bed of the Ilissus is absolutely dry. Cp. Modern Greece by H. M. Baird (1856) p. 294: "The little river Cephisus...scatters fertility and verdure around. Great was the contrast between its banks and the rest of the plain, which in the month of October is dry, parched, and dusty. The whole valley, in its width of six miles, had been stripped of nearly every vestige of vegetation; for not a drop of water had fallen during the previous four or five months."—minu/qw is both trans. and intrans. in Homer; intrans. in the Ionic of Hippocr. (who has it of flesh "wasting"). Aesch. has it twice in lyrics (intrans.); Soph. only here.

*khfisou=. Chr. Wordsworth (Athens and Attica p. 137) observes that the Athenian poets never praise the Ilissus (perhaps because it was too much associated with the prose of daily life), though Plato, in the Phaedrus, makes some amends; they keep their praises for the Cephisus (so Eur. Med. 835). On the other hand the Ilissus, not the Cephisus, is the representative river of Attica for more distant singers, from Apollonius Rhodius (I. 215) to Milton (Par. Reg. 4. 249).

noma/des, wandering. The word alludes to irrigation by ducts or canals (a system still in use), but does so far more poetically than would be the case if (with E. Curtius) we made it active, with r(ee/qrwn for object. gen., "distributing the streams." There is no example of an adj. of this form (as spora/s, strofa/s, forba/s) having an active sense. Cp. O. T. 1350 n.

e)p' h)/mati, a very rare use in Attic, meaning here that on (or for) each day the river gives what that day requires. Cp. Il. 10.48 (never did I hear) a)/ndr' e(/na tossa/de me/rmer' e)p' h)/mati mhti/sasqai (as one day's work): more oft. e)p' h)/mati tw=|de, "on this day," Il. 13.234, 19. 110. Herodotus has the gen. e)p' h(me/rhs e(ka/sths in a similar sense (5. 117); this phrase, too, is un-Attic.

w)kuto/kos, giving an early reward to the cultivator's labour. Cp. w)kuto/koio *sela/nas (because thought e)pi\ tai=s loxei/ais kai\ w)di=si bohqei=n), poet. ap. Plut. Mor. 282 C. w)kuto/kion, a medicine used in childbed, Ar. Th. 504.
pedi/wn e)pini/ssetai, a partitive gen. (helped by e)pi-), cp. e)/rxontai pedi/oio, Il. 2.801.
o)/mbrw|, water: see on O. T. 1427. (Not, "with the help of rain.")
st. xqono/s, possessive gen. with pedi/wn.

sternou/xou, having ste/rna: an expressive word for the expanse of the Attic pedi/on, varied by gentle undulations, or by rocky knolls like Colonus itself. Suidas quotes a poet. phrase ste/rna gh=s: cp. the common use of mastoi/ for round hills or knolls. Hes. Theog. 117 *gai=) eu)ru/sternos: Pind. Nem. 7.33
eu)ruko/lpou
...xqono/s. Both ste/rna and nw=ta were applied, says the schol., to th=s gh=s ta\ pediw/dh kai\ eu)re/a. The epithet helps, with w)kuto/kos, to suggest the image of a mighty living frame, quickened by the veins of irrigation.
*mousa=n. Paus. 1.30.2 (in the Academy, cp. on 55) e)/sti de kai\ *mousw=n te bwmo\s kai\ e(/teros *(ermou= kai\ e)/ndon *)aqhna=s.
nin refers to xqono/s in 691: this region generally.
ou)d' a(. The ou)d' au)= of L is somewhat prosaic, and implies a contrast between the deities which is unfitting here.

*)afrodi/th is not among the divinities of the Academy or Colonus in Paus. 1. 30, though there was an altar of *)/erws in front of the entrance to the Academy. But she was often associated with Demeter and Cora (cp. Paus. 3.19.4, and Baumeister Denkmäler p. 419); and she was also specially connected by an Attic legend with the Cephisus (Eur. Med. 835).

xrusa/nios, when she drives her chariot drawn by sparrows (Sappho fr. 1. 10), doves, or swans. The word occurs only once in Il. (6. 205), as epith. of Artemis, and once in Od. (8. 285), as epith. of Ares. Paus. 9.23.4 (speaking of a lost hymn by Pindar to Persephone) a)/llai te e)s to\n *(/a|dhn ei)si\n e)piklh/seis kai\ o( xrush/nios, dh=la w(s e)pi\ th=s *ko/rhs th=| a(rpagh=|. So, here, the epith. suggests a visit of the goddess from above.

Thus far the theme has been Colonus and the adjacent region. Now the praises take a larger range. Athena's gift of the olive, Poseidon's gift of the horse, are here celebrated as common to Attica (ta=|de xw/ra|, 700, cp. 668): though the latter had a special interest for Colonus Hippius, and the former for the Academy, where an olive was shown, said to have sprung up next after the primal olive in the *pandrosei=on of the Erechtheum (Paus. 1.30.2).

ga=s *)asi/as, sc. o)/n, possessive gen., with e)pakou/w, hear of as belonging to. The poet does not mean, of course, that he has never heard of the olive as growing in the Peloponnesus or in Asia Minor. It is enough to recall the strepth=s kaloume/nhs e)lai/as futo/n of Epidaurus (said to have been twisted by Heracles, Paus. 2.28.2), and the speculation of Thales in the olive-oil presses of Miletus and Chios (e)laiourgei=a, Arist. Pol. 1.11). He means that nowhere else has he heard of an olive-tree springing from the earth at a divine command, or flourishing so greatly and so securely under divine protection.

*dwri/di, as Schneidewin remarked, is an anachronism (cp. 1301), since legend placed Oedipus before the Trojan war, and the Dorian conquest of the Peloponnesus after it; but Attic tragedy was not fastidious on such points. In Eur. Hec. 450 the Peloponnesus is *dwri\s ai)=a. Cp. on 66.

na/sw|: cp. Eust. ad Dion. Perieg. 403 h( tou= *pe/lopos nh=sos e)/sti me\n kuri/ws *xerro/nhsos, o(/mws de\ nh=sos me\n le/getai, w(s para\ braxu\ toiau/th ou)=sa. In the 10th century we find the Peloponnesus called simply h( nh=sos by Constantinus Porphyrogenitus, peri\ tw=n *qema/twn ("the provinces") p. 52 e)/sti de\ pa=sa h( nh=sos u(po\ e(ni\ strathgw=| tetagme/nh.

*pe/lopos has been regarded by some as a gloss: see on 709 f. But, apart from the fact that 709 f. are shorter by uu, it need move no suspicion; for, if not necessary here, it is at least fitting, and is often joined with nh=sos. Tyrtaeus fr. 2 eu)rei=an *pe/lopos na=son a)fiko/meqa. Cypria fr. 8 diede/rketo nh=son a(/pasan | *tantali/dew *pe/lopos. Ion Omphale fr. 24 a)/meinon h)\ to\n *pe/lopos e)n nh/sw| tro/pon. — Cp. Aesch. Eum. 702
(the Areiopagus is a safeguard) oi(=on ou)/tis a)nqrw/pwn e)/xei
ou)/t' e)n *sku/qaisin ou)/te *pe/lopos e)n to/pois.
fu/teum). fi/teum), which Blaydes prefers, occurs only once in trag. (Aesch. Ag. 1281, of Orestes); it seems more appropriate to a "scion" (child) than to a plant.

a)xei/rwton was read here by Pollux (2. 154), and is thus carried back to about 160 A.D.; it is also in A and a majority of our other MSS.; while L's a)xei/rhton is clearly a corruption. The question is whether a)xei/rwton means (1) "unvanquished," the only sense in which it occurs elsewhere, as Thuc. 6.10 oi( *xalkidh=s...a)xei/rwtoi/ ei)si: or (2) a)xeirou/rghton, as Pollux takes it, "not cultivated by human hands." xei/rwma usu. meant "a conquest," or "a violent deed"; yet Aesch. could say tumboxo/a xeirw/mata (work of the hand in mound-making) Theb. 1022. A bold artist in language might similarly, perhaps, have ventured on a)xei/rwtos as ="not hand-wrought." My reason for preferring "unvanquished" is the context. While blasto/n (697) refers to the miraculous creation of the olive by Athena, au)topoio/n refers (I think) to its miraculous self-renewal after the Persians had burnt it. Her. 8.55 deute/rh| te h(me/rh| a)po\ th=s e)mprh/sios *)aqhnai/wn oi( qu/ein u(po\ basile/os keleuo/menoi w(s a)ne/bhsan e)s to\ i(ro/n, w(/rwn blasto\n e)k tou= stele/xeos o(/son te phxuai=on a)nadedramhko/ta. This connection of ideas is further indicated by the next phrase, e)gxe/wn etc. For au)topoio/s as "self-produced" (i.e. producing itself from itself) cp. au)toto/kos, au)tofa/gos, au)tofo/nos. Chandler (Accent. § 457 2nd ed.) remarks that all compounds of -poios are oxytone (quoting Arcadius 88. 2): au)to/poios (as our MSS. give it) in this passage "is the one solitary exception, and therefore probably a false accent."

fo/bhma. Androtion (circ. 280 B.C.), in his *)atqi/s, stated that the sacred olives (mori/ai) in Attica had been spared by the Peloponnesian invaders under Archidamus, who sacrificed to Athena. The Atthis of Philochorus, a contemporary of Androtion, made the same statement (schol. ad loc.).
ta=|de … xw/ra|, locative dat.: in Attica.

me/gista: cp. 219 makra/, 319 faidra/, O. T. 883 u(pe/ropta n. The light soil of Attica (to\ lepto/gewn), and the climate, esp. favoured the olive: cp. Theophr. Causs. Plantt. 2. 4. 4 h( spila\s (stony ground) kai\ e)/ti ma=llon h( leuko/geios (670 n.) e)laiofo/ros. For Greece, the olive-zone begins s. of the plains of Thessaly, as for Italy it begins s. of the plains of Lombardy. The olive is found in Phthiotis and Magnesia: in Epeirus, only on the sea-coast.

paidotro/fou, nourishing the young lives in the land. The epithet is especially fitting here, after the recent allusion to Demeter and Cora, because at the Thesmophoria the prayer to those goddesses associated Earth with them as h( kourotro/fos: see Ar. Thesm. 295. Cp. Juv. Sat. 3. 84 quod nostra infantia caelum Hausit Aventini, baca nutrita Sabina (the olive). Hesych. (s.v. ste/fanon e)kfe/rein) says that it was the Attic custom ste/fanon e)lai/as tiqe/nai pro\ tw=n qurw=n, when a male child was born; as wool, when a female (cp. foribus suspende coronas: Iam pater es). But there is no such allusion here. Nor could paidotr. mean "propagated from the parent olive" on the acropolis, as Schneidewin thought.

to\ me/n tis k.t.l. Two points first claim notice. (1) ou)/te and nearo/s are both in the MSS., but both cannot be right. Cp. v. 715. If with Porson the first ou)/te is changed to ou), the second ou)/te must certainly be changed to ou)de/. A single ou)/te cannot follow ou), though a repeated ou)/te can (Tr. 1058). Elmsley's ou)/te ne/os is hardly probable. (2) gh/ra| shmai/nwn seems to me impossible. It surely could not mean either (a) "commanding in old age"—the elderly Archidamus in contrast with the young Xerxes— or (b) "commanding the elderly men." The difficulty is not in the sense of

shmai/nwn itself, for which cp. Il. 1.288
pa/ntwn me\n krate/ein e)qe/lei, pa/ntessi d' a)na/ssein,
pa=si de\ shmai/nein,—he would be master, king, captain (shma/ntwr): it is in the combination with gh/ra|.

Now comes this question:—Was the antithesis here between youth and age, or between some other notions? Hartung writes ou)/t' h)=ros ou)/te gh/ra|, understanding, "neither in spring nor in winter," shmai/nwn, "by his word of command": but such a fig. sense of gh/ra| is inconceivable. Nauck's ou)/t' h)=ros ou)/t' e)n w(/ra| | xeimw/nwn is too far from the MSS., and the plur. is strange. I incline to believe that the poet indeed meant "neither young nor old," but without any personal reference, and merely in this general sense:—"from generation to generation of men these sacred trees are safe." The words o( ga\r ai)e\n o(rw=n suit this. The conjecture sunnai/wn has palaeographic probability (for a cursive text): for the phrase cp. Eur. fr. 370 meta\ d' h(suxi/as poliw=| gh/rai+ sunoikoi/hn.
ku/klos, the eye of Zeus (so ku/kloi, Ph. 1354), not the "orb" of the sun.

*mori/ou *dio/s. Attic Orators, vol. I. p. 289: "Throughout Attica, besides the olives which were private property (i)/diai e)lai=ai", Lys. or. 7 § 10) there were others which, whether on public or on private lands, were considered as the property of the state. They were called moriae (mori/ai)—the legend being that they had been propagated (memorhme/nai) from the original olive which Athena herself had caused to spring up on the Acropolis. This theory was convenient for their conservation as State property, since, by giving them a sacred character, it placed them directly under the care of the Areiopagus, which caused them to be visited once a month by Inspectors (e)pimelhtai/, Lys. or. 7 § 29), and once a year by special Commissioners (gnw/mones, ib. § 25). To uproot a moria was an offence punishable by banishment and confiscation of goods (ib. § 41).
*mori/ou, from the objects protected; so *zeu\s i(ke/sios, kth/sios, etc.

glaukw=pis, with grayish-blue eyes: the Homeric epithet has been suggested by glauka=s in 701. The altar of *zeu\s *mo/rios, otherwise called *kataiba/ths, was in the Academy, where there was also a shrine of Athena close to the mori/ai (Apollodorus ap. schol.); hence there was a special reason for the conjunction of the deities here.
This antistrophe is devoted to Poseidon, as the strophe to Athena.

matro/polei, "mother-city" (Athens), since the men of Colonus, like all other dwellers in Attica, may deem themselves her children. So Pind. Nem. 5.8 *ai)aki/das ...matro/poli/n te, their native state (Aegina): Ant. 1122 *bakxa=n matro/polin *qh/ban (with allusion to Semelè). Not, "capital city," which would be prosaic: this sense occurs as early, however, as Xen., Anab. 5. 2. 3 e)\n de\ h)=n xwri/on mhtro/polis au)tw=n.

If vv. 696 f. are sound as they stand, the problem here is to supply uu, and Porson's xqono\s seems best. mega/lou...me/giston, au)/xhma...au)/xhma (713) must not be judged with modern fastidiousness: see on 554.

eu)/ippon, eu)/pwlon harmonizes with a strain of feeling which pervades the ode,—that the bounty of the gods to Attica is continued from day to day and from age to age. The supply of good i(/ppoi is perpetually replenished by good pw=loi: "est in equis patrum Virtus."

eu)/ippon further suggests i(ppei=s, since (as ="well-horsed") it is often said of heroes (Pind. Ol. 3.39 eu). *tundarida=n). The Boeotian Orchomenus is kalli/pwlos, Pind. Ol. 14.2. For au)/xhma eu)/ippon, a glory consisting in good horses, cp. 1062, Pind. Ol. 3.37 r(imfarma/tou | difrhlasi/as: P. 8. 37 ni/kan...qrasu/guion: Isth. 1. 12 kalli/nikon...ku=dos.

eu)qa/lasson. The well of salt water shown in the Erechtheum (u(/dwr qala/ssion e)n fre/ati Paus. I. 26. 5) was called qa/lassa. It was said to have been created by a blow from Poseidon's trident; the three holes which were shown are still visible (see Penrose's drawing and description in Smith's Dict. Geog. 1. 279 b). Her. 8.55 *)erexqe/os...nho/s, e)n tw=| e)lai/h te kai\ qa/lassa e)/ni. Apollod. 3. 14. 1 (Poseidon) a)ne/fhne qa/lassan h(\n nu=n *)erexhi+/da kalou=si.

eu)/ippon, eu)qa/lasson are brought close together as expressing the two great attributes of Poseidon, Hom. Hymn. 22.4
dixqa/ toi, *)ennosi/gaie, qeoi\ timh\n e)da/santo,
i(/ppwn te dmhth=r' e)/menai swth=ra/ te nhw=n: Aristoph. Eq. 551
i(/ppi' a)/nac *po/seidon, w(=|
xalkokro/twn i(/ppwn ktu/pos
… a(nda/nei,
kai\ kuane/mboloi qoai\
misqofo/roi trih/reis.
su\ ga/r, after the voc.: cp. su\ de/ (507).

ei(=sas (i(/zw) nin ei)s to/d' au)/xhma, didst establish her in this glory, as in a royal throne: cp. Her. 3.61 tou=ton... ei(=se a)/gwn e)s to\n basilh/ion qro/non. The phrase is Homeric, Od. 1.130 au)th\n d' e)s qro/non ei(=sen a)/gwn.
i(/ppoisin with to\n a)kesth=ra: cp. Ai. 1166 brotoi=s to\n a)ei/mnhston | ta/fon.

a)kesth=ra=swfronisth/n, healing their mania/des no/soi, and bringing them to a calm temper (Il. 13.115 a)ll' a)kew/meqa qa=sson: a)kestai/ toi fre/nes e)sqlw=n): cp. Athen. 627 E (music is introduced at banquets) o(/pws e(/kastos tw=n ei)s me/qhn kai\ plh/rwsin w(rmhme/nwn i)atro\n lamba/nh| th=s u(/brews kai\ th=s a)kosmi/as th\n mousikh/n. Pind. Ol. 13.68 fi/ltron to/d' i(/ppeion, 85 fa/rmakon prau+/, said of the bit (xalino/s) given by Athena to Bellerophon for Pegasus.
prw/taisi tai=sde … a)guiai=s, first in these roads (about Colonus); locative dat.:

kti/sas, "having instituted," brought into use among men, as one could say kti/zein no(mima on the analogy of kti/zein e(orth/n etc. Greek mythology places Poseidon in two distinct relations to the horse. (a) As creator. Servius ad Verg. Geo. 1. 12 ideo dicitur ecum invenisse quia velox est eius numen et mobile sicut mare. (So waves on a rough sea are "white horses," Ital. cavalloni.) The Thessalians connected this myth with the cult of Poseidon *petrai=os, who had caused the first horse (*sku/fios) to spring from a rock in Thessaly,—the name being taken from sku/fos, a rocky cup, where perh. marks in the rock were shown. From Tzetzes on Lycophron 767 it seems that this legend was in later times localised at Colonus also. Arcadia and Boeotia, too, had their legends, in which the first horse was called *)ari/wn (the wondrous steed of Adrastus in Il. 23.346). (b) As tamer. This was the prominent trait of the Corinthian and Attic legends. At Corinth Poseidon was worshipped as damai=os, and Athena as xalini=tis (cp. Pind. Ol. 13.65 ff.). In Thessaly the horse-yoking Poseidon was called i)/myios: Hesych. i)/myas: zeu/cas *qettaloi/, i)/myios *poseidw=n o( zu/gios. In Aesch. PV 462 ff. Prometheus is the first who taught men to drive animals,— u(f' a(/rma t' h)/gagon filhni/ous | i(/ppous.

Poseidon has taught men to row as well as to ride. He fits the oars to their hands. But, instead of ta
 de\ pla/tan xersi\ para/yas, the form is varied to a passive constr. If paraptome/na is sound, this seems the best account of it,—para/, "at the side," suggesting the notion, "as an aid." (If from parape/tomai, it could be only aor., which the sense excludes.) Conjecture might proceed on either of two views:—(a) that in the strophic v. 704 the correction ai)e
 is true, so that paraptome/na is metrically sound: (b) that in 704 the MS. ei)saie
 is true, so that here we require u--uu-. On the latter view I would suggest that prosarmozome/na is suitable, and on this paraptome/na may have been a gloss; cp. Eur. I. T. 1405 (xe/ras) kw/ph| prosarmo/santes.

eu)h/retmos, adj. compounded with a noun cognate in sense to the subst. (pla/ta): cp. bi/os makrai/wn (O. T. 518 n.), logos kako/qrous (Ai. 138), eu)/pais go/nos (Eur. I. T. 1234), eu)ph/xeis xei=res (Hipp. 200).
e)/kpagla, neut. plur. as adv., cp. 319.
a(li/a with qrw/|skei: cp. on 119 e)kto/pios.

tw=n e(katompo/dwn *nhrh/|dwn, the Nereids with their hundred feet, the fifty Nereids whose dance and song lead the ship on her way. (But in Pind. fr. 122 kora=n a)ge/lan e(kato/gguion prob. denotes 100, not 50, persons, as though gui=on were sw=ma.) The choice of the number (though here meant merely to suggest a numerous sisterhood) is not accidental: fifty was the number regularly assigned to the Nereids by the earlier Greek poets, as Hesiod Th. 264, Pindar Isthm. 5. 6, Aesch. Fr. 168, Eur. Ion 1081. Later it becomes a hundred; so Plat. Critias 116E (describing Poseidon's temple in the island of Atlantis) *nhrh=|das de\ e)pi\ delfi/nwn e(kato\n ku/klw|: tosau/tas ga\r e)no/mizon au)ta\s oi( to/te ei)=nai; and so Ovid Fasti 6. 499. *nhreu/s (√nu, ne/w, na=ma, etc.) and his daughters represent the sea's kindly moods: the Nereids who dance and sing around and before the ship are the waves. In e(katompo/dwn the second part of the compound suggests "dancing," cp. on pukno/pteroi (17).

Second e)peiso/dion. Creon comes, in the hope of persuading Oed. to return with him. Failing, he causes his attendants to carry off Antigone,—Ismene having already been captured elsewhere. He is about to seize Oed., when Theseus enters, sends pursuers after Creon's men, and compels Creon himself to set out with him to find them.

so
 … dh\ is more poetical and more impressive than soi\ … dei=: cp. 197, El. 1470
ou)k e)mo
 to/d), a)lla\ so/n,
to\ tau=q' o(ra=n: Ph. 15 a)ll' e)/rgon h)/dh so
 ta\ loi/f' u(phretei=n: Aesch. Theb. 232 so
 d' au)= to\ siga=n. But soi\...dei=, though a rare, is an admissible construction; besides Eur. Hipp. 940 (quoted on 570) cp. Xen. Anab. 3.4.35 dei= e)pisa/cai to
 i(/ppon *pe/rsh| a)ndri\ kai\ xalinw=sai dei=: Mem. 3. 3. 10 ei)/ soi de/oi dida/skein: Oecon. 7. 20 dei= me/ntoi toi=s me/llousin a)nqrw/pois e(/cein o(/ ti ei)sfe/rwsin: ib. 8. 9 ei)...diale/gein de/oi au)tw=|. We cannot read soi\ … dh\ with L, and understand pa/resti, as Campbell proposes.

fai/nein ta\ lampra\ e)/ph = fai/nein ta\s a)reta\s di' a(\s e)painei=sqe, to illustrate the praises by deeds: cp. Od. 8.237 a)ll' e)qe/leis a)reth\n sh\n faine/men h(/ toi o)phdei=. fai/nein e)/ph could not mean strictly bebaiou=n e)/ph, to "make" the words "good."
The a)ntilabh/ (division of the verse between two persons) marks excitement: cp. 652, 1099, 1169.
h(mi=n, ethic dat.: cp. 81.
fai/noit' a)/n, a courteous entreaty. Aesch. Theb. 261 le/gois a)\n w(s ta/xista.
te/rma th=s swthri/as (defining gen.), the end which consists in safety, cp. te/los qana/toio. When the attack has been made and repulsed, he will feel finally assured.
pare/stai, sc. to\ te/rma th=s s.

e)gw/. It is unsafe to argue that kurw= could not be a gloss, because it is a poetical word. It was just such a conjecture as correctors of the later age readily made, to smooth a supposed difficulty, or in mere wantonness. With ge/rwn opposed to ou) gegh/rake we requlre e)gw/ opposed to xw/ras. It is different when the pers. pron. is omitted because the main antithesis is between two verbal notions: as in Aesch. Eum. 84 (I will not betray thee) kai\ ga\r ktanei=n s' e)/peisa, for I persuaded (not I persuaded) thee to slay.
o)mma/twn possessive gen., th=s e)mh=s e)peiso/dou objective gen., both with fo/bon: a fear belonging to the eyes (showing itself in them), about my advent.
ei)lhfo/tas: Ai. 345 ta/x' a)/n tin' ai)dw=... la/boi (conceive): Eur. Suppl. 1050 o)rgh\n la/bois a)/n.
new/rh: cp. on 475.
o(\n, relat. to e)me/ implied in th=s e)mh=s (cp. on 263). mh/t' a)fh=t) k.t.l. is an independent sentence, co-ordinated with the relat. clause o(\n mh/t' o)knei=te: see on 424.
w(s with boulhqei/s, marking more strongly the agent's own point of view, cp. on 71.
dra=n ti, euphemistic, to take any forcible measures: so, in a good sense, Thuc. 1.20 boulo/menoi...dra/sante/s ti kai\ kinduneu=sai, to do something notable if they must incur the risk.

ei)/ tin), instead of ei)/tis (sqe/nei), by assimilation, ei)/tis being treated as forming a single adj.: Ai. 488 ei)/per tino/s, sqe/nontos e)n plou/tw|, *frugw=n: Thuc. 7.21 tou= te *guli/ppou kai\ *(ermokra/tous kai\ ei)/ tou a)/llou peiqo/ntwn: cp. Xen. Anab. 5.2.24 a)ne/lamyen oi)ki/a...o(/tou dh\ e)na/yantos (some one or other).

thliko/sd) is clearly right. It confirms the previous assurance that his errand is peaceful, and it harmonises with pei/swn. "I have not come to use force. No, I was sent, an aged envoy, to persuade him," etc. If we read thliko/nd) Creon's diplomacy is at fault. He should not begin by reminding them that Thebes had suffered Oedipus to wander in misery for so many years.

ou)k e)c e(no\s stei/lantos, not in consequence of one man's sending (stei/lantos predicate): keleusqei\s goes only with a)stw=n u(po\ pa/ntwn. The combination of particles in different cases is esp. freq. when one is a gen. absol. (as if e)c were absent here): Ph. 170 f.
mh/ tou khdome/nou brotw=n
mhde\ cu/ntrofon o)/mm' e)/xwn: Tr. 292: Dem. or. 23 § 156 ei)=den, ei)/te dh/ tinos ei)po/ntos ei)/t' au)to\s sunei/s: Thuc. 1.67 ou)x h(su/xazon a)ndrw=n te sfi/sin e)no/ntwn kai\ a(/ma peri\ tw=| xwri/w| dedio/tes. But it occurs also without gen. abs., as Ant. 381 a)pistou=san | … a)/gousi … kai\ e)n a)frosu/nh| kaqelo/ntes.

a)stw=n marks the public character of his mission from Thebes, while a)ndrw=n would be intolerably weak. It cannot be justified by Herm.'s argument, that Soph. added it in the second clause because he had omitted it in the first, since e(no\s needed no addition. a)/ndra in 735 probably caused the slip.

h(=ke/ moi ge/nei, it devolved on me by kinship. Cp. Eur. Alc. 291 kalw=s me\n au)toi=s katqanei=n h(=kon bi/ou (acc. absol.), when they had reached a time of life mature for dying. The personal constr. occurs in Eur. Her. 213 ge/nous me\n h(/keis w(=de toi=sde, thou art related to them in this degree. In such examples h(/kei, h(/kw cannot properly be regarded as mere substitutes for prosh/kei, prosh/kw.
ge/nei (caus. dat.): cp. O. T. 1016 h)=n soi *po/lubos ou)de\n e)n ge/nei. Bergk's h)=k' e)/moig' e(ni/ is unnecessary.
ei)s plei=ston po/lews, to the greatest extent of all the citizens, i.e. more than any other Theban.
ei)s as in ei)s u(perbolh/n, e)s ta\ ma/lista, etc. (cp. e)pi\ ple/on): the gen. after the superl. adv., as Ai. 502 me/giston i)/sxuse stratou=.
a)ll) opens his direct appeal: cp. 101.

dikai/ws, with right, since Thebes, which had been his tro/fos so long (760), has a better claim to him than Athens, however hospitable. And Creon has an especial right to urge the claim as being now the guardian of the family honour (755). Not: "as they owed it to thee to do": nor, "in due form," as opp. to private overtures.

e)k de\ tw=n. When the art. stands as demonstr. pron., it is usu. the first word in the clause: but cp. 1699 (to
): Aesch. Eum. 2 e)k de\ th=s *qe/min: Plat. Euthyd. 303 C polla\ me
 ou)=n kai\ a)/lla...e)n de\ toi=s kai\ tou=to: Eur. Alc. 264 oi)ktra
 fi/loisin, e)k de\ tw=n ma/list' e)moi/. (In Soph. Ph.1243 e)n de\ toi=s e(gw/ is doubtful; L has toi=sd'.)

o(/sw|per, sc. ma/lista: cp. Tr. 312
e)pei/nin tw=nde plei=ston w)/ktisa
ble/pous', o(/sw|per kai\ fronei=n o)=den mo/nh, where plei=ston is grammatically needed with o(/sw|per, though mo/nh is added as if e)peidh/, and not o(/sw|per, had preceded. Schol. e)gw\ ma/lista/ se kalw=, o(/sw|per plei=ston a)lgw= toi=s paqh/masin,—where the absence of any ref. to the words ei) mh\...ka/kistos has caused suspicion: but the schol.'s aim was simply to explain the syntax.
pleiston … ka/kistos: Ph. 631 th=s plei=ston e)xqi/sths: Eur. Med. 1323 w)= me/giston e)xqi/sth gu/nai: Alc. 790 th\n plei=ston h(di/sthn.

ce/non would apply to any one living in a country not his own: cp. 562. Oed. is not merely an exile, but a wandering beggar. The rhythm makes it better to take o)/nta with ce/non only, and to connect a)lh/thn with xwrou=nta.

e)pi\ mia=s pr., in dependence on (cp. on 148), but without conscious reference to the metaphor of an anchor: cp. Lys. or. 31 § 9 (of a me/toikos) e)pi\ prosta/tou w)|kei, he lived under the protection of a citizen as his patron (so Lycurg. Leocr. § 145 oi)kh/sas...e)pi\ prosta/tou).
ta/las has nearly the force of an interjection, "ah me!": cp. 318.
ou)k e)/doca pesei=n a)/n=o(/ti pe/soi a)/n.

e)s tosou=ton ai)ki/as: cp. O. T. 771 e)s tosou=ton e)lpi/dwn | e)mou= bebw=tos, n. So El. 191 a)eikei= su\n stola=| (of Electra). The penult. of ai)ki/a, as of the epic a)eiki/a, is always long; hence the later spelling a)ei/keia, ai)/keia (Eustath. 1336. 58), often found in our MSS.

o(/son, i.e. ei)s o(/son: cp. Dem. or. 19 § 342 e)pi\ th=s au)th=s h(=sper nu=n e)cousi/as...menei=: Plat. Rep. 533E ou) peri\ o)no/matos h( a)mfisbh/thsis, oi(=s tosou/twn pe/ri ske/yis o(/swn h(mi=n pro/keitai.
h(/de du/smoros is added as if the preceding statement had been general ("I had not thought that any royal maiden," etc.)
to\ so\n ka/ra, a way of alluding to his blindness without mentioning it: cp. 285.

ptwxw=|. The poet. tendency was often to treat adjectives with three terminations as if they had only two. Cp. the Homeric poulu\n e)f' u(grh/n (Il. 10.27): qh=lus e)e/rsh (Od. 5.467), h(du\s a)u+tmh/ (Od. 12.369), pikro\n...o)dmh/n (Od. 4.406): below, 1460 (cp. O. T. 384 n.): Tr. 207 koino\s...klagga/: so ib. 478 patrw=|os, and 533 qurai=os: Eur. Bacch. 598 di/ou bronta=s, 992 i)/tw di/ka fanero/s, i)/tw: Helen 623 w)= poqeino\s h(me/ra.

thlikou=tos is fem. only here and El. 614. The point of thlikou=tos is that her marriageable age is passing by in these perilous wanderings. There is a similar thought in Electra's complaint (El. 962). Cp. 1116, 1181.

tou)pio/ntos possessive, a(rpa/sai epexegetic: belonging to the first comer, for him to seize. O. T. 393
to/ g' ai)/nigm' ou)xi\ tou)pio/ntos h)=n
a)ndro\s dieipei=n (n.).
a)=r); equiv. in sense to a)=r' ou); "are you satisfied that it is so?" i.e. "is it not so?" O. T. 822 a)=r' e)/fun kako/s; | a)=r' ou)xi\ pa=s a)/nagnos;
w)= ta/las, nom. instead of voc., cp. 185; so O. T. 744 oi)/moi ta/las, n.; below, 847.

"I have uttered a cruel reproach against my kindred and myself. But indeed the reproach is one that cannot be hid, so long as thou and thy daughter are seen wandering thus. Hide it, then, thou (no one else can)—by coming home." Unless we correct nun to nin (=ta\ e)mfanh=), it is better to place a point, and not merely a comma, at kru/ptein: "But (I have some excuse) for," etc.,—the elliptical use of a)ll' ou) ga/r, as at 988, El. 595, Tr. 552. So the schol.: w(/ste suggnw/mhs ei)mi\ a)/cios le/gwn: ou) ga\r du/namai kru/ptein. With only a comma at kru/ptein, a)lla/ would belong to kru/yon: "But,—since it is impossible, etc.—hide thou,"—when the position of nun is awkward.—So in O. T. 1424 Creon urges the Theban elders to take Oed. into the house, forbidding them toio/nd' a)/gos | a)ka/lupton ou(/tw deiknu/nai.

pro\s qew=n patrw/|wn, the gods of thy fathers, i.e. of the Labdacid house, which traced its descent from Agenor, son of Poseidon and father of Cadmus. This peculiarly strong adjuration occurs also Ant. 839, Ph. 933: cp. El. 411 w)= qeoi\ patrw=|oi, sugge/nesqe/ g' a)lla\ nu=n: fr. 521. 8 (women are parted by marriage) qew=n patrw/|wn tw=n te fusa/ntwn a)/po.
qelh/sas: cp. O. T. 649 piqou= qelh/sas fronh/sas t) (n.).
a)/stu, no less than do/mous, is qualified by tou\s patrw/|ous (cp. 297). Creon's real purpose was to establish Oedipus just beyond the Theban border (399).

ei)pw/n here=proseipw/n: so Il. 12.210 dh\ to/te *pouluda/mas qrasu
 *(/ektora ei)=pe parasta/s: Ai. 764 o( me
 ga au)to
 e)nne/pei: te/knon, etc. Cp. ib. 862
ta\ *trwi+ka\
pedi/a prosaudw=: xai/ret), w)= trofh=s e)moi/: ib. 1221 ta\s i(era\s o(/pws | prosei/poimen *)aqa/nas. Usu. eu)= or kakw=s le/gein tina/ is to speak well or ill of him: Xen. Mem. 2.3.8 eu)= le/gein to
 eu)= le/gonta.
h( d' oi)/koi (po/lis) is somewhat bold, but scarcely warrants Wecklein's change to h( d' e)kei). Cp. 351, Aesch. Suppl. 390 kata\ no/mous tou\s oi)/koqen (the laws of your country).

panto\s with lo/gou dikai/ou: "thou who wouldst borrow a crafty device from any plea of right"—as he here uses the lo/gos di/kaios about duty to friends and fatherland for the purpose of enticing Oedipus back. Cp. Ph. 407
e)/coida ga/r nin panto\s a)\n lo/gou kakou=
glw/ssh| qigo/nta: Eur. I. A. 97 pa/nta prosfe/rwn lo/gon. This is better than to make panto\s neut., taking lo/gou d. as defining gen. with mhxa/nhma: "thou who from anything wouldst borrow a crafty device consisting in a fair plea": for which, however, we might cp. Eur. Hec. 248 pollw=n lo/gwn eu(rh/maq' w(/ste mh\ qanei=n, Ant. 312 e)c a)/pantos...kerdai/nein, and below, 807.

a)
 fe/rwn=o(\s fe/rois a)/n: as in Ph. 407 f. (quoted above) a)
...qigo/nta=o(/ti qi/goi a)/n. Dem. or. 18 § 258 po/ll' a)
 e)/xwn e(/ter' ei)pei=n peri\ au)th=s paralei/pw,=o(/te e)/xoimi a)/n. Cp. O. T. 11 n.
In L's pei/ra=i (sic) we trace the wish of Didymus (schol.) to read pei/ra|, i.e. "by a stratagem." It would then be necessary to take ka)me\ as="even me" (who have had such experiences).
peira=| is manifestly right: tau=ta is cogn. accus., mou being understood.
deu/teron … e(lei=n, to get me a second time into thy power. This is explained by vv. 765—771, which set forth how they had abused their former control over the blind man.

e)n oi(=s=e)n tou/tois, e)n oi(=s, in things (snares), having been caught in which, etc.: cp. El. 1476
ti/nwn pot' a)ndrw=n e)n me/sois a)rkusta/tois
pe/ptwx' o( tlh/mwn; Eur. Phoen. 263
de/doika mh/ me diktu/wn e)/sw
labo/ntes ou)k e)kfrw=s).

ma/list' a)\n a)lgoi/hn: because his dearest wish now is that his grave should bless his friends and harm his foes (92). If the Thebans could entice him back, and become masters of his grave, they might baffle that wish; and yet he would not even have burial in Theban soil (406).
pro/sqen te, answered by nu=n te in 772. The interval is somewhat long, but the first te merely prepares the ear for a statement in two parts.

oi)kei/ois, due to my own acts: it was horror at his own involuntary crimes that made him eager to quit Thebes: cp. O. T. 819
kai\ ta/d' ou)/tis a)/llos h)=n
h)\ 'gw\ 'p' e)mautw=| ta/sd' a)ra\s o( prostiqei/s. So Ai. 260 oi)kei=a pa/qh, | mhdeno\s a)/llou parapra/cantos: El. 215 oi)kei/as ei)s a)/tas | e)mpi/pteis.
nosou=nq', as if ou)k h)/qeles e)kpe/mpein was to follow; but the changed form of phrase requires the dat. qe/lonti. Cp. O. T. 350 e)nne/pw se\...e)mme/nein,...w(s o)/nti (n.).
ou)k h)/qeles qe/lonti k.t.l., the will on my side was not met by will on yours: cp. Tr. 198 ou)x e(kw/n, e(kou=si de\ | cu/nestin: Ant. 276 pa/reimi d' a)/kwn ou)x e(kou=sin.

prosqe/sqai, "bestow," a sense freq. in the active, but somewhat rare in the midd.: cp., however, Ant. 40 prosqei/mhn (ple/on ti, "contribute"), Aesch. Eum. 735 yh=fon d' *)ore/sth| th/nd' e)gw\ prosqh/somai. The midd. usu.="to annex" (404), or "to take on oneself" (O. T. 1460 n.). Cp. on prosqh/sei, 153.
h)=, the old Attic form, given by L in 973, 1366 (though not elsewhere), and attested by ancient scholia for fr. 406 and O. T. 1123, where see n.
mesto\s with partic.: [Dem.] or. 48 § 28(prob. by a contemporary of Dem.) e)peidh\ de\ mesto\s e)ge/neto a)ganaktw=n: Eur. Hipp. 664 misw=n d' ou)/pot' e)mplhsqh/somai | gunai=kas.
e)cew/qeis ka)ce/b.: for the impf. cp. 356, 441.
tou=t): Ant. 96 to\ deino\n tou=to, this danger of which thou speakest.

po/lin, the State in the person of its head, Theseus: ge/nos, the people of Attica, as represented by the elders of Colonus. Cp. Ai. 861 kleinai/ t' *)aqh=nai kai\ to\ su/ntrofon ge/nos. So El. 706 *ai)nia\n ge/nos: fr. 61 ko/rh| te ka)rgei/a| ge/nos.

metaspa=n, to snatch to the other side (cp. metakinei=n, metapei/qein etc.), found only here, but not open to just suspicion, though Blaydes changes it to m' a)pospa=n. So meqe/lkein in Anth. Plan. 5. 384.

sklhra\ malqakw=s le/gwn, putting hard purposes into soft words: disguising the ungenerous treatment which was really contemplated (399) under the name of a recall to home and friends (757). For the verbal contrast cp. Epicharmus fr. 121 w)= ponhre/, mh\ ta\ malaka\ mw/eo mh\ ta\ sklh/r' e)/xh|s, "woo not softness, lest thou wed hardness." Arist. Rhet. 3.7.10(speaking of the relation to be observed between the sounds of words, and the tones of the orator's voice) e)a\n ou)=n ta\ malaka\ sklhrw=s kai\ ta\ sklhra\ malakw=s le/ghtai, a)pi/qanon gi/gnetai. Cp. 1406.
au(/th, subject (instead of tou=to, see on 88),

ti/s te/ryis predicate: a)/kontas object to filei=n: What pleasure is this, —that people should be hospitable to one against one's inclination? Thuc. 3.12 ti/s ou)=n au(/th h)\ fili/a e)gi/gneto h)\ e)leuqeri/a pisth/;

filei=n, Il. 6.15 pa/ntas ga\r file/esken o(dw=| e)/pi oi)ki/a nai/wn: Od. 8.42 o)/fra cei=non e)ni\ mega/roisi file/wmen. So often a)gapa/w. Better thus than: "what joy is it (for thee) to caress me against my will?" The illustration (776 ff.) shows that a)/kontas refers to the reluctance of Oed., not to the constraint put by the oracle on the Thebans.
tosau/th was a mere blunder.

w(/sper merely introduces the illustration, like "For instance." Plat. Gorg. 451A w(/sper a)/n, ei)/ ti/s me e)/roito... ei)/poim' a)/n: Rep. 420 C w(/sper ou)=n a)
 ei) h(ma=s a)ndria/ntas gra/fontas proselqw/n tis e)/yege le/gwn,...metri/ws a)
 e)dokou=men pro\s au)to
 a)pologei=sqai le/gontes.
tis before ei) is here a case of "hyperbaton," in which Soph. is sometimes bold: cp. O. T. 1251 n.
tuxei=n: cp. O. T. 1435 kai\ tou= me xrei/as w(=de liparei=s tuxei=n;

w(=n xrh/|zois. The verb in the relative clause takes the optative mood of the verb in the principal clause (e)/xonti=o(/te e)/xois): cp. Eur. Hel. 435 ti/s a)\n mo/loi | o(/stis diaggei/leie, and n. to O. T. 506.

h( xa/ris: when the benefit (the thing done) should bring with it no sense of a favour conferred: xa/ris and xa/rin being used in two different senses: cp. xa/rin a)/xarin...e)pikra=nai (Aesch. Ag. 1545) to grant a boon which gives no pleasure.
a)=r): see on 753. The second a)/n is warranted by the stress on th=sd), and is more likely than th=sde/ g': cp. on O. T. 339.
kai\ su\, thou on thy part: cp. on 53.
lo/gw| … toi=si d' e)/rgoisin: cp. El. 60 o(/tan lo/gw| qanw\n | e)/rgoisi swqw=: Eur. Tr. 1233 o)/nom' e)/xousa, ta)/rga d' ou)/.

kai\ toi=sd). The Chorus had been present when Ismene told Oed. of the Theban designs, and when he uttered an imprecation on his sons (399—460): and Theseus left the stage at 667. But fra/sw refers to the explicit and public statement of Creon's baseness, now addressed, before his face, to the Chorus.

pa/raulon, having my abode (au)lh/) beside you, i.e. a)/gxi gh=s *kadmei/as (399), but outside of it. So Ai. 892 ti/nos boh\ pa/raulos e)ce/bh na/pous; "whose cry burst from the covert of the wood at our side?": fr. 460 pa/raulos *(ellhsponti/s, a neighbour at the Hellespont.
kakw=n a)/natos: see on a)nh/nemon xeimw/nwn 677.

th=sd) is a certain correction of the MS. tw=nd), which would be awkward if masc. (as = the Athenians), and pointless if neut., since nothing has yet been said between Creon and Oed. about such kaka/. The schol., kai\ i(/na h( *qh/bh a)blabh\s e)/stai e)k tau/ths th=s gh=s, confirms th=sd). Join th=sde xqono/s with kakw=n, "evils coming from this land" (gen. of source).

a)pallaxqh=| is absol., "get off," as El. 1002 a)/lupos a)/ths e)capallaxqh/somai: Ar. Plut. 271 a)pallagh=nai | a)zh/mios. If it were joined with th=sde xqono/s, "get free of this land" (as Wecklein takes it), the phrase would imply that Thebes was already involved in a feud with Athens. Besides, the words would naturally mean, "get safely out of this land."

tau=ta … ta/d), a good instance of the normal distinction. Cp. Her. 6.53 tau=ta me\n *lakedaimo/nioi le/gousi,...ta/de de\...e)gw\ gra/fw: Xen. Anab. 2.1.20 tau=ta me\n dh\ su\ le/geis: par' h(mw=n de\ a)pa/ggelle ta/de. In poetry, however, ou(=tos often refers to what follows (as Od. 2.306
tau=ta de/ toi ma/la pa/nta teleuth/sousin *)axaioi/,
nh=a kai\ e)cai/tous e)re/tas), and o(/de to what has just preceded: cp. on 1007.

xw/ras with a)la/stwr, my scourge of the land, the avenging spirit which, through my curse, will ever haunt the land: for the gen., cp. Tr. 1092 *neme/as e)/noikon (the lion), bouko/lwn a)la/stora, scourge of herdsmen: Xenarchus (Midd. Comedy, c. 350 B.C.) *boutali/wn fr. 1. 3 a)la/stwr ei)spe/paike *pelopidw=n, a very fiend of the Pelopidae has burst in. If we joined e)kei= xw/ras, the phrase could mean nothing but "in that part of the country," which is pointless here. For e)nnai/wn cp. Aesch. Suppl. 415 baru\n cu/noikon...a)la/stora. The erasure after e)/st) in L suggests to me the possibility that e)/sw | xw/ras and e)kei= | xw/ran (depending on e)nnai/wn) may have been alternative readings, from which ours has been composed; but there is no evidence.

tosou=ton, e)nqanei=n mo/non is bold. The infin. must be explained as in appos. with tosou=ton,—"just thus much right in the land—the right to die in it." For the regular construction, see O. T. 1191 tosou=ton o(/son dokei=n: Aesch. Theb. 730
(in ref. to these same brothers) si/daros
xqo/na nai/ein diaph/las, o(po/san kai\ fqime/noisin kate/xein,
tw=n mega/lwn pedi/wn a)moi/rous: Xen. Anab. 4.8.12 tosou=ton xwri/on katasxei=n...o(/son e)/cw tou\s e)sxa/tous lo/xous gene/sqai tw=n polemi/wn kera/twn: Thuc. 1.2 nemo/menoi...ta\ au(tw=n e(/kastoi o(/son a)pozh=n. The conjecture of Blaydes, o(/sonper instead of tosou=ton, is hardly probable.

e)nqanei=n: cp. [Eur.] Rhes. 869 w)= gai=a patri/s, pw=s a)\n e)nqa/noimi/ soi; a poet. word: in Lys. or. 16 § 15 the prose e)napoqano/ntwn should prob. be restored. Remark that e)nqanei=n can mean only "to die in," not "to lie dead in": but the sense is, "just enough ground, with a view to dying (instead of reigning) on Theban soil"; i.e., as much as a dead man will need. The phrase is half-proverbial: Aristoph. Eccl. 592 mhde\ gewrgei=n to\n me\n pollh/n, tw=| d' ei)=nai mhde\ tafh=nai. Freeman, Old English History p. 313,/bibl> "...What will my brother King Harold of England give to King Harold of Norway?" … "Seven foot of the ground of England, or more perchance, seeing he is taller than other men." Shaksp. H. IV. Pt. i. 5. 4. 89
When that this body did contain a spirit,
A kingdom for it was too small a bound;
But now two paces of the vilest earth
Is room enough.
safeste/rwn: see on 623. The kai\ of two MSS. (A, R) is strongly recommended by Greek usage, and is probably to be combined with e)k, which, though not necessary with klu/w, has L's support.
klu/w, pres., know by hearing, as Ph. 261, Tr. 68, etc.: cp. 240 n.

to\ so\n … sto/ma, thy mouth has come hither suborned: thou hast come as a mere mouthpiece of the Thebans, secretly pledged to aid their designs on me. Cp. O. T. 426 (Teiresias says) kai\ *kre/onta kai\ tou)mo\n sto/ma | prophla/kize, my message from Apollo.

u(po/blhton: cp. Ai. 481
ou)dei\s e)rei= poq' w(s u(po/blhton lo/gon,
*ai)/as, e)/lecas, a)lla\ th=s sautou= freno/s, a word not true to thy nature. So u(po/pemptos of an insidious emissary, Xen. Anab. 3.3.4.

pollh\n e)/xon sto/mwsin, with a hard and keen edge,—thoroughly attempered to a shameless and cruel task. sto/mwsis was the process of tempering iron to receive an edge or point (sto/ma); cp. Arist. Meteor. 4.6 th/ketai de\ kai\ o( ei)rgasme/nos si/dhros, w(/ste u(gro\s gi/gnesqai kai\ pa/lin ph/gnusqai. kai\ ta\ stomw/mata poiou=sin ou)/tws: u(fi/statai ga\r kai\ a)pokaqai/retai ka/tw h( skwri/a (dross). o(/tan de\ polla/kis pa/qh| kai\ kaqaro\s ge/nhtai, tou=to sto/mwma gi/gnetai (this makes tempered iron). Hence, fig., Plut.
