Mor. 988 D th=s a)ndrei/as oi(=on bafh/ tis o( qumo/s e)sti kai\ sto/mwma: Lycurg. 16 ta\ d) u(gieina\ (bre/fh) ma=llon stomou=sqai kai\ kratu/nesqai th\n e(/cin, have their constitutions tempered and strengthened. Aristoph. Nub. 1107
me/mnhs' o(/pws
eu)= moi stomw/seis au)to/n, e)pi\ me\n qa/tera
oi(=on dikidi/ois, th\n d' e(te/ran au)tou= gna/qon
sto/mwson oi(/an e)s ta\ mei/zw pra/gmata, alluding to a two-edged blade; schol. o)cunei=s... a)konh/seis. The double sense of sto/ma has suggested the parh/xhsis with sto/mwsin: cp. Tr. 1176 tou)mo\n o)cu=nai sto/ma. Ai. 650
o(\s ta\ dei/n' e)karte/roun to/te,
bafh=| si/dhros w(/s, e)fhlu/nfhn sto/ma: "I, erst so wondrous firm,—yea, as iron hardened in the dipping,—felt the keen edge of my temper softened." Cp. Ai. 584 glw=ssa... teqhgme/nh.

kaka/ and swth/ria are predicates: cp. Eur. Hipp. 471 a)ll' ei) ta\ plei/w xrhsta\ tw=n kakw=n e)/xeis. Cp. Ant. 313
e)k tw=n ga\r ai)sxrw=n lhmma/twn tou\s plei/onas
a)twme/nous i)/dois a)\n h)\ seswsme/nous. Oed. means: "By pleading with me to return, you will only illustrate your own heartlessness: you will never win me as a safeguard for Thebes."

If oi)=da is right (as it seems to be), mh/ can hardly be explained otherwise than by emphasis, i.e. by the strong assurance which the speaker expresses. But what form should the partic. have? (1) With the MS. pei/qwn, the sense is: "However, I am assured that I am not persuading you of this,—go!" In 656
oi)=d' e)gw/ se mh/tina
e)nqe/nd' a)pa/cont' a)/ndra appears to be a like case of strong assurance. Cp. O. T. 1455. In 1121 there is another: e)pi/stamai ga\r th/nde... te/ryin par' a)/llou mhdeno\s pefasme/nhn. Here, however, oi(=da mh\ pei/qwn is so far stranger, that the emphasis appears less appropriate in stating the speaker's consciousness of what he himself is doing. (2) The v.l. pei/qont), extant in at least one MS. (F), removes this objection. "However, I am assured that you are not persuading (either the Athenians or me, cp. 803)—go!" (3) pei/swn would be liable to the same remark as pei/qwn. (4) pei/sont) would complete the parallelism with 656, but is not required by the "strong assurance" view, which applies to past (1121) or present as well as to future.—Another view is that mh/ gives a quasi-imperative force: "I know that you shan't persuade." This might apply to 656. Here it is much more difficult, esp. if we do not adopt pei/sont): in 1121 it fails.
With i)/sqi … me for oi)=da...de the imper. would explain mh/ (cp. on 78): and we may note that in O. T. 376 the MSS. changed se...e(mou= into me...sou=. But the context confirms oi)=da.

In later Greek mh/ with partic., in regard to fact, was common, as Luc. Dial. Mort. 16 pw=s ou)=n a)kribh\s o( *ai)ako\s w)\n ou) die/gnw de mh\ o)/nta e)kei=non; "failed to discern that you were not he," where mh\ o)/nta, though it might be paraphrased by ei) mh\ h)=sqa, virtually=o(/ti ou)k h)=sqa. In Mod. Greek the partic. always takes mh/, not de/n. This latter tendency may conceivably have affected our MSS.: e.g. toia/d' ou) pei/qwn may have once stood here.

ei) terpoi/meqa, if we should have content therewith: cp. Ant. 1168
plou/tei te ga\r kat' oi)=kon, ei) bou/lei, me/ga,
kai\ zh= tu/rannon sxh=m' e)/xwn: e)a\n d' a)ph=|
tou/twn to\ xai/rein, ta)/ll' e)gw\ kapnou= skia=s
ou)k a)\n priai/mhn a)ndri\ pro\s th\n h(donh/n.
Which of us do you consider the greater sufferer by your present attitude? Me, because I am not to bring you back? Or yourself, when you reject your friends and country?

dustuxei=n has been explained as "to be in error," referring to Creon's ignorance of the lot in store for Thebes (787); but it is simpler to take it of Creon's failure to win Oedipus. However great that loss may be, Creon means, the loss to Oed. himself will be greater still.

e)s ta\ sa/, "with regard to your doings"; cp. 1121: O. T. 980 su\ d' ei)s ta\ mhtro\s mh\ fobou= numfeu/mata (n.). h)\ s' ei)s ta\ sautou=, se\ being elided, though emphatic: O. T. 64 po/lin te ka)me\ kai\ s' o(mou= ste/nei.
e)n tw=| nu=n lo/gw|, in our present discussion (from 728).

Creon had said, in effect, "Your happiness is as much my object as our own." "My happiness," Oed. rejoins, "will be best secured if your application is rejected by the people of Colonus, as by myself."
fu/sas, cp. 150, El. 1463 ( w(s ) kolastou= prostuxw\n fu/sh| fre/nas: Her. 5.91 do/can...fu/sas au)ca/netai.

lu=ma, a "stain," or "reproach." In the only other place where Soph. has the word (Ai. 655 lu/maq' a(gni/sas e)ma/) it has its primary sense of "something washed off" (from √*l*g, another form of √*l*ov, whence lou/w). lu/mh is only another form, and Eur. uses lu=ma in the sense proper to lu/mh, Eur. Tro. 588 lu=m' *)axaiw=n, their "bane" (Hector).
tre/fei, pass. (as O. T. 374 mia=s tre/fei pro\s nukto/s), thou livest on to disgrace thy years by thy folly. Not midd., "dost nourish a reproach."
Cp. O. T. 545 le/gein su\ deino/s (Oed. to Creon).
e)c a(/pantos, starting from anything as the a)formh/ or u(/lh of discourse; "on any theme." So e)k marks the conditions from which action sets out (w(s e)k tw=nd), Ai. 537).
eu)= le/gei, pleads speciously: Eur. Hec. 1191 du/nasqai ta)/dik' eu)= le/gein.

to\ kai/ria, the reading of Suidas, is supported by such passages as Aesch. PV 927 o(/son to/ t' a)/rxein kai\ to\ douleu/ein di/xa: Eur. Alc. 528 xwri\s to/ t' ei)=nai kai\ to\ mh\ nomi/zetai. In Philemon *sikeliko/s fr. 1. 7 e(/teron to/ t' a)lgei=n kai\ to\ qewrei=n e)/st' i)/sws, the second to\ is doubtful. But for ta\ kai/ria, the reading of the MSS., it may be urged that the phrase is ta\ kai/ria (le/gein, dra=n etc.) in Aesch. Th. 1, 619, Suppl. 446, Ch. 582, Eur. I. A. 829, Soph. Ai. 120, while El. 228 fronou=nti kai/ria (without art.) is isolated. If ta\ is retained, the ellipse of to\ is illustrated by 606, where see n.: and add trag. incert. fr. 469 xwri\s ta\ *musw=n kai\ *frugw=n o(ri/smata.

o(/tw|=tou/tw| o(/tw|, in the opinion of one who possesses only such sense as yours: for the ethic dat. cp. 1446, Aristoph. Av. 445 pa=si nika=n toi=s kritai=s: Ant. 904 kai/toi s' e)gw\ )ti/mhsa toi=s fronou=sin eu)=. For i)/sos, only so much, cp. O. T. 810 ou) mh\n i)/shn g' e)/tisen: Her. 2.3 nomi/zwn pa/ntas a)nqrw/pous i)/son peri\ au)tw=n e)pi/stasqai, equally little: for i)/sos kai\ instead of w(/sper, O. T. 1187.
pro\ tw=nde, as O. T. 10 pro\ tw=nde fwnei=n (n.).

e)formw=n with e)/nqa xrh/, keeping jealous watch at the place where I am destined to dwell: fig. from a hostile fleet watching a position; cp. Dem. or. 3 § 7 h)=n tou=to w(/sper e)mpo/disma/ ti tw=| *fili/ppw| kai\ dusxere/s, po/lin mega/lhn e)formei=n toi=s e(autou= kairoi=s. me with fu/lass' only: in class. Gk. e)formei=n does not take acc.

For me followed by e)me/, cp. El. 1359 a)lla/ me | lo/gois a)pw/llus, e)/rg' e)/xwn h(/dist' e)moi/, where e)moi/ is not more emphatic than me. So in Tr. 1171 ka)do/koun pra/cein kalw=s: | to\ d' h)=n a)/r' ou)de\n a)/llo plh\n qanei=n e)me/, where there is no contrast between e)me/ and some one else: Ant. 292 w(s ste/rgein e)me/: Ph. 299 to\ mh\ nosei=n e)me/, where the stress is on the verb, not on the pronoun. And so here, too, it may be doubted whether e)me/ conveys such an emphasis as would be given by an italicised "my,"— implying a reproof of meddlesomeness. The stress is rather on xrh\ nai/ein: Apollo has brought him to this rest (89).

This passage, which has been variously altered, appears to me to be sound as it stands in the MSS. Oedipus has undertaken to speak for the men of Attica (e)rw= ga\r kai\ pro\ tw=nde). Creon refuses to identify him with them, bitterly reminding the Theban that his real ties are elsewhere. "I call them—not thee— to witness my protest": i.e. "I have a just claim on thee, which thou repellest:— I appeal to a judgment more impartial than thine own." The words mark the point at which he drops persuasion. He now turns to menace. "But, for the tone of thy reply to kinsmen" (meaning, to himself, cp. on 148 smikroi=s), "if I catch thee"—an aposiopesis. (Cp. Il. 1.580
ei)/per ga/r k' e)qe/lh|sin *)olu/mpios a)sterophth\s
e)c e(de/wn stufeli/cai: o( ga\r polu\ fe/rtero/s e)stin: Verg. Aen. 1. 135 Quos ego … )
martu/romai, antestor: cp. Aristoph. Pax 1119 *t*p. w)= pai=e pai=e to\n *ba/kin. *i*e. martu/romai.

a)ntamei/bei: a)mei/bomai usu. takes a simple acc. of the person to whom a reply is made (991); but cp. Her. 8.60 to/te me\n h)pi/ws pro\s to\n *kori/nqion a)mei/yato: and, since a)pokri/nomai pro/s tina was common, it would have been strange if the same construction had been rigidly denied to a)mei/bomai. Even if

pro\s were not taken with a)ntamei/bei here, it could still mean "in relation to": cp. Tr. 468 kako\n | pro\s a)/llon ei)=nai, pro\s d' e)/m' a)yeudei=n a)ei/. So Ai. 680
e)/s te to\n fi/lon
tosau=q' u(pourgw=n w)felei=n boulh/somai.
oi(=a causal=e)pei\ toiau=ta: cp. on 263.
tw=nde summ. with bi/a|: cp. 657.

h)= mh\n in a threat, as Aesch. PV 907
h)= mh\n e)/ti *zeu/s, kai/per au)qa/dh fronw=n,
e)/stai tapeino/s.
ka)/neu tou=de, sc. tou= e(lei=n se. Cp. O. T. 1158 a)ll' ei)s to/d' h(/ceis, sc. ei)s to\ o)le/sqai. The MS. ka)/neu tw=nde could here mean nothing but "e'en apart from these men."

luphqei\s e)/sei,=a fut. perf., here implying, "wilt soon be grieved" (though it could also mean, "wilt suffer a lasting grief"): so O. T. 1146 ou) siwph/sas e)/sei; Ant. 1067 a)ntidou\s e)/sei. In prose the part. thus used with e)/somai is the perf., not the aor.
poi/w| su\n e)/rgw|, on the warrant of what deed,—since luphqei\s e)/sei implies that something has already been done to cause the pain which will soon be felt.

su
 has the same force as in su
 qew=|:— "with what deed to support the threat." Cp. O. T. 656 e)n ai)ti/a| | su
 a)fanei= lo/gw| … balei=n, to accuse one with the help of an unproved story. Xen. sometimes has su/n thus where a simple instrum. dat. would suffice: An. 3. 1. 22 i)e/nai e)pi\ to
 a)gw=na polu\ su
 fronh/mati mei/zoni: 3. 2. 8 ei)...dianoou/meqa su
 toi=s o(/plois...di/khn e)piqei=nai au)toi=s.
a)peilh/sas e)/xeis=a perf.: cp. O. T. 577 n.

th\n me\n, Ismene, who left the scene at 509 to make the offerings in the grove. Creon may have seized her, as a hostage, before his entrance at 728; or may have signed to one of his guards to go and do so, when he found that Oedipus was stubborn.
ta/de might be cognate acc.,= ta/de ta\ oi)mw/gmata (cp. Aesch. Ag. 1307 *k*a. feu=, feu=. *x*o. ti/ tou=t' e)/feucas;), but it rather means, "this capture."
The th/nde g) of the MSS. could be retained only if mou were changed to kai\ and given to Creon.
ou) makr. xro/nou: see on 397.
to\n a)sebh=, because Oedipus is under the protection of the deities (287), and especially because, as he may well suppose, Ismene has been snatched from the sacred grove (cp. on 818).

qa=sson, oft. in impatient command, as 839, Ai. 581 pu/kaze qa=sson: O. T. 430 ou)k ei)s o)/leqron; ou)xi\ qa=sson; Write ta\ nu=n rather than tanu=n, since it is opp. to a(\ pro/sqen: di/kaia, predicate.
ei)/rgasai (his capture of Ismene) need not be changed to ei)rga/sw, since pro/sqen can mean "already."
u(mi=n, addressing his guards (723). Cp. the order given by Oed. to pinion the herdsman (O. T. 1154), and by Creon (in Ant. 578) to lead off the sisters.
a)\n ei)/h: here in giving a command with cold sternness. Cp. 725 (in request), O. T. 343 (in fixed resolve).
poi= fu/gw; cp. on 310.

qew=n … h)\ brotw=n; Ai. 399
ou)/te ga\r qew=n ge/nos ou)/q' a(meri/wn
e)/t' a)/cios ble/pein tin' ei)s o)/nasin a)nqrw/pwn.

ou)x a(/yomai. With these words, Creon steps towards Antigone. His actual seizure of her is marked by the words tou\s e)mou\s a)/gw. The fut., therefore, is more dramatic than a(/ptomai would be. And Wecklein's rejection of 830 f. would enfeeble the scene.

th=s e)mh=s, since he considers himself as now the guardian of his nieces,—their father having forfeited all rights at Thebes (cp. O. T. 1506 n.): El. 536 a)ll' ou) meth=n au)toi=si th/n g' e)mh\n ktanei=n.
tou\s e)mou\s: cp. 148 smikroi=s (=Antigone); Ant. 48 a)ll' ou)de\n au)tw=| tw=n e)mw=n m' ei)/rgein me/ta (i.e. from my brother): O. T. 1448 o)rqw=s tw=n ge sw=n telei=s u(/per (for thy sister).

—886 The phrase tou\s e)mou\s a)/gw indicates the moment at which Creon lays his hand on Antigone. It is followed by 11 verses, 833—843, in which the dochmiacs of the Chorus, blended with iambic trimeters, mark excitement. Antistrophic to these are the 11 verses, 876—886, which in like manner follow the moment at which Creon lays his hand on Oedipus. As a lyric interposition in dialogue, the passage has a kommatic character, though it does not constitute a kommo/s proper in the same sense as 510—548, 1447—1499, or 1670— 1750.

a)fh/seis: 838 me/qes. The former is properly, "allow to depart,"—the latter, "release from one's grasp"; but they differ here only as "let her alone" from the more specific "unhand her." Cp. 857 ou)/toi s' a)fh/sw, I will not allow thee to leave Colonus.

ei)s ba/sanon ei)= xerw=n, to the test of (afforded by) blows: cp. xeirw=n no/mos, the arbitrament of blows (as opp. to di/khs no/mos), Her. 9.48 pri\n...h)\ summi/cai h(me/as e)s xeirw=n te no/mon a)pike/sqai. Xen. Cyr. 2.1.11 w(s xei=ras summi/contas toi=s polemi/ois.
ei)= as in the common phrase ei)s xei=ras i)e/nai tini/, or sunie/nai.
ei)/rgou, said as the Chorus approach him threateningly: cp. O. T. 890 tw=n a)se/ptwn e)/rcetai (n.).
mwme/nou, meditating, designing: a part. used once in dialogue by Soph. (Tr. 1136 h(/marte xrhsta\ mwme/nh), and twice in lyrics by Aesch. (Ch. 45, 441).
po/lei: tai=s *qh/bais schol. The accent of ma/xhi in the MSS. cannot weigh in deciding between ma/xei and maxei=, since such errors of accent are countless; and the fut. is distinctly better here.

ou)k h)go/reuon...; a familiar phrase; Aristoph. Ach. 41 ou)k h)go/reuon; tou=t' e)kei=n' ou(gw\ )legon: Plut. 102 ou)k h)go/reuon o(/ti pare/cein pra/gmata | h)melle/thn moi; Nub. 1456 ti/ dh=ta tau=t' ou)/ moi to/t' h)goreu/ete; So O. T. 973 ou)/koun e)gw/ soi tau=ta prou)/legon pa/lai;—Oed. alludes to 587, 653.

mh\ )pi/tass' a(\ mh\ kratei=s, do not give orders in matters where you are not master. a(\ is not for w(=n, but is cogn. accus. (or acc. of respect), as O. T. 1522 pa/nta mh\ bou/lou kratei=n: | kai\ ga\r a(kra/thsas. For the gen. in a like sense cp. Her. 9.16 e)xqi/sth...o)du/nh..., polla\ frone/onta mhdeno\s krate/ein, to have many presentiments, and power over nothing. Ant. 664 tou)pita/ssein toi=s kratu/nousin, to dictate to one's masters. Theocr. 15. 90 pasa/menos e)pi/tasse (wait till you are our master before you give us orders).
At Creon's words, when he laid his hand on Antigone (832), one of his guards stepped up, and placed himself at her side.

xala=n le/gw soi, like ou)k a)fh/seis and me/qes, is said to Creon. Creon's soi/, a mocking echo of theirs, is said to the guard: "and I tell thee to start on thy journey." If it were said to the Chorus, the sense would be either, (1) "and I tell thee to begone," or (2) "and I tell thee that [she] is to go": but (1) is not idiomatic, and (2) is impossible.
pro/baq' … ba=te, as oft. esp. in Eur., e.g. Or. 181 dioixo/meq', oi)xo/meq'.
w(=de=deu=ro (O. T. 7 n.): cp. 182.
e)/ntopoi, the other dwellers at Colonus.

po/lis … sqe/nei: our city—yea, our city—is being brought low by sheer strength: e)nai/retai, because the majesty of the State is destroyed when its asylum is violated. In po/lis e)ma/, the stress is on the first word, not on the second.

sqe/nei with e)nai/retai seems to be sufficiently defended by Eur. Bacch. 953 ou) sqe/nei nikhte/on | gunai=kas, where it differs from bi/a| only as it differs here,—i.e. as meaning strictly, "by an exertion of strength," not, "by violence": cp. ib. 1127 a)pespa/racen w)=mon, ou)x u(po\ sqe/nous, not by her own strength (since the god made it easy for her). Some place a point at e)ma/, taking sqe/nei with pro/baq', come forth in strength: but such a use of sqe/nei alone is harsher than those in which sqe/nei takes an adj., as e)pelqw\n ou)k e)la/ssoni sqe/nei (Ai. 438), or panti\ sqe/nei, "with all one's might." Rather than Wecklein's e)/t' ou) sqe/nei, I would propose—if any change were needed—
po/lis e)nai/retai, po/lis: i)/t), a)sqenei=
pro/baq' w(=de/ moi. But no change seems needful.
moi: ethic dat.; cp. 81.
w)= ta/las: cp. 753.

e)k tou/toin … skh/ptroin, by means of these two supports,—the art. being omitted, as 471 tou=to xeu=m). This is simpler than to construe, "with the help of these (girls) as supports." (For tou/toin, as fem. dual, cp. on 445.) We should then have to take it as a case of the pron. assimilated to the gender of the predicate (see on tau/thn...pau=lan 88).

e)k refers to the skh=ptra as an antecedent condition of his walking. Essentially the same use, though under slightly different phases, appears in 807 e)c a(/pantos: Tr. 875 ( be/bhken ) e)c a)kinh/tou podo/s: Ph. 91 e)c e(no\s podo/s: El. 742 w)rqou=q' o( tlh/mwn o)rqo\s e)c o)rqw=n di/frwn.

skh/ptroin: cp. 1109: Eur. Hec. 280
h(/d' a)nti\ tollw=n e)sti/ moi parayuxh/,
po/lis, tiqh/nh, ba/ktron, h(gemw\n o(dou=.

odoiporh/sh|s. As between -eis and -his in verbal endings, neither L nor any of our MSS. has authority. The reason for preferring the aor. subj. here is one of usage. ou) mh\ o(doiporh/sh|s is a denial: ou) mh\ o(doiporh/seis, a prohibition. The latter is grammatically as right as the other, but does not suit this context. (The remarks on 177 refer to the 1st and 3rd pers. fut. ind., not to the 2nd.)

nika=n, to worst,—by carrying your point against them (not with ref. to future defeats of Thebans by Athenians, 621). Cp. 1204: Ai. 1353 pau=sai: kratei=s toi tw=n fi/lwn nikw/menos, thou conquerest, when thy friends conquer thee.

tu/rannos, one of the royal house: cp. Tr. 316 mh\ tw=n tura/nnwn; "is she of the royal stock?" The Creon of O. T. 588 does not wish tu/rannos ei)=nai (to be king) ma=llon h)\ tu/ranna dra=n: but the captor of the blind man's daughters must seek a touch of dignity from any source.
gnw/sei ta/de, "thou wilt understand these things" (=thy present acts in their true bearings),—explained by o(qou/nek), etc., "viz., that" etc.
au(to\n =seauto/n: so 930, 1356: but au(to\n =e)mauto/n 966, O. T. 138 (n.).
For dra=|s followed by ei)rga/sw, instead of e)/drasas, cp. O. T. 54 w(s ei)/per a)/rceis … w(/sper kratei=s (n.).

bi/a| fi/lwn applies to his former conduct, since, in searching out his origin, he acted against the passionate entreaties of Iocasta (O. T. 1060ff. ). Greek idiom uses a parataxis, ou)/te nu=n ... ou)/te pro/sqen, where ours would subordinate the second clause to the first, "now, as before": cp. 308.

o)rgh=| xa/rin dou/s: cp. 1182: El. 331 qumw=| matai/w| mh\ xari/zesqai kena/: Cratinus fr. inc. 146 e)/sqie kai\ sh=| gastri\ di/dou xa/rin. We remember his blow at Laïus (pai/w di' o)rgh=s O. T. 807) — his anger with Teiresias (w(s o)rgh=s e)/xw, ib. 345) — his anger with Iocasta (ib. 1067) — his frantic self-blinding (ib. 1268).

The guards, carrying off Antigone, have already left the scene (847); cp. 875 mou=nos. Creon is now about to follow them, when the Chorus again approach him, and protest that he shall not leave Colonus unless the two maidens are restored.

tw=nde. So the plur. ai(/de of the two sisters below, 1107, 1367, 1379 (immediately after the masc. dual toiw/d', referring to the brothers), 1668; ta/sd' 1121, 1146, 1634, O. T. 1507, Ant. 579. On the other hand the dual of o(/de occurs only thrice in Soph.; above, 445 toi=nde: tw/de El. 981f. bis. (Below, 1121, ta/de is a corrupt v.l. for ta/sde.) It is surely needless, then, to write toi=nde here. But Reisig's plea for the plur. is over-subtle,— that it contrasts with the extenuating tone of tou/toin in 859 (merely two). Rather Creon uses the dual because he is thinking of the two sisters together as the "two supports" of Oed. (848, 445). The plur. differs from the dual simply by the absence of any stress on the notion of "a pair." The Chorus are thinking how he had first seized Ismene (818) and then Antigone.
r(u/sion: Then thou shalt soon deposit even a greater security for my city.

po/lei=Thebes, as in Creon's former words, 837 po/lei maxei=. r(u/sios denotes what one draws to oneself, carries off, (1) as booty, (2) as a security, (3) in reprisal. Here qh/seis points to (2), since e)ne/xuron tiqe/nai, to deposit a pledge, was a regular phrase: Aristoph. Eccl. 754
po/teron metoikizo/menos e)cenh/noxas
au)/t', h)\ fe/reis e)ne/xura qh/swn; "or are you taking them to be deposited as securities?" Plat. Legg. 820 E e)ne/xura...tou\s qe/ntas (those who have given the pledges)... tou\s qeme/nous (those to whom they have been given).

po/lei dat. of interest, as u(potiqe/nai "to mortgage" takes a dat. of the mortgagee: Dem. or. 27 § 25 o( u(poqei\s tw=| patri\ ta)ndra/poda.—The version, "you will cause a greater prize to be taken from Athens," is inadmissible.

qh/seis po/lei could not mean, "cause for Athens," in the sense, "cause to be taken from Athens." If qh/seis meant "cause" (instead of "pay"), po/lei would still be the city which received the r(u/sion.

e)fa/yomai: Aesch. Suppl. 412 kai\ mh/te dh=ris r(usi/wn e)fa/yetai, (and so) "that the foeman shall not lay hands on you as prizes" (where the king of Argos is speaking to the Danaïdes whom he protects).

After deino
 le/gois (L), or le/geis, a syllable has to be supplied conjecturally. Triclinius added w(s ("be sure that," 45) before tou=to: but this mars the rhythm: and the simple fut. (as in 860) is more forcible. The optat. le/gois of L, which is not likely to be a mere error for le/geis, strongly favours Hermann's simple remedy, deino
 le/gois a)/n, "'twere a dread deed that thou threatenest" (if only thou couldst do it): cp. on 647 me/g' a)
 le/gois dw/rhma. Next to this, I should prefer Wecklein's deino\s lo/gois ei)=.
pepra/cetai, "will have been done": i.e. will be done forthwith: Dem. or. 19 § 74 e)/fh...tau=ta pepra/cesqai duoi=n h)\ triw=n h(merw=n. Cp. O. T. 1146 n.

h)\n mh/ g). Piderit is clearly right (I think) in giving this verse to the Chorus, not to Creon. Creon, who has long since dropped the semblance of courtesy with which he began (759), cannot, of course, mean to express serious deference for the wishes of Theseus; while, as an ironical defiance, the words would be extremely tame. In the mouth of the Chorus, however, the threat has point, since they know their king's public resolve (656); it has also dramatic force, since he is soon to appear (887). The words of Oed. (863) refer to 861.

a)peirga/qh|: cp. El. 1271 ei)rgaqei=n (and so Eur.): Aesch. Eum. 566 kateirgaqou= (aor. imper. midd.). The forms e)e/rgaqen, a)poe/rgaqe (aor., or, as some would call them, impf.) are Homeric. See n. on O. T. 651 ei)ka/qw.

fqe/gm), "voice," rather than "word": the conj. qre/mm) (Blaydes) would efface an expressive touch. yau/eis might be defended as present of intention or attempt (cp. on 993 ktei/noi): but yau/seis is more natural, and expresses indignation with greater force.

au)dw= siwpa=n. Creon forbids the utterance of the curse which he forebodes; and the injunction reminds Oedipus that he is near the Awful Goddesses who impose abstinence from all ill-omened words. "Nay" (ga/r), he cries, "may they suffer me to utter one imprecation more (e)/ti"). ga/r implies, "I will not yet be mute"; cp. also its use in wishes, ei) ga/r, ei)/qe ga/r, etc. e)/ti recalls the former imprecation on his sons (421 ff.).
a)/fwnon … a)ra=s: cp. on 677 a)nh/nemon...xeimw/nwn.
th=s is a certain correction of the MS. gh=s (*t for *g).
See Appendix on this passage.
o(/s, with caus. force, "since thou hast...": see on oi(/tines, 263.

yilo\n o)/mm) can mean only "a defenceless eye," i.e. a defenceless maiden (Antigone) who was to him as eyesight. The phrase has bitter point, since Creon himself, in his smooth speech, had pathetically described Antigone as tou)pio/ntos a(rpa/sai (752). It is also less bold in Greek than in English, owing to the common figurative use of o)/mma, as if he had said, "my defenceless darling" (cp. on O. T. 987).

yilo\n should not be taken as acc. masc. with me: this would be tame and forced. Cp. below 1029 ou) yilo\n ou)d' a)/skeuon, not without allies or instruments: Ph. 953 yilo/s, ou)k e)/xwn trofh/n (when stripped of his bow).
a)pospa/sas takes a double acc. (like a)fairei=n, etc.): this is so natural that we need not desire o(/s g) or o(/s mou.

e)coi/xei, as 894 oi)/xetai...a)pospa/sas, though he is still present: so 1009 oi)/xei labw/n. As oi)/xomai cannot have a pres. sense, the departure meant can be only that of his guards (847): so that e)coi/xei merely adds the notion of "away" to a)pospa/sas.—Cp. El. 809 a)pospa/sas ga\r th=s e)mh=s oi)/xei freno/s, etc.

se/ t' au)to
 seems preferable to se\ kau)to
, since te … kai\ was usual in such formulas with au)to/s, cp. 462, 559, 952, 1009, 1125: though te was sometimes omitted when a third clause followed, as Antiph. or. 5 § 11 e)cw/leian au(tw=| kai\ ge/nei kai\ oi)ki/a| th=| sh=| e)parw/menon. I hardly think that qew=n can be right. It would be partitive, "of the gods, the allseeing Sun." When a partitive gen. stands thus, it ought to be emphatic, as in El. 1485 ti/ ga brotw=n a)
 su
 kakoi=s memigme/nwn | qnh/skein o( me/llwn etc. But here there is no stress on "gods" as opp. to other beings. I should prefer qeo\s, from which qew=n may have arisen by the carelessness of a copyist who connected it with ge/nos.
*(/hlios: invoked O. T. 660 (n.) ou) to\n pa/ntwn qew=n qeo\n pro/mon *(/alion, as the all-seeing god whom no deceit can escape.
bi/on cogn. acc., instead of gh=ras.

ka)me\: see on 53. In the Antigone Creon's wife Eurydicè and his son Haemon com mit suicide,—another son, Megareus, having already devoted his life for Thebes. But in Creon's own person, at least, the curse was fulfilled by his surviving all that he loved best. (Cp. Ant. 1317 ff.)
o(ra=te: he calls on them to witness the unnatural imprecation: cp. 813 martu/romai.
e)/rgois: cp. on 782.
r(h/masin is said with a bitter consciousness of impotence at this critical moment.
mou=nos, as 991, 1250: cp. O. T. 1418 n.

bradu/s (cp. 306) seems more fitting here than baru/s, which has no MS. warrant except L's superscript variant ghrw=n (sic) baru/s,—perh. a corruption of gh/ra| baru/s. In O. T. 17 su\n gh/ra| barei=s=weighed down with age, while in Ai. 1017 e)n gh/ra| baru/s=peevish in old age. The conjecture braxu/s was intended to mean "weak" (880).
i)w\ ta/las: see on 833.

ta/nde ( po/lin ) ou)ke/ti po/lin nemw=, I will no longer reckon Athens a city. Cp. O. T. 1080 e)mauto\n pai=da th=s *tu/xhs ne/mwn: El. 597
kai/ s' e)/gwge despo/tin
h)\ mhte/r' ou)k e)/lasson ei)s h(ma=s ne/mw. The fut. is better than the pres. here, since the latter would assume Creon's triumph.

toi=s … dikai/ois, instrumental dat., by means of ta\ di/kaia, i.e., by having justice on one's side. "In a just cause, one feeble man is stronger than a city." Cp. fr. 76 toi=s ga\r dikai/ois a)nte/xein ou) r(a/|dion: fr. 78 kai\ ga\r dikai/a glw=ss' e)/xei kra/tos me/ga. Here he speaks of the moral force with which *di/kh inspires her champion, while in 957 he admits himself to be physically helpless—kei) di/kai' o(/mws le/gw.
braxu\s, of slight physical strength: cp. 586: and for me/gan cp. on 148.
ta/=a(/: cp. on 747.

*zeu/s g' a)\n … su\ d' ou)/. The lacuna certainly preceded these words. The words in the strophe answering to ta/ g' ou) telei= and to the lacuna are 838 f. *x*o. me/qes xeroi=n | th\n pai=da qa=sson. It is probable, then, that the lost words here belonged to the Chorus, being such as *zeu/s moi cuni/stw.
u(/bris: for the quantity, cp. 442 n.
a)nekte/a, nom. neut. plur.: cp. on 495 o(dwta/.
pro/moi, invoking a higher power than the e)/ntopoi of Colonus (841), prepares the entrance of the king. For the plur., meaning Theseus, cp. a)/naktas 295 n., 1667.

pe/ran perw=s' oi(/de dh/, "yonder men" (with a gesture in the direction taken by Creon's guards) "are already passing towards the other side." Elmsley wrote pe/ra, which as adv. would mean "further." But pe/ran is right, since the Chorus is thinking of a passage from the Attic to the Boeotian side of the frontier, as of a passage across a river. pe/ra is ultra, "to some point beyond" a line which is either left to be understood, or expressed in the gen.: pe/ran is trans, "on, or to, the further side" of a river, sea, or intervening space. perw=si implies only that the fugitives are on their way to the border,—not that they are now actually crossing it.
dh/ nearly=h)/dh: O. T. 968 n.
bwmo\n, Poseidon's altar at Colonus: see on 55.
e)/sxet): see on 429.
qa=sson h)\ kaq' h(donh\n: see on 598.
e)/gnwn: so O. T. 1325 gignw/skw safw=s | kai/per skoteino/s, th/n ge sh\n au)dh\n o(/mws.
ta\ poi=a tau=ta; The art. is prefixed to poi=os when it asks for further definition: Plat. Crat. 395D *s*w. ei) a)lhqh= (e)sti\) ta\ peri\ au)to\n lego/mena. *e*p*m. ta\ poi=a tau=ta;
oi)/xetai: cp. on 867.
th\n mo/nhn: his sons are as dead to him (cp. 445).
per in the thesis of the 3rd foot is remarkable, and very unpleasing. Rhythm and sense would both gain if we could read oi)=a kai\ pe/ponq' ("indeed suffered").
ou)/koun tis … a)nagka/sei, "will not some one, then, compel?"="then let some one compel": cp. O. T. 430 n.
tou/sde bwmou\s: the plur. might be merely poetical for the sing. (888, cp. Ant. 1006), but here perh. refers to the association of Poseidon *(/ippios with Athena *(ippi/a (1069).

Join speu/dein a)po\ quma/twn, a)/nippon, i(ppo/thn te a)po\ r(uth=ros: to hasten from the sacrifice, some on foot, others on horseback, with slack rein. The worshippers of the *(/ippios and *(ippi/a are in part i(ppei=s (cp. 1070), and have their horses with them. The place of a)po\ r'. is due to the fact that these horsemen are the important pursuers, a)/nippon being added merely to give the notion of a pursuit en masse. Thus there is some formal resemblance to Ant. 1108
i)/t', i)/t', o)pa/ones
oi(/ t' o)/ntes oi(/ t' a)po/ntes, though there "present and absent" is merely a colloquial phrase for "every one."

a)po\ r(uth=ros, "away from the rein," i.e. "unchecked by the rein," immissis habenis: Phrynichus ap. Bekker Anecd. p. 24 a)po\ o(uth=ros tre/xein i(/ppon: oi(=on a)po\ xalinou= h(\ a)/neu xalinou=. Cp. El. 1127 a)p' e)lpi/dwn, contrary to my hopes: Tr. 389 ou)k a)po\ gnw/mhs, not against my judgment: and so ou)k a)po\ tro/pou (not unreasonably), ou)k a)po\ kairou=, etc. Plut. Dion 42 ou(=toi diela/santes th\n o(do\n i(/ppois a)po\ r(uth=ros h(=kon ei)s *leonti/nous th=s h(me/ras h)/dh kataferome/nhs, "having ridden the whole distance at full speed." For the o_ in a)po\ before r(, cp. Ant. 712 n.

di/stomoi … o(doi/. See map in Appendix on 1059. The two roads meant are probably:—(1) A road leading from Colonus, north of the Sacred Way, to the pass now called Daphnè, a depression in the range of Mount Aegaleos through which the Sacred Way issued from the plain of Athens, after which it skirted the shores of the bay of Eleusis. The beginning of this road is shown by the map in the Introduction. (2) A road diverging from the former in a N.W. direction, and going round the N. end of the same range of Aegaleos, at a point some miles N. of the Daphnè pass, into the Thriasian plain. By either route the captors could gain the pass of Dryoscephalae, over Mount Cithaeron, leading from Attica into Boeotia. The hope of Theseus is that the pursuers may reach the point of bifurcation before the captors, since it is conceivable that the latter should wait to be joined by their master, Creon. see on 1054 ff.
ma/lista with e)/nqa, lit., "to about the place where": cp. Her. 1.191 a)ndri\ w(s e)s me/son mhro\n ma/lista/ kh|, "just about to the height of a man's thigh."
i)/q', said to the pro/spolos (897).

di' o)rgh=s h(=kon, "were in such wrath," rather than, "had come hither in such wrath." Cp. Eur. Or. 757 le/con: dia\ fo/bou ga\r e)/rxomai, "for I begin to fear." Her. 1.169 dia\ ma/xhs...a)pi/konto *(arpa/gw|, gave him battle. Cp. on O. T. 773.
meqh=k), suggesting a relaxed grasp, is better than the more general a)fh=k) here: cp. 834.

ou(/sper … tou\s no/mous: antecedent drawn into relative clause: cp. Ant. 404 qa/ptousan o(
 su\ to
 nekro
 | a)pei=pas, where the schol. quotes Cratinus (fr. 159), o(/nper *filokle/hs to
 lo/gon die/fqoren.
tou/toisi, instrum. dat.,

a(rmosqh/setai, he shall be brought to order, regulated: Aristoph. Eq. 1235
*k*l. pai=s w)
 e)foi/tas e)s ti/nos didaska/lou;
*a*l. e)n tai=sin eu)/strais kondu/lois h(rmotto/mhn, "was kept in order" by blows: Lucian Toxaris 17 to
 a(rmosth
 o(\s h(/rmoze th
 *)asi/an to/te.
e)nargei=s, before my eyes: Tr. 223 ta/d' a)nti/prw|ra dh/ soi | ble/pein pa/rest' e)nargh=.
a)/gwn, as Il. 2.558 sth=se d' a)/gwn: below, 1342. Cp. 475 labw/n.
kata/cia dra=n would be more usual than kataci/ws dra=n: but the latter is no more incorrect than is o)rqw=s or kalw=s dra=n.
w(=n=tou/twn w(=n, possessive gen., here denoting origin: cp. on 214.

Athens "practises justice," i.e. respects the rights of other states; and "determines (krai/nousan") nothing without law, i.e. admits no claim which the laws do not sanction. Oedipus had placed himself and his daughters under the protection of Attic law. Creon should have sought legal warrant for their removal. Instead of doing so, he has used violence.
ei)=t), "after that," "nevertheless": cp. 418, 1005.
a)fei\s: cp. 1537.

ta\ … ku/ria, the constituted authorities, like ta\ te/lh, a phrase suggestive of constitutional monarchy, in which the citizens have some voice: as Theseus himself says in Eur. Suppl. 350 a)lla\ tou= lo/gou | prosdou\s e)/xoim' a)\n dh=mon eu)mene/steron (proposing to refer a question to the people), and describes himself (ib. 353) as e)leuqerw/sas th/nd' i)so/yhfon po/lin.
e)peispesw\n, of an abrupt or violent entrance, as Xen. Cyr. 7.5.27 oi( d' e)pi\ tou\s fu/lakas taxqe/ntes e)peispi/ptousin au)toi=s pi/nousi.
a)/geis, of taking captive, as in a)/gein kai\ fe/rein:
pari/stasai, bring to your own side, subjugate; Thuc. 1.98 *naci/ois...e)pole/mhsan kai\ poliorki/a| paresth/santo.

ke/nandron … h)\ dou/lhn tina\, some State destitute of inhabitants, or else only peopled by spiritless slaves. Cp. O. T. 56, and Thuc. 7.77 a)/ndres ga\r po/lis, kai\ ou) tei/xh ou)de\ nh=es a)ndrw=n kenai/. So in Aesch. Suppl. 913 the king of Argos asks the insolent herald, a)ll' h)= gunaikw=n e)s po/lin dokei=s molei=n; The desire to find Creon's a)/boulon (940) here has prompted the conjecture h)\ boulh=s di/xa: but see on 940.

tw=| mhdeni/, dat. of to\ mhde/n: cp. Tr. 1107 ka)
 to\ mhde
 w)=. Her. 8.106 o(/ti me a)nt' a)ndro\s e)poi/hsas to\ mhde
 ei)=nai (sc. eu)nou=xon). Cp. O. T. 638, 1019.

*qh=bai. A courteous exoneration of Thebes accords with the hereditary ceni/a which this play supposes: see on 632, and cp. the compliments to Thebes in 929, 937. It has been seriously suggested that all these touches must have been inserted by Sophocles the grandson, because in the poet's time Athens and Thebes were not usually on the best terms.

e)pai/deusan, more than e)/qreyan, implying a moral and mental training: cp. Pind. fr. 180
ou)/toi me ce/non
ou)d' a)dah/mona *moisa=n e)pai/deusan klutai\
*qh=bai: so of the Spartan public training, Thuc. 1.84 a)maqe/steron tw=n no/mwn th=s u(peroyi/as paideuo/menoi. Athens is th=s *(ella/dos pai/deusis (id. 2. 41).
puqoi/ato, cp. 945, and n. on 44.

sulw=nta k.t.l., forcibly carrying off what belongs to me,—yes, and what belongs to the gods, when you seek to lead captive unhappy men who are suppliants. It is best to put a comma after ta\ tw=n qew=n, which is explained by bi/a| a)/gonta, etc. He robs the gods when he seeks to seize the sacred suppliant of the Eumenides (44, 287). He robs Theseus (ta)ma\) when he seizes persons who are under the protection of Attic law (915). If ta\ tw=n qew=n fwtw=n a)ql. i(kth/ria were joined (as Blaydes prefers), the double gen. would be very awkward.

fwtw=n a)qli/wn i(kth/ria=literally "suppliant objects consisting in hapless per sons,"=fw=tas a)qli/ous i(kthri/ous. The gen. defines the "material," or nature, of the i(kth/ria, as in El. 758 sw=ma deilai/as spodou= is a body consisting in (reduced to) ashes. We could not render, "the emblems of supplication brought by hapless persons." Nor, again, "the suppliants belonging to a wretched man" (the two maidens). In the following periphrases we see an analogous poet. use of the neut. plur., though the relation to the gen. is not precisely the same: Ant. 1209 a)qli/as a)/shma...boh=s, "confused accents of a mournful cry," where the gen. might be either of material, as here, or possessive: ib. 1265 w)/moi e)mw=n a)/nolba bouleuma/twn (partitive gen.): Eur. Phoen. 1485 ou) prokaluptome/na botruxw/deos | a(bra\ parh/idos, "not veiling the delicate cheek,"—for this is clearly the sense, rather than "spreading a delicate veil" (sc. kalu/mmata) over it.
e)pembai/nwn: cp. on 400. Theseus points his reproof, as Oed. did in 776 ff., by asking Creon to imagine their respective situations reversed.
ei)=xon, since e)ndikw/tata=me/gista dikaiw/mata: Thuc. 1.41 dikaiw/mata ta/de pro\s u(ma=s e)/xomen: and so id. 3. 54 parexo/menoi...a(\ e)/xomen di/kaia, advancing the just pleas which are ours.
a)/neu ge tou= krai/nontos, iniussu dominatoris, cp. Il. 15.213 a)/neu e)me/qen kai\ *)aqhnai/hs a)gelei/hs, without my consent and hers.
xqono\s, gen. with kr., as Ai. 1050 o(\s krai/nei stratou=.

o(/stis h)=n: the verb in the relative clause is assimilated to the form of the conditional sentence: cp. Plat. Men. 89 B ei) fu/sei oi( a)gaqoi\ e)gi/gnonto, h)=sa/n pou a)\n h(mi=n oi(\ e)gi/gnwskon tw=n ne/wn tou\s a)gaqou\s ta\s fu/seis: Xen. Mem. 1.7.3 kuberna=n katastaqei\s (=ei) katastaqei/h) o( mh\ e)pista/menos a)pole/seien a)\n ou)\s h(/kista bou/loito.

ou)/q' ei(=lkon ou)/t' a)
 h)=gon. The chief protasis is contained in the partic. e)pembai/nwn (924),=ei) e)pene/bainon, while ei) … ei)=xon merely subjoins a special case in which the apodosis would still hold good:—ei) e)pene/bainon, ou)k a)
 ei(=lkon, ou)de\ (ei(=lkon a)
) ei) ei)=xon. Remark that the form of the apodosis, ou)/q' ei(=lkon...a)
 etc., does not logically imply, "I am now dragging," but merely, "I am not now forbearing to drag": there is no opportunity for such abstention, since the fact supposed by e)pembai/nwn ("If I were on Theban soil") is non-existent. The conditional form with the imperf. indic. has been preferred to that with the optative (used in the similar illustration at 776), because Theseus is thinking of what Creon is actually doing.

ce/non, for whom the first rule should be, a)stoi=s i)/sa meleta=n (171, cp. 13). Cp. Aesch. Suppl. 917 (the Argive king to the Egyptian herald who threatens to drag off the Danaïdes by force), ce/nos me\n ei)=nai prw=ton ou)k e)pi/stasai.

a)ci/an ou)k ou)=san, immeritam; Dem. or. 21 § 217 ei)mi\ d' ou) tou/twn u(mi=n a)/cios, "I do not deserve such (harsh) treatment at your hands": cp. a)ciou=n tina/ tinos, to condemn one to a punishment, O. T. 1449 (n.).

th\n au)to\s au(tou=: cp. 1356, Ai. 1132 tou/s g' au)to\s au(tou= polemi/ous: Aesch. PV 921 e)p' au)to\s au(tw=|: ib. 762 pro\s au)to\s au(tou= kenofro/nwn bouleuma/twn. In this hyperbaton au)to/s merely adds emphasis to the reflexive. If au)to/s is meant to stand out with its full separate force, it precedes the prep., as au)to\s pro\s au(tou= twice in Soph. (Ant. 1177, Ai. 906).
o( plhqu/wn xro/nos, the growing number of thy years; cp. on 377 and 7.

tou= nou=, which is just what old age ought to bring: fr. 240
kai/per ge/rwn w)/n: a)lla\ tw=| gh/ra| filei=
xw( nou=s o(martei=n kai\ to\ bouleu/ein a(\ dei=: Aesch. fr. 391 gh=ras ga\r h(/bhs e)sti\n e)ndikw/teron.
tina, simply "some one": not here a threatening substitute for se/ (as in Ai. 1138, Ant. 751). Indifference as to the agent strengthens insistence on the act.

The essence of the notion conveyed by me/toikos, in ordinary Attic usage, was a voluntary sojourn, terminable at the will of the sojourner. Hence the irony here. With a similar force the Attic poets apply it to one who has found his "last, long home" in foreign earth. Aesch. Cho. 683
ei)/t' ou)=n komi/zein do/ca nikh/sei fi/lwn,
ei)/t' ou)=n me/toikon, ei)s to\ pa=n a)ei\ ce/non,
qa/ptein: "whether his friends decide to bring his ashes home, or to bury him among strangers, an alien utterly for ever": so a Persian whose corpse was left at Salamis is sklhra=s me/toikos gh=s e)kei= (Pers. 319): Eur. Her. 1033 me/toikos a)ei\ kei/somai kata\ xqono\s (the Argive Eurystheus buried in Attica). Cp. O. T. 452 n.
bi/a| te kou)x e(k. as O. T. 1275 polla/kis te kou)x a(/pac.
kou)x e(kw/n, not kai\ mh\ e(kw/n, though dependent on ei), since ou)x e(kw/n=a)/kwn: cp. Ai. 1131 ei) tou\s qano/ntas ou)k — e)a=|s qa/ptein: Lys. or. 13 § 62 ei) me\n ou)=n ou)-polloi\ h)=san.

The words tw=| nw=| have been suspected by recent criticism. They seem to me sound. The sense is, "these things, which I say to you, are purposed by my mind as really as they are uttered by my tongue." With tw=| nw=| a verb meaning "I intend" (e.g. dianoou=mai) should strictly have been used; but the verb appropriate to a)po\ glw/sshs is made to serve for both. For a similar zeugma cp. O. T. 116 ou)d' a)/ggelo/s tis ou)de\ sumpra/ktwr o(dou= | katei=d', where the verb appropriate to a)/ggelos, viz. h)=lqe, has to be supplied from katei=d). To Meineke's tou= nou= (governed by a)po/) it may be objected that e)k would be the right prep., as in e)k qumou=, e)k yuxh=s. a)po\ glw/sshs usu.="by word of mouth" (as opp. to "by letter"), as in Thuc. 7.10.— For the antithesis cp. Plat. Symp. 199A h( glw=tta ou)=n u(pe/sxeto, h( de\ frh\n ou)/ (alluding to Eur. Hipp. 612).
o(ra=|s i(/n' h(/keis; an indignant reproach, as O. T. 687.

a)f' w(=n=a)po\ tou/twn, a)f' w(=n (cp. on 274): "Judging by the folk from whom thou art sprung (the Thebans, cp. 919), thou seemest just"— i.e., a member of a just race. For a)po/ of judging by a thing, cp. on 15. The Greek sense of the prep. with the relative here is really the same as with the supplied antecedent. It is our idiom which makes them seem different.
e)gw\ ou)/t): so 998: O.T. 332 e)gw\ ou)/t' e)mauto/n: Ant. 458 e)gw\ ou)k e)/mellon: Ph. 585 e)gw/ ei)m' *)atrei/sais.

L's le/gw, of which le/gwn was a correction, came in by mistake from 936. Schneidewin's ne/mwn has been generally received, and is clearly right: cp. on 879. While a)/nandron answers to ke/nandron h)\ dou/lhn in 917, a)/boulon (940), which implies the lack of a guiding mind, answers to ka)/m' i)/son tw=| mhdeni/ in 918.—Creon's speech is as clever as it is impudent. He has only anticipated what the Athenians themselves would have wished. Indeed, he has acted in reliance on the Areiopagus (950). If his method has been rough, he was provoked by the violence of Oedipus.

au)tou\s, the people implied in th\n po/lin (939). Cp. Eur. Bacch. 961
ko/mize dia\ me/shs me *qhbai/as xqono/s,
mo/nos ga\r au)tw=n ei)m' a)nh\r tolmw=n ta/de. So in Her. 5.63 au)tou\s after *qessali/hs, and 8. 121 au)tw=n after *ka/ruston.

e)mpe/soi has here the constr. of e(/loi: cp. Eur. I. A. 808
deino\s e)mpe/ptwk' e)/rws
th=sde stratei/as *(ella/d', ou)k a)/neu qew=n. This is decisive against here reading au)toi=s, the commoner constr.
cunai/mwn, Oed., Ant., and Ism.: Creon refers first to the general claim of kindred; then to the special reasons against detaining Oed.

ka)/nagnon. Cp. O. T. 821 

le/xh de\ tou= qano/ntos e)n xeroi=n e)mai=n

xrai/nw, di' w(=nper w)/let): a)=r' e)/fun kako/s;

a)=r' ou)xi\ pa=s a)/nagnos;  So here, too, a)/nagnon refers to the taint of murder, aggravated by union with the wife of the slain. "Both a parricide, and, in a complex sense, impure,—yea, guilty of incest."
decoi/at): cp. on 44. The fut. optat. after a secondary tense, as O. T. 538 f., 792, 796, 1271 ff.
hu(re/qhsan. Attic inscriptions nearly as old as the poet's time confirm hu(- against eu(-: cp. O. T. 546 n.

te/knwn has been suspected. The literal meaning of a)no/sioi ga/moi te/knwn can be nothing but "unholy nuptials with children" (such as Iocasta's with Oed.). But here the sense should be, "unholy nuptials with parents": cp. 978 mhtro\s...ga/mous. Can te/knwn, then, be defended? Thus, I think.

cuno/ntes suggests the consort. Hence a)no/sioi ga/moi te/knwn is said, with poetical boldness and also with a certain designed obscurity, in this sense:—"a woman who has made an unholy marriage with her son."

Wecklein takes te/knwn as "relative" gen. with a)no/sioi, in the sense of paidourgi/as, spora=s: "a marriage unholy in respect of its offspring." This seems forced. Musgrave's toke/wn would be more specious if the gen. of a noun in -eu/s anywhere else suffered synizesis in this place of the verse. (In 1361 fone/ws is in the 4th place.) Soph. has gone/wn El. 146, 241, and toke/wn ib. 187, Eur. the latter H. F. 915, Or. 815, and in these 5 places (all lyric) the words are scanned as trisyllables: a fact which, so far as it goes, is against toke/wn here. Neither te/knois nor te/knw| is a probable remedy; nor is fi/lwn. In my belief te/knwn is sound.
toiou=ton, introducing a reason for a preceding statement, as Ai. 164 (toiou/twn), 218 (toiau=t)), 251 (toi/as), 562 (toi=on).—

eu)/boulon suggests the title of the Court, h( e)c *)arei/ou pa/gou boulh/. If the Council of the Areiopagus (Creon assumes) became aware that a polluted person, such as Oedipus, was in Attica, it would take steps for his expulsion. Such a proceeding would doubtless have come within the limits of the general moral censorship actually possessed by the Areiopagus, at least in the earlier days of the Athenian democracy. Indeed that court is found exercising authority of a like kind (though only by special warrant) even after the reforms of Pericles and Ephialtes. Cp. Deinarchus or. 1 § 58, where the Ecclesia commissions the Areiopagus to inquire into the conduct of a merely suspected person, and the Areiopagus, having done so, reports to the Ecclesia (tou= dh/mou prosta/cantos zhth=sai th\n boulh/n,...kai\ zhth/sasan a)pofh=nai pro\s u(ma=s, a)pe/fhnen h( boulh/, etc.). See also Plut. Sol. 22, Isocr. or. 7 §§ 36-55, and my Attic Orators vol. II. p. 211.
xqo/nion=e)gxw/rion, a use found in Ai. 202 xqoni/wn a)p' *)erexqeida=n (=au)toxqo/nwn), and fr. adesp. (Nauck^{2}) xqoni/ous *)inaxi/das.

qumou=, the anger which moved Creon to make the seizure: cp. 874 ou)/toi kaqe/cw qumo/n. Theseus had said that Creon's violence disgraced his years (931). Creon replies, "There is no old age for anger, except death"; i.e., "anger, under gross insult, ceases to be felt only when a man is dead, and can feel nothing." Schol.: tou=to de\ kai\ paroimiakw=s le/getai, o(/ti o( qumo\s e)/sxaton ghra/skei. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 682 ou)k e)/sti gh=ras tou=de tou= mia/smatos. Here, too, gh=ras is figurative,— "decay," "abatement," of anger; while qanei=n has its literal sense, the subject being tina/ understood.
qano/ntwn: El. 1170 tou\s ga\r qano/ntas ou)x o(rw= lupoume/nous: Tr. 1173 toi=s ga\r qanou=si mo/xqos ou) prosgi/gnetai.
kei) here=ei) kai\: cp. 661.
smikro\n: cp. 148 (smikroi=s), 880 (braxu/s), where see n.

pro\s … ta\s pra/ceis, "against your deeds," i.e., any measures that you may take to deprive me of my captives. Cp. Arist. Pol. 6.5. 3 pro\s tau=ta a)ntipra/ttein. He hints that, though he cannot resist now, he will take steps, when he returns to Thebes, for obtaining redress by force of arms: cp. 1036 oi)/koi de\ xh(mei=s ei)so/mesq' a)\ xrh\ poei=n.— Note the repeated a)ntidra=n (953, 959) and o(/mws (957 f.): cp. 554 n.
tou=. Which is more disgraced,— the involuntary sufferer, or the author of deliberate insults to an unhappy kinsman?
moi, dat. of interest, "for my reproach,"
dih=kas, sent through thy mouth, —poured forth: cp. El. 596 h(\ pa=san i(/hs glw=ssan: fr. 844. 3 pollh\n glw=ssan e)kxe/as ma/thn. In Tr. 323 dih/sei glw=ssan is Wakefield's correction of dioi/sei.
a)/kwn: cp. on 522.
qeoi=s: the synizesis as in O. T. 1519, and about 26 other places of dialogue in Soph.: he admits it also in lyrics, as O. T. 215.

a)/n cannot go with mhni/ousin. since the partic. does not represent an apodosis, as a)
 fe/rwn does in 761 (n.). On the other hand, a)/n does not here give any conditional force to h)=n, which is a simple statement of fact. Rather ta/x' a)/n is here felt as one word,="perhaps." "It was dear to the gods,—perhaps because they were wroth." The origin of this usage was an ellipse: qeoi=s h)=n fi/lon, ta/xa (d)) a)
 (fi/lon ei)/h) mhni/ousin, "and perhaps (it would be dear) because they were wroth": where the supplied ei)/h expresses a conjecture about a past fact, as in Her. 1.2 ei)/hsan d' a)
 ou(=toi *krh=tes. Cp. O. T. 523 a)ll' h)=lqe me
 dh\ tou=to tou)/neidos ta/x' a)
 | o)rgh=| biasqe/n, "this reproach came under stress, perchance, of anger." See Appendix.

e)pei\ kaq' au(to/n g). "My fate must have been a divine judgment upon me for the sins of ancestors. For you could not discover against me (e)moi/, dat. of interest, cp. 962),—taken by myself (kaq' au(to/n, apart from those ancestors),—any charge of sin, in retribution for which (a)nq' o(/tou) I proceeded to sin (impf. h(ma/rtanon) against myself and my kindred." If any voluntary crime on his part had preceded his involuntary crimes, the latter might have been ascribed to an a)/th sent on him by angry gods. But he had committed no such voluntary crime. For au(to/n=e)mauto/n see on 852 f.

Others take a)nq' o(/tou as="in that," "because," and understand:—"For you cannot charge any guilt on me personally (kaq' au(to/n"), in that I sinned against myself and my kindred. But (1) kaq' au(to/n could not naturally express this contrast between the badness of the acts and the innocence of the agent. It contrasts the man with the ge/nos. (2) a)nq' o(/tou regularly (if not always)="in return for which," "wherefore": e.g. El. 585
di/dacon a)nq' o(/tou tanu=n
ai)/sxista pa/ntwn e)/rga drw=sa tugxa/neis: Eur. Alc. 246 ou)de\n qeou\s dra/santas a)nq' o(/tou qanei=: I. T. 926 h( d' ai)ti/a ti/s a)nq' o(/tou ktei/nei po/sin; So Hec. 1131, 1136.
e)pei\ di/dacon: "for else—if this is not so—tell me": the controversial e)pei/, on which see O. T. 390 n. Note the early repetition (after 966): see on 554: cp. a)ll) 985, 988.

ei)/ ti qe/sfaton: "if, by oracles (xrhsm., instrum. dat.), some divine doom was coming on my sire, that he should die," etc.: i(knei=to, impf., because the doom was impending from the moment at which the Delphic oracle spoke: that moment itself, on the other hand, is marked by the aor. in O. T. 711
xrhsmo\s ga\r h)=lqe *lai+/w| pot)...
w(s au)to\n h(/coi moi=ra pro\s paido\s qanei=n. See Introd. to the O. T. p. xix.

The simple inf. qanei=n could have depended on qe/sfaton, but w(/ste is added, as below 1350; Plat. Prot. 338C a)du/naton h(mi=n w(/ste *prwtago/rou tou=de sofw/tero/n tina e(le/sqai: Eur. Hipp. 1327 *ku/pris ga\r h)/qel' w(/ste gi/gnesqai ta/de: Thuc. 1.119 dehqe/ntes w(/ste yhfi/sasqai: 8. 45 pei=sai w(/ste sugxwrh=sai.
pai/dwn, allusive plur. for sing., cp. 295 a)/naktas (n.)

ou)/te...ou): cp. Ant. 249
ou)/te tou genh=|dos h)=n
plh=gm), ou) dike/llhs e)kbolh/: Eur. Or. 41
w(=n ou)/te di=ta dia\ de/rhs e)de/cato,
ou) lou/tr' e)/dwke xrwti/: ib. 1086
mh/q' ai(=ma/ mou de/caito ka/rpimon pe/don,
mh\ lampro\s ai)qh/r: Her. 8.98 ou)/te nifeto/s, ou)k o)/mbros, ou) kau=ma, ou) nu/c. But of the converse, ou)...ou)/te, there is no certain example.—
bla/stas, plur., O. T. 717: patro\s and mhtro\s, gen. of origin with bl. gen. ei)=xon as=e)/blaston: he was not yet begotten or conceived.
fanei\s du/sthnos, having been born to misery (as being fated to slay his sire): so 1225 e)pei\ fanh=|, when one has come into the world. This is better here than, "having proved unfortunate."

e)gw\ )fa/nhn: for the prodelision of the temporal augment in the 6th place, cp. Ant. 457: Eur. Helen 263 ( ei)/qe ) ai)/sxion ei)=dos a)nti\ tou= kalou= )labon (Porson's correction of labei=n): Ai. 557 e)c oi(/ou )tra/fhs.
e)s xei=ras: cp. on 835.
mhde\n is adjective with w(=n (=tou/twn a(\), and adverb with (tou/tous) ei)s ou(/s.

The MSS. have pw=s g' a)/n, but g' should probably be omitted. In L, at least, there is a perceptible tendency to insert g), t), etc., superfluously (cp. cr. n. on 260); and here the first g' would weaken the second, while pw=s needs no strengthening. In O. T. 1030, where L and most MSS. have g)...ge, we should read d)...ge. There is, however, no objection to a doubled ge where each of two words in the same sentence is to be emphasised (Her. 1.187).
a)=kon=a)kou/sion: see on 240.

L's tlh/mwn might be either (a) predicate with the verb, or (b) nom. for voc., as 185 w)= tla/mwn, where see n. But (a) would be rather weak; and a direct address, rather than a half-comment (as in 185), is fitting here. tlh=mon, then, seems most probable.
ou)=n here="indeed"; in 985 "at all events."
ei)s to/d' e)celq. a)no/sion sto/ma, having gone to such lengths of impious speech, i.e. having outraged the most sacred ties of kinship by these public taunts. Cp. 438 e)kdramo/nta (n.).

a)no/sion sto/ma agrees with to/d', depending on ei)s. Since sto/ma was familiar to poetry in the sense of lo/gos (cp. O. T. 426), this version is clearly preferable to taking ei)s to/d' separately and a)no/s. st. as accus. of respect.

—984 He has just said, "why force me to speak of Iocasta's marriage, when it was such as I will tell?" (980). In these three vv. he tells of what sort it was,—viz., incestuous, but unconsciously so;—a double reason why Creon should have spared the taunt.
e)/tikten="she was my mother"—she, who was becoming my bride—though neither of us knew it at the time of the marriage. Cp. Eur. Ion 1560 h(/de ti/ktei s), "she is thy mother"; and O. T. 437, 870.

au(th=s o)/neidos, because, although she was morally guiltless in the marriage, yet such a union was, in fact, shameful: cp. O. T. 1494, 1500. Yet Nauck condemns these vv. because (1) they do not explain the mhtro\s ga/mous of 978, and (2) o)/neidos is illogical after ou)k ei)dui=a. Kaibel, who also condemns them, compares (Deutsche Litteraturz., 1886, p. 733) Eur. Her. 224 f.
i(ke/tas a)lh/tas suggenei=s, oi)/moi kakw=n,
ble/yon pro\s au)tou\s ble/yon, e(/lkesqai bi/a|: where the only points of likeness are oi)/moi kakw=n and the iteration. Rhetoric of a similar cast, and prompted by the same thought, occurs in O. T. 1403 ff., 1496 ff.

dusstomei=n (only here) with acc., as El. 596 th\n mhte/ra | kakostomou=men. Those who still write dustomei=n have some eminent modern critics with them; but on the other side it should be borne in mind that the MSS. (rarely older than the 11th or 10th cent.) which vouch for such forms as dustatei=n or dusti/beutos vouch also for such spellings of compounds with pro/s as prostei/xw, prostauro/w, proste/llw, where pross is unquestionably right.
a)/kwn. A single te linking whole sentences is not rare in Soph. (e.g. 1437, O. T. 995); but a)/kwn t) (Vat.) may be right here.

a)ll' ou) ga\r. Distinguish two uses of this formula. (1) With an ellipse, as here,—"but (your charges are untrue), for." In this, ga/r may be represented by "in fact," or "indeed." Cp. on 755. (2) When there is no ellipse, as O. T. 1409 a)ll' ou) ga\r au)da=n e)/sq' a(\ mhde\ dra=n kalo/n,...kalu/yat). Then ga/r ="since."

The MS. a)kou/somai kako\s="will be pronounced evil" (in the report of fairminded men): cp. Ph. 1074 a)kou/somai me\n w(s e)/fun oi)/ktou ple/ws | pro\s tou=d: "I shall be reproached, as full of pity, by yon man": ib. 607 o( pa/nt' a)kou/wn ai)sxra\ kai\ lwbh/t' e)/ph. But the conjecture a(lw/somai has certainly more force and point: cp. O. T. 576 ou) ga\r dh\ foneu\s a(lw/somai: Ant. 46 ou) ga\r dh\ prodou=s' a(lw/somai.

e)mforei=s (ingeris), "heapest on me," "urgest against me," is supported, as against e)mfe/reis, by the common use of the word in later Greek, as Plut. Pomp. 3 polla\s e)nefo/rei plhga\s toi=s strw/masin: Alciphro 1. 9 e)pi\ tw=| sfete/rw| ke/rdei ei)s tou\s a)pra/gmonas e)mforou=sin u(/breis, "for their own gain they heap insults on quiet people."
fo/nous: the rhetorical pl., as 962.
a)/meiyai: cp. on 814 a)ntamei/bei.

ei)/ tis … ktei/noi, should attempt to slay; cp. Od. 16.432 pai=da/ t' a)poktei/neis, "and art seeking to slay his son": Antiph. or. 5 § 7 o(/tan d' a)/neu kindu/nwn ti diapra/sswntai, are seeking to effect. (For the parallel use of the imperf., see 274.) The optat. in putting the imaginary case, as 776: cp. on 927.
au)ti/ka (not, "for instance," but) with e)nqa/de, at this moment and on this spot, cp. nunc iam ilico (Ter. Ad. 2. 1. 2).

to
 di/k.: for the ironical article cp. Ant. 31 to
 a)gaqo
 *kre/onta.

dokw= me/n, "I should think so," with the emphasis on the verb, not on the 1st pers.: El. 61 dokw= me/n, ou)de\n r(h=ma su\n ke/rdei kako/n: fr. 83 dokw= me/n, ou)dei/s. Cp. Plat. Phaedo 68B ou)k a)/smenos ei)=sin au)to/se; oi)/esqai/ ge xrh/. So Crito 53 D, 54 B: also oi)=mai e)/gwge Crito 47 D.

perible/pois. This compound occurs nowhere else in Soph., nor does he use peri/bleptos. But Eur. uses them five times (Andr. 89, H. F. 508, Ion 624, I. A. 429, Ph. 551), and Ar. has the verb once (Eccl. 403). In all six places, as here, the i is made long. On the other hand, the i of peridromh/ and its cognates is usually, if not always, short (Eur. El. 458, Helen. 776, Tro. 1197, fr. 1068. 2: Aesch. Suppl. 349: Aristoph. Vesp. 138, Eq. 56, etc.): and Aesch. Ch. 207 has peri^grafa/. In Aristoph. Pax 879 perigra/feis is ambiguous in the comic trimeter.
ei)se/bhn suits the imagery of a)go/ntwn (see on 253): cp. Aesch. Suppl. 470 a)/ths d' a)/busson pe/lagos ou) ma/l' eu)/poron | to/d' e)sbe/bhka.
After a)nteipei=n and like words the person gainsaid is denoted by the dat.; the argument, by peri/ tinos or pro/s ti. Here we begin with a neut. dat.
oi)=s (instead of pro\s a(\ or peri\ w(=n), which implies a personification of the lo/gos. Then, at the end of the sentence,

e)moi/ is pleonastically added, by a sort of afterthought. This double dative, though irregular, does not seem to warrant the change of e)moi/ into e)/xein. e)moi/ gives greater vividness to the thought of the dead brought face to face with the living.
a)\n with a)nteipei=n.
e)gw\ ou)de\: cp. 939.
patro\s yuxh\n … zw=san="my father's life, if it could live again,"=simply pate/ra zw=nta: not, "his departed spirit, if it could visit this world."

yuxh/ in the trag. never means "a departed spirit" (Il. 23.104 yuxh\ kai\ ei)/dwlon), but always the anima of the living: cp. Aesch. Ag. 1456 (of Helen) mi/a ta\s polla\s … | yuxa\s o)le/sas' u(po\ *troi/a|. For the periphrasis here cp. El. 1126
w)= filta/tou mnhmei=on a)nqrw/pwn e)moi\
yuxh=s *)ore/stou loipo/n: Ant. 559 h( d' e)mh\ yuxh\ pa/lai | te/qnhken.
a(/pan, "anything," cp. on 761:
kalo\n with le/gein, dictu honestum, cp. on 37.

r(hto\n a)/rr.: Dem. or. 18 § 122 boa=|s r(hta\ kai\ a)/rrhta o)noma/zwn: or. 21 § 79 pa/ntas h(ma=s r(hta\ kai\ a)/rrhta kaka\ e)cei=pon. Remark that in neither place does Dem. place a kai\ before r(hta/, or a te after it. The form which he gives was doubtless the familiar one. On the other hand, in a phrase of different meaning, Dem. or. 1 § 4 to\ ga\r ei)=nai pa/ntwn e)kei=non e(/na o)/nta ku/rion kai\ r(htw=n kai\ a)porrh/twn, "of what is to be published or to be kept secret." O. T. 300 didakta/ te | a)/rrhta/ t' (n.). Verg. Aen. 1. 543 deos memores fandi atque nefandi: Hor. Epp. 1. 7. 72 dicenda tacenda locutus.

to\ *q. o)/noma qwp., "to pay court to the great name of Th. (to the renowned Th.)." Creon had been courteous to Theseus, as Theseus towards Thebes, and nothing more: there is no qwpei/a in 940. But Oed. is incensed by the contrast between the rough words spoken of himself (944 ff.) by Creon, and the fair words to Theseus.
qwpeu=sai: cp. 1336.
kalo/n, not as in 1000, but="seasonable": cp. O. T. 78 ei)s kalo\n...ei)=pas (n.): El. 384 nu=n ga\r e)n kalw=| fronei=n.

w(s katw/|khntai kalw=s, lit., "that it has been administered well," the perf. here denoting that a good administration is thoroughly established in it (cp. on te/trofen, 186). The political senses of katoike/w and katoiki/zw should be carefully distinguished. (1) h( po/lis kalw=s katoikei=tai=the city is dwelt-in on good principles, "is well administered": see Plat. Legg. 683A. (2) h( po/lis kalw=s katw/|kistai=the city has been established on good principles, "has a good constitution": see Legg. 752 B. In this verse the poetical peculiarity is the use of the perf. where a prose-writer would have said either katoikou=ntai or else katw|kisme/nai ei)si/. Oed. refers to Creon's implied praise of Athenian loyalty (941 ff.), and esp. to his mention of the Areiopagus (947 ff.).
ka)=|q': cp. on 914.
polla\ with w(=d'.
ei)/ tis gh= qeou\s: see on 260.

tw=|d', referring to what has just preceded (cp. on 787), as Ant. 464, 566, Ai. 1080. The dat., marking the point in which the excellence is shown, is the usu. constr.: so Thuc. has proe/xein duna/mei (1. 9), nautikw=| (1. 25), plh/qei … kai\ e)mpeiri/a| (1. 121), gnw/mh| (2. 62), etc.: Xen. Anab. 3.2.19 e(ni\ de\ mo/nw| proe/xousin h(ma=s: Lac. 15. 3 plou/tw| u(perfe/rein: Her. 8.138 r(o/da o)dmh=| u(perfe/ronta: 8. 144 xw/rh ka/llei+ kai\ a)reth=| me/ga u(perfe/rousa: 9. 96 ka/llei+ kai\ mega/qei+ u(perfe/rwn. Surely, then, usage is strongly for tw=|d' as against tou=q'.

kle/yas, in purpose (so far as Oed. himself is concerned), though not in fact: Ai. 1126 di/kaia ga\r to/nd' eu)tuxei=n, ktei/nanta/ me; Eur. Ion 1500 e)/kteina/ s' a)/kous) (Creusa to her living son), "doomed thee to perish." We could hardly detach kle/yas from to\n i(ke/thn, and render: "from which having stolen (the maidens), thou didst seek to seize me, after carrying off my daughters."
e)xeirou=, impf. of endeavour: see 274: cp. 950.
oi)/xei: see on 867.

kataskh/ptw litai=s, "enjoin on you with prayers," is an unexampled use of this compound. On the other hand e)piskh/ptw was often used in entreaty, as Aeschin. or. 3 § 157 klai/ontas, i(keteu/ontas,...e)piskh/ptontas mhdeni\ tro/pw| to\n... a)lith/rion stefanou=n. Wecklein supports his attractive conjecture ka)cepiskh/ptw (Ars Soph. em. p. 99) by Ph. 668 ka)cepeu/casqai.
cei=nos: cp. 33. Elsewhere, with the exception of fr. 726. 4, Sophocles uses in dialogue only the vocative of the Ionic form.—
ai( de\ s.: while he is innocent, his fortunes have been appalling,
a)/ciai d' a)m., but (all the more) deserve sympathy.

a)/ciai … a)munaqei=n, worthy that one should succour them. The forms in -qon have not always an aoristic force, e.g. in El. 1014 ei)kaqei=n has no such force (cp. on O. T. 651): but here, at least, as 461 e)pa/cios...katoikti/sai shows, an aorist inf. is not less fitting than a present. For the act. inf., see on 461.

The contrast with paqo/ntes, and the impossibility (as I think) of justifying e)chrpasme/noi, confirm F. W. Schmidt's e)ceirgasme/noi. Since E also represented H in the older Ionic alphabet, the origin of the vulgate is at once explained if it is supposed that in *e*c*e*r*g*a*s*m*e*n*o*i the *g became *p,—one of the slightest and easiest of all errors in uncial writing.

e)chrpasme/noi must be explained in one of two ways. 1. "The captured ones are speeding." Here (a) speu/dousin is most strange as="are being carried off": it should imply eagerness. (b) The masc. plur. is strangely used when two girls are definitely meant. It is different when a woman, speaking of herself in the plur., uses the masc. (El. 399),— when the masc. sing. is used by the leader of a female Chorus (Eur. Hipp. 1105),—or when the masc. sing. is used in an abstract statement, though with allusion to a woman (El. 145). 2. "The captors are hurrying away." There is no other instance of h(/rpasmai, simple or in comp., as a perf. middle, while the pass. use is common. This may be an accident, for there are several instances of perfect forms which can be either passive or middle,—e.g. ei)/rgasmai, tetimw/rhmai (pass. in Thuc. 7.77, midd. in Antiph. Tetr. 3. b. § 8), memi/mhmai (pass. in Her. 2.78, midd. ib. 169 etc.). But it is a fact which increases the difficulty of assuming a middle sense here.
e(/stamen: the same form in O. T. 1442, Tr. 1145. In El. 21, too, I would restore i(/n' e(/stamen for the corrupt e)ntau=q' e)me/n.
a)m. fwti\, i.e. Creon himself. The tone is half sulky, half whining. He has given up the game.

a)maurw=| here "feeble" (cp. 880 braxu/s, 958 smikro/n), but in 182 "dim" (where see n.). Cp. 391 toiou=d' u(p' a)ndro/s, said by Oed. of himself; and so 1109 fwto/s.—Others render: "for the blind man" (Oed.), a dat. of interest with poei=n. This seems harsh.
th=s e)kei==th=s e)kei=se: Her. 9.108 e)kei=...a)pi/keto: Thuc. 3.71 tou\s e)kei= katapefeugo/tas. Cp. El. 1099 o(doiporou=men e)/nqa (=oi)=) xrh/|zomen: Ph. 256 mhdamou= dih=lqe.

pompo
 d) k.t.l. Three views of this clause require notice. I place first the view which seems to me right. 1. The construction is:— ( prosta/ssw se\ me
 ) kata/rxein o(dou= th=s e)kei=, e)me\ de\ pompo
 xwrei=n: "my pleasure is,—that you should show the way thither (i.e., to where the maidens are), and that I should go as your escort." The governing verb which is supplied, prosta/ssw, contains the general notion dokei= moi, "it seems good to me," "it is my pleasure." For e)me/ with inf. where e)gw/ is subj., cp. Od. 8.221 tw=n d' a)/llwn e)me/ fhmi polu\ profere/steron ei)=nai. Schaefer well cites Il. 3.88
a)/llous me
 ke/letai …
teu/xea ka/l' a)poqe/sqai, …
au)to
 d' e)n me/ssw| kai\ a)rhi+/filon *mene/laon
… ma/xesqai, where au)to/n, referring to the subject of ke/letai, is parallel with e)me/ here: "Paris urges that the others should lay their arms aside, but that he and Menelaus should fight." The word pompo/n (used in 723 of Creon's own followers) has here a touch of grim irony: cp. Il. 13.416 e)pei/ r(a/ oi( w)/pasa pompo/n, "given him a companion,"—i.e., sent his slayer to the shades along with him. pompo/n could not well mean, "as an escort for the maidens on their return." On this view d' e)me/ is better than de/ me.

2. Reading moi:—"that you should go as my guide": cp. Od. 4.826 toi/h ga/r oi( pompo\s a(/m' e)/rxeta (Athena conducting Telemachus). The following clause i(/n)...e)kdei/ch|s e)moi/ makes this somewhat weak.

3. Governing me by pompo/n: "that you should guide me on the way." Cp. Ant. 786 kai/ s' ou)/t' a)qana/twn fu/cimos ou)dei/s, where se is governed by the adj. This was the view of Erfurdt and Reisig: it was also held by Shilleto. But the supposed construction, always rare, is extremely harsh here, where pompo/n would naturally be taken as agreeing with me.

h(mi=n, "for us," i.e. so that we may find them: ethic dat. (cp. 81). Campbell defends the MS. h(mw=n as if e)/xeis...h(mw=n="hast taken from us," comparing 821 th\n pai=d' e)/xeis mou, where, however, the gen. is possessive, and O. T. 1522, where mou depends on e(/lh|. ta\s pai=das h(mw=n could mean only "our maidens,"—which is hardly to be justified as the language of a paternal government.
e)gkratei=s, sc. tw=n pai/dwn:

feu/gousin, sc. oi( e)ceirgasme/noi (1016), Creon's guards. Theseus is not sure whether these guards have merely carried the sisters to some spot in Attica, at which they are to await Creon himself, or are already in full flight with them to Boeotia.
a)/lloi: the horsemen who at 900 were told speu/dein a)po\ r(uth=ros.

ou(\s xw/ras th=sde fugo/ntes ou) mh/ pote e)peu/cwntai qeoi=s, "from whom having escaped out of this land, never shall they make grateful (e)p-") vows to the gods. feu/gw can take a gen. of separation, denoting the thing, or the region, from which one escapes: Od. 1.18 ou)d' e)/nqa pefugme/nos h)=en a)e/qlwn. This gen. is here combined with an acc., as in Eur. Suppl. 148 *tudeu\s me\n ai(=ma suggene\s feu/gwn xqono/s, flying from the land, from (the penalties of) a brother's murder: cp. Or. 1506 pou= )stin ou(=tos o(\s pe/feuge tou)mo\n e)k do/mwn ci/fos:

e)peu/cwntai implies a vow of thank-offerings for safety: cp. Xen. Anab. 3.2.9 eu)/casqai tw=| qew=| tou/tw| qu/sein swth/ria o(/pou a)
 prw=ton ei)s fili/an xw/ran a)fikw/meqa. Aesch. Theb. 276 (qeoi=s) e)peu/xomai | qh/sein tro/paia. The partic. fugo/ntes expresses the cause to which e)pi/ in the compound refers: cp. Ant. 483 dedrakui=an gela=n. (Distinguish the different sense of the verb in Plat. Soph. 235C ou)/te a)/llo ge/nos ou)de
 mh/pote e)kfugo
 e)peu/chtai th
...me/qodon, glory in having eluded.)
a)ll), "nay"; cp. 237. In e)cufhgou= (only here), e)k refers to the moment of starting, while u(po/="onward," as in u(pa/gw.

e)/xwn e)/xei, cp. our phrase, "the biter bitten." Aesch. Ag. 340 ou)/ ta)\n e(lo/ntes au)=qis a)nqaloi=en a)/n. Hor. Ep. 2. 1. 156 capta ferum victorem cepit. Isaiah xiv. 2 and they shall take them captives, whose captives they were.
qhrw=nq' recalls the metaphor used by Creon himself, th/nd' e)xeirou/mhn a)/gran (950).

h( tu/xh=Destiny: see on O. T. 977 ti/ d' a)\n foboi=t' a)/nqrwpos, w(=| ta\ th=s tu/xhs | kratei=. The "irony of fate" is better denoted by tu/xh than by the proposed substitute *di/kh (El. 528 h( ga\r *di/kh nin ei(=len, ou)k e)gw\ mo/nh).

ta\ … do/lw| kth/mata=ta\ do/lw| katakthqe/nta, the instrum. dat. with the noun as with the cognate partic.: Tr. 668 tw=n sw=n *(hraklei= dwrhma/twn: Plat. Legg. 631C ei)/s te dro/mon kai\ ei)s ta\s a)/llas pa/sas kinh/seis tw=| sw/mati: Soph. 261 E tw=n th=| fwnh=| peri\ th\n ou)si/an dhlwma/twn.
tw=| mh\ dikai/w|: cp. 73.

kou)k a)/llon e(/ceis ei)s to/d), and you will not have another (to aid you) with a view to this (i.e. to the removal of the captives). For this use of e)/xein cp. Andoc. or. 1 § 63 e(/ceis h(ma=s e)pithdei/ous: for ei)s to/d) cp. 507.
w(s e)/coida, "(I speak of another,") for I know, etc.: w(s causal; cp. 45.
ou) yilo\n: see on 866.

a)/skeuon: El. 36 a)/skeuon au)to\n a)spi/dwn te kai\ stratou=. The allusion is not, of course, to Creon's guards, but to some Attic accomplices, whose secret aid had emboldened him to make the attempt (1031). The ancient Greek was quick to explain disaster by treason; thus it instantly occurs to Oedipus that some Theban must have been concerned in the murder of Laïus (O. T. 124). After Aegospotami, "the general belief...held that the Athenian fleet had been sold to perdition by some of its own commanders" (Grote VIII. 300). Theseus had no definite ground for his suspicion, but its utterance serves to place him (for a Greek audience) on the proper level of wary sagacity.

e)s tosh/nd' u(/brin … to/lmhs. The to/lma is the audacious spirit manifested in the u(/bris, or outrageous action. The gen. to/lmhs seems best taken as partitive, e)s tosh/nd' u(/brin h(/konta being equiv. to e)s tosou=ton h(/konta: cp. Isocr. 8 § 31 ei)s tou=to ga/r tines a)noi/as e)lhlu/qasin (and n. on O. T. 771): "you have come to such a point of violence in the daring which now possesses you." If the gen. is taken as possessive, u(/bris to/lmhs nearly =u(/bris tolmhra/: but the addition of th=s parestw/shs tanu=n makes this awkward.

a)ll' e)/sq' o(/tw|. Cp. Aristoph. Nub. 1347
w(s ou(=tos, ei) mh/ tw| )pepoi/qein, ou)k a)\n h)=n
ou(/tws a)ko/lastos:
a)ll' e)/sq' o(/tw| qrasu/netai.

pisto\s, active: Aesch. PV 916 qarsw=n kaqh/sqw toi=s pedarsi/ois ktu/pois | pisto/s. So mempto/s, "blaming" (Tr. 446); u(/poptos, "suspecting" (Eur. Hec. 1135); a)fo/bhtos, "not fearing" (O. T. 885); a)/yaustos, "not having touched" (ib. 969); a)mfi/plhktos, "beating around" (Ph. 688).
ti tou/twn, ironical for tau=ta: O. T. 1140 le/gw ti tou/twn, h)\ ou) le/gw pepragme/non;

ta\ nu=n is slightly better than tanu=n. (1) With ta\ nu=n the sense is:—"Or do the things said just now seem to you no less vain than (the things said) at the time when you were plotting these deeds?" alluding to the remonstrances and menaces of the Chorus, 829 ff. ta\ nu=n te xw(/te is then like ta)ma\ ka)kei/nwn (606), one article doing double duty. (2) With tanu=n: "Or do these things (tau=ta", supplied from tou/twn) seem to you to have been said in vain, both now, and when you were plotting these deeds? But it is natural that Theseus should refer to his own words—by ta\ nu=n—rather than to thoughts which the Chorus had suggested before him.

e)nqa/d' w)\n has been generally suspected, because the qualification, "while here," seems to suit Creon better than Theseus. But, though e)nqa/d' o)/nt) e)rei=s e)me/ lies near, the vulgate is right. "While here," said of Theseus, means, "since this is your own realm, in which you have force at command."
mempto\n e)moi/, predicate; "you will say nothing to my dissatisfaction": i.e. "you can say what you please,—I shall not dispute it." It is vain to argue with a master of legions.

xwrw=n a)pei/lei nu=n, "threaten (if you will) now—only set out." The enclitic nun ("well then") would be weak here: nu=n takes point from 1037. For the partic. expressing the leading idea of the sentence, cp. Tr. 592 a)ll' ei)de/nai xrh\ drw=san: Andoc. or. 3 § 34 fhmi\...strathgo\n...lanqa/nonta dei=n tou\s pollou\s tw=n a)nqrw/pwn kai\ e)capatw=nta a)/gein e)pi\ tou\s kindu/nous, "he must elude their notice, and beguile them, if he is to lead them," etc.: Thuc. 1.20 *(/ipparxon oi)/ontai tu/rannon o)/nta a)poqanei=n, "was reigning when he was killed": 4. 11 ta\s sfete/ras nau=s, biazome/nous th\n a)po/basin, katagnu/nai e)ke/leue: "he cried, 'Wreck your ships, if you must—but force your way ashore.'"

pistwqei\s, as Od. 21.218 o)/fra m' e)u+\ gnw=ton pistwqh=to/n g' e)ni\ qumw=|, that ye twain may be assured in your minds: but elsewhere e)pistw/qhn is said of him who gives the pledge (Eur. I.A. 66 etc.): cp. on 650.

o)/naio, a blessing, usu. with simple gen., as Eur. I. A. 1359 o)/naio tw=n frenw=n, "bless thee for thy kindness," or a defining partic., as Or. 1677 gh/mas o)/naio: but there is no reason to suspect xa/rin, for which Blaydes suggests tro/pou. Cp. 569 to\ so\n gennai=on.

div2.head: 1044-1095: Second stasimon
div2.p: Second sta/simon.—1st strophe (1044—1058)=1st antistr. (1059 —1073). 2nd strophe (1074—1084)= 2nd antistr. (1085—1095).—The Chorus utter their longing to be at the scene of the fight between the Theban captors and the Attic rescuers. They predict the speedy victory of the latter, and invoke the gods to help.

div3.p: ei)/hn o(/qi: cp. Ai. 1218 (Chorus) genoi/man i(/n' u(la=en e)/pesti po/ntou | pro/blhm), etc.: Eur. Hipp. 732 (Chorus) a)liba/tois u(po\ keuqmw=si genoi/man, | i(/na etc.

e)pistrofai\, the wheeling-about of Creon's guards, carrying off their captives, when overtaken by the Attic pursuers. For the military use of the word see on 536. a)ndrw=n e)pistrofai/=a)/ndres e)pistrefqe/ntes: cp. El. 417 ei)sidei=n patro\s...deute/ran o(mili/an: Eur. Her. 581 u(mei=s d), a)delfw=n h( parou=s' o(mili/a: Alc. 606 a)ndrw=n *ferai/wn eu)menh\s parousi/a.

xalkobo/an cannot be resolved into two separate epithets,—"brassclad," and "clamorous": rather it seems to mean, "with noise of brass,"—the clatter of shields and swords in battle. Cp. O. T. 190, where the Death-god (the plague) is an Ares who is a)/xalkos a)spi/dwn, yet peribo/atos. xalkeo/fwnos, "with voice as of brass," is not really similar: it is the epithet of Stentor (Il. 5.785) and of Cerberus (Hes. Theog. 311).

mei/cousin: cp. Il. 15.510 h)\ au)tosxedi/h| mi=cai xei=ra/s te me/nos te. The Attic spelling in the age of Sophocles was mei/cw (not mi/cw), e)/meica, verb. adj. meikto/s: and so in the proper names *meici/as, *mei/cippos, etc.: see Meisterhans pp. 25, 87. There is no epigraphic evidence for the pres.; but, as Curtius remarks (Gr. Verb p. 111 Eng. tr.), mei/gnumi: mig :: dei/knumi: dik.

h)\ pro\s *puqi/ais h)\ lampa/sin a)ktai=s. The Chorus here imagine the Athenians as pursuing the Thebans through the pass of Daphne, over Mount Aegaleos, towards Eleusis. Two points are mentioned as possible scenes for a fight.

(1) *pu/qiai a)ktai/, the Pythian shores; the shore of the bay of Eleusis just beyond the pass of Daphnè on the N.W., near the salt-springs called *(rei/toi (Thuc. 2.19). The distance from Colonus is about six miles. *pu/qiai alludes to the *pu/qion, an Ionic temple of Apollo (some fragments from which are among the Elgin marbles in the British Museum), situated on the site of the present monastery of Daphnè, in the narrowest and highest part of the pass. (Cp. Leake, Demes pp. 144 f.: Paus. 1.37.6.) Others take the *pu/qiai a)ktai/ to mean Oenoe, where also there was a temple of Apollo. But (a) Oenoe was about 12 miles N.W. of Eleusis, near the pass of Dryoscephalae over Cithaeron. a)ktai/ could not be said of such an inland place, and the distance imagined is too great. (b) The order of mention indicates the *pu/qiai a)ktai/ as nearer than Eleusis to Colonus.

(2) lampa/des a)ktai/, "the torch-lit shores" (cp. Harpocr. 184, quoted on 56, e(orta\s lampa/das): the coast of the same bay of Eleusis at a point about 5 miles W.N.W. of the former point,—viz. at Eleusis itself. The yearly celebration of the great Eleusinia began on or about the 16th of Boedromion (September). On the 20th of that month an image of Iacchus was borne in a torch-light procession along the i(era\ o(do/s from Athens to Eleusis. This procession is indicated by the xoro\s mustw=n in Aristoph. Ran. 316 ff.: see ib. 340
e)/geire floge/as lampa/das, e)n xersi\ ga\r h(/keis tina/sswn,
*)/iakx), w)= *)/iakxe,
nukte/rou teleth=s fwsfo/ros a)sth/r. The search of Demeter for Persephone was also represented at Eleusis in a pannuxi/s of torch-bearing mystae. Cp. Aesch. fr. 376 (speaking of Eleusis) lamprai=sin a)strapai=si lampa/dwn sqe/nei. Ar. Th. 1151 o)/rgia semna\ qeai=n, i(/na lampa/si fai/neton a)/mbroton o)/yin.
po/tniai, Demeter and Persephone (Cora), who in Ar. Th. 1156 are called *qesmofo/rw polupotni/a. Cp. 683.

tiqhnou=ntai, as the spiritual nurturers of their faithful votaries. Simonides, too, has this word in a fig. sense, fr. 150. 7 eu)= d' e)tiqhnei=to glukera\n o)/pa *dwri/ois *)ari/stwn | *)argei=os ("cultivated").
te/lh: Plat. Rep. 560E teloume/nou yuxh\n mega/loisi te/lesi: Eur. Hipp. 25 semnw=n e)s o)/yin kai\ te/lh musthri/wn: Aesch. fr. 377 mustikou= te/lous: in prose usu. teletai/.

qnatoi=sin, esp. fitting here, since the highest value of the Eleusinia consisted in opening a prospect of bliss after death. Soph. fr. 753
w(s tri\s o)/lbioi
kei=noi brotw=n, oi(\ tau=ta derxqe/ntes te/lh
mo/lws' e)s *(/aidou: toi=sde ga\r mo/nois e)kei=
zh=n e)/sti, toi=s d' a)/lloisi pa/nt' e)kei= kaka/. Pindar fr. 114 o)/lbios o(/stis i)dw\n kei=n' ei)=s' u(po\ xqo/n): oi)=de me\n bi/ou teleuta/n, oi)=den de\ dio/sdoton a)rxa/n. Isocr. or. 4 § 28 h(=s ( teleth=s ) oi( metasxo/ntes peri/ te th=s tou= bi/ou teleuth=s kai\ tou= su/mpantos ai)w=nos h(di/ous ta\s e)lpi/das e)/xousin.

w(=n kai\ xruse/a k.t.l.: w(=n refers to qnatoi=sin: kai\ ("also") has the effect of limiting the reference to those persons on whom the pledge of secrecy has been imposed; — "those mortals on whose lips has been set the divine seal of the ministrant Eumolpidae": i.e. those who have been duly initiated by the Eumolpid Hierophant at Eleusis, and have been bound by him to secrecy.

klh\|s *eu)molpida=n (possessive gen.), the silence which they impose. Perhaps we should read be/bak' e)k. The Eumolpidae figure here as interpreters between the Two Goddesses and mortals, not as guardians of a secret which they may not communicate. Hence the above version is better than either of the following:—(1) w)=n referring to po/tniai: "whose seal has been set on the lips of the Eumolpidae": (2) w(=n referring to te/lh: "the seal whereof has been set on the lips of the E."
