klh\|s, "that which closes," cannot well be rendered "key" here, any more than in Aesch. fr. 309 a)ll' e)/sti ka)moi\ klh\|s e)pi\ glw/ssh| fu/lac. The apparent boldness of a Greek metaphor is sometimes thus mitigated by the poet's consciousness of the literal sense; as when Pindar calls an inspiring thought an a)ko/nh,—literally, "sharpener," conventionally "whetstone"); or when he calls the master, who tempers a chorus into harmony, a krath/r (Ol. 6. 82, 91: cp. my paper in Journ. Hellen. Stud. III. 171). — Cp. the bou=s e)pi\ glw/ssh| (Aesch. Ag. 36), perh. a mere metaphor from a heavy weight,—parodied by Menander *(aliei=s fr. 1 paxu\s ga\r u(=s e)/keit' e)pi\ sto/ma. Anthol. Pal. 10. 42 a)rrh/twn e)pe/wn glw/ssh| sfragi\s e)pikei/sqw. Eur. Med. 660 kaqara\n a)noi/c | anta klh=|da frenw=n, "having unlocked his heart in sincerity." klh|dou=xos was said either of a tutelar deity or of a priestess, and on the vases the symbolic key, adorned with woollen threads, is sometimes borne by the priestess (Passeri III. 294, Welcker Alte Denkm. III. 450 ff. etc.): but there is no evidence for the Eleusinian Hierophant actually putting a key to the lips of the initiated.
xruse/a, divine, precious,—because of the truths revealed: O. T. 157 xruse/as te/knon *)elpi/dos.

prospo/lwn *eu)molpida=n. The Eleusinia had four chief ministrants. 1. The i(erofa/nths. This office was hereditary in the Eumolpid gens; Plut. De Exil. 17 *eu)/molpos e)mu/hse kai\ muei= tou\s *(/ellhnas (as the earliest hierophant, and the ancestor of his successors). 2. The da|dou=xos: hereditary in the gens of Callias and Hipponicus, which traced itself from Triptolemus. 3. The i(erokh/ruc: hereditary in the gens of the *khruki/dai (or *kh/rukes). 4. The altar-priest, i(ereu\s o( e)pi\ bwmw=|, or e)pibw/mios, who offered the sacrifice. It is not known whether this office was hereditary. As some relationship seems to have existed between the Eumolpidae and the two other gentes, prospo/lwn here possibly includes (2) and (3), but is more naturally taken of the i(erofa/nths only. A hydria found at Cumae, and belonging to a Campanian collection now at St Petersburg, exhibits an Eleusinian group of deities and priests, among whom the i(erofa/nths is distinguished by a long white stole, partly embroidered with gold, a myrtle wreath, and the thyrsus. (It is reproduced by Baumeister, Denkmäler des kl. Alt.., p. 474, pl. 520.)

I incline to believe that the MS. words e)/nq' oi)=mai to\n e)grema/xan are sound, and that the variant o)reiba/tan may have arisen by corruption from e)grema/xan. See Appendix on this passage. The fact that the antistrophic passage is certainly unsound in the MSS. has increased the doubt: see on 1069.

e)grema/xan, "rousing the fight," is a fit epithet for the champion who overtakes the captors, and forces them to a contest. Elsewhere we find only the fem. e)grema/xh, as epithet of Pallas, Hom. Hymn. 5.424. Cp. Bacchyl. 12. 100[=13.67 of Kenyon's ed.] a)ersima/xous.

*qhse/a has the final a long in 1458, but short here: cp. Eur. Hec. 882 cu
 tai=sde to
 e)mo
 fone/a timwrh/somai, =870 ed. Porson, who adds Philemon ap. Athen. 7. 307 E kestre/) o)pto/n. Is the MS. kai\ after *qhse/a genuine? If so, e)mmei/cein is here intrans., like e)pi-, pros-, summignu/nai: and the sense is, "Theseus and the two maidens will soon meet amid a battle-cry of confident prowess." Thus with e)mmei/cein we are to understand a)llh/lois. The verb is fitting, because the maidens, though their sympathies are with Theseus, are in the midst of the hostile force.

au)ta/rkei boa=| is dat. of circumstance. This I believe to be the right view. Not, "Th. and the maidens will join battle with the foe," sc. toi=s polemi/ois: for the maidens are in the hands of the foe. Such a phrase is not defensible merely because in spirit they are with Theseus.

Many critics, however, now regard kai\ as spurious: for *qhse/a kai\ Dindorf proposes *ai)gei+/dan: for *qhse/a kai\ ta\s Wecklein *qhse/a pai=das. The sense would then be:—"Theseus will soon bring the sisters into (i.e., will soon raise around them) a battle-cry of confident prowess,"—by attacking their captors. This is possibly right: but a change of kai\ ta\s into pai=das is hardly likely. In Ph. 79 pai=, which Erfurdt changed to kai/, is clearly sound.
disto/lous="two journeying" sisters, —as borne off by their captors: see on 17 pukno/pteroi. Not, "separately carried off," with ref. to two bands of Thebans (cp. 818).
au)ta/rkei, "self-sufficing," and so "self-reliant," giving confident promise of victorious rescue.
tou/sd' a)na\ x.: i.e. in Attica, before the border can be passed.

The poet has left the details of the rescue indistinct. Creon's guards first carried off the girls (844), and Theseus sent mounted Athenians in pursuit (897). Afterwards, Theseus commands Creon to lead him to where the girls are; if they are "in these regions" (1020 e)n to/poisi toi=sd)), Theseus himself will recover them: if, however, the guards are already flying with them, then Theseus has nothing to do; the mounted Athenians, who have already started, will pursue (1020 ff.). But from the words of Theseus in 1148 it is plain that they have been rescued by his personal prowess, of which he forbears to boast (kompei=n, 1149): and the same inference must be drawn from Antigone's words (1117). How are these facts to be reconciled? We can only suppose that the mounted Athenians, who started first, halted to watch the di/stomoi o(doi/ (900), while Creon's guards also halted somewhere in concealment, to await their master. Theseus, with Creon, was thus enabled to overtake his Athenians before the struggle. The fact is that Sophocles did not care to think out these points, about which an Athenian audience in the theatre would not trouble themselves. Cp. on O. T. 758.

Hartung's ei)s nomo/n for the MS. e)k nomou= is certain. With the latter, we could only render: "they will approach (the region) to the west of the snowy rock, out of (leaving) the pastures of the Oeatid territory." The rare acc. with pela/zw could be supported by Eur. Andr. 1167 dw=ma pela/zei: but the ellipse of xw=ron with to\n e)fe/speron is surely impossible.
nomou=, being always masc., could not agree with *oi)a/tidos, and the latter, without art., could not stand for *oi)a/tidos gh=s: while *oi)ate/os is most improbable.

pelw=s), if sound, must be fut. of pela/zw, as pela=n clearly is in El. 497. The evidence for a pres. pela/w is scanty (Hom. Hymn. 7.44 pela/an: poet. ap. Plut. Mor. 457 C imperat. pe/la: Oppian Cyn. 1. 514 pela/ei: cp. Veitch Irreg. Verbs). The fut. seems defensible here, as="they will (presently) approach": though Hartung's perw=s) may be right. Construe, then: — h)/ pou pelw=s' ei)s e)fe/speron pe/tr. nif. *oi)a/tidos nomo/n: "or perchance they will presently approach the pastures to the west of the snowy rock of Oea."

The place meant is not certain. See note and map in Appendix. But the scholium here deserves at least thus much weight: it is our one ancient warrant for a definite view. Like the other old scholia in L, it probably dates (in substance) from the later Alexandrian age, which possessed many Attic writings, now lost, on the topography of Attica. The scholiast takes the nifa\s pe/tra to be a rock or crag of Mount Aegaleos;— the same which was called lei/a pe/tra, "the smooth rock," by Istros, a writer on Attica, c. 240 B.C., whom he quotes. The schol. then explains *oi)a/tidos by the fact that Aegaleos e)p' e)sxa/twn e)sti\ tou= dh/mou tou/tou, "skirts that deme," —namely, of *oi)/h. It cannot reasonably be doubted that this statement about *oi)/h, if it did not rest on the scholiast's own knowledge, was derived from Istros, or from some other old writer on Attic topography.

The meaning will then be:—"Or perhaps the captors did not take the road through the pass of Daphnè, which goes by the sea-coast to Eleusis. Perhaps they went round the N. end of Aegaleos, and will soon be emerging on the Thriasian plain, to the west of Aegaleos, near the deme of Oea." This is also Leake's view (Demi of Attica p. 154). The route supposed would be in the general line of that taken by Archidamus and the Peloponnesians in 431 B.C., when they moved from Oenoe E.S.E. to Acharnae, e)n decia=| e)/xontes to\ *ai)ga/lewn o)/ros,— i.e. keeping it to the S.,—dia\ *krwpia=s, a deme in the valley between the N. end of Aegaleos and the S.W. end of Parnes. Hartung, referring to the lei/a pe/tra of Istros, conjectures li^ta/dos, as="smooth," for nifa/dos: but though late poets could use li^to/s for li_to/s, the i^ is most improbable for Soph.

r(imfarma/tois … a(mi/llais =a(mi/llais r(i/mfa ferome/nwn a(rma/twn (see on 710 au)/xhma...eu)/ippon), emulous careers of swift chariots, as El. 861 xalargoi=s e)n a(mi/llais, races of swift steeds: cp. Ant. 1065 troxou\s a(millhth=ras h(li/ou, rapid courses of the sun.

a(lw/setai, sc. o( *kre/wn, "he will be worsted" (not, "captured," since he was already in the hands of Theseus): cp. Thuc. 1.121 mia=|...nikh=|...a(li/skontai, they are sure to be overthrown by one victory of ours. For the ellipse of the subject, where the mind could readily supply it, cp. Xen. Cyr. 2.4.24 poreu/somai dia\ tou= pedi/ou eu)qu\s pro\s ta\ basi/leia. kai\ h)
 me
 a)nqisth=tai, "and if the enemy (the king) resist," etc.—This is better than (1) "the fugitive will be captured," supplying o( feu/gwn from feu/gontes: (2) "a capture will be made,"— taking the verb as impers.: or (3) "the battle will be won," a(lw/setai o( a)gw/n, as Elms. takes it, comparing 1148 a(gw
 h(|re/qh.

prosxw/rwn, the neighbours of the grove, the Coloniates (cp. 493); not, "our neighbours the Thebans," for the Chorus are predicting an easy victory, not a tough fight. Colonus and its neighbourhood had furnished a contingent to the party of rescue (897).

*qhseida=n, schol. *)aqhnai/wn: cp. *kekropi/dai, *)erexqei=dai, Aeneadae, etc.: here, followers of Theseus from Athens, as distinct from the Coloniates. We could not well understand, with Ellendt, "the Coloniates, and the followers of Theseus generally," as if *qhseida=n included prosxw/rwn.

a)kma/, vigour, might: Pind. Isthm. 3. 68
a)ll' o)noto\s me\n i)de/sqai,
sumpesei=n d' a)kma=| baru/s, "dread to grapple with in his strength."

We require u - instead of the MS. kat'. Bothe gets this by supposing non-elision of kata\ before a)mpukth/ria. This, though rare, is possible: cp. Ai. 425 xqono\s molo/nt' a)po\ | *(ellani/dos: Tr. 510 *bakxi/as a)/po | h)=lqe. But I cannot believe kata\ | a)mpukth/ria to be Greek, as meaning either (1) "according to the full speed given by the headgear," i.e. by shaking the reins,—Paley: or (2) "in the direction of the bridles,"— i.e. "every horseman gives his steed its head," Campbell. Instead of kat', Hermann gives xalw=s): Schneidewin proposed kaqei=s' (cp. Eur. Bacch. 695 kaqei=san ei)s w)/mous ko/mas). This, if it had become katei=s), might easily have shrunk to the MS. kat', through the rest of the word being taken for ei)s.

a)mpukth/ria fa/lara pw/lwn is the MS. reading. Hesychius s.v. has: a)mpukth/ria: ta\ fa/lara. *sofoklh=s *oi)di/podi e)n *kolwnw=|. This proves what the metre (on any view of 1054) already hinted,— that fa/lara is a gloss. a)mpukth/rion here="bridle," as a)mpukth/r in Aesch. Theb. 461 i(/ppous d' e)n a)mpukth=rsin e)mbrimwme/nas: where the schol. (minor) expressly says that a)/mpuc (properly the head-band) was similarly used: kuri/ws oi( peri\ th
 kefalh
 i(ma/ntes tou= xalinou= a)/mpuc kalou=ntai: and so Quintus Smyrnaeus uses a)/mpuc, 4. 511. It is but a slight poetical extension of meaning to use a)mpukth/ria as including the bridle-reins. The MS. pw/lwn is against the metre, unless 1054 f. are very boldly altered (see Metrical Analysis). When the gloss fa/lara had crept into the text, pw/lwn (suggested by 1062) may have been tacked on to it. Wecklein's conjecture, a)mpukth/ria stomi/wn ("the reins of the bits") gives an exact correspondence with 1054 e)/nq' oi)=mai to
 e)grema/xan. Nothing better has been suggested.
a)/mbasis, in such a context, needs not to be defined by pw/lwn. For the apocopè, cp. Ant. 1275 a)ntre/pwn, n.
oi(\, as if a)naba/tai had gone before: cp. Ai. 235 w(=n after poi/mnhn: Her. 8.128 perie/drame o(/milos,...oi(\ etc. Cp. 942 n. (au)tou/s after po/lin).
ta\n i(ppi/an: see on 55.

gaia/oxon, in the Homeric use, is most simply explained as "earth-embracer," with ref. to the Homeric idea of *)wkeano/s flowing round the earth: though some understand "reigning on earth" (as Zeus in heaven, and Hades in the nether world Il. 15.190). Some take it here as = "guarding our land," like g. *)/artemin in O. T. 160: and this certainly has more special point here. But would the constant Homeric epithet of Poseidon be applied to him in a sense different from the Homeric? All Greek hearers would think of the gaih/oxos *)ennosi/gaios.

*(re/as, here a monosyllable, as in Il. 15.187,—the only instance of this form in Il. or Od., but a dissyllable in Hom. Hymn. 5.459, th\n d' w(=de prose/eipe *(re/h liparokrh/demnos. Elsewhere in the Hymns the form is always *(rei/h, as in Il. 14.203. In Hes. Th. 634 *(rei=a is read.

Rhea, in the Greek theogony, is daughter of Uranos and Gaia, wife of Cronus, and "mother of the gods." The cult was that of the "Phrygian Mother" Cybele in a special phase, and came very early to Greece from Lydia: in Attica it was intimately connected with the Eleusinian cult of Demeter (cp. Hom. Hymn. 5.442, Eur. Helen 1301 ff. ). The *mhtrw=|on at Athens, the temple of Rhea Cybele, contained a celebrated statue of the goddess, by Pheidias or his pupil Agoracritus.
e)/rdous): "are they (the pursuers) in action, or on the point of being so? for (w(s) I have a foreboding, etc."

me/llousin, sc. e)/rcein: cp. Tr. 74
*eu)boi=da xw/ran fasi/n, *eu)ru/tou po/lin,
e)pistrateu/ein au)to\n h)\ me/llein e)/ti: Ph. 567 w(s tau=t' e)pi/stw drw/men), ou) me/llont' e)/ti: ib. 1255 a)lla\ ka)me/ toi | tau)to\n to/d' o)/yei drw=nta kou) me/llont' e)/ti.

gnw/ma moi my mind promna=tai/ ti (adv.) somehow pleads for the belief, presages. promna=sqai means (1) to woo for another, ko/rhn tini/: (2) fig., to seek to obtain anything for another, e.g. dw=ra/ tini. The bold use here comes through the notion of pleading, or speaking persuasively, as the promnh/stria to the maiden on behalf of the lover. This use is bolder than the fig. use in Plat. Menex. 239 C, where the question is of themes which have already been "married to immortal verse," as distinguished from others in respect of which Poetry e)/ti e)stin e)n mnhstei/a|, is still in the stage of courtship. Of these latter, says the orator, I will speak—e)painou=nta/ te kai\ promnw/menon a)/llois e)s w)|da\s...au)ta\ qei=nai, commending them, and wooing them for others (i.e. for the poets), with a view to their putting them into verse. (A passage which has often been misunderstood as if promn. a)/llois meant "pleading with others":—so Lidd. and Scott, with Ast.)

a)nta/sein (Buecheler),—a conjecture which had occurred independently to myself,—seems the most probable correction of a)\n dw/sein. The Chorus express a presentiment that they will soon again be brought face to face with the maidens who were dragged away before their eyes; and this prepares for the approaching entrance of Antigone and Ismene, 1097 ta\s ko/ras ga\r ei)sorw=.

a)nta/w usu. takes a dat. of meeting a person, but sometimes a gen., as Il. 16.423 a)nth/sw ga\r e)gw\ tou=d' a)ne/ros (in battle). With the gen., a)nta/w also=kurei=n, tugxa/nein: Od. 3.97 h)/nthsas o)pwph=s: Her. 2.119 ceini/wn h)/nthse mega/lwn. Cp. Soph. Ant. 982 a)/ntas' *)erexqeida=n, she attained unto them (traced her lineage back to them). Here the idea of obtaining back is blended with that of being brought face to face. It is not, then, a valid objection that the Chorus do not move to meet the maidens.

To a)ndw/sein the objections are: (1) it could not possibly mean a)posw/sein, "give back." In Pind. fr. 133. 3, the sole passage quoted for this sense, a)ndidoi yuxa\n pa/lin is not "gives back," but "sends up," to the sunlight,—like gh= a)nadi/dwsi karpo/n. We must not be confused by our "give up." (2) To supply "Creon" or "the enemy" as subject is extremely awkward. (3) The sing. ta\n...tla=san, etc., which this requires, cannot well be defended on the ground that Antigone is chiefly thought of.

With e)ndw/sein we have to render:— "that the sufferings of those who have endured dread things, and found dread sufferings at the hands of kinsmen, will remit,"—become milder. Hippocrates (Progn. 43) uses the intrans. e)ndido/nai of a malady which remits its force. But is pa/qh … e)ndw/sein tolerable here, where the question is not of the sisters' sufferings being mitigated, but of their triumphant deliverance from the hands of the enemy? If, again, e)ndw/sein="give up," it incurs the 2nd and 3rd objections to a)ndw/sein.
kat' a)=mar here=kat' h)=mar...to\ nu=n (Ai. 753), as moi=ra kaqameri/a (El. 1414) ="the doom of to-day."
a)ellai/a: O. T. 466 a)ella/dwn | i(/ppwn.
taxu/rrwstos goes closely with it in sense, "with a swift, strong impetus, as of the storm,"taxe/ws r(wome/nh, w(s a)/ella: cp. Il. 23.367 e)rrw/onto meta\ pnoih=|s a)ne/moio.

Hermann's a)/nwq' for the au)tw=n d) of the MSS., with ai)wrh/sasa for qewrh/sasa, gives the most probable correction of the passage. a)/nwqe, for a)/nwqen, though it does not occur elsewhere in trag., is once used by Aristoph. Eccl. 698 (a)/nwq' e)c u(perw/|ou), and we can hardly doubt that a tragic poet would have admitted it,—at least in lyrics,—when metre required. Note these points. (1) If we read tw=nd' with Wunder, the gen. tw=nd' a)gw/nwn must be governed in one of two ways: (a) by ku/rsaimi, when ai)qeri/as nefe/las must mean, "from a cloud." This is possible (cp. O. T. 808 o)/xou...kaqi/keto n.): but it is awkward. It is much more natural to take ai)qer. nefe/las with ku/rsaimi. (b) By something substituted for qewrh/sasa. Wecklein makes the gen. depend on ai)wrh/sasa, as="having lifted above": but the gen. would mean "from," as Ant. 417 xqono\s
div3.l: ...a)ei/ras: and the rise here is not from the fight below. He has since conjectured (Neue Philol. Rundschau, 1886, p. 386) au)tw=n a)/nwqen: which is near to the letters of L (see cr. n.): but au)tw=n (referring to a)gw/nwn in 1080) seems a little weak; and in any case I should prefer a)/nwqen au)tw=n. qe/a| te/ryasa, plh/sasa, etc., have no palaeographic likelihood, and are further condemned by the aorist tense where we should require the present. I had thought of tw=nd' a)gw/nwn | u(/perq' a)/rasa, but prefer Herm.'s remedy.
div3.p: qewrh/sasa cannot be defended by Campbell's version, "having gone as a spectator with mine eye."
qewrh/sousa is read by Blaydes, who renders, "to give my eye a sight." This, as Paley says, is not Greek.
ai)wrei=n, not e)wrei=n, is the classical Attic form: cp. on O. T. 1264.

In the MS. order of the words, i)w\ *zeu=, pa/ntarxe qew=n (monosyll.)=1074 e)/rdous' h)\ me/llousin; w(s, and panto/pta, po/rois=1075 promna=tai/ ti/ moi. This requires the final a of the voc. panto/pta to be long, which is impossible, though some edd. tacitly assume it. Meineke's remedy, panto/pt' w)=, is not probable: and panto/ptas (nom. for voc.) could not stand here. The simple transposition which I have made in the text removes the difficulty. In 1088 the MSS. have e)pinikei/w| sqe/nei: yet it is certain that the order of the words should be the reverse.
damou/xois (cp. on 458), the people of Attica.
sqe/nei: cp. Tr. 497 me/ga ti sqe/nos a( *ku/pris e)kfe/retai ni/kas a)ei/.
e)pinikei/w| for e)piniki/w|: cp. Ant. 358 u(pai/qreia (Boeckh, for ai)/qria).

to\n eu)/agron teleiw=sai lo/xon (grant to the Athenians) to accomplish the successful surprise,— the way-laying of Creon's guards, by which the Athenians will secure their quarry (a)/gra), viz. the maidens.

to\n eu)/agron, proleptic: cp. Tr. 477
th=sd' ou(/nex' h( polu/fqoros
kaqh|re/qh patrw=|os *oi)xali/a do/rei.

lo/xon, "ambuscade," seems here to have the more general sense, "scheme of capture" (cp. Od. 4.395 fra/zeu su\ lo/xon qei/oio ge/rontos, a way to take him): though there is nothing in the scanty references to the pursuit which necessarily excludes the idea of a literal ambush. Taking lo/xon as="company," we could render, "grant this to our folk,—that thou shouldst crown the successful band with victory" (teleiw=sai): cp. El. 1508 w)= spe/rm' *)atre/ws … | th=| nu=n o(rmh=| telewqe/n, "crowned with peace by this day's effort": but the construction thus supposed is less simple, while the frequent poetical association of lo/xos with capture points to the other sense.
semna/ te pai=s, sc. po/roi (from po/rois, 1086).

to
 a)greuta
, the hunter. Cp. Aesch. fr. 195 (Heracles, in the *promhqeu\s *luo/menos, when aiming his shaft at the eagle) *)agreu\s d' *)apo/llwn o)rqo
 i)qu/noi be/los. Paus. (1. 41. 3) saw at Megara a temple dedicated to *)agrote/ran *)/artemin kai\ *)apo/llwna *)agrai=on. Xenophon, in his treatise on hunting, bids the hunter pray tw=| *)apo/llwni kai\ th=| *)arte/midi th=| *)agrote/ra| metadou=nai th=s qh/ras (Cyneg. 6. 13).—Note the change from vocative (*zeu=), and 3rd pers. (pai=s) with optat., to the constr. of acc. and infin. with ste/rgw. Cp. O. T. 204 *lu/kei' a)/nac...209 to
 xrusomi/tran te kiklh/skw: Aesch. PV 88 w)= di=os ai)qh/r etc....kai\ to
 pano/pthn ku/klon h(li/ou kalw=.

o)pado\n … e)la/fwn, as follow ing them in the chase. Artemis *)agrote/ra had a temple at Athens in the suburb *)/agrai, on an eminence by the Ilissus; and to her, as "smiter of deer," the festival of the *)elafhbo/lia was held in the month thence named (Mar.—Apr.). Hom. Hymn. 27.2
e)lafhbo/lon, i)oxe/airan, …
h(\ kat' o)/rh skio/enta kai\ a)/krias h)nemoe/ssas
a)/grh| terpome/nh pagxru/sea to/ca titai/nei. She is also e(llofo/nos, Corp. Inscr. 5943 (e(llo/s, a faun), qhrokto/nos, qhrofo/nos, etc.

puknosti/ktwn: cp. Eur. Hipp. 215
ei)=mi pro\s u(/lan
kai\ para\ peu/kas, i(/na qhrofo/noi
stei/bousi ku/nes,
baliai=s e)la/fois e)gxrimptome/na: Alc. 584 poikilo/qric | nebro/s.

ste/rgw, "I desire." Schol. shmai/nei me\n oi)=on prosi/emai: teleuta=| de\ ei)s i)/son tw=| prokalou=mai, “the (literal) sense is nearly, "I approve" (or "consent"); but the ultimate (or virtual) sense is, "I invoke".” The scholiast saw the impropriety of rendering, "I am content that the gods should come to help us," and so imagined this transition of meaning. His only fault lay in starting from the special and derivative sense of ste/rgein, "to be content," and not from its primary sense, "to love," whence poetry could easily draw the neighbouring sense, "to desire." So in O. T. 11 ste/rcantes= "having formed a desire." Hermann and others take ste/rgw here as="I entreat," —getting the idea of "praying" through that of "revering" (as implied in the storgh/ of children for parents, etc.). Hermann so takes the word in the Orphic Argonautica 772 meilixi/ois ste/rcoi te paraifa/menos e)pe/essin ("entreat him"), where Ruhnken conjectured qe/lcoi.
dipla=s a)rwga\s, two aids (abstract for concrete), Apollo and Artemis. Cp. O. T. 164 trissoi\ a)leci/moroi profa/nhte/ moi (Zeus, Apollo, Artemis).

div2.head: 1096-1210: Third episode
div2.p: Third e)peiso/dion. The maidens are restored to their father by Theseus; who also brings word that an unknown suppliant has placed himself at the altar of Poseidon, praying to speak with Oedipus.

div3.p: tw=| skopw=| me\n, "to thy watcher at least" (cp. 802 e)moi\ me/n). The Chorus, left alone with the blind man, has acted as his watchman.
me/n implies, "if my mere presage (1075) did not persuade, my eyes, at least, may be trusted."

prospoloume/nas has been much suspected (see cr. n.). The verb prospolei=n elsewhere occurs only in the act. as=to be a pro/spolos (with dat., Eur.). So doruforei=n=to be a body-guard, r(abdouxei=n to be a lictor. And if the passives doruforei=sqai (Plat., etc.) and r(abdouxei=sqai (Plut. Num. 10) can mean to be escorted by dorufo/roi or r(abdou=xoi, it is not plain why the pass. prospolei=sqai should not mean to be escorted by pro/spoloi. The attendants are the o)pa/ones (1103) of Theseus. The version "moving hither" (Schaefer) is wrong.

ti/s a)\n … doi/h, "who would give?"="oh that some one would give!" Aesch. Ag. 1448
ti/s a)\n …
mo/loi fe/rous' e)n h(mi=n
moi=r' a)te/leuton u(/pnon. So more often pw=s a)/n.
doi/h, by a sudden gift of sight to the blind eyes.

filta/twn t'. The omission of t) by the first hand in L was clearly a mere slip. From 1117, and from the words of Theseus himself (1148), it is manifest that he is supposed to have aided personally in the rescue. Cp. on 1054 ff.

mhdama/, ou)dama/ are used by the poets when the final must be short; mhdamh=|, ou)damh=|, when it must be long. Where, as here, either form is possible, L is not a safe guide in choosing between them. The mh-adverb occurs 5 times in Soph.: here L has mhdama=: in Ph. 789 (a like case) mhdamh=i. Above, 517, where mhdama/ is necessary, L has mhdama=: in 1698 (a like case), mhdamh=i. The ou)-adv. occurs 4 times in Soph., and L has always ou)dama=i, which is necessary only in Ant. 874, while ou)dama/ is necessary ib. 830: either could stand ib. 763, Tr. 323. Thus L's perispomenon form has displaced a necessary -a/ in 3 places, while only one place of all 9 requires the long form.

to\ mhdama\ e)lpisqe\n h(/cein, the generic mh/, one which was never expected, etc.,— and which, therefore, is the more welcome. Cp. O. T. 397 o( mhde\n ei)dw/s, n. —basta/sai dhloi= para\ toi=s *)attikoi=s to\ yhlafh=sai (Suidas s.v.): Eur. Alc. 917 fili/as a)lo/xou xe/ra basta/zwn.

a(\ teu/cei need not be explained as an attraction for w(=n teu/cei, since the neut. plur. acc. of pronouns and adjectives can stand after tugxa/nein and kurei=n, rather as a cognate or adverbial acc. than as directly governed by the verb: cp. Aesch. Cho. 711 tugxa/nein ta\ pro/s- fora, and see on O. T. 1298.
su\n po/qw| … h( xa/ris, the grace shown (by granting thy wish) is combined with a desire (on our own part).
e)/rnh, like qa/los (which, however, was used only in nom. and acc. sing.).—
tw=| teko/nti as Aesch. Cho. 690: so the allusive plur., O. T. 1176.
pa=n, sc. texqe/n.
skh=ptra: see on 848.
fwto/s: cp. 1018.

qanw\n can mean only, "having died,"—"after my death": but the reading, which has been suspected, seems sound. The sense is:—"were I to die now, I could not after my death be said to have been altogether unhappy, when my last hours had been thus cheered."

e)rei/sate … pleuro\n a)mfide/cion, "press each her side (to mine) on right and left"—Antigone on his one hand, Ismene on the other. Cp. O. T. 1243 a)mfideci/ois a)kmai=s, with the fingers of both hands, where see n.

e)mfu/nte, clinging close, like the Homeric e)n d' a)/ra oi( fu= xeiri/ (Il. 6.253), e)/fun e)n xersi\n e(/kastos Od. 10.397, clasped my hands, each and all. For the paronomasia with fu/santi cp. O. T. 878 xrhsi/mw| xrh=tai n.: for the masc. ending, see on 1676 i)do/nte.
With ka)napau/saton (note that L has ka)napau/seton) the words are usu. taken to mean, "and give me relief from this hapless wandering, desolate before," —i.e. since Antigone was carried off (844).

pla/nou, then, must mean, "wanderer's doom," for we cannot explain it merely of restless movements on the scene since his daughter's departure. But this seems forced. Wecklein explains it figuratively, of the insecurity felt by a blind man who has no guide ("Haltlosigkeit und Unsicherheit, wie sie der Blinde ohne Führer fühlt"). But how could pla/nou alone denote this mental state? Neither to\n pro/sq' e)/rhmon tou=de dusth/nou pla/nou nor tou= pr. e)rh/mou to/nde du/sthnon pla/nou mends matters. Schneidewin (rightly, I think) referred pla/nou to the carrying away of the maidens by Creon's guards, rendering, "repose from your late forlorn and hapless wandering." But a)napau/saton could not thus stand for the midd.: when the act. seems to do so, there is an acc. to be mentally supplied, as Thuc. 4.11 a)napau/ontes e)n tw=| me/rei, (not "resting," but) "relieving (their comrades) in turn": Xen. Hellen. 5.1.21 e)peidh\ de\ a)pei=xe pe/nte h)\ e(\c sta/dia tou= lime/nos h(suxi/an ei)=xe kai\ a)ne/paue (sc. ta\s nau=s). I would read ka)napneu/saton: for the gen. cp. Ai. 274 e)/lhce ka)ne/pneuse th=s no/sou: Il. 11.382 a)ne/pneusan kako/thtos: 15. 235 a)napneu/swsi po/noio. At such a moment it is surely natural that the father should have a word of sympathy for the late terror and distress of his helpless daughters, instead of dwelling solely on the pain to himself of being left without their support. The e in L is a trace of the truth.

tai=s thlikai=sde: i.e. it is not fitting for young maidens to make long speeches in such a presence. The epithet need not be pressed as implying extreme youthfulness (cp. 751). We seem to hear a covert criticism on some drama in which this maxim had been neglected. (A similar allusion has been supposed in El. 1289 ff., but is doubtful: see n. there.) So Eur., in Ph. 751, o)/noma d' e(ka/stou diatribh\ pollh\ le/gein, glances at Aesch. Theb. 375—652, and in fr. 165 at Soph. Ant. 563 f.—Cp. 1148.

o(/d' … tou=de: cp. El. 981
tou/tw filei=n xrh/, tw/de xrh\ pa/ntas se/bein:
tw/d' e)/n q' e(ortai=s etc.: Ant. 384 h(/d' e)/st' e)kei/nh … th/nd' ei(/lomen etc.

Hermann's change of the MS. tou)mo\n into tou=t' e)moi/ t) has been accepted by many edd. But the sense is most unsatisfactory. If tou)/rgon means the deed of rescue, as is most natural, the meaning will be: "this deed will be a short story both for thee and for me": i.e. "I shall not have to relate it, and you will be so much interested in listening to Theseus that you will not find it tedious." But is this tolerable,—to say nothing of the somewhat ungracious suggestion that the account of their deliverer's exploit would otherwise be fatiguing? The alternative version would be worse still: "this task (viz. that of reciting, or of hearing) will be short both for thee and me." I cannot but think, then, that this popular correction, though palaeographically easy, is untenable.

I have little doubt that Wex is right, or nearly so, in his ou(= ka)/sti tou)/rgon. The lo/gos should be his to whom belongs the e)/rgon. This supposes an accidental loss of ou(=, after which ka)/sti grew into kai\ soi/ te. The words tou)mo\n w)=d' e)/stai braxu\ then mean, "my part will thus be brief" (as you desire it to be, 1115) — consisting simply in referring Oed. to Theseus.
Take pro\s to\ lipare\s with mhku/nw| lo/gon: "do not wonder if with eager insistence I prolong my words to my children, now that they have appeared unexpectedly":

pro\s to\ l.=liparw=s, as pro\s bi/an=biai/ws, pro\s h(donh/n =h(de/ws: Ai. 38 pro\s kairo/n=kairi/ws: El. 464 pro\s eu)se/beian (le/gei)=eu)sebw=s. It is possible to join pro\s to\ l. with qau/maze, as Schneidewin and others do, comparing Tr. 1211 fobei= pro\s tou=to: but such a constr. for qauma/zein is without example.
te/kna, acc. governed by mhku/nw lo/gon as=dia\ makrw=n proshgorw=: see on 223: cp. 583, 1150.
a)/elpta, adv.: cp. 319.
th\n e)s ta/sde, having reference to them, i.e. caused by their return. Cp. ei)s in to/ g' ei)s e(auto/n (O. T. 706 n.), Eur. Or. 542 hu)tu/xhsen e)s te/kna.
mhdeno\s, instead of ou)deno/s, gives the emphasis of strong assurance: cp. on 797.

w(s instead of a(\ or oi(=a: cp. the phrase dido/nai eu)= (642). Schneidewin cp. Hom. Hymn. 5.136 doi=en...te/kna teke/sqai | w(s e)qe/lousi tokh=es: Ant. 706 w(s fh\s su/, kou)de\n a)/llo, tou=t' o)rqw=s e)/xein.
au)tw=| te k.t.l.: see 462 n., and cp. 308.
to/ g' eu)sebe/s: see on 260.
mo/nois: on 261.

tou)pieike\s: an equitable and humane disposition. Arist. Eth. Nic. 5.10 to\ e)pieike\s di/kaion me/n e)stin, ou) to\ kata\ no/mon de/, a)ll' e)pano/rqwma nomi/mou dikai/ou. Her. 3.53 tw=n dikai/wn ta\ e)pieike/stera protiqei=si, "prefer the more equitable course to the letter of their right." Soph. fr. 699
o(\s ou)/te tou)pieike\s ou)/te th
 xa/rin
oi)=den, mo/nhn d' e)/sterce th
 a(plw=s di/khn (speaking of Hades). Cp. Isocr. or. 15 § 300; Athens might be called the a)/stu th=s *(ellados both for other reasons kai\ ma/lista dia\ to
 tro/pon tw=n e)noikou/ntwn (the Athenian character): ou)de/nas ga ei)=nai praote/rous ou)de\ koino- te/rous ou)d' oi(=s oi)keio/teron a)/n tis to
 a(/panta bi/on sundiatri/yeien: "no people are gentler, or of larger sympathies, or more kindly associates throughout life."

ei)dw\s d' a)mu/nw k.t.l., "and I have experienced these qualities which I requite (acknowledge) with these words": cp. Ph. 602 (the gods) e)/rg' a)mu/nousin kaka/, requite evil deeds. The stress is on ei)dw/s, which is interpreted by the next v., e)/xw ga/r etc. Better thus than, "and I am conscious that I requite these merits (merely) with these (feeble) words." For that sense we should need something like fau/lois d' a)mu/nwn oi)=da toi=s lo/gois ta/de.— Others render: "And as one who has had experience I thus support these sayings (about Athens),"

ta/de being an adverbial cogn. acc., as O. T. 264 ta/d' w(sperei\ tou)mou= patro\s | u(permaxou=mai. But toi=sde toi=s lo/gois would then refer to what others say of Athens, whereas it plainly refers to what he himself has just said.
yau/sw, sc. au)th=s.

ei) qe/mis, "if it is lawful,"—a reverential or courteous formula usu. employed when the speaker believes that the act is lawful, as fr. 856. 14 ei)/ moi qe/mis, qe/mis de\ ta)lhqh= le/gein, | *dio\s turannei= pleumo/nwn,—if it is lawful to say so,—and it is lawful to say the truth,—she (Aphrodite) sways the heart of Zeus: so Tr. 809 f., etc. Here, however, the impulse of Oed. is abruptly checked by the thought that he is defiled:—kai/toi ti/ fwnw=; "but what am I saying?"

pw=s s'. Hermann's change of d' to s' is necessary, since otherwise the sense would be, "and how could I wish to touch a man,—I who," etc.; when a)ndro\s would be unendurably weak. But the words a)/qlios gegw\s are clearly sound. a)/qlios being a euphemism like sumfora/ said of a defilement or crime (O. T. 99). There is no justification for the bold change pw=s a)
 a(gno
 o)/nta se (Dind.), or the still bolder pw=s d' a)
 e)/rnos *ai)ge/ws (Mekler). Cp. the words of Heracles (when stained with blood-guilt) to Theseus, Eur. H. F. 1233 feu=g), w)= talai/pwr), a)no/sion mi/asm' e)mo/n.
ti/s ou)k=pa=sa: cp. O. T. 1526 ou)= ti/s ou) zh/lw| politw=n tai=s tu/xais e)pe/blepen; (n.): fr. 871 o(/pou ti/s o)/rnis ou)xi\ klagga/nei;
khli\s kakw=n, O. T. 833 khli=d'e)mautw=| sumfora=s a)figme/nhn.
cu/noikos: Plat. Phileb. 63D a)=r' e)/ti prosdei=sq' u(mi=n ta\s megi/stas h(dona\s cunoi/kous ei)=nai...; cp. on O. T. 337.
ou)k e)/gwge/ se, sc. qe/lw qigei=n:
ou)d' ou)=n, nor indeed will I allow it (ei) kai\ su\ qe/leis).

Oedipus is indeed i(ero/s (287), as the suppliant of the Eumenides, and eu)sebh/s (ib.), as obeying the word of Apollo; but at this moment he feels that, in the eye of religious law, he is still formally what Creon has just called him—patrokto/nos and a)/nagnos (944). Contrast the more passionate strain of his words in O. T. 1413, when he urges the Thebans to cast him forth—i)/t), a)ciw/sat' a)ndro\s a)qli/ou qigei=n. To touch him—he there says—can defile no one, because his unique doom places him apart.

brotw=n is changed by Nauck to kakw=n, and by Dindorf to e)mw=n ("my affairs"), on the ground that e)mpei/rois needs definition. But if the preceding words leave any need for such definition, it is supplied in the next v. by suntalaipwrei=n ta/de. Only those who, like his daughters, are already involved in the family sorrows can show him the offices of affection without fear of a new stain from the contact.

au)to/qen, i.e., "from where thou now art,"—without drawing near to receive an embrace. Cp. Il. 19.76
toi=si de\ kai\ mete/eipen a)/nac a)ndrw=n *)agame/mnwn
au)to/qen e)c e(/drhs, ou)d' e)n me/ssoisin a)nasta/s,—from where he sat, without rising.
e)s to/d' h(me/ras: cp. El. 14 toso/nd' e)s h(/bhs: ib. 961 e)s toso/nde tou= xro/nou (to this time of thy life).

ou)/t' ei)/ ti k.t.l.: lit., "if you have used somewhat great (ple/on) length of speech": e)/qou=e)poih/sw. Cp. Thuc. 5.89 ou)/te met' o)noma/twn kalw=n...mh=kos lo/gwn a)/piston pare/comen. ti (adv., O.T. 969) courteously softens the phrase.

qauma/sas e)/xw=teqau/maka: cp. 817: Plat. Phaedr. 257 C to\n lo/gon de/ sou pa/lai qauma/sas e)/xw, and ib. 258 B ou)x w(s u(perfronou=ntes,...a)ll' w(s teqaumako/tes. For the perfect, see on 186 te/trofen.

ou)/t): see cr. n. and cp. on 450. pro\ tou)mou= prou)/labes k.t.l., received their words first, in preference to speech with me. We need not supply e)/pous with tou)mou=, which="my part," "what I had to say"; cp. Tr. 1068 ei) tou)mo\n a)lgei=s ma=llon. The verb prolamba/nein nowhere = proairei=sqai/ ti/ tinos, to prefer one thing to another. It is pro\ tou)mou= which here suggests preference, while prou)/labes merely expresses priority in time.
ga\r="indeed," conveying an assurance.
dei/knumi d): cp. on 146 dhlw= d).

The usu. constr. is yeu/dein tina/ tinos, while yeu/dein tina/ ti is comparatively rare: and so here ou)de/n seems to be adv., while w(=n (=tou/twn a(/) is gen. after e)yeusa/mhn. So I should take Plat. Legg. 921A th
 timh
 tw=n e)/rgwn o)feile/tw w(=n a)
 to
 e)kdo/nta yeu/shtai, "of which he has disappointed the contractor,"—though an attraction of acc. into gen. is equally possible.
For the gen. with a)kraifnei=s cp. 1519: Eur. Hipp. 949 kakw=n a)kh/ratos.

h(|re/qh: cp. Her. 9.35 ou(/tw dh\ pe/nte sfi...a)gw=nas tou\s megi/stous... sugkataire/ei, helps them to conquer in five of the most important contests. Nauck formerly conjectured a(/gwn="the captor" (Creon).—Cp. on 1116.

lo/gos, by inverse attraction, instead of an acc. lo/gon governed by sumbalou= gnw/mhn as=sundia/skeyai (cp. on 223). Cp. Eur. Phoen. 940
e)k ge/nous de\ dei= qanei=n
tou=d', o(\s dra/kontos ge/nuos e)kpe/fuke pai=s. When the antecedent is thus drawn into the case of the relat., the case is more often the acc.: see on 56 to/pon.
lo/gos here=a subject for consideration (cp. our "argument" in the old sense of "theme").
e)mpe/ptwken, has presented itself to me: so Plat. Prot. 314C peri/ tinos lo/gou dielego/meqa o(\s h(mi=n kata\ th\n o(do\n e)ne/pesen.

sumbalou= gnw/mhn, not "collect your thoughts" (Blaydes), but "contribute your opinion," i.e. help me to decide what should be done. Her. 8.61 (Adeimantus in the council of Greek leaders) po/lin … to\n *qemistokle/a parexo/menon ou(/tw e)ke/leue gnw/mas sumba/llesqai, "he said that T. should have a city to represent before he contributed his views." Plat. Polit. 298C (if we should decide) culle/cai...e)kklhsi/an..., e)cei=nai de\ kai\ tw=n i)diwtw=n kai\ tw=n a)/llwn dhmiourgw=n peri/ te plou= kai\ peri\ no/swn gnw/mhn cumbale/sqai.

ei)pei=n qauma/sai: for the inf. act., cp. on 37, 461. So O. T. 777
( tu/xh ) qauma/sai me\n a)ci/a,
spoudh=s ge me/ntoi th=s e)mh=s ou)k a)ci/a.
a)/nqrwpon, emphatic (as O. T. 977, cp. ib. 1528 qnhto\n o)/nt)). A mortal cannot read the future, and therefore can never be sure that an incident, seemingly trivial, will not prove momentous.
ti/ d' e)/sti; cp. 311.

di/daske/ me w(s mh\ ei)do/t). The mh/ is due to the imperative: cp. Ph. 253 w(s mhde\n ei)do/t' i)/sqi m' w(=n a)nistorei=s: ib. 415 w(s mhke/t' o)/nta kei=non e)n fa/ei no/ei: Plat. Rep. 327C w(s toi/nun mh\ a)kousome/nwn ou(/tw dianoei=sqe.

w(s ou), instead of w(s mh/, sometimes stands, however, with the partic. (esp. in gen. or acc. absol.), although the verb is imperative: Eur. Med. 1311 w(s ou)ke/t' o)/ntwn sw=n te/knwn, fro/ntize dh/: Lys. or. 27 § 16 mh\...a)zhmi/ous a)fi/ete,...w(/sper tou= o)nei/dous a)ll' ou) th=s zhmi/as au)toi=s me/lon. And, when the verb is not imperative, w(s ou) in such cases is normal, as Xen. Mem. 2.3.3 tw=n d' a)delfw=n a)melou=sin, w(/sper e)k politw=n me
 gignome/nous fi/lous, e)c a)delfw=n de\ ou) gignome/nous: Thuc. 4.5 e)n o)ligwri/a| e)poiou=nto, w(s...ou)x u(pomenou=ntas: 6. 24 e)/rws e)ne/pese toi=s pa=sin...e)kpleu=sai,...w(s...ou)de
 a)
 sfalei=san mega/lhn du/namin. This is against referring mh\ ei)do/t) here to a cause independent of the imperative, viz. to the mental conception implied by
w(s: for though (e.g.) e)di/dacas w(s mh\ :ei)do/ta could mean, "you instructed me on the supposition that I knew not," usage indicates that w(s ou)k ei)do/ta would then have been preferred.
h(mi=n, ethic dat. (81).

e)/mpolin: cp. 637. As Theseus was returning from the rescue, word had been brought him that a stranger had seated himself as a suppliant on the steps of the altar of Poseidon at Colonus (see on 55). This man said merely that he was a kinsman of Oedipus; and that he wished to speak a few words to him (1162). The fact that he was not from Thebes, but from Argos (1167), seems to have been inferred from something in his dress, for Theseus says that he does not know whence the man had come (cp. 1161). Polyneices took this precaution of becoming a i(ke/ths because he did not know what power might now be at the command of the paternal anger which he foresaw (cp. 1165).

prospeso/nta pws: lit., "having somehow rushed to" the altar: i.e. he had come in the absence of those Coloniates who had hurried from the sacrifice to the rescue (899), and no one had witnessed his arrival. (Cp. 156 prope/sh|s, 915 e)peispeswn.)
pws could not mean, "for an unknown reason."
bwmw=| with prospeso/nta, rather than locative dat. with kaqh=sqai: with the latter cp. 1160 qa/khma, 1163 e(/dra (O. T. 15 prosh/meqa, ib. 20 qakei=, and ib. 2 n.).

e)/kuron. In Eur. Hipp. 746 ku/rwn was restored by Heath from MS. ku^rw=n (v.l. nai/wn): elsewhere Attic poets have only kure/w. Il. 23.821 has ku=ron: Hom. Hymn. 5.189 ku=re: and the form was used by the Alexandrian poets. It seems unnecessary, then, to conjecture kurw=n e)/quon (Blaydes).
h(ni/x' w(rmw/mhn, "when I first set out," lit., "when I proceeded to set out": i.e. when he left the sacrifice, summoned by the cry of the Chorus, 887.
tw=| qakh/mati, instrum. dat.:
pros- as in prosaitei=n (cp. on 122).

sou= seems to be an objective gen. with mu=qon, a colloquy with thee (cp. e)ma\n le/sxan, 167). We find ai)tw= tina, para/ tinos, pro/s tinos, etc., but never the simple gen. ai)tw= tinos (like de/omai/ tinos).

ou)k o)/gkou ple/wn, on a subject of no great pretensions,—i.e. not so important as to demand any great exertion from the old man. Cp. Eur. Phoen. 717 e)/xei tin' o)/gkon ta)/rgos *(ellh/nwn pa/ra. This seems better than to take o)/gkou here as="effort," a sense which it bears (in a different context) below, 1341 braxei= su\n o)/gkw| (non magna mole). If we rendered, "of no great compass" (i.e. length), ou)k o)/gkou ple/wn would merely repeat braxu/n.

Heath's insertion of t) after a)pelqei=n is necessary, unless we adopt Nauck's e)lqei=n qe/lont), i.e. "they say that, wishing to confer with you, he asks that he may retire safely from his journey hither" (his journey to Attica from Argos): but this throws too much stress on the return. Vauvilliers seems clearly right in restoring mo/non from the MS. molo/nt). The latter would go with e)lqei=n: "they say that he asks that, having approached, he may confer with you": but this is weak; and it would be even worse to take molo/nt) as="after his arrival" (at Colonus). mo/non fits the tone of the context. The suitor prefers his request in as modest a strain as possible.
kat' *)/argos. This brings the first flash of light to Oed.,—he remembers Ismene's words (378). Cp. on 1156.
tou=to is best taken as acc. after tuxei=n: cp. 1106 n., and O. T. 1155 ti/ prosxrh/|zwn maqei=n; But it might, of course, be acc. after prosxrh/|zoi, tuxei=n being epexegetic inf.

sxe\s ou(=per ei)=, "stop where thou art," i.e. "say no more"—do not go on to urge that I should receive this visitor. Cp. Eur. I. A. 1467 sxe/s, mh/ me proli/ph|s: Hipp. 1354 sxe/s, a)peirhko\s sw=m' a)napau/sw. This correction (Heath's) of the MS. i)/sxes is much better than Doederlein's i)/sxe s'. While the intrans. e)/xe is common as "hold!" (Plat. Prot. 349E etc.), we never find e)/xe se in that sense.
ti/d' e)/sti soi; "what is the matter with thee?" Cp. 311.
pra/gmatos poi/ou; The construction de/omai/ sou/ tinos, though less freq. than de/omai/ sou/ ti, occurs in good prose, as Xen. Cyr. 8.3.19 deo/menoi *ku/rou a)/llos a)/llhs pra/cews.
a)kou/wn tw=nd), hearing these words (1167): cp. 418: for tw=nd) referring to what precedes, 787.

o(/s=o(/stis: O. T. 1068 mh/pote gnoi/hs o(\s ei)=: Ai. 1259 maqw\n o(\s ei)=. Plat. Meno. 80D peri\ a)reth=s, o(\ e)/stin, e)gw\ me\n ou)k oi)=da. Her. 9.71 genome/nhs le/sxhs o(\s ge/noito au)tw=n a)/ristos.

prosta/ths, one who presents himself before a god as a suppliant: so 1278: schol. o( i(ke/ths, o( prosesthkw\s tw=| bwmw=|. Elsewhere the word always="protector" or "patron" (as O. T. 303, 411, 882, Tr. 209). Cp. El. 1377
h(/ se (sc. to\n *)apo/llwna) polla\ dh\
a)f' w(=n e)/xoimi liparei= prou)/sthn xeri/, "have oft come before thee with offerings of my best in suppliant hand."

o(/n g' e)gw\ ye/caimi, who is he, to whom I could possibly have any objection? See note in Appendix on 170; and cp. Aesch. PV 292 ou)k e)/stin o(/tw| | mei/zona moi=ran nei/maim' h)\| soi/. Distinguish 561 o(poi/as e)cafistai/mhn, which is not strictly similar (see n. there).
stugno/s has greater force through its position: "my son, king—a son whom I hate": cp. 1615 sklhra/n.
lo/gwn: for the gen. cp. 418.

a)/lgista a)ndrw=n,=a)/lgion h)\ panto\s a)/llou a)ndro\s (lo/gwn), more reluctantly than the words of any one else. The usage is similar to that by which a Greek could say, purami/da a)peli/peto e)la/ssw tou= patro/s (Her. 2.134), instead of th=s t. p., or h(\n o( path/r. Cp. O. T. 467 n. More often the words would mean, a)/lgion h)\ pa=s a)/llos a)nh/r (so oi)=mai ka/llist' a)nqrw/pwn le/gein, Plat. Ion 530 C).
a(\ mh\: "such things as thou dost not wish" (quae non cupias): cp. 1186, 73 n.

The emphasis is on klu/ein, not on tou=d): "why is it painful to thee to give this man a hearing?" Theseus has no need to ask, "why is it painful to thee to hear this man?"—for he knows already how Oed. has been treated by his sons (599). The sense is thus the same as if we kept the MS. tou=t': "why is this thing painful to thee,—namely, to hear?" (Cp. Ph. 1121 kai\ ga\r e)moi\ tou=to me/lei, mh\ filo/tht' a)pw/sh|: and O. T. 1058.) But, when the question has already been put in an abstract form (ou)k a)kou/ein e)/sti etc.), it would be tame to reiterate it in the same form. By tou=de it is adapted to the particular case. Cp. 1117 tou=de xrh\ klu/ein.
fqe/gma tou=q' (art. omitted, as 629), "that voice"—his son's. The blind man could not express loathing more vividly: cp. 863.
h(/kei, has come to be: O. T. 1519 qeoi=s g' e)/xqistos h(/kw. (Not, "has come hither.")

mh/ m' a)na/gkh| prosba/lh|s, "do not force me to the necessity" of yielding,—the a)na/gkh being, as it were, a rock on which his course is driven: cp. Aesch. Eum. 564 to
 pri
 o)/lbon | e(/rmati prosbalw
 … w)/let). We cannot properly call this "an inverted expression" for mh/ moi a)na/gkhn prosba/lh|s, which would suggest a wholly different image: cp. Tr. 255 o(/rkon au(tw=| prosbalw/n: ib. 41 e)moi\ pikra\s | w)di=nas … prosbalw/n.
ei)kaqei=n: cp. 862, 1015.
to\ qa/khm) (1160), his suppliant e(/dra at the altar of Poseidon, in whose name he implored the boon.

e)canagka/zei: cp. 603. If we point at sko/pei, as is best, then mh\ … h)=| is elliptical: "(beware, I say) lest." Cp. Plat. Gorg. 462E *p*w*l. ti/nos le/geis tau/ths; ("what calling do you mean?") *s*w. mh\ a)groiko/teron h)=| to\ a)lhqe\s ei)pei=n, "I fear it may be scarcely courteous to say the truth."
pro/noia … tou= qeou=, respect for the god: Andoc. or. 1 § 56 ei)=pon...a(\ h)/kousa..., pronoi/a| me\n tw=n suggenw=n kai\ tw=n fi/lwn, pronoi/a| de\ th=s po/lews a(pa/shs. Cp. on O. T. 978.
fulakte/a, must be observed, like fula/ssein no/mon, o(/rkia, etc. For slightly different, though kindred, uses of the verb, cp. 626, 1213.
piqou= moi, "comply with me," grant this wish, as El. 1207, Tr. 470 (n.): while pei/qou is rather, "be persuaded," as El. 1015, and above, 520.—
kei) where ei) kai/ would be normal: cp. 661.
ve/a: see on 751: cp. 1116.

to\n a)/ndra to/nde, Theseus (cp. 1100). "Allow him at once to gratify his own mind (his hinted desire that Polyneices should be heard, 1175), and to gratify Poseidon as he wishes to do," i.e. by granting the prayer made in Poseidon's name. The whole phrase xa/rin parasxei=n belongs to both clauses; a(\ is acc. of respect. The subj. to bou/letai is Theseus, not o( qeo/s.—These two vv. mark two leading traits in the character of Theseus—his sense of justice (freni/), and his piety (qew=|).
u(/peike here=sugxw/rei, "concede to us that..."; so parei/kein in prose.
paraspa/sei, sc. o( kasi/gnhtos. Cp. Ant. 791 su\ kai\ dikai/wn a)di/kous | fre/nas paraspa=|s e)pi\ lw/ba|, "thou wrenchest the minds e'en of the just unto injustice, for their bane."
a(\ mh/=(tau=ta) a)\ mh/ (1175), "in respect of such words as shall not be spoken for thy good,"—a tribute, marked by feminine tact, to her father's judgment.
le/cetai is always pass. in trag.: cp. 581 dhlw/setai, and see on O. T. 672.

kakw=s is Hermann's easy and certain correction of the MS. kalw=s. "Evilly devised deeds are disclosed by speech": i.e. even supposing that Polyneices is harbouring ill designs, the best way to discover them is to converse with him. Cp. Ant. 493
filei= d' o( qumo\s pro/sqen h(|rh=sqai klopeu/s,
tw=n mhde\n o)rqw=s e)n sko/tw| texnwme/nwn,—where the bad consoience is supposed to bewray itself even before (pro/sqen) investigation. With kalw=s, the words are merely "a rhetorical generality," as Campbell (who retains it) says: i.e. speech is a good thing, "for it is by speech that all man's best discoveries are revealed." But surely we need something more relevant to the matter in hand.

Meineke rejects the three verses, 1189—1191, because (1) e)/fusas au)to/n is too abrupt: (2) it is too much to tell Oed. that he must bear anything from his son: (3) the phrase ta\ tw=n kaki/stwn etc. is indefensible. As to (1), few readers can fail to perceive that the "abruptness" is both forcible and pathetic at the moment when she turns from colder and more external arguments to the plea of natural affection. As to (2), it is enough to observe that Antigone means, "The relationship between parent and child is indelibly sacred. No wickedness on your son's part can alter the fact that he is your son." As to (3), see next n.

dussebe/stat), w)= (Dawes) seems right: it amends the MS. ta\ tw=n kaki/stwn dussebesta/twn by simply striking off the final n. "The most impious among the worst of deeds" is a vehement phrase suited to the passion of the appeal. Among evil deeds, ta\ kaka/, those which outrage gods or kinsfolk form a class, ta\ dussebh=. If kaki/stwn were changed to ka/kista, the latter must be an adv., and tw=n dussebesta/twn must be masc.: "the deeds of men who in the worst way are most impious." ka)sebesta/twn ("the deeds of the worst and most impious men") is less probable.

qe/mis se/ g' ei)=nai. The MSS. here agree in the nominative. Vauvilliers suggested that e)sti/ might be supplied, taking se/ g' ei)=nai in the sense of se/ g' o)/nta, and comparing e(kw\n ei)=nai, etc. This may be rejected, as may also Reisig's dussebe/stat' a)/n, with ei)/h for ei)=nai: for then we should require ou)de\ in 1189. Is qe/mis, then, indeclinable in this phrase? That is now the received view. It rests, however, solely on the fact that our MSS. have qe/mis, and not qe/min, here, and in four other places, Plat. Gorg. 505D, Xen. Oec. 11 § 11, Aelian Nat. An. 1. 60, Aesch. Suppl. 335. Porson believed that, with Dawes, we ought to read qe/min. That is my own opinion; but, as the question must be considered doubtful, I have preferred to leave qe/mis in the text, and to submit the evidence in the Appendix.

a)ll' au)to/n: ei)si\, etc., is the traditional reading, on which a)ll' au(to/n was a variant, adapted, seemingly, to the fatuous interpretation, "Nay, you will hurt yourself" (see cr. n.). It is a robust faith which can accept a)ll' au)to/n as an aposiopesis. a)ll' e)/ason, "Nay, allow (him to come)," is perhaps the best remedy, since we can suppose au)to/n to have been an explanatory gloss which supplanted the verb. For the synizesis cp. O. T. 1451 a)ll' e)/a me, n. a)ll' e)/a au)to/n as = uu- is surely impossible for tragedy. Musgrave's a)ll' ei)=con is intrinsically preferable to either, but leaves the corruption unexplained. I had thought of ai)dou= nin ("have compassion on him"). If au)to/n had supplanted nin, *a*i*d might have become *a*l*l.

e)cepa/|dontai fu/sin, "are charmed out of their nature": lit. "are subdued by the charm, in their nature" (acc. of respect). Plat. Phaedo 77E a)ll' i)/sws e)/ni tis kai\ e)n h(mi=n pai=s, o(/stis ta\ toiau=ta fobei=tai: tou=ton ou)=n peirw/meqa pei/qein mh\ dedie/nai to\n qa/naton w(/sper ta\ mormolu/keia. *)alla\ xrh/, e)/fh o( *swkra/ths, e)pa/|dein au)tw=| e(ka/sths h(me/ras, e(/ws a)\n e)cepa/|shte ("charm him out of us"). Plut. De Iside et Os. 384 A ta\ krou/mata th=s lu/ras, oi(=s e)xrw=nto pro\ tw=n u(/pnwn oi( *puqago/reioi, to\ e)mpaqe\s kai\ a)/logon th=s yuxh=s e)cepa/|dontes ou(/tw kai\ qerapeu/ontes, "subduing by the charm (of music) the passionate and unreasoning part of the soul." Phaedr. 267 D o)rgi/sai te au)= pollou\s a(/ma deino\s a)nh\r ge/gone, kai\ pa/lin w)rgisme/nois e)pa/|dwn khlei=n, "soothe them, when angered, by his charming." Aesch. PV 172 meliglw/ssois peiqou=s | e)paoidai=sin. The frequency of the metaphor is due to the regular use of e)pw|dai/ in the medical practice of the age: thus Pindar describes Cheiron as using (1) incantations, (2) draughts, (3) amulets, (4) surgery (Pyth. 3. 51), and Plato's list of remedies is the same, with kau/seis added (Rep. 426 B). In Od. 19.457 an e)pw|dh/ stops hemorrhage, and in [Dem.] or. 25 § 80 is applied to epilepsy. Sophocles Tr. 1001 has ti/s ga\r a)oido/s (=e)pw|do/s),
ti/s o( xeirote/xnhs
i)atori/as, o(\s th/nd' a)/thn
...katakhlh/sei; Ai. 582 qrhnei=n e)pw|da\s pro\s tomw=nti ph/mati. Lucian mocks the notion that a fever or a tumour can be scared by an o)/noma qespe/sion h)\ r(h=sin barbarikh/n (Philops. 9). Cp. Shaksp. Cymbeline 1. 6. 115
'tis your graces
That from my mutest conscience to my tongue
Charms this report out.
e)kei=na, away yonder, in the past.

patrw=|a kai\ m., connected with them: so Ant. 856 patrw=|on d' e)kti/neis tin' a)=qlon. He is to turn from his present causes for anger (ta\ nu=n) to the issues of his former anger—when he slew his sire.
mhtrw=|a, because the slaying prepared the marriage.

teleuth\n, result: Her. 7.157 tw=| de\ eu)= bouleuqe/nti prh/gmati teleuth\ w(s to\ e)pi/pan xrhsth\ e)qe/lei e)pigi/nesqai. For the constr. cp. Ant. 1242
dei/cas e)n a)nqrw/poisi th\n a)bouli/an
o(/sw| me/giston a)ndri\ pro/skeitai kako/n.

ta)nqumh/mata (cp. 292), "the food for meditation" (on the evils of anger) which his blindness might furnish— itself due to an act of anger, the climax of acts traceable to the anger in which he slew Laïus. Cp. 855.
a)de/rktwn: "being deprived of thy sightless eyes,"="being deprived of thine eyes, so that they shall see no more," the adj. being proleptic: cp. 1088 to\n eu)/agron n.
thtw/menos: the pres. thta=sqai denotes a state ("to be without"), not an act ("to lose"); cp. Hes. Op. 408 mh\ su\ me\n ai)th=|s a)/llon, o( d' a)rnh=tai, su\ de\ thta=|, "and thou remain in want."

Notice the dat. prosxrh/|zousin (with kalo/n), followed by the acc. au)to/n with pa/sxein, and paqo/nta with e)pi/stasqai. A literal version shows the reason:—"It is not fitting for the askers of just things to sue long, nor that a man should himself be well-treated, and then not know how to requite it." Importunity is here viewed as touching the dignity of the suppliants; ingratitude, in its moral aspect.—
ou)d), sc. kalo/n e)sti. Cp. Isocr. or. 4 § 175 a)/cion e)pisxei=n, a)ll' ou)k e)peixqh=nai.
ou)k e)pi/stasqai: with the inf. after ou) kalo/n e)sti the normal negative would be mh/, or mh\ ou): but ou) is treated as forming one word with the inf.: cp. Il. 24.296 ei) de/ toi ou)-dw/sei.
ti/nein=a)mei/besqai: see on 229.

The structure of ou)d' au)to
 … ti/nein illustrates the Greek tendency to co-ordinate clauses: cp. Isocr. or. 6 § 54 pw=s ou)k ai)sxro/n,...th
 me
 *eu)rw/phn kai\ th
 *)asi/an mesth
 pepoihke/nai tropai/wn,... u(pe de\ th=s patri/dos...mhde\ mi/an ma/xhn fai/nesqai memaxhme/nous; We sometimes meet with the same construction in English: e.g. "For one thing I am sorry, and that is that the English Government might have prevented the conflict with one single word, and yet has not thought it necessary to interfere."
The stress is on barei=an: "Grievous (for me) is the gratification (to yourselves) in regard to which ye prevail over me by your words; however (d' ou)=n) it shall be as ye wish."

h(donh\n is a bold acc. of respect with nika=te, suggested by the constr. with a cognate acc., ni/khn nika=te, since the pleasure is secured by the victory. Cp. on 849 nika=n. We cannot well take h(d with le/gontes, "ye prevail over me in" (or "by") "speaking of a pleasure" etc.
d' ou)=n: cp. Ai. 115 su\ d' ou)=n … | xrw= xeiri/, "well, then, (if thou must)."
e)leu/setai: this form occurs Tr. 595, Aesch. PV 854, Suppl. 522: not in Eur., Comedy, or Attic prose, unless it be genuine in Lys. or. 22. 11. The Att. fut. is ei)=mi.
kratei/tw th=s e). yuxh=s, "become master of my life," acquire the power to dispose of me,—alluding to the Thebans' plan for establishing him on their border (cp. 408).
th=s e)m. y. is merely a pathetic periphrasis for e)mou=: see on 998.

klu/ein is not perfectly courteous, as Wecklein says, who reads le/gein,—perhaps rightly. But for klu/ein it may be pleaded that, just after so signal a proof of good-faith and valour, Theseus might be excused if he showed a little impatience at the reiterated fears of Oedipus. Cp. their conversation at 648—656. Besides,
ta\ toiau=t), a phrase which implies some annoyance, must refer to the fears just uttered, rather than to pledges which should allay them.

If d) is omitted (with Wecklein) after kompei=n, we must either make kompei=n ou)xi\ bou/lomai a parenthesis (as he does), or else point thus:
klu/ein:
w)= pre/sbu, etc. The abruptness would add a certain spirit to the words. But the d' after kompei=n may well be genuine, if we conceive him as checking the impulse to remind Oed. of the prowess already shown: — "however, I do not wish to boast."
su\ de\
sw=s i)/sqi could not mean, "know that you are safe": w)/n is indispensable: and the choice lies between (1)
su\ d' w)\n
sw=s i)/sq', and (2)
su\ sw=s
w)\n i)/sq'. For (2) it may be said that the MS. sw=n is more easily explained by it, and that de\ might have been added to complete v. 1209: for (1), that it is nearer to the actual text (in which sw=n may have sprung from w)/n superscript), and that sw=s is more effective if it begins the verse in which sw/zh| follows.

div2.head: 1211-1248: Third stasimon
div2.p: Third stasimon. (1) Strophe 1211—1224 = antistr. 1225— 1238. (2) Epode 1239—1248. See Metrical Analysis.—The old men of Colonus comment on the folly of desiring that life should be prolonged into years at which man's strength is "but labour and sorrow." The helpless and afflicted stranger before them suggests the theme, which serves to attune our sympathy, as the solemn moment of his final release draws nearer.

div3.p: o(/stis tou= ple/onos m. xrh/|zei, whoever desires the ampler portion, zw/ein (epexeg. inf.) that he should live (through it), parei\s, having neglected, i.e. not being content, tou= metri/ou (xrh/|zein), to desire a moderate portion: i.e., "whoever desires the larger part (of the extreme period allotted to human life), and is not satisfied with moderate length of days."

xrh/|z. with gen., as Ai. 473 tou= makrou= xrh/|zein bi/ou, which also illustrates the art. with ple/onos: cp. O. T. 518 ou)/toi bi/ou moi tou= makrai/wnos po/qos. For xrh/|z. tou= pl. m., zw/ein, instead of xrh/|z. zw/ein to\ ple/on me/ros, cp. 1755: Plat. Crito 52B ou)d' e)piqumi/a se a)/llhs po/lews ou)d' a)/llwn no/mwn e)/laben ei)de/nai.

parei/s, if sound, must be construed in one of two ways: (1) as above, which is best: or (2) in Hermann's way, parei\s tou= metri/ou (xrh/|zwn) zw/ein, "negligens vivere modicam partem expetens," scorning to live with desire of a modest span only. Others make it govern

metri/ou, "neglecting the moderate portion," and for the gen. Campbell quotes Plat. Phaedr. 235 E pare/nta tou= ... e)gkwmia/zein. Liddell and Scott give the same citation along with this passage, which they render, "letting go one's hold of moderation," i.e. giving it up. But the active parie/nai never governs a gen. (in the nautical parie/nai tou= podo/s, "to slack away the sheet," the gen. is partitive): and a reference to Plat. Phaedr. 235 E will show that tou= has nothing to do with the inf., but is masc. The passage runs:— ti/na oi)/ei le/gonta w(s xrh\ mh\ e)rw=nti ma=llon h)\ e)rw=nti xari/zesqai, pare/nta tou= me\n to\ fro/nimon e)gkwmia/zein, tou= de\ to\ a)/fron ye/gein, a)nagkai=a gou=n o)/nta, ei)/t' a)/ll' a)/tta e(/cein le/gein; i.e., "if he omitted to praise the sense of the one (tou= me/n", the non-lover), and to blame the folly of the other (tou= de/, the lover).

Hartung explains his ta\n metri/ou parei\s | zwa/n as "neglecting the life of moderate span" (sc. me/rous). Though the phrase to\ me/trion parei/s ("in neglect of due limit") occurs in Plat. Legg. 691C (quoted by Wunder), it seems very doubtful whether parei\s is sound here. The conjecture pe/ra (Schneidewin) is possible, but derives no real support from the fact that para\ to\ kai/rion kai\ to\ me/trion occurs in the schol.'s loose paraphrase. Verrall ingeniously proposes pare\k, which, however, does not occur in Tragedy. Possibly tou= metri/ou proqei\s, "in preference to the moderate portion."
skaiosu/nan, perversity, folly: cp. Ant. 1028 au)qadi/a toi skaio/tht' o)fliska/nei.
fula/sswn, cleaving to: Eur. Ion 735 a)/ci' a)ci/wn gennhto/rwn | h)/qh fula/sseis. Cp. 626, 1180.
e)n e)moi\, me iudice, e)n denoting the tribunal, as O. T. 677 (n.) e)n...toi=sd' i)/sos, "just in their sight": Plat. Legg. 916B diadikaze/sqw de\ e)/n tisi tw=n i)atrw=n.
ai( makrai\ | a(me/rai, the long days (of any given long life),
polla\ me\n dh\ kate/qento are wont (gnomic aor.) to lay up full many things,

lu/pas (gen. sing.) e)ggute/rw somewhat near to grief: i.e. advancing years are apt to accumulate around men a store of cares, regrets, sorrows,—in brief, a store of things which are nearer to pain than to joy; while in the mean time the joys of earlier days have vanished.
lu/pas e)ggute/rw is a sort of euphemism: cp. Ant. 933 oi)/moi, qana/tou tou=t' e)gguta/tw | tou)/pos a)fi=ktai, "this word hath come very nigh unto death"—i.e. threatens imminent death.

The middle katati/qesqai is continually used in Attic of "storing up,"— either literally, as karpou/s, qhsaurou/s, si=ton,—or figuratively, as xa/rin, kle/os, fili/an, e)/xqran. Therefore I would not render kate/qento simply, "set down," as if the meaning were that many things, once "near to joy," are moved by the years, and set down nearer to grief; though this view is tenable. (Cp. Aristoph. Ran. 165
*d. ta\ strw/mat' au)=qis la/mbane.
*c. pri\n kai\ kataqe/sqai;) —Not, "oft (polla\) lay up griefs (lu/pas acc. pl.) nearer (us)."
ou)k a)\n i)/dois o(/pou (sc. e)sti/, as Ai. 890 a)/ndra mh\ leu/ssein o(/pou): cp. Aesch. Eum. 301 to\ xai/rein mh\ maqo/nq' o(/pou frenw=n, "knowing not where to find joy in thy soul."

tou= de/ontos (Reiske) is indicated by the schol. in L, tou= metri/ou, tou= i(kanou=, and is, I think, true. The phrase, o(/tan pe/sh| tis e)s ple/on tou= de/ontos, means, "when one has lapsed into excess of due limit" in respect of prolonged life, i.e. when one has outlived those years which alone are enjoy able, and at which the line of the me/trion me/ros (1212) is drawn.
pe/sh| (cp. pi/ptein ei)s kaka/, etc.) suggests a joyless decline of life, with decay of the faculties.

The vulgate tou= qe/lontos would be gen. of to\ qe/lon (see on 267): "when a man has lapsed into excess of wish," i.e. of wish for prolonged life; not, of self-indulgence; for the whole gist of the passage is that joy is left behind by simply living on: the satiety of jaded appetite (which can befall the young) is not in point here. Assuredly tou= qe/lontos in this context is not Greek. Blaydes, reading tou= sqe/nontos, explains, "when a man has outlived his strength": but could pe/sh| e)s ple/on tou= sq. mean, "live to a point of time beyond to\ sq."?

o( d' e)pi/kouros i)sote/lestos, "and the succourer (i.e., the deliverer from life's troubles) comes at the last to all alike,"— when the doom of Hades has appeared, —"namely, Death at the end." The man who is to attain long life has the same end before him as the man of shorter span,— viz. death; the only difference is that the long-lived man has to go through years of suffering which the other escapes, until death comes to him as a welcome e)pi/kouros. Cp. Ai. 475
ti/ ga\r par' h)=mar h(me/ra te/rpein e)/xei,
prosqei=sa ka)naqei=sa tou= ge katqanei=n; "what joy is there in the sequence of the days,—now threatening, now delaying—death?"

i)sote/lestos might be defended as act., "making an end for all alike," (see examples on 1031,) but is better taken as pass., lit., "accomplished for all alike," i.e. forming the te/los for them. The phrase te/los qana/toio was in the poet's mind, and has blended itself with the image of a personal deliverer. (Cp. on O. T. 866, 1300.)—Whitelaw takes i)sote/lestos (as pass.) with moi=ra, a doom paid alike by all; i.e. all are i)sotelei=s in paying the tribute of their lives to Pluto. This may be right; but the accumulation of epithets on moi=ra becomes somewhat heavy, while e)pi/kouros is left in a long suspense.

a)nume/naios: to death belongs the qrh=nos, not the joyous song of the marriage procession, or the music of the lyre, with dancing: cp. Eur. I. T. 144
qrh/nois e)/gkeimai,
ta=s ou)k eu)mou/sou molpa=s
a)lu/rois e)le/gois. So Aesch. (Suppl. 681) calls war a)/xoron a)ki/qarin dakruogo/non *)/arh: cp. Eur. Tro. 121 a)/tas keladei=n a)xoreu/tous: Aesch. Eum. 331 u(/mnos e)c *)erinu/wn

a)nape/fhne, hath suddenly appeared: Il. 11.173
(oxen) a(/s te le/wn e)fo/bhse molw\n e)n nukto\s a)molgw=|
pa/sas: th=| de/ t' i)h=| a)nafai/netai ai)pu\s o)/leqros: "he turns all to flight, and to one of them sheer death appeareth instantly." Cp. a)naku/ptw.
mh\ fu=nai to\n a(/p. nika=| lo/gon, lit., "Not to be born exceeds every possible estimate,"—of the gain, as compared with the loss, of being born.

o( a(/pas lo/gos is strictly, the whole range of possible appreciation: for the art. with a(/pas cp. Thuc. 6.16 peri\ tw=n a(pa/ntwn a)gwni/zesqai, for the sum of their fortunes: ib. 6 th\n a(/pasan du/namin th=s *sikeli/as, the total power. Rate the gain of being born as high as you please; the gain of not being born is higher. Two other ways are possible:—(1) "Not to be born excels the whole account,"—i.e. excels all the other things (joys, sorrows, of life) that come into account. The drawback to this is the somewhat strained sense of lo/gon. (2) "Stands first on the whole reckoning," (to\n a(/. lo/gon being cogn. acc., or acc. of respect)—i.e. when a balance is struck between the good and the evil of being born. This seems too cold and cautious for the context.

The form hints that Soph. was thinking of the verses of Theognis (425 ff.) which the schol. quotes, without naming that poet, as familiar (to\ lego/menon):—
pa/ntwn me\n mh\ fu=nai e)pixqoni/oisin a)/riston,
mhd' e)sidei=n au)ga\s o)ce/os h)eli/ou,
fu/nta d' o(/pws w)/kista pu/las *)ai+/dao perh=sai
kai\ kei=sqai pollh\n gh=n e)piessa/menon. Diog. Laert. 10. 1. 126 quotes Epicurus as censuring these lines, and remarking that a man who really thought so ought to quit life,—e)n e(toi/mw| ga\r au)tw=| tou=t' e)/stin. Cic. Tusc. 1. 48. 115 Non nasci homini longe optimum esse, proximum autem quam primum mori: where he translates the lines of Eur. (fr. 452)
e)xrh=n ga\r h(ma=s su/llogon poioume/nous
to\n fu/nta qrhnei=n ei)s o(/s' e)/rxetai kaka/:
to\n d' au)= qano/nta kai\ po/nwn pepaume/non
xai/rontas eu)fhmou=ntas e)kpe/mpein do/mwn. Alexis (Midd. Com., 350 B.C.) *mandragorizome/nh 1. 14
ou)kou=n to\ polloi=s tw=n sofw=n ei)rhme/non,
to\ mh\ gene/sqai me\n kra/tisto/n e)st' a)ei/,
e)pa\n ge/nhtai d), w(s ta/xist' e)/xein te/los.
e)pei\ fanh=|, when he has been born, cp. 974: for subj., 395.

The MS. bh=nai kei=qen o(/qen per h(/kei is usu. defended as an instance of "attraction"; but it is harsher than any example that can be produced. Thus in Plat. Crito 45B pollaxou= me
 ga kai\ a)/llose o(/poi a)
 a)fi/kh| a)gaph/sousi/ se, where a)/llose stands for a)/lloqi by attraction to o(/poi, it is not preceded by a verb answering to bh=nai here. Who could say, a)pelqw
 a)/llose (for a)/lloqen) o(/poi a)
 a)fi/kh|, if he meant, "having departed from another place, whithersoever you may have come"? So, here, bh=nai kei=qen o(/qen per h(/kei surely could not mean, "to go to that place whence he has come." bh=nai and h(/kei being thus sharply opposed, each verb requires its proper adverb. I should prefer to read kei=s' o(po/qen, as Blaydes proposed. Cp. Tennyson, "The Coming of Arthur," (of man's destiny,) "From the great deep to the great deep he goes."

polu\ deu/teron: easily the second-best thing: Thuc. 2.97 h( basilei/a (h( tw=n *)odrusw=n)...tw=n...e)n th=| *eu)rw/ph| megi/sth e)ge/neto xrhma/twn proso/dw|,...i)sxu/i+ de\ ma/- xhs kai\ stratou= plh/qei polu\ deute/ra meta\ th\n tw=n *skuqw=n (where "easily second" suits the context better than "decidedly inferior").
polu\ with compar., as Il. 6.158 polu\ fe/rteros, Thuc. 1.35 polu\...e)n plei/oni ai)ti/a|, etc. (but pollw=|...prw=ton Ant. 1347).

w(s eu)=t' a)\n … kama/twn e)/ni; The first point to decide in this vexed passage is:—Does Sophocles here speak of to\ ne/on as a brief space of joy before the troubles of life begin? Or is to\ ne/on itself the period of fierce passions and troubles? The former, I think. Cp. Ai. 552 ff.
(Ajax speaking to his young son)kai/toi se kai\ nu=n tou=to/ ge zhlou=n e)/xw,
o(qou/nek' ou)de\n tw=nd' e)paisqa/nei kakw=n.
e)n tw=| fronei=n ga\r mhde\n h(/distos bi/os,
e(/ws to\ xai/rein kai\ to\ lupei=sqai ma/qh|s.
… te/ws de\ kou/fois pneu/masin bo/skou, ne/an
yuxh\n a)ta/llwn. Tr. 144
to\ ga\r nea/zon e)n toioi=sde bo/sketai
xw/roisin au(tou=, kai/ nin ou) qa/lpos qeou=,
ou)d' o)/mbros, ou)de\ pneuma/twn ou)de\n klonei=,
a)ll' h(donai=s a)/moxqon e)cai/rei bi/on, etc.

parh=|, then, must be taken from pari/hmi, not from pa/reimi, unless we are prepared to write fe/rei, and boldly to alter tis pla/gxqh, etc. For parh=| ("remit,""give up"), cp. Eur. Tro. 645 parei=sa po/qon: Plat. Rep. 460E e)peida
 th
 o)cuta/thn dro/mou a)kmh
 parh=|.

ti/s plaga\ (Herwerden) is the best correction yet proposed for the MS. tis pla/gxqh. Cp. Aesch. Pers. 251 w(s e)n mia=| plhgh=| kate/fqartai polu\s | o)/lbos: Eum. 933 plhgai\ bio/tou. For other interpretations and conjectures see Appendix.
fqo/nos (see cr. n.), the root of so much evil, is more naturally placed before sta/seis, while fo/noi is more fitting as a climax than at the beginning of the list.

kata/mempton, "disparaged," because often spoken of as dreary (cp. o)low=| e)pi\ gh/raos ou)dw=|, gh/rai+ lugrw=|, etc.). Shaksp. As You Like It 2. 3. 41 "When service should in my old limbs lie lame, And unregarded age, in corners thrown."

e)pile/logxe, "next (e)pi-") falls to his lot. Cp. Pind. O. 1. 53 a)ke/rdeia le/logxen qamina\ kakago/ros (Dor. acc. pl.), "sore loss hath oft come on evil-speakers," a gnomic perf., as here. Here, too, we might understand to
 a)/nqrwpon: but the verb seems rather to be intrans., as oft. lagxa/nw: Eur. Hel. 213 ai)w
 dusai/wn tis e)/laxen, e)/laxen: Od. 9.159 e)s de\ e(ka/sthn | e)nne/a la/gxanon ai)=ges, "fell to the portion of each ship": Plat. Legg. 745D kaqierw=sai to\ laxo
 me/ros e(ka/stw| tw=| qew=|. The ellipse of the object here is made easier by the notion which the verb conveys, "'tis the turn of old age next."—Not: "he obtains old age next."

a)krate/s, "weak": Eustath. 790. 92 a)krate\s e)kei=no/s fhsin, ou) to\ a)ko/laston, a)lla to\ poiou=n pa/resin, w(s mh\ e)/xonta to\n ge/ronta kratei=n e(autou=. So Hesych. s.v., quoting Eur. in the lost Aeolus. Cp. Ph. 486 kai/per w)\n a)kra/twr o( tlh/mwn, xwlo/s. Perhaps an Ionic use of a)krath/s, for Hippocr. has it in this sense (Aph. 1247): in Attic prose it always means "without control" over passion or desire (impotens). For a)/filon placed after gh=ras, cp. Ph. 392 n.
kaka\ kakw=n, "ills of ills," ="worst of ills": O. T. 465 a)/rrht' a)rrh/twn (n.).
cunoikei=: cp. 1134.

bo/reios a)kta\, a shore exposed to the north wind, and so lashed by the waves (kumatoplh\c) which that wind raises xeimeri/a, in the stormy season. Cp. Ant. 592 sto/nw| bre/mousin a)ntiplh=ges a)ktai/ (in a like comparison). So Tr. 112 polla\ ga\r w(/st' a)ka/mantos h)\ no/tou h)\ bore/a tis | ku/mat' … i)/doi (of the troubles of Heracles).

kat' a)/kras, "utterly," in the sense of "violently": perh. with a reminiscence of Od. 5.313 (quoted by Campbell)w(s a)/ra min ei)po/nt' e)/lasen me/ga ku=ma kat' a)/krhs, "the great wave smote down on him" (Odysseus on his raft): in Ant. 201 prh=sai kat' a)/kras (of destroying a city).
kumatoa_gei=s, breaking like billows.
Compare this poet. indication of the four points of the compass with the prose phraseology in Xen. Anab. 3.5.15, pro\s e(/w, pro\s e(spe/ran, pro\s meshmbri/an, pro\s a)/rkton.
a)na\ me/ssan a)kti=n)="in the region of the noon-tide ray," i.e. these waves of trouble are supposed to be driven by a south wind (cp. Tr. 112, n. on 1240).

*(pipa=n. Arist. Meteor. 1.13 (Berl. ed. 350 b 6) u(p' au)th
 de\ th
 a)/rkton u(pe th=s e)sxa/ths *skuqi/as ai( kalou/menai *(pi=pai, peri\ w(=n tou= mege/qous li/an ei)si
 oi( lego/menoi lo/goi muqw/deis. It is fortunate that this passage is extant, showing, as I think it does beyond all reasonable doubt, that Soph. here named the Rhipaean mountains, "beyond utmost Scythia," as representing the North. Aristotle's words prove that the name *(pi=pai for these mountains was thoroughly familiar. Cp. Alcman of Sparta (660 B.C.) fr. 51 (Bergk), *(pi/pas, o)/ros e)/nqeon (a)nqe/on Lobeck) u(/la|, | *nukto\s melai/nas ste/rnon. Hellanicus (circ. 450 B.C.) fr. 96 (Müller) tou\s de\ *(uperbore/ous u(peta\ *(ri/paia o)/rh oi)kei=n i(storei=. Damastes of Sigeum (his younger contemporary) fr. 1 a)/nw d' *)arimaspw=n ta\ *(pi/paia o)/rh, e)c w)=n to
 bore/an pnei=n, xio/na d' au)ta\ mh/pote e)llei/pein: u(pe de\ ta\ o)/rh tau=ta *(uperbore/ous kaqh/kein ei)s th
 e(te/ran qa/lassan. For the age of Sophocles, these mountains belonged wholly to the region of myth, and so were all the more suitable for his purpose here. The Roman poets, too, used the "Rhipaei montes" to denote the uttermost North (Verg. Geo. 1. 240, etc.). The name *(ri=pai was only r(ipai/,—the "blasts" of Boreas coming thence.
e)nnuxia=n, wrapped in gloom and storm: cp. 1558.

Others, not taking r(ipa=n as a name, render: (1) "From the nocturnal blasts,"— but this would not sufficiently indicate the north. (2) "From the vibrating starrays of night," like El. 105 pamfeggei=s a)/strwn | r(ipa/s. But there would be no point in saying that troubles come on Oedipus from the West, the East, the South, and—the stars. There is, indeed, a secondary contrast between the brightness of the South and the gloom of the North; but the primary contrast is between the regions.

div2.head: 1249-1555: Fourth episode
div2.p: Fourth e)peiso/dion, divided by a kommo/s (1447—1499). Polyneices is dismissed with his father's curse. Hardly has he departed, when thunder is heard (1456). Theseus is summoned, and receives the last injunctions of Oedipus, who knows that his hour has come. Then Oedipus, followed by his daughters and by Theseus, leads the way to the place where he is destined to pass out of life (1555).

div3.p: kai\ mh\n, introducing the new comer (549):
h(mi=n ethic dat. (81).

a)ndrw=n ge mou=nos (cp. 875), "with no escort at least," in contrast to Creon, 722 a)=sson e)/rxetai | *kre/wn o(/d' h(mi=n ou)k a)/neu pompw=n, pa/ter. Oedipus dreaded that his son, like Creon, would make an attempt to carry him off by violence: cp. 1206 ei)/per kei=nos w(=d' e)leu/setai, | mhdei\s kratei/tw etc.: and Antigone hastens to assure him at once that Polyneices comes otherwise than as Creon came. He is alone, and in tears. For the gen. cp. Ai. 511 sou=...mo/nos.—Others: —(1) "he, and no one else": this seems somewhat weak. (2) "weeping as no man weeps" (but only women):—a modern view of weeping: it is enough to remember Achilles and Aeneas.

a)stakti\ has i_ in 1646. The general rule (Blomfield glossar. Aesch. PV 216) is that such adverbs, when from nouns in h or a, end in ei (as au)toboei/): when from nouns in os, in i, which is more often short, but sometimes long. For i^ cp. e)gerti/ (Ant. 413), newsti/ (El. 1049), skuqisti/ (fr. 429), a)wri/ (Aristoph. Eccl. 741), a)ndristi/ (ib. 149), dwristi/ (Eq. 989), the Homeric a)moghti/, megalwsti/, etc. For i_, a)noimwkti/ (Ai. 1227), a)nidrwti/ (Il. 15.228), a)spoudi/ (8. 512), a)nwisti/ (Od. 4.92), etc.
a)stakti\, not sta/gdhn (stillatim): Plat. Phaedo 117C e)mou= ge...a)stakti\ e)xw/rei ta\ da/krua. So Eur. I. T. 1242 a)sta/ktwn...u(da/twn, and Apoll. Rh. 3. 804 a)stage/s.
w(=de=deu=ro: cp. 1286, O. T. 7.
katei/xomen gnw/mh|, apprehended: Plat. Men. 72 D ou) me/ntoi w(s bou/lomai/ ge/ pw kate/xw to\ e)rwtw/menon.

dra/sw, probably aor. subj. (cp. 478), though it might be fut.: cp. Tr. 973 ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ mh/somai; oi)/moi. So Eur. Phoen. 1310 oi)/moi, ti/ dra/sw; po/ter' e)mauto\n h)\ po/lin | ste/nw dakru/sas, etc. The Phoenissae being the earlier play, it is possible that Soph. had it in mind, but it is quite as likely that the coincidence is accidental: it is at any rate trivial.

e)nqa/d' e)kbeblhme/non, in exile here: Plat. Gorg. 468D ei)/ tis a)poktei/nei tina\ h)\ e)kba/llei e)k po/lews h)\ a)fairei=tai xrh/mata (cp. e)kpi/ptein, of being exiled). We might understand, "shipwrecked here," e)kba/llw being regularly used of casting ashore; but I prefer the simpler version.
su\n: cp. El. 191 a)eikei= su\n stola=|.
th=s: see on 747.

ge/rwn … pi/nos: Od. 22.184 sa/kos eu)ru\ ge/ron, pepalagme/non a)/zh| (stained with rust): Theocr. 7. 17 a)mfi\ de/ oi( sth/qessi ge/rwn e)sfi/ggeto pe/plos (cp. anus charta, Catull. 68. 46). So Aristoph. Lys. 1207 a)/rtos...neani/as
sugkatw/|khken, has made an abiding home, emphatic perf., cp. 186 te/trofen (n.), 1004.
pleura\n marai/nwn can mean only that the squalor of the raiment is unwholesome for the body to which it clings. Cp. Aesch. PV 596 no/son..
div3.l: ... a)\ marai/nei me. We cannot render merely, "marring the comeliness of thy form" (as Ellendt, de sordibus corpus dehonestantibus).
div3.p: krati\ o)mmatosterei=, locative dat.: cp. on 313.

a)kte/nistos: Her. 7.208 (the Lacedaemonians before Thermopylae) tou\s me\n dh\ w(/ra gumnazome/nous tw=n a)ndrw=n, tou\s de\ ta\s ko/mas ktenizome/nous. The ktei/s was usu. of boxwood, ivory, or metal.
a)/|ssetai: Il. 6.510 a)mfi\ de\ xai=tai | w)/mois a)i+/ssontai.
a)delfa\ … tou/toisin: but Ant. 192 a)delfa\ tw=nde. The dat. occurs elsewhere (as Plat. Tim. 67E), but the gen. is much commoner.
