forei= is taken by some as "obtains by begging"; but a conjecture to that effect would be hardly in place. Obviously it means simply "carries," and alludes to a wallet (ph/ra) carried by Oed., for the reception of the spanista\ dwrh/mata (4). This was a part of the conventional outfit for the wandering beggar ; so, when Athena turned Odysseus into that guise, she gave him
skh=ptron kai\ a)eike/a ph/rhn,
pukna\ r(wgale/hn: e)n de\ stro/fos h)=en a)orth/r: "a staff, and a mean, much-tattered wallet; and therewith was a cord to hang it" (Od. 13.437).
"And I testify that I have come to be, have proved myself, most vile in regard to thy maintenance":
h(/kein as 1177 e)/xqiston...h(/kei (n.). (Better thus than, "I, who have come hither, am," etc.)
trof. tai=s sai=sin, dat. of respect.
mh\ )c a)/llwn: El. 1225 *h*l. w)= fqe/gm), a)fi/kou; *o*r. mhke/t' a)/lloqen pu/qh|.
a)lla\ … ga\r, "but since": see on 988.
*zhni\ su/nqakos qro/nwn, a sharer with Zeus on his throne: cp. on 1382. Where we should say, "an attribute" of godhead, the Greeks often use the image of assessor.

*ai)dw\s, here compassion; see on 237. *ai)dw/s, as well as *)/eleos, had an altar at Athens (see Paus. 1.17.1, cited on 260). Shaksp. Merch. 4. 1. 193 (mercy): "It is enthroned in the hearts of kings, It is an attribute to God Himself; And earthly power doth then show likest God's, When mercy seasons justice."
e)p' e)/rgois pa=si, in all deeds: cp. Il. 4.178 ai)/q' ou(/tws e)pi\ pa=si xo/lon tele/sei' *)agame/mnwn, "in all cases" (as in this).

kai\ pro\s soi/, "nigh to thee also." In this sense pro/s is usu. said of places (see 10), very seldom of persons (except in such phrases as a(\ pro\s toi=s qesmoqe/tais e)/lege, before their tribunal, Dem. or. 20 § 98). In Ant. 1188 kli/nomai
div3.l: ...pro\s dmwai=si="sink into their arms": in Ai. 95 e)/bayas e)/gxos eu)= pro\s *)argei/wn stratw=|=on them; and so ib. 97 pro\s *)atrei/daisin.

div3.p: tw=n ga\r h(marthme/nwn: "there are remedies for the faults committed (i.e. if Oed. will return to Thebes with Polyneices), while there is no possibility of adding to them." In this appeal for pardon, the "faults" most naturally mean those committed by the speaker; but the vague phrase which he has chosen permits the thought that there have been errors on both sides.

prosfora\ implies at once a confession and an assurance: the son has behaved as ill as possible; he could not, even if he would, add to his offence. Hartung's a)nafora/ could not mean what he intends, "there is no possibility of recalling the past," but only, "there is no possibility of referring the blame elsewhere,"—of putting it on other shoulders.
ti/ siga=|s; An anxious pause, while Oed. remains silent: cp. 315, 318.

mh/ m' a)postrafh=|s: Xen. Cyr. 5.5.36 h)= kai\ filh/sw se; *ei) su\ bou/lei, e)/fh. *kai\ ou)k a)postre/yei me w(/sper a)/rti; But the place from which one turns is put in the gen., as O. T. 431 oi)/kwn tw=nd' a)postrafei/s.
a)tima/sas, of rejecting a suppliant, cp. 49, 286.

w)= spe/rmat): for the plur. cp. 600. The v.l. spe/rma ta)ndro\s might be defended by Tr. 1147 ka/lei to\ pa=n moi spe/rma sw=n o(maimo/nwn (cp. ib. 304); but the sing., when it refers to more than one person, is usu. rather "race," like spe/rma *pelopidw=n Aesch. Cho. 503. Cp. 330.

e)mai\ d'. When different relationships of the same person are expressed, the second is introduced by de/, without a preceding me/n: Aesch. Pers. 151 mh/thr basile/ws, | basi/leia d' e)mh/ Eur. Med. 970 patro\s ne/an gunai=ka, despo/tin d' e)mh/n: Her. 7.10 patri\ tw=| sw=|, a)delfew=| de\ e)mw=|: 8. 54 *)aqhnai/wn tou\s fuga/das, e(wutw=| de\ e(pome/nous.

a)ll' u(mei=s ge, "Ye at least" (since I have failed): cp. El. 411 sugge/nesqe/ g' a)lla\ nu=n (now, at least): ib. 415 le/g' a)lla\ tou=to (this, at least): ib. 1013 nou=n sxe\s a)lla\ tw=| xro/nw| pote/: Tr. 320 ei)/p), w)= ta/lain), a)ll' h(mi/n: Dem. or. 3 § 33 e)a\n ou)=n a)lla\ nu=n g' e)/ti...e)qelh/shte.

duspro/soiston=xalepo\n prosfe/resqai (midd.), hard for one to hold intercourse with. Cp. Plat. Lys. 223 B e)do/koun h(mi=n...a)/poroi ei)=nai prosfe/resqai, they "seemed to us hard to deal with." The epithet refers to his sullen silence, and is defined by a)prosh/goron. In Eur. I. A. 345 duspro/sitos e)/sw te klh/|qrwn spa/nios, Thuc. 1.130 duspro/sodon... au(to\n parei=xe, the sense is "hard of access," i.e. living in a haughty seclusion. Cp. Tr. 1093 le/ont), a)/platon qre/mma ka)prosh/goron (the Nemean lion).
sto/ma: for the periphrasis cp. 603.

w(s mh/ m' a)/timon … ou(/tws a)fh=| me. The objection to a)fh=| ge is that a second ge (though possible, see on 387) is here weak after qeou= ge. As to its place after a)fh=|, that is paralleled by 1409. On the other hand a repeated me, in the utterance of impassioned entreaty, may be defended by 1407 ff. mh/ toi/ me... mh/ m' a)tima/shte/ ge: cp. Tr. 218 i)dou/ m' a)natara/ssei | eu)oi= m' o( kisso/s: Eur. Phoen. 497
e)moi\ me/n, ei) kai\ mh\ kaq' *(ellh/nwn xqo/na
teqra/mmeq', a)ll' ou)=n cuneta/ moi dokei=s le/gein.

Elmsley's conjecture ou(/tws a)fih=|, which Hartung adopts, is unmetrical. i(/hmi has i^ always in pres. subj. and opt.: Il. 13.234 meqi/h|si ma/xesqai: Hom. Hymn. 4.152 proi/h| be/lea stono/enta: Theogn. 94 glw=ssan i(h=|si kakh/n: Od. 2.185 w(=d' a)niei/hs. In Aristoph. Lys. 157 ti/ d); h)\n a)fi/wsin a)/ndres h(ma=s, w)= me/le (so the MSS.), Kuster brought in a gratuitous error by writing a)fi/ws), which Dindorf has adopted. (As Chandler says, a)fi/wsi is a false accent for a)fiw=si. Accent., 2nd ed. § 794, cp. § 820.) In the pres. indic., imper., inf., and part., i_ is normal, but Homeric verse usually has i^ in thesis (as when i(/entai ends a line); and the part. i(ei/s (i_ in Aristoph. Eq. 522) occurs with i^ in Trag. (Aesch. Th. 493, etc.). Cp. El. 131 n.
a)fh=tai (Blaydes) would mean "let go hold of" (with gen., O. T. 1521 te/knwn d' a)fou=), not "dismiss."
tou= qeou= ge, Poseidon (1158): ge emphasises the whole phrase, to which o)/nta would usu. be added (cp. 83): cp. O. T. 929 o)lbi/a … | ge/noit;, e)kei/nou g' ou)=sa pantelh\s da/mar.
prosta/thn: cp. on 1171.
ou(/tws, so contemptuously: cp. O. T. 256, Ant. 315.
xrei/a|, a causal (rather than modal) dat., cp. 333 po/qoisi: Ph. 162 forbh=s xrei/a| | sti/bon o)gmeu/ei.

ta\ polla\ r(h/mata, "the many words" (of any given long speech), with gnomic aor., as 1214 ai( makrai\ | a(me/rai kate/qento. Distinguish 87 ta\ poll' e)kei=na kaka/, "those many," in a definite allusion. (ta\ polla\ must not be taken separately as adv., "oft.")

h)\ te/ryanta/ ti etc.: "by giving some pleasure,—or by some utterance of indignation, or of pity." Not, "by exciting some indignation or some pity." Neither dusxerai/nein nor katoikti/zein is ever causative in classical Greek. In Eur. I. A. 686 katw|kti/sqhn is not, "I was moved to pity," but "I bewailed myself," the pass. aor. in midd. sense, as often. The emotion of the speaker will awaken a response in the hearer.
a)fwnh/tois in act. sense: so a)nau/datos (Tr. 968), a)/fqegktos (Aesch. Eum. 245); cp. a)fo/bhtos, "fearless," O. T. 885: and n. above on 1031.
e)chgei=, praecipis (but otherwise in 1520). Cp. Ai. 320 e)chgei=t), "he ever taught" (Tecmessa recalling the utterances of Ajax).

poiou/menos a)|rwgo/n, "making my helper," i.e. appealing to his name: cp. O. T. 240 (to
 a)/ndra) koino
 poei=sqai, "make him partner": Theognis 113 mh/pote to
 kako
 a)/ndra fi/lon poiei=sqai e(tai=ron.
w(=de with molei=n (epex. inf.), "that I should come hither": cp. 1251.
a)ne/sthsen: cp. 276.
le/cai t' a)kou=sai/ t): see on 190.
e)co/dw|: see 1165.
boulh/somai, "I shall wish" (i.e. until the hoped-for fulfilment of the wish has been attained). So O. T. 1077 (where see n.), Ai. 681, etc.
qe/lw de\ le/cai ( tau=ta ) a(\ h)=lqon, those things for which I came; cognate acc. of errand, as O. T. 1005 tou=t' a)fiko/mhn: Plat. Prot. 310E au)ta\ tau=ta kai\ nu=n h(/kw. See n. on O. T. 788.
pana/rxois is fitting, since each brother claimed the sole power (373).

gerai/teros, (Jacobs and Nauck,) for geraite/ra|, has been received by several edd., including Dindorf and Wecklein. The common idiom doubtless favours it; yet the phrase, "brought into being by the elder birth," is surely intelligible as a poetical fusion of gonh=| prote/ra| pefukw/s with gerai/teros pefukw/s.

In Attic prose the comparative of geraio/s always implies the contrast between youth and a more advanced period of life (Thuc. 6.18 a(/ma ne/oi geraite/rois bouleu/ontes). The use in the text, to denote merely priority of birth (Attic presbu/teros), is Ionic, as Her. 6.52 a)mfo/tera ta\ paidi/a h(gh/sasqai basile/as, tima=n de\ ma=llon to\n gerai/teron: and poetical, as Theocr. 15. 139 o( gerai/tatos ei)/kati pai/dwn.
a)nq' w(=n, "wherefore": cp. O. T. 264 n.—In *)eteoklh=s the o might be either long or short (cp. on 1): elsewhere Soph. has the name only in Ant. 23, 194 (*)eteokle/a beginning both verses).
lo/gw|, in an argument upon the claim, before a competent tribunal.
ei)s e)/legxon: cp. 835 ta/x' ei)s ba/sanon ei)= xerw=n.

xeiro\s ou)d' e)/rgou is a species of hendiadys,—the practical test of single combat (cp. Ai. 814 ta/xos ga\r e)/rgou kai\ podw=n a(/m' e(/yetai). We cannot distinguish xeiro/s, as the duel, from e)/rgou, as a trial of strength between adherents, since Thebes was with Eteocles. Hermann's ou)d) (for the MS. ou)/t)), before e)/rgou, is necessary, unless we suppose an ou)/te understood before xeiro/s: cp. on O. T. 236 ff.

ma/lista me
 with le/gw, not with th
 sh
 *)er.: "and of these things I hold (as the most probable account) that the curse on thy race is the cause;— then from seers also I hear in this sense." Cp. El. 932
oi)=mai ma/list' e)/gwge tou= teqnhko/tos
mnhmei=) *)ore/stou tau=ta prosqei=nai/ tina, "I think it most likely that...": Ph. 617 oi)/oito me
 ma/lisq' e(kou/sion labw/n, "he thought it most likely that he (could bring him) without compulsion." The me/n after ma/lista opposes this view, the most likely, to other views (not stated) which are possible, though less probable: e)/peita is not opposed to me/n, but introduces the fact which confirms his conjecture.

th
 sh
 *)erinu
, the Fury who pursues thee and thy race, the family curse, 369 th
 pa/lai ge/nous fqora/n (cp. 965), as Oed. himself called his sons' strife peprwme/nhn (421). Not, "thy curse on thy sons": Polyneices knows nothing of the imprecation uttered at 421 ff. It is a distinctive point in the Sophoclean treatment of the story that the curse of Oed. on his sons comes after the outbreak of war between them, not before it, as with Aesch. and Eur.: see Introd.

ma/ntewn, at Argos, probably alluding to Amphiaraus (1313). This Argive utterance as to the cause of the brothers' strife may be conceived as a part of the oracles noticed at 1331, which also concerned the issue.

The ga\r seems meant to introduce a further account of what the ma/nteis at Argos had said; but no such explanation is given. ga\r cannot be explained, at this point in the story, as the mere preface to narrative (O. T. 277); that should have stood in 1292. Yet I would not write d' a)/r'. The hearers are left to understand that he found the seers among his new allies.
to\ *dwriko/n, simply as being in the *dwri/di na/sw| *pe/lopos (see on 695); cp. on 378 (proslamba/nei).

gh=s *)api/as, a name for the Peloponnesus (Aesch. Ag. 256), from the mythical king *)=apis, who crossed over from Naupactus, "before Pelops had come to Olympia," as Paus. says, and purged the land of monsters. The Sicyon myth made him son of Telchin (Paus. 2.5.7); Aesch. calls him i)atro/mantis pai=s *)apo/llwnos (Suppl. 263). Distinguish 1685 a)pi/an ga=n, "a far land" (a)po/).

teti/mhntai: for the pf., expressing fixed repute, cp. on 186, 1004: Thuc. 2.45 fqo/nos ga\r toi=s zw=si pro\s to\ a)nti/palon, to\ de\ mh\ e)mpodw\n a)nantagwni/stw| eu)noi/a| teti/mhtai, is in permanent honour.

dori/: see on 620. This was the ordinary form, i.e. the form used in prose, as by Thuc. In the iambic verse of tragedy it is only once necessary (Eur. Hec. 5 ki/ndunos e)/sxe dori\ pesei=n *(ellhnikw=|). In lyrics it was freely used by Aesch. and Eur. But neither the iambics nor the lyrics of Soph. anywhere require it, while they thrice require do/rei. The question, then, is: Are we to assume that Soph. never used dori/? As the MSS. give that form even where do/rei is necessary, their evidence is indecisive. On general grounds it is more probable that Soph. should have admitted both forms. This was Hermann's view; among recent editors, Bellermann supports it.

to\n e(pta/logxon … sto/lon, "the expedition with seven bodies of spearmen"; i.e. the compound adj. is equivalent to two separate epithets, "sevenfold," and "armed with spears": cp. on 17 pukno/pteroi. The boldness of the phrase consists in the collective sing. sto/lon being used instead of a plur. like ta/ceis (1311). Not, "under the seven spears of seven leaders," as if the lo/gxh of each leader was an ensign. Cp. on 1311. The art. to/n, because the expedition is no longer a project, but a fact (1312).

pandi/kws, as asserting just claims in fair fight. The device on the shield of the Aeschylean Polyneices is *di/kh leading a man in golden armour, with the words,
kata/cw d' a)/ndra to/nde, kai\ po/lin
e(/cei patrw/|wn dwma/twn t' e)pistrofa/s (Theb. 647).
tou\s ta/d' e)kpr., Eteocles: for pl., cp. 148.
au)to/s t): cp. 462. The genitives are simply subjective, "prayers of mine and of theirs," i.e. made by us (cp. 1326), rather than gen. of connection, "about myself," etc.

ta/cesin … lo/gxais. The "allies" are the chieftains. They have marched "with their seven hosts and their seven spears," because each, carrying his spear, rides at the head of his own body of spearmen. Polyneices, who is one of the seven, thinks of himself for the moment as present with his comrades in arms.

dorussou=s=dorusso/os, a word used also by Hes. and Aesch. (not Hom.), and usu. rendered "spear-brandishing." But this seems to confuse seu/w with sei/w. On the analogy of the Homeric laosso/os, "urging on the host" (epith. of Ares etc.), and the Pindaric i(pposo/as, "steed-urging,"

dorusso/os should mean rather "spearhurling" (cp. Il. 11.147 o(/lmon d' w(\s e)/sseue kuli/ndesqai, sent him rolling like a ball of stone). "Charging with the spear" is less suitable, since the epic do/ru is rather a missile than a cavalry-lance.

*)amfia/rews (-uu-, cp. on 1), son of Oecles, "at once the Achilles and the Calchas of the war" (as Schneidewin says), is the most pathetic figure of the legend. He foresees the issue; but his wife Eriphylè, the sister of Adrastus, persuades him to go (having been bribed by Polyneices with Harmonia's necklace); and when all the chiefs save Adrastus have fallen, the Theban soil opens, and swallows up Amphiaraus and his chariot: El. 837: Pind. Nem. 9.24: 10. 8. Cp. Ol. 6. 15
(Adrastus speaking) poqe/w stratia=s o)fqalmo\n e)ma=s,
a)mfo/teron ma/ntin t' a)gaqo\n kai\ douri\ ma/rnasqai. Aesch. makes him the type of ill-fated virtue (Theb. 597). In contrast with the u(/bris of the other chiefs, his swfrosu/nh is marked by the absence of any device (sh=ma) on his shield (ib. 591, Eur. Phoen. 1112 a)/shm' o(/pla). The same Greek feeling for a tragic prescience is seen in the story so beautifully told by Herod. (9. 16) of the Persian guest at the banquet of Attagīnus.

ta\ prw=ta me
 … prw=ta de/: the art. is to be repeated with the second clause. For the epanaphora cp. 5: Il. 1.258 oi(\ peri\ me
 boulh
 *danaw=n, peri\ d' e)ste\ ma/xesqai.

oi)wnw=n o(doi=s, in respect to the paths of birds of omen, i.e. in applying the rules of augury to their flights. Cp. Il. 12.237
tu/nh d' oi)wnoi=si tanupteru/gessi keleu/eis
pei/qesqai: tw=n ou)/ ti metatre/pw ou)d' a)legi/zw,
ei)/t' e)pi\ deci/) i)/wsi, etc. Quite different is O. T. 311 a)/llhn mantikh=s...o(do/n, some other way of divination (as distinct from augury).

The thirteen lines (1313— 1325) which contain the list of chiefs illustrate the poet's tact. There is no pomp of description, no superfluous detail; but the three most interesting points are lightly touched,—the character of Amphiaraus, the character of Capaneus, and the parentage of Parthenopaeus. The dramatic purpose is to dignify the strife, and to heighten the terror of the father's curse, which falls not only on the guilty son, but on his allies (cp. 1400).

The list agrees in names, though not in order, with Aesch. Th. 377—652, where each name is associated with one of the seven gates of Thebes, as probably in the epic Thebaid. (Cp. Ant. 141 ff., where the seven champions appear as having been slain and spoiled,—the special doom of Amphiaraus being ignored.) Eur. Phoen. 1104—1188 also has this list, except that Eteoclus is omitted, and Adrastus (the one survivor) substituted. In his Supplices Eteoclus and Adrastus are both included, while either Hippomedon or Amphiaraus seems to be omitted.
*tudeu/s: cp. Aesch. Th. 377 ff.: Eur. Phoen. 1120 ff., Suppl. 901 ff.
*)ete/oklos: Aesch. Th. 457 ff.: Eur. Suppl. 872 ff.
*(ippome/dont): Aesch. Th. 486 ff.: Eur. Phoen. 1113 ff.

kataskafh=| … dh|w/sein puri/= "to destroy it with fire, in such a manner as to raze it to the ground": puri/ is instrum. dat., and coheres closely with the verb; kataskafh=| is dat. of manner, but with proleptic force, like O. T. 51 a)ll' a)sfalei/a| th/nd' a)no/rqwson po/lin, =w(/ste a)sfalh= ei)=nai.

*kapaneu\s is the giant in whom the u(/bris of the assailants takes its most daring and impious form, the Goliath or Mezentius of the story: cp. Ant. 133, Aesch. Th. 422 ff. In Ph. 1128 Eur. follows this conception; but in Suppl. 861 ff. he presents Capaneus in a totally new light, as no less modest than trusty. That whole passage of the Supplices,—in which Eur. seeks to individualise some of these champions more closely,—is curious and characteristic.
*parqenopai=os, son of Atalanta by Meilanion, her vanquisher in the foot-race. Another version made Ares the father.
e)pw/numos th=s pro/sqen a)dmh/ths, "so named after her who before was a virgin," xro/nw| mhtro\s loxeuqei/s, "having been born of her when at last she became a mother."

xro/nw| (437), after her long virginity. The gen. mhtro/s as O. T. 1082 th=s ga\r pe/fuka mhtro/s. In Aesch. Th. 536 this hero has ou)/ ti parqe/nwn e)pw/numon | fro/nhma: cp. Eur. Phoen. 1106 o( th=s kunagou=.
e)gw\ de\ so/s: "And I, thy son,—or (the corrective kai/), if not really thy son,...thine at least in name."

po/tmou: for gen., cp. last n. He does not mean, "thou art not to blame for my tainted birth," but,—"disowned by thee, I have no sire but evil Destiny." For ge/ toi cp. O. T. 1171 kei/nou ge/ toi dh\ pai=s e)klh/|zeq'.

a)nti\ pai/dwn ... i(keteu/omen here=pro\s pai/dwn, "by them," i.e. "as you love them," a very rare use of a)nti/, but one which comes easily from its ordinary sense, "in return for," "as an equivalent for." It would be as much as their lives are worth to refuse the prayer. (In El. 537 a)nt' a)delfou= is sometimes taken as="for his sake," but this is by no means certain.)

mh=nin ...ei)kaqei=n, concede thy wrath to me, i.e. remit it: the same constr. (though not in the same application) as Ph. 464
o(phni/k' a)\n qeo\s
plou=n h(mi\n ei)/kh|, concede a voyage to us. This is better than to make mh=nin acc. of respect.— For the form of ei)k., cp. 862.
tou)mou= after tw=|d' a)ndri\, as O. T. 533 ta\s e)ma/s followed by tou=de ta)ndro/s: cp. on 6.

Since pa/tras must clearly go with both verbs, it would seem that, aided by e)ce/wse, the poet has used a)pesu/lhsen with the constr. of a)peste/rhsen. Elsewhere we find only a)posula=n ti/ tinos, to strip a thing from a man (cp. 922), or a)posula=n tina/ ti, to strip a man of a thing. We cannot here take pa/tras as gen. of the person robbed, ("snatched me from my country,") since e)ce/wse implies that the expeller is within the country. Nor could we well read pa/tran ("took my country from me").

xrhsthri/wn. The oracle brought to Oed. by Ismene (389) had been received at Thebes (apparently) before the expulsion of Polyneices, since Oed. complains that the two brothers did not avail themselves of it in order to recall him (418). It was to the effect that the welfare of Thebes depended on Oedipus. If Polyneices means the same oracle here, oi(=s a)\n will be Thebes, on the one hand, and any foreign foe of Thebes on the other. But the reference here is rather to a special oracle concerning the war between the brothers, which Polyneices has heard from the ma/nteis at Argos (cp. 1300).

prosqh=|: join thyself: cp. [Dem.] or. 11 § 6 (speaking of the Persian king's power in the Peloponnesian war) o(pote/rois pro/sqoito (the "Attic" alternative for prosqei=to, cp. Buttmann Gr. § 107, Obs. 3), tou/tous e)poi/ei kratei=n tw=n e(te/rwn. So in the genuine Dem. or. 6 § 12 ei) d' e)kei/nois prosqei=to, and in Thuc. (3. 11; 6. 80; 8. 48, 87) etc. — Cp. n. on 404.
e)/fask): sc. ta\ xrhsth/ria.

krhnw=n: so Ant. 844 Antigone cries,
i)w/, *dirkai=ai krh=nai *qh/bas t'
eu)arma/tou a)/lsos. So Ajax at Troy, when dying, invokes krh=nai/ te potamoi/ q' oi(/de along with the Sun-god. Orestes, returning to Argos, brings an offering to the Inachus (Aesch. Cho. 6). Wecklein quotes an inscription from Rangabé Antiqu. Hellen. nr. 2447 kai\ [o)mnu/w] h)/rwas kai\ h(rwa/ssas kai\ kra/nas kai\ potamou\s kai\ qeou\s pa/ntas kai\ pa/sas. The word krhnw=n is certainly sound; the peculiarity is that, instead of a general word like e)gxwri/wn, we have o(mogni/wn, which strictly suits qew=n only. o(mo/gnioi qeoi/=gods which belong to (protect) the same ge/nos, here, the gods of the Labdacid ge/nos (369): cp. 756. The variant pro\s qew=n would make the verse more impassioned, but would also make the limited fitness of o(mogni/wn more felt; L's kai\ is better.
piqe/sqai: cp. 1181.

The v.l. ptwxo\s for ce/nos doubtless arose from a feeling that the word repeated should be that which immediately preceded me/n (cp. on 5): but ptwxoi\ kai\ ce/noi forms one notion, in which ce/noi is the more important element.

qwpeu/ontes, the word used by Creon in taunting Oed. (1003), is unpleasant, but Polyneices means it to be so; his aim is to move Oedipus to loathing of his present lot. Quintil. 6. 2. 24 Haec est illa quae dei/nwsis vocatur, rebus indignis asperis invidiosis addens vim oratio (cp. Ar. Rhet. 2. 21 § 10 e)n sxetliasmw=| kai\ deinw/sei). To the Athenian e)leu/qeros the very essence of a free man's dignity was au)ta/rkeia: hence it is a trait of the megalo/yuxos (Ar. Eth. N. 4. 8), pro\s a)/llon mh\ du/nasqai zh=n a)ll' h)\ pro\s fe/lon: douliko\n ga/r: where the saving clause would apply to Oedipus.
dai/mon): cp. 76.

e)ceilhxo/tes is clearly right; cp. Eur. fr. 115, Ar. Th. 1070
ti/ pot' *)androme/da peri/alla kakw=n
me/ros e)ce/laxon; Soph. has the verb El. 760 patrw/|as tu/mbon e)kla/xh| xqono/s.

e)ceilhfo/tes was defended by Herm. as "having received from Eteocles,"—the dispenser of our fortunes:— which seems far-fetched. In Ph. 1429 a)ristei=) e)klabw\n strateu/matos (L e)kbalw/n), the genit. ("out of") interprets the compound.
ta/las, nom. for voc., as 753: cp. on 185.

a(bru/neti, not merely, "lives softly," but "waxes proud." In Attic the midd. and pass. a(bru/nomai seems always to have this further sense, like kallu/nomai, lampru/nomai, semnu/nomai: e.g. Plat. Apol. 20 C e)kalluno/mhn te kai\ h(bruno/mhn a)/n, ei) h)pista/mhn tau=ta. The act., however, approaches the simpler sense in Aesch. Ag. 918 mh\ gunaiko\s e)n tro/pois e)me\ | a(/brune, "make me luxurious."

freni/, wish, purpose: cp. 1182: Ant. 993 ou)/koun pa/ros ge sh=s a)pesta/toun freno/s. The decisive objection to the conjecture xeri/ is that the assistance meant by cumparasth/sei is moral, and freni/ marks this. The proposed reading would make the verb too suggestive of the doro\s...e)n xeimw=ni...parasta/ths (Ant. 670).
o)/gkw|, "trouble," see on 1162.
su\n: cp. 1602 taxei=...su\n xro/nw|.
diaskedw=, scatter his power to the winds: cp. 620.
sth/sw … sth/sw d': for the omission of me/n, cp. Ant. 806 ff. n.
a)/gwn: cp. on 910.

ou)de\ swqh=nai, not even to return alive from the expedition (much less conquer): a freq. Attic sense of sw/zomai, as Xen. Anab. 3.1.6 o( *cenofw=n e)ph/reto to
 *)apo/llw ti/ni a)
 qew=n qu/wn...a)/rista e)/lqoi th
 o(do
 h(
 e)pinoei=, kai\ kalw=s pra/cas swqei/h.
tou= pe/myantos, Theseus, who, on leaving the scene at 1210, brought, or sent, word to the suppliant. Cp. 298.
ei)pw\n … e)/kpemyai, say, ere thou dismiss: see on 1038.

dhmou=xoi (cp. 1087 ga=s ta=sde damou/xois), the reading of the first hand in L, is clearly preferable to dhmou=xos. For the latter, Herm. urged that (1) Oed. is too angry to be so polite, and (2) the mere name of Theseus is not enough here, without a title. Both these arguments might with more justice be inverted: for (1) it is precisely in the formal a)/ndres th=sde dhmou=xoi xqono/s that we catch the note of suppressed passion; (2) *qhseu/s, so emphatic as the first word in 1350, would be weakened by dhmou=xos in 1348: and (3) with dhmou=xos we should here need the article. The elders of Colonus are addressed as "guardians of this land" because, in the temporary absence of Theseus, they represent him. So 145 (to the Chorus) w)= th=sd' e)/foroi xw/ras.
dikaiw=n w(/st): see on 970.

o)mfh=s. We should press the word too much if we rendered, "my prophetic voice"; though it always has a certain solemnity, owing to its traditional poetic use in reference to a god or an oracle: see on 550.
a)ciwqei\s … ka)kou/sas g), "having been deemed worthy thereof (sc. e)paisqe/sqai o)mfh=s th=s e)mh=s"), yea, and having heard, etc. This is simpler than to supply toiou/twn with a)c. from toiau=ta.
toiau=q' followed by a(\ instead of oi)=a, as O. T. 441, Ant. 691, Thuc. 1.41 and oft.; so Lat. talis qui, old Eng. such... which (Shaksp. Wint. 1. 1. 26, etc.).

o(/s g), w)= ka/kiste: cp. 866 o(/s m), w)= ka/kiste (to Creon): for the causal o(/s, see on 263. Oedipus first explains to the Chorus why he deigns a reply at all, and then suddenly turns on his son. As the schol. well says, daimoni/ws th=| a)postrofh=| xrh=tai a)po\ tou= xorou= e)pi\ to\n *polunei/khn. Profound resentment could not be more dramatically expressed.—
skh=ptra kai\ qro/nous: cp. 425, 448.

a(\, which things: the neut. plur. of o(/s being used substantivally, with ref. to the masc. qro/nous no less than to skh=ptra: cp. Xen. Cyr. 8.2.22 karpou=mai a)sfa/leian kai\ eu)/kleian, a(\ ou)/te katash/petai ou)/te u(perplhrou=nta lumai/netai: Isocr. or. 9 § 22 ka/llos kai\ r(w/mhn kai\ swfrosu/nhn, a(/per tw=n a)gaqw=n prepwde/stata toi=s thlikou/tois e)sti/n.
to\n au)to\s au(tou=: see on 930.

e)/qhkas a)/polin … kai\ forei=n, didst make me homeless, and cause me to wear: so in Pind. Pyth. 1.40 (quoted by Schneidewin) e)qelh/sais tau=ta no/w| tiqe/men eu)/andro/n te xw/ran, "mayest thou take these things into thy providence, and make the land happy in her sons." Cp. also the double sense of poiei=n Thuc. 2.29 o( *numfo/dwros th/n te tou= *sita/lkou cummaxi/an e)poi/hse kai\ *sa/dokon to\n ui(o\n au)tou= *)aqhnai=on ("brought about" ... "made"). The constr. of ti/qhmi with acc. and inf. is not rare in poetry: cp. Eur. Hec. 357, Her. 990, Med. 717, etc.
a)/polin: cp. 208.
tau/tas without ta/s: cp. 629.

po/nw| … kakw=n=polupo/nois kakoi=s, the gen. being added to define po/nw| more closely. Since po/nos was a word of such general meaning, the phrase, though unusual, seems defensible. Cp. such phrases as dusoi/stwn po/nwn | a)=ql' (Ph. 508), po/nwn | latreu/mat' (Tr. 356), a)/eql' a)gw/nwn (ib. 506).
bebhkw\s, as El. 1056 o(/tan ga\r e)n kakoi=s | h)/dh bebh/kh|s: ib. 1094 moi/ra| me\n ou)k e)n e)sqla=| | bebw=san.
e)moi/ depending on tau)tw=|: cp. O.T. 284 n.

klausta\ … oi)ste/a: for the plur., see on 495. There is no sound basis for the view that klausto/s=deflendus, klauto/s=defletus. Whether with or without the s, the verbal adj. meant simply "bewept," and took on a potential sense only as invictus could mean "unconquerable." See O. T., Appendix, on v. 361.
e)moi\ me\n, "by me, on my part," has no clause formally answering to it: but the antithesis is implied in the doom of Polyneices (1370 ff.).

I have little doubt that ta/d', e(/wsper, not ta/d', w(/sper, is the true reading here. The synizesis of e(/ws was familiar through Homer: Od. 2.148 tw\ d' e(/ws me/n r() e)pe/tonto meta\ pnoih=|s a)ne/moio: Il. 17.727 e(/ws me
 ga/r te qe/ousi diarrai=sai memaw=tes. In Ph. 1330 w(s a)
 au(to\s h(/lios, Scaliger rightly changed w(s to e(/ws (first adopted by Wunder); Brunck, with less probability, to e)/st). In Ai. 1117 w(s a)
 h)=|s o)=o/s per ei)=, w(s is more easily defended; but there also (I now think) e(/ws was rightly conjectured by Scaliger.

e(/wsper here could not be trisyllabic, since the anapaest in the first place must be contained in one word, the only exception being the prep. and its case, as e)pi\ tw=|de d' h)go/reue *diomh/dhs a)/nac, Eur. Or. 898. (In fr. 355 taxu\ d' au)to\ dei/cei tou)/rgon, w(s e)gw\ safw=s, from the *lh/mniai, the explanation may be that the drama was satyric, and borrowed a license from Comedy. Meineke would read ta/x' au)to\.) With w(/sper the sense is, "however I may live,"—i.e. whether my remaining life be less, or even more, wretched than now. Clearly, however, the sense wanted is not this, but, "as long as I live."
fone/ws (predicative), a strong word, as O. T. 534 (Oed. to Creon) foneu\s w)\n tou=de ta)ndro\s e)mfanw=s.

memnhme/nos, nom., by attraction to e(/wsper a)\n zw=, instead of a dat. agreeing with e)moi/: cp. Il. 7.186
to\n i(/kane …
o(/s min e)pigra/yas kune/h| ba/le, fai/dimos *ai)/as.

mo/xqw| … e)/ntrofon: cp. Ai. 622
palaia=| me\n su/ntrofos a(me/ra|,
leukw=| de\ gh/ra| [e)/ntrofos MSS., but see n. there].

e)k se/qen, since the brothers had passively sanctioned his expulsion (441): e)k of the prime cause, as O. T. 1454. Cp. Xen. Hellen. 1.1.27 o(/ti feu/goien u(po\ tou= dh/mou (had been banished by the people).

e)paitw=, act., used by Soph. only here and O. T. 1416 (of a humble request): midd. once, El. 1124. The author of the Rhesus, also, has used it of mendicancy, 715 bi/on d' e)paitw=n ei(=rp' a)gu/rths tis la/tris.
ei) d' e)ce/fusa … mh\: for the hyperbaton of mh/ cp. O. T. 329 ta)/m), w(s a)\n ei)/pw mh\ ta\ s), e)kfh/nw kaka/ (where see n.): Ph. 66 ei) d' e)rga/sei | mh\ tau=ta.

to\ so
 me/ros, acc. of respect; so Ant. 1062: cp. O. T. 1509 pa/ntwn e)rh/mous, plh
 o(/son to\ so
 me/ros.
ei)s to\ sumponei=n: cp. 335, and for ei)s, 1028.
a)p' a)/llou: cp. Ai. 547 (he will not flinch) ei)/per dikai/ws e)/st' e)mo\s ta\ patro/qen.

toiga/r s' o( dai/mwn. The thought is: "Therefore the avenging deity has his eyes upon thee; not yet, however, with a gaze so fierce as that which he will turn on thee anon, if (as thou tellest me) these hosts are marching against Thebes." A certain measure of retribution has already come on the wicked son, who is "a beggar and an exile" (1335); and the measure will soon be filled by a fratricide's death. For ei)sora=| cp. 1536: so ble/pein pro/s tina, 279. The me\n after ei)sora=| properly implies such a statement as this:—ei)sora=| me\n nu=n, au)ti/ka de\ kai\ ma=llon ei)so/yetai. Instead of the second clause, a more reticent and more impressive form of speech is abruptly substituted, — ou)/ ti/ pw w(s au)ti/k). With L's pou ("I ween") the sense would be the same. Dobree's se dai/mwn … o(\s au)ti/k) is less effective, because it destroys the unity and continuity of the divine retribution.
I hold ei)/per to be right: it refers to the statement made by Polyneices, which it does not call in question, but merely notes as the condition.

kinou=ntai refers to the march from Argos: it would be over-subtle to take it of the advance from the camp in the plain to the walls of the city. With Heimsoeth's ei)/ poq' the sense would be: "if ever these hosts are destined to move," the pres. with pote/ being an "oracular" future (Ph. 113 ai(rei= ta\ to/ca tau=ta th\n *troi/an mo/na).

kei/nhn e)rei/yeis is a certain correction (by Turnebus, Paris, ann. 1553) of kei/nhn e)rei= tis, and has been accepted by nearly all subsequent editors. Cp. the threat *qh/bhs a)/stu dh|w/sein puri/, 1319: and kataska/yanti, 1421. It was necessary to take Thebes by storm before Polyneices could establish his power. The only natural sense for the MS. reading is, "for it is impossible that any one shall call Thebes a city." In Aeschylus Eum. 457 the total destruction of Troy is expressed by the phrase su\ *troi/an a)/polin *)ili/ou po/lin | e)/qhkas, "madest it to be no city": and the MS. reading here might more easily be defended if the sense were precisely the opposite to what it actually is.—Campbell, keeping e)rei= tis, renders, "for there is one" (i.e. Polyneices) "who shall never call Thebes his “city”." But there is nothing in the Greek answering to "his." The general associations of the word po/lis surely could not supply the absence of the essential word au(tou=. There is no contrast here, surely, between a)/stu, as "town," and po/lis, as civitas.
ai(/mati … mianqei\s, not merely "covered with (thine own) blood," but "stained with a brother's blood," as Ant. 171 (of these brothers) pai/sante/s te kai\ | plhge/ntes au)to/xeiri su\n mia/smati.

toia/sd). His former imprecation, uttered on hearing Ismene's tidings, implied the same doom which is more plainly denounced here (421—427: 451 f.). Manifestly it is to this that pro/sqe refers. Campbell holds, however, that, in this passage, Sophocles has abandoned what is otherwise the distinctive point in his conception of the curse on the sons,— viz. that it was delivered only after the outbreak of their strife for the throne (cp. on 1298),—and that pro/sqe denotes some moment before Oed. had left Thebes. I can perceive no ground for this. The question is more than a detail: it must affect our estimate of the play as a work of dramatic art. See Introd.
e)canh=k), sent up, from my inmost soul: the notion being that the a)rai/, when they have once passed the father's lips, are thenceforth personal agencies of vengeance: hence 1376

cumma/xous. So e)canie/nai is said of the earth "sending up,"—calling into activity,—plagues or dread beings (Eur. Phoen. 670, etc.). Distinguish a)fh=ka (Ant. 1085), e)fh=kas (Eur. Hipp. 1324), of launching curses, etc., like missiles.

a)nakalou=mai, simply, "I invoke," not, "I invoke again." In this compound the prep. has two different meanings, (1) "aloud," as in a)naboa=n, a)nakhru/ssein, and (2) "up" or "back," as in a)nie/nai. Cp. Her. 9.90 qeou\s...a)nakale/wn, "calling aloud on the gods": El. 693 *)argei=os...a)nakalou/menos: Tr. 910 to\n au(th=s dai/mon' a)nakaloume/nh. So in Eur. Suppl. 626 keklhme/nous me\n a)nakalou/meq' au)= qeou/s="again (au)=") we call aloud, etc.

i(/n' a)ciw=ton. The thought is, "I call the Curses (to destroy you twain), that ye may deign to revere parents," etc.: a Greek way of saying, "that ye may rue your neglect to revere them." The irony consists in the lesson being learned only when it is too late to practise it. Cp. Tr. 1109
prosmo/loi mo/non,
i(/n' e)kdidaxqh=| pa=sin a)gge/llein o(/ti
kai\ zw=n kakou/s ge kai\ qanw\n e)tisa/mhn: Ant. 310 (ye shall die),
i(/n' ei)do/tes to\ ke/rdos e)/nqen oi)ste/on
to\ loipo\n a(rpa/zhte (cp. the form of threat, "I'll teach thee to do such things"): cp. also ib. 715, O. T. 1273, Ai. 100.

tou\s futeu/santas se/bein. Attic law imposed the penalty of disfranchisement on a son convicted of neglecting to support a parent in sickness or old age (ghroboskei=n), or of other grave failure in filial duty. When such a case of ka/kwsis gone/wn came before a court, the accuser could speak at any length (a)/neu u(/datos, Harpocr. 161), and was not liable to the e)pwbeli/a, or fine in 1/6th of the damages laid, if he failed to gain a fifth of the votes. Diog. L. 1. 2. 55 dokei= de\ (Solon) ka/llista nomoqeth=sai: e)a/n tis mh\ tre/fh| tou\s gone/as, a)/timos e)/stw. Aeschin. or. 1 § 28 e)a/n tis le/gh| e)n tw=| dh/mw|, to\n pa/tera tu/ptwn h)\ th\n mhte/ra, h)\ mh\ tre/fwn, h)\ mh\ pare/xwn oi)/khsin, tou=ton ou)k e)a=| le/gein (o( no/mos). Xen. Mem. 2.2.14 (beware) ei)/ ti parhme/lhkas th=s mhtro\s...mh/ se ai)sqo/menoi tw=n gone/wn a)melou=nta pa/ntes a)tima/swsin, ei)=ta e)n e)rhmi/a| fi/lwn a)nafanh=|s. The example of the birds is quoted (El. 1058), esp. of the stork (Aristoph. Av. 1355).

kai\ mh\ )catima/zhton, sc. tou\s futeu/santas: "and that ye may not utterly scorn your parents, because the father (ei) =o(/ti") is blind from whom ye, such evil sons, have sprung—for your sisters did not thus. tuflou= has the chief emphasis: the father's blindness emboldened the impiety of the base sons, while it only stimulated the devotion of the daughters. For the gen. cp. 1322.—Others understand: "do not think it a light matter that ye have been such sons of a blind sire" (ei) as after qauma/zw, e)lew=, etc.): but this sense for e)catima/zhton seems much less natural.

e)/futon is the MS. reading, as 1696 e)/bhton, 1746 e)la/xeton: and there are about 10 other places in Attic writers where the MSS. give -ton for the 2nd pers. dual of secondary tenses. Against this group is to be set a smaller group (of some 9 passages) in which -thn is established, ei)xe/thn h)/dh, O.T. 1511, being the only one proved by metre. Curtius (Verb 1. 80, Eng. tr. 53) would leave the normal -ton where, as here, the MSS. support it. Though Attic usage, misled by the analogy of -thn in the 3rd pers., sometimes admitted it in the 2nd, it also (he thinks) retained -ton. The tendency of recent editors has been to write -thn everywhere. But, in the absence of better proof that -ton had been wholly discarded, a consensus of MSS. seems entitled to the benefit of the doubt. I cannot find any evidence on this point from the best source,—inscriptions.

toiga\r to\ so\n q.: "wherefore they (sc. ai( *)arai/) have the control over thy supplication (to Poseidon) and thy throne" (said bitterly—"the throne of which thou dreamest"). to\ do/n (etc.) is like the ironical use of inverted commas: cp. El. 1110, Ph. 1251, Ant. 573. Polyneices has two pleas: (1) As i(ke/ths of Poseidon, he had adjured his father to remember *ai)dw/s, who is enthroned with Zeus, and to bless his enterprise, 1267. (2) As eldest-born, he claimed the throne by right, 1293. Oedipus answers that *di/kh, no less than *ai)dw/s, sits with Zeus. The son has broken the eternal laws (a)rxai=oi no/moi) of natural duty. Therefore this highest
*di/kh annuls both his pleas. His father's curse has the final control.
qa/khma as 1160, 1179: to make it a mere hendiadys with qro/nous would grievously enfeeble these words.
kratou=sin, with acc., not of the person conquered (as more often), but of the domain over which the rule extends: cp. Aesch. Suppl. 254 kai\ pa=san ai)=an..
h( palai/fatos, declared from of old (by inspired poets and seers), a freq. epithet of oracles, etc., and significant here, where the higher law is opposed to the conventional right of the elderborn.

cu/nedros with *zhno\s: Pind. Ol. 8.21
e)/nqa *sw/teira, *dio\s ceni/ou
pa/redros, a)skei=tai *qe/mis: cp. on 1267. A passage quoted by Schneidewin and others as from Demosthenes cannot claim that authority,—for or. 25 kata\ *)aristogei/tonos a/ is now generally allowed to be a work of the later Rhetoric,—but is noticeable as illustrating palai/fatos: § 11 th
 a)parai/thton kai\ semnh
 *di/khn, h(
 o( ta\s a(giwta/tas teleta\s h(mi=n katadei/cas *)orfeu\s para\ to
 tou= *dio\s qro/non fhsi\ kaqhme/nhn pa/nta ta\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn e)fora=n.

a)rxai/oisno/mois, causal dat., "by," "under sanction of," the
a)/grapta ka)sfalh= qew=n
no/mima …
ou) ga/r ti nu=n te ka)xqe\s a)ll' a)ei/ pote
zh=| tau=ta, Ant. 454. See on O. T. 865. As to Bergk's conjecture qro/nois, we should expect either pa/redros..qro/nois, or cu/nedros..qro/nwn.

ka)pa/twr … e)mou=, and without a father in me: for the gen. cp. on 677 a)nh/nemon...xeimw/nwn. Plat. Legg. 928E e)n ou)=n a)/llh| politei/a| pai=s a)pokekhrugme/nos (publicly disowned by his parents) ou)k a)\n e)c a)na/gkhs a)/polis ei)/h, tau/ths de\...a)nagkai/ws e)/xei ei)s a)/llhn xw/ran e)coiki/zesqai to\n a)pa/tora (the disowned child). From e)mou= supply e)moi/ with a)po/ptustos (cp. Aesch. Eum. 191).

sullabw\n, taking them with thee,—a colloquial phrase, bitter here: cp. Ph. 577 e)/kplei seauto\n sullabw/n: sometimes playful, as in Aristoph. Av. 1469 a)pi/wmen...sullabo/ntes ta\ ptera/: see on O. T. 971.
kalou=mai. The midd. (rare in Attic except as a law-term, to cite one before a court, Aristoph. Nub. 1221) is fitting here, since the *)arai/ are his creatures, and do his work.
e)mfuli/ou, stronger than patrw/|as, and suggestive of the unnatural strife: cp. Ant. 1263 ktano/ntas te kai\ | qano/ntas ble/pontes e)mfuli/ous.
do/rei: see on 620.
nosth=sai with acc., as Eur. I. T. 534 ou)/pw neno/sthk' oi)=kon. Cp. 1769.
to\ koi=lon *)/argos: on 378.
ktanei=n q' is better than ktano/nq' (Blaydes), as giving a more separate prominence to the fratricide.
( tou=ton ) u(f' ou(=: Xen. Symp. 8. 17 ti/s misei=n du/nait' a)\n u(f' ou(= ei)dei/h kalo/s te ka)gaqo\s nomizo/menos;

patrw=|on. What is meant by the "horrible paternal gloom of Tartarus"? Clearly patrw=|on must have some reference to the personal relationships of the speaker, but that reference might be variously defined. (1) The primeval Darkness, father of all (as Apollo is patrw=|os dia\ th\n tou= *)/iwnos ge/nesin, Plat. Euthyd. 302 C). Aristoph. Av. 693 *xa/os h)=n kai\ *nu\c *)/erebo/s te me/lan prw=ton kai\ *ta/rtaros eu)ru/s: cp. Hes. Th. 116. The point will then be twofold; the Furies are pai=des a)rxai/ou *sko/tou (see on 40); and Darkness, father of all, is invoked by the father who is cursing his son,— as *zeu\s patrw=|os is the god to whom an outraged father appeals (Aristoph. Nub. 1468). (2) The nether gloom which hides Laïus (so Hermann). The thought will then be that the family a)ra/ which slew Laïus is to slay Polyneices. It seems hardly the fit moment, however, for Oed. to recall his own parricidal act. (3) The nether gloom which is to be thy sole patrimony, patrw=|on being proleptic. This appears a little too subtle for the direct vehemence of the curse. (4) A darkness like that in which thy blind father dwells: cp. O. T. 1314
i)w\ sko/tou
ne/fos e)mo\n a)po/tropon.

I prefer (1), but suspect that the poet used patrw=|on with some measure of deliberate vagueness, leaving the hearers to choose between its possible associations, or to blend them. No emendation seems probable: see cr. n.

a)poiki/sh|: Tr. 954
ge/noit' e)/pouros e(stiw=tis au)/ra,
h(/tis m' a)poiki/seien e)k to/pwn.

ta/sde dai/monas: the Eumenides, one of whose general attributes it was to punish sins against kinsfolk, are invoked separately from the personal *)arai/ of the sufferer (1375): so El. 111
*po/tni' *)ara/,
semnai/ te qew=n pai=des *)erinu/es. The Curse calls the Furies into action. Cp. on 1434.
*)/arh, the Destroyer, whether by strife, as here, or by pestilence (O. T. 190 n.).

e)ca/ggelle, "publish,"—with bitter irony, since the son dares not tell it even to a bosom-friend: see 1402.—The word was used esp. of traitors who carried news out of a city or camp to the enemy (cp. n. on O. T. 1223).—kai\ pa=si, e'en to all. (kai/...te could not stand for te... kai/ as "both"—"and": cp. O. T. 347 n.)
ge/ra, a fit word, since used esp. of royal prerogatives: Thuc. 1.13 e)pi\ r(htoi=s ge/rasi patrikai\ basilei=ai.
ou)/te … te, as O. T. 653, Ph. 1321, Ant. 763, El. 350, 1078, fr. 86, 4. The converse, te … ou)/te, is not found (n. on 367).
o(doi=s, his journeys from Thebes to Argos, and from Argos to Attica. Ant. 1212 dustuxesta/thn | ke/leuqon e(/rpw tw=n parelqousw=n o(dw=n. (Not, "proceedings.")

Wecklein reads cunh/domai/ sou (for soi): rightly, I think. With soi, tai=s parelqou/sais o(doi=s is usu. taken as causal, "on account of thy past journeys": but such a dat., in addition to the dat. of the person, is most awkward. We should expect either the dat. with e)pi/, or else a gen., as Dem. or. 15 § 15 *(rodi/ois ge...sugxai/rw tw=n gegenhme/nwn. And cunh/domai was constantly used with a dat. of the thing in which one takes joy, or of which one approves: Isocr. or. 5 § 8 sunhsqei\s...toi=s peri\ th=s ei)rh/nhs: or. 8 § 87 sunhsqhso/menoi tai=s h(mete/rais sumforai=s (exult in): Eur. Med. 136 ou)de\ sunh/domai ...a)/lgesi dw/matos: Hipp. 1286 ti/...toi=sde sunh/dei; (these deeds): Rhes. 958 ou) mh\n qano/nti g' ou)damw=s sunh/domai (his death): Arist. Rhet. 2.4. 3 to\n sunhdo/menon toi=s a)gaqoi=s (rejoicing in one's prosperity).
oi)/moi with gen., as Ai. 367, Ant. 82, El. 1143.
th=s e)mh=s with keleu/qou also: cp. O. T. 417 mhtro/s te kai\ tou= sou= patro/s.

oi(=on … o(dou= te/los, a compressed phrase for oi(=on te/los me/llousan e(/cein o(do/n, "on a journey destined to have what an end." (Aesch. PV 284 h(/kw dolixh=s te/rma keleu/qou | diameiya/menos, is less strong, since te/rma can go with h(/kw.) Such a compression becomes intelligible when it is remembered that the purpose or end of a journey could be expressed in Greek by a bold use of the "internal" accus., as in a)ggeli/hn e)lqo/nta (Il. 11.140), etc.

oi(=on, acc., is object to fwnh=sai only, but exerts a causal force over a)postre/yai also (as w(/ste would have done): the first ou)d'="not even," the second links the two infinitives:—"such that 'tis not lawful even to utter it to any of my comrades, or to turn them back." The utterance would turn them back: but the curse is too dreadful to be revealed.

a)ll' o)/nt): sc. dei=, evolved from the negative ou)d' e)/cesti: cp. O. T. 817
o(\n mh\ ce/nwn e)/cesti mhd' a)stw=n tini
do/mois de/xesqai, …
w)qei=n d' a)p' oi)/kwn.
tou=d) is often taken here as= e)mou= (450), when it would go with o(/maimoi: but it rather means Oed., like tou=d' in 1407. A change of reference, within three vv., would be awkward. Cp. 331.
a)ll) begins the appeal (237): it might be "at least" (1276), but the other view is better, esp. as sfw/ g) follows.
ta\ sklhra\: cp. 774.

tau=t', for the MS. tou=d', seems a true correction, since (1) the threefold tou=d' in three lines exceeds the limit of probable repetition; and (2) it appears a decided gain to have tau=ta with ta\ sklhra/.
mh/ toi/ me … mh/ m': see on 1278 f.
qe/sqe e)n ta/foisi="lay me in the tomb":
qe/sqe e)n kteri/smasi="give me a share of funeral honours": cp. Her. 3.3 th\n de\...e)n timh=| ti/qetai. There is thus a slight zeugma of the verb (cp. 1357).

kteri/smata (only plur.) is used by Soph. and Eur. for the Homeric kte/rea, gifts to the dead, or funeral rites: Od. 1.291 sh=ma/ te/ oi( xeu=ai kai\ e)pi\ kte/rea kterei+/cai. In El. 434, 931 kteri/smata (=e)nta/fia ib. 326) are the gifts of libations, flowers, etc., brought to Agamemnon's grave. Cp. Ant. 203 ta/fw| | kteri/zein.

The poet's allusion to his own Antigone is lightly and happily made. Polyneices here naturally prays for regular funeral rites. That prayer was doomed to disappointment. And yet the kteri/smata for which he asks are represented by the xoai\ tri/spondoi which, in the Antigone, his sister pours, after the symbolic rite of scattering dust on the unburied corpse (Ant. 431).

komi/zeton, "win,"=komi/zesqon, with gen. of the person from whom, as O. T. 580 pa/nt' e)mou= komi/zetai. Cp. 6 fe/ronta = fero/menon. The same use of the act. komi/zw occurs in Homer (as Il. 11.738 ko/missa de\ mw/nuxas i(/ppous), Pind. Nem. 2.19 ni/kas e)ko/mican, etc.
oi(=s=tou/tois a(/, by reason of (causal dat.) the services which you render.

oi)/sei, "will bring," i.e. will have added to it. Cp. Ai. 866 po/nos po/nw| po/non fe/rei. As o( nu=n e)/painos is the praise for eu)se/beia, the thought is properly this:—"The natural piety, which brings you this praise for serving your father, will bring you further praise for serving your brother."
th=s e)mh=s u(pourgi/as, causal gen. with e)/painon (understood): e)mh=s=shown to me: cp. 419.

— 1446 The dialogue between sister and brother illustrates her affection for him, and thus strengthens the link (1405 ff.) between this play and the Antigone. It has, however, a further dramatic purpose. The version of the paternal curse adopted by Sophocles tended to suggest this question to the spectator:—Why should Polyneices persevere in the war, when his defeat and death had been definitely foretold to him? For he plainly believes the prediction (cp. 1407, 1435), though he affects to think that there is a chance of escape (1444). The answer is furnished by the traits of his character which this dialogue brings out. They give the h)qikh\ pi/stis for a course which might otherwise have seemed improbable.
to\ poi=on: the art. marks the lively interest felt by the speaker: see 893. The v.l. w)= filta/th moi, poi=on, is inferior.

w(s ta/xista/ ge. Instead of ge, we should rather expect dh/: but ge, emphasising ta/xista, will not seem weak if we regard the clause as supplementary: "turn back thy host—yes, and with all speed too." Distinguish the ordinary use of ge with the adverb in response: Ant. 1102 *k*r. dokei=s pareikaqei=n; *x*o. o(/son g), a)/nac, ta/xista.

po/lin, Thebes, rather than his adopted city, Argos. Oedipus had declared, indeed, that his son should not destroy Thebes (1372): but Antigone is ready to suppose a different event as possible (pa/tran kataska/yanti, 1421); and, in any case, Thebes would suffer the scourge of war.

The MS.
pw=s ga\r au)=qis au)= pa/lin
stra/teum' a)/goimi tau)to/n is defensible if we take pw=s a)/goimi as dubitative, "How could I possibly lead?" See Appendix on 170. But there is at least a strong probability that the poet used a)/n here, instead of employing the much rarer construction. So far as our MSS. are concerned, the dropping out of a)/n after a)/goimi is not much less likely than the change of a)/n into au)=. Either would have been easy. I prefer au)=qis a)\n... a)/goimi to au)=qis au)=...a)/goim' a)/n, because a)/n is thus more forcibly placed, and serves also to bring out au)=qis. We have au)=qis au)= pa/lin in Ph. 952, but usually au)=qis pa/lin (364: Ph. 127, 342, 1232: Tr. 342: Ai. 305: fr. 444. 3).

To Porson's au)=qis au)=...a)/goimi tau)/t) a)/n the drawback is the elision. We find tau)/t) for the plur. tau)ta/ (O. T. 284, 840 etc.); but tragedy, which preferred tau)to/n to tau)to/ (though admitting the latter under metrical necessity, O. T. 734), would hardly have elided the o in that word. Ant. 462 au)/t) (for au)to/) is solitary in Soph.: L has au)=t).

tau)to\n has been needlessly suspected and altered. "The same host" means an army to which the same realms should again send contingents,—not necessarily, of course, an army composed throughout of the same men.
au)=qis, an echo of his word: cp. O. T. 570, 622, 1004.
pa/tran, native city: cp. O. T. 1524 w)= pa/tras *qh/bhs e)/noikoi: hence kataska/yanti. So Ant. 199 ff. gh=n patrw/|an … | prh=sai.
presbeu/ont) = presbu/teron o)/nta, as often in good prose: Thuc. 6.55 ge/graptai meta\ to\n pate/ra...dia\ to\ presbeu/ein a)p' au)tou= (because he was his eldest son).
ou(/tw goes best with gela=sqai: cp. 1339.

The MS. e)kfe/rei is usu. taken as intrans., "come to fulfilment." The only relevant support for this is Tr. 824 o(po/te teleo/mhnos e)kfe/roi | dwde/katos a)/rotos, "come to an end." The sense is different in Il. 23.376 e)/kferon i(/ppoi, "shot ahead" (and so Xen. Equest. 3. 4, of a horse running away). Hence Hermann's surely forced rendering here, "rush forward to their fulfilment." But e)kfe/rei may be also 2nd pers. pres. midd., "fulfil for thyself." Cp. the use of the active in Il. 21.450 misqoi=o te/los... *(=wrai | e)ce/feron, accomplished the term of our hire: Pind. Nem. 4.60 *xei/rwn
div3.l: ...to\ mo/rsimon e)/kferen. Soph. has e)kfe/retai as="she achieves for herself" in Tr. 497. Here, "thou art fulfilling," has clearly more point than, "they are being fulfilled." I should therefore read e)kfe/reis with Tyrwhitt, did not e)kfe/rei (as midd.) yield the required sense even better.
div3.p: e)s o)rqo\n, recte, so that the event is parallel with the prediction: Ant. 1178 w)= ma/nti, tou)/pos w(s a)/r' o)rqo\n h)/nusas: cp. O. T. 506 n.

e)c a)mfoi=n instead of e)c a)llh/loin. Death is to proceed from you both: the phrase leaves it to be understood that the death which proceeds from each is for the other. To read au(toi=n (Blaydes) is no improvement. The plur. reflexive pron. is sometimes, indeed, so used (e.g., Isocr. or. 4 § 15 ta\s pro\s h(ma=s au)tou\s e)/xqras), and Soph. has it once, Ant. 145, kaq' au(toi=n=kat' a)llh/loin, though Eustathius (1547. 29) blamed Menander for imitating that. If a)mfoi=n fails to mark mutuality, au(toi=n might be taken of a double suicide.

xrh/|zei ga/r: "aye, for he wishes it": implying that the wish may have prompted the prophecy. It is hard to see why interpreters should have sought to efface this tragic touch by taking xrh/|zei as=impers. xrh/, or, with the schol., as=xrhsmw|dei=,—both alike impossible.
e(/pesqai: for the irregular order of words, cp. O. T. 1251 xw(/pws me\n e)k tw=nd' ou)ke/t' oi)=d' a)po/llutai (n.): Ant. 682 n.
ou)d), not even (to begin with); cp. Her. 3.39 tw=| ga\r fi/lw| e)/fh xariei=sqai ma=llon a)podidou\s ta\ e)/labe h)\ a)rxh\n mhde\ labw/n, "than if he had not taken them at all."

flau=r), a euphemism for kaka/: cp. Arist. Rhet. 2.13. 1 (old men are persuaded) ta\ plei/w fau=la ei)=nai tw=n pragma/twn, "unsatisfactory."—So ta)ndea= for ta\ xei/rw: the defects or weak points in one's case, the things which threaten failure: cp. Her. 7.48 ei)...tau/th| fai/netai e)ndee/stera ei)=nai ta\ h(me/tera prh/gmata, if our side seems somewhat weak here. For the thought, cp. Andoc. or. 3 § 34 fhmi\ ga\r...pole/mou me\n o)/ntos a)/ndra strathgo\n th=| po/lei te eu)/noun ei)do/ta te o(/ ti pra/ttoi lanqa/nonta dei=n tou\s pollou\s tw=n a)nqrw/pwn kai\ e)capatw=nta a)/gein e)pi\ tou\s kindu/nous.
e)/stai me/lousa: cp. 653.

kakh\, dira, ill-omened (like kako\s o)/rnis), with pro\s tou=de k.t.l.—tou=d) *)erin.: cp. 1299: so Od. 11.280 mhtro\s *)erinu/es: Her. 4.149 *)erinu/wn tw=n *lai+/ou te kai\ *oi)dipo/dew. "His Erinyes" are those whom his *)arai/ summon: Il. 9.454 polla\ kathra=to stugera\s d' e)peke/klet' *)erinu=s: though the Curse and the Fury are sometimes identified, as Aesch. Th. 70 *)ara/ t), *)erinu\s patro\s h( megasqenh/s.

eu)odoi/h, in contrast with his own o(do/s. The conjecture eu)= didoi/h (Burges), accepted by some of the best edd., effaces a natural and pathetic touch. The MS. sfw=|n, if right, might be compared with the dat. after words of showing favour (eu)menh/s etc.): perhaps also with the dat. after h(gei=sqai and o(dopoiei=n. But in 1407, where sfw/ is certain, the MSS. have sfw=|n: and the acc. with eu)odou=n is slightly recommended by the analogy of o(dou=n, o(dhgei=n. Suidas, too, has eu)odw=: ai)tiatikh=|: though this might be explained by the post-classical constr. of eu)odou=n, which, as in the Septuagint, was with acc. In Her. 6.73 w(s *kleome/nei+ eu)wdw/qh to\...prh=gma, Stein reads w(dw/qh: in any case, the dat. there ("for Cleomenes") has no bearing on the question of dat. or acc. here.—In Aristoph. Ran. 1528
eu)odi/an a)gaqh\n a)pio/nti poihth=|
e)s fa/os o)rnume/nw| do/te, the noun has its literal sense (referring to the return of Aeschylus to earth): and so prob. in Aesch. fr. 34.

ta/d' ei) qano/nti moi | telei=t'. The MSS. have telei=te … qano/nt). With Lobeck, I hold the simple transposition to be the true remedy. The i of the dative could be elided in Homeric Greek; but among the alleged instances in Attic drama there is not one which bears examination. See Appendix.
e)pei\ ou) = u-, a frequent synizesis, which Soph. has again Ph. 446, 948, 1037, fr. 479. 3: so e)gw\ ou)/t) O. T. 332 etc.

e(/ceton, sc. telei=n ti. The sense is:—"if ye will perform these things (i.e. the last rites, 1410) for me in my death,—as ye will no more be able (to do aught) for me in life." Since telei=n was specially appropriate to ritual (see 503), there is a certain awkwardness in the transition to its general sense (630 etc.) as merely=u(pourgei=n. But the harshness is at least much less than that of such zeugmas as Greek idiom permitted (cp. 1357), and does not seem to warrant the view that the verse is spurious. The conjecture ou)/ me zw=nta/ g) is improbable.—It has been said that the thought is repeated in ou) ga/r m' e)/ti | ble/pont' e)so/yesq' au)=qis: but the latter is a different statement, and a climax—"Ye will be able to serve me no more while I live—nay, ye will no more see me alive."
me/qesqe, sc. e)mou=: cp. 838.
The change of persons within the verse (a)ntilabh/) marks excitement: cp. 652, 820, 1169.
kai\ ti/s: cp. 606.
prou=pton, since his father has prophesied the end (1385 ff.): cp. on 1414.

mh\ su/ g), a caressing remonstrance: so Eur. Hec. 405 (Polyxena to her aged mother) bou/lei pesei=n pro\s ou)=das;...mh\ su/ g): ou) ga\r a)/cion: Phoen. 531
(Iocasta to her son Eteocles) ti/ th=s kaki/sths daimo/nwn e)fi/esai
filotimi/as, pai=; mh\ su/ g): a)/dikos h( qeo/s. But mh/ moi su/ (Med. 964) repels.
a(\ mh\ dei=: cp. 73.
ei) … sterhqw=, an epic use sometimes admitted by the Attic poets: see on O.T. 198.—
tau=ta d), "Nay, these things rest with Fortune, that they should be either thus or otherwise" (that I should die, or survive).
tau=ta, nomin.: fu=nai, epexeget. infin.: for this de/ in reply (modifying or correcting the last speaker's statement), see on O. T. 379.
e)n tw=| d., dependent on: see on 247.

fu=nai has been needlessly suspected. Here, with adv., it is merely equivalent to the intrans. e)/xein, as elsewhere in poetry it is sometimes little more than ei)=nai. El. 860 pa=si qnatoi=s e)/fu mo/ros. Cp. Aesch. PV 511 ou) tau=ta tau/th| moi=ra/ pw telesfo/ros | kra=nai pe/prwtai. For kai\ … kai/, instead of h)\...h)/, cp. 488.

The MS. sfw=|n is better than sfw\, to which some edd., following Elmsley, have needlessly changed it. "For you two my prayer is—that ye ne'er meet with ills." The contrast between his own case and theirs is thus more impressively marked than it would be by the acc. ("my prayer is that you two ne'er meet with ills"). For the dat. of the person in whose interest the prayer is made, cp. O. T. 269, Ph. 1019, Ai. 392. For
a)rw=mai in a good sense cp. Tr. 48, Ai. 509, Il. 9.240, Her. 1.132 (e(wutw=|...a)ra=sqai a)gaqa/).
pa=sin, ethic dat., "in the sight of all": cp. 810 n.

div2.head: 1447-1499: Commos
div2.p: 1st strophe 1447—1456=1st antistr. 1462—1471: 2nd str. 1477—1485=2nd antistr. 1491— 1499. Each strophe is separated from the next by five trimeters, spoken by Oed. and Ant. At the close of the 2nd antistrophe Theseus enters, and he also has five trimeters. See Metrical Analysis.

The dramatic purpose is to divide the two great scenes of the fourth e)peiso/dion (1249—1555). Sophocles here shows himself a master of stage-effect in the highest sense. This momentary pause in the action gives a wonderful impressiveness to the sudden signal from heaven (1456).

div3.p: ne/a ta/de … kigxa/nei. Two views are admissible: I prefer that which is here placed first. (1) h)=lqe/ moi="I have seen come," not, "have come on me," moi being ethic dative (81). The Chorus alludes to the doom pronounced on Polyneices and his brother. "Here are new ills which I have seen come from the blind stranger,—unless perchance, Fate is finding fulfilment." Oedipus has often spoken of the fate which pursues his race (964 etc.), and the Chorus correct their first phrase by surmising that haply this fate, not Oedipus, is the real agent of the doom on the brothers. The schol. took h)=lqe/ moi as a foreboding of the Chorus that they might be involved in these alien ills: but moi seems merely to express sympathy.

(2) Others suppose that a low rumbling of thunder was heard immediately after the exit of Polyneices, and that e)/ktupen ai)qh/r in 1456 merely marks the first loud sound. ne/a ta/de … kaka\ are then the evils which the Chorus forebode from the incipient thunder: h)=lqe/ moi="have come upon me."

ei)/ ti moi=ra mh\ kigxa/nei is then taken either as before, or thus:—"if haply his end is not coming upon him." To this view we may object:—(a) It is much more natural to suppose that the beginning of the thunder is denoted by e)/ktupen. Each step in the crescendo of the thunder is marked by words of the Chorus: a second, and louder, peal comes at 1462, a third at 1476. The whole effect of the passage depends on the moralising of the Chorus (1451 ff.) being interrupted by the sudden crash at 1456. (b) After the exit of Polyneices, we naturally expect from the Chorus some comment on the father's curse and the son's doom. (c) If ne/a kaka\ meant "new ills" brought on the Chorus by Oed., the language would rather imply that they had suffered something else from him before,—which is not the case.

neo/qen strengthens ne/a, and might mean, "from a new occasion" (the visit of Polyneices); but it seems more probable that the poet used it merely in the sense of "newly" (lit., "from a recent moment"); schol. newsti/. For the form cp. Il. 7.97 lw/bh ta/de g' e)/ssetai ai)no/qen ai)nw=s, "with horrors of horrors": ib. 39 oi)o/qen oi)=os, "singly and alone."
ei)/ ti moi=ra mh\ kigxa/nei: for ti="perchance," cp. O. T. 124 (n.): the formula ei)/ ti mh/ is used in noticing an alternative which occurs to one as an afterthought, ib. 969.

kigxa/nei "is overtaking" (its victims), the acc. being understood, as Il. 17.671
pa=sin ga\r e)pi/stato mei/lixos ei)=nai
zwo\s e)w/n: nu=n au)= qa/natos kai\ moi=ra kixa/nei. (The full constr., 22. 303 nu=n au)=te/ me moi=ra kixa/nei.) So 11. 451 fqh= se te/los qana/toio kixh/menon. Wecklein (who reads kigxa/nh|) understands, "unless fate prevent them" (ta\ kaka/),—as if it were a hope that the curse on the brothers might not be fulfilled. This surely strains the sense of the verb.

mata=n. The MS. ma/thn seems plainly corrupt. The sense is: "for I cannot say that any decree of deities is in vain": i.e. ma/thn must stand for ma/taion ei)=nai. Isocr. or. 4 § 5 has w(/st' h)/dh ma/thn ei)=nai to\ memnh=sqai peri\ tou/twn (=ma/taion): but that does not justify the use of the adv. alone here. Nor can it go with fra/sai. For mata=n cp. Aesch. Eum. 142 i)dw/meq' ei)/ ti tou=de froimi/ou mata=|, "is in vain."
a)ci/wma prop., "what one thinks right"; here, "decree," "ordinance"; in 1459 "request." Cp. Dem. or. 18 § 210 ta\ tw=n progo/nwn a)ciw/mata, their political maxims.

fra/sai: cp. Aesch. Ch. 591
ptana/ te kai\ pedoba/mon' a)\n a)nemoe/ntwn
ai)gi/dwn fra/sai ko/ton.—These words are a comment on the last. Perchance it is Fate that is being fulfilled; for a heaven-appointed fate never fails of fulfilment.
o(ra=|. The hiatus is easily avoided by d' (Bergk), but, though somewhat harsh, is excused by the slight pause.

tau=t)=a)ciw/mata daimo/nwn. With stre/fwn (for the corrupt e)pei/), the sense is:—"Watchful, ever watchful of these divine decrees is Time,—overthrowing some fortunes, and the next day, again, exalting others on high." Cp. Eur. fr. 424 mi/) h(me/ra | ta\ me\n kaqei=len u(yo/qen, ta\ d' h)=r' a)/nw.

o(ra=|, as Ph. 843 ta/de me\n qeo\s o)/yetai, "will look to" this. Time is the vigilant minister of Fate. The mighty are humbled (as the Labdacidae have been); the lowly, again, are exalted. The last words contain an unconscious hint that the sufferings of Oedipus are well-nigh finished, and that honour is coming to him. At that instant, the thunder is heard.

The MS. words e)pei\ me
 e(/tera … a)/nw are thus paraphrased by the schol.: polla\ me
 au)/cwn par' h)=mar, polla\ de\ ei)s to\ e)/mpalin tre/pwn. This makes it certain that, instead of e)pei/, the schol. had some participle, as the form of the sentence plainly requires. For stre/fwn cp. Eur. fr. 540 feu=, ta\ tw=n eu)daimonou/ntwn w(s ta/xa stre/fei qeo/s. Soph. Tr. 116 to
 *kadmogenh= | stre/fei, to\ d' au)/cei bio/tou | polu/ponon, the troubles of his life now bring reverse, now glory, to Heracles. This was a poetical use of stre/fw, which the schol.'s words ei)s to\ e)/mpalin tre/pwn were meant to explain. tre/pw itself was not used alone as=a)natre/pw, though often in phrases with that sense: cp. the frag. of a satyric drama (Aesch. fr. 304)—of a domesticated pig—
h(\ polla/ g' e)n do/moisin ei)/rgastai kaka/,
donou=sa kai\ tre/pousa tu/rb' a)/nw ka/tw. Wecklein's e)pe/xwn ("checking," "arresting") would agree more closely with the metre of the antistrophe as given by the MSS. (see on 1469). But stre/fwn requires only the slightest change there, and is metrically preferable on other grounds (see Metrical Analysis): it is also a better contrast to au)/cwn. — The MS. e)pei\ me/n is untranslatable. It has been explained as (1) "sometimes"=o(te\ me/n: (2) by an ellipse of a verb, as e)/dwken (Hermann). Neither is possible.
e)/ktupen, the epic aor., only here in Attic: elsewhere e)ktu/phsa.
pw=s a)/n: cp. on 1100.
ei)/ tis e)/ntopos,—other, that is, than the Chorus: some one who could be sent on the errand. Cp. 70, 297.

deu=ro … po/roi, cause him to come hither. porei=n, to give, is never found as=poreu/ein, to make to come (1476): and here the phrase is strictly a compressed one, "enable me to speak to him, (by bringing him) hither." But the associations of po/ros and poreu/ein have doubtless influenced it. Cp. El. 1267
ei)/ se qeo\s e)po/risen
a(me/tera pro\s me/laqra.—Cp. Pind. Pyth. 3.45 kai/ r(a/ nin *ma/gnhti fe/rwn po/re *kentau/rw| dida/cai ("gave," with the like notion as here of bringing to).
pa/nt), adv.: Ai. 911 o( pa/nta kwfo/s: O. T. 475 n.
ti/ d), after the voc.: cp. 507.
ta)ci/wm): see on 1451.
pterwto\s: Verg. Aen. 5. 319 et ventis et fulminis ocior alis.

a)/cetai: the fut. midd. here merely=a)/cei, for "cause me to be led" would be strained. In Od. 21.322 ou)/ ti/ se to/nd' a)/cesqai o)i+o/meq' ("wed thee"), the midd. has its proper special force: cp. ib. 214. In Eur. Hipp. 625 it is doubtful. In Aesch. Ag. 1632 etc. it is passive.

While the MS. words i)/de ma/la me/gas e)rei/petai correspond with the first verse of the strophe (1447), the second verse here exceeds its strophic counterpart by uu. Hermann supplied ne/a in the strophe: Heinrich Schmidt omits o(/de here. We need not do either. The erasure in L at ma/la me/gas shows that some disturbance had occurred; and this may have concerned the order of words. If we write
me/gas, i)/de, ma/l' o(/d' e)rei/petai
ktu/pos a)/fatos dio/bolos, we get an exact correspondence, without either adding to the strophe or taking from the antistrophe.
e)rei/petai, ruit (cp. Ai. 309 n.); the very sky seems to come down with the crash: so Valerius Flaccus 8. 334 ruina poli of thunder.
ktu/pos … dio/bolos, the noise of a bolt hurled by Zeus: cp. on 710 au)/xhma ...eu)/ippon.
a)/kran, the tips, not the roots: cp. 1624.
e)/pthca, aor. referring to a moment just past, where we should ordinarily use the pres.: Ai. 693 e)/fric' e)/rwti. Cp. O. T. 337 n.
qumo/n, acc. of part affected.

ou)rani/a: schol. a)nti\ tou= taxei=a. This seems to be merely a marginal note by the "diorthotes" of L, not one of the ancient scholia which he copied into the MS.: and I doubt whether it points to a different reading. Rather, probably, it means that the writer took ou)rani/a as= "rushing from the sky." Heinrich Schmidt defends ou)rani/a as -u-: others deny that such a synizesis is possible. But in Aesch. Th. 288 kardi/as answers metrically to e)xqroi=s (305); in his Suppl. 71 kardi/an=the last two syllables of stugou=ntes (80); and ib. 799 kardi/as=the first two of gaia/oxe (816). Dindorf cuts the knot in all these places by adopting ka/rza, an Aeolic form mentioned in Etym. M. 407. 21,—surely a most improbable remedy. It is more reasonable to infer that so easy a synizesis as that of ia was sometimes allowed in the lyrics of Attic drama. Elmsley's ou)ri/a (suggested by the schol.'s taxei=a) is unsuitable here. From Hesych. a)/rgios: leuko/s, taxu/s, Wecklein suggests a)rgi/a, comparing the Homeric a)rgh=ta kerauno/n. If any change were needed, I should prefer ou)ranw=|.

ti/ … a)fh/sei te/los; "what end (event) will (the lightning) bring forth?" For a)fie/nai as="to emit," "produce from one's self," cp. Arist. Hist. An. 6. 14 a)fia=si to\ ku/hma,...th=s qhlei/as a)fiei/shs to\ w)|o/n. This use, which was common, suggests how the word might be figuratively said of the storm giving birth to some disastrous issue. We need not, then, seek a correction (as e)fh/sei or e)fh/cei).
ma\n, "verily," here nearly=an exclamation, such as "ah!" Cp. on 182.

L has de/deia to/d', which might easily have grown out of de/doika d' (Nauck). The latter is recommended by metre, giving an exact correspondence if in 1454 we read stre/fwn: cp. on 1453 f. With de/dia to/d' it is necessary to suppose a very improbable resolution of - into uu; see Metrical Analysis.
a)forma=|, sc. h( a)straph/, "rushes forth" (from the sky),—better here than the v.l. e)forma=|.

cumfora=s, not definitely "misfortune," but rather, more generally, "grave issue." The thought is merely that something momentous always follows such a storm. Cp. O. T. 44 ta\s cumfora\s ...tw=n bouleuma/twn, the issues or effects of counsels.
w)= me/gas ai)qh/r is a cry, rather than an address like w)= *zeu=: yet in Aesch. PV 88, in a direct address, we have w)= di=os ai)qh/r, followed by the voc. pammh=to/r te gh=.

h(/kei tw=|d' e)p' a)ndri/. We may render the prep. "upon" me, but properly it is rather "against" me;—the doom, from which there is no a)postrofh/, advances to take him. Cp. O. T. 509 e)p' au)tw=| ptero/ess' h)=lqe ko/ra. (Not, "in my case," as ib. 829.) The conjecture tw=|de ta)ndri\ is needless, and impairs the solemnity of the words.

sumbalw\n e)/xeis (cp. 817, 1140), hast inferred, a freq. sense of the act. in Attic: Her. in this sense prefers the midd. As w)= pai=des (1472) evidently means the daughters, this v. is rightly given to Antigone; but her question reminds us that she, and she only, had heard Oed. speak of the signs which should announce his end (95).
moi, ethic dat., "I pray you": cp. O. T. 1512 tou=t' eu)/xesqe/ moi, "I would have this to be your prayer."
e)/a is the cry of one startled by a sight or sound (Aesch. PV 298 e)/a: ti/ xrh=ma leu/ssw;): only here in Soph.
ma/l' au)=qis, "again, and loudly": El. 1410 i)dou\ ma/l' au)= qroei= tis.

a)mfi/statai, because the peals of thunder, now at their loudest, seem to be around them on every side. Cp. Od. 6.122 w(/ste me koura/wn a)mfh/luqe qh=lus a)u+th/: so peri\...h)/luq' i)wh\ | fo/rmiggos (17. 261), a)/shma peribai/nei boh=s (Ant. 1209): but the phrase here is more vigorous, suggesting the image of a threatening foe.

diapru/sios, as with ke/lados, Eur. Hel. 1308; o)lolugai/, Hom. Hymn. 4.19: in Homer only as adv., h)/u+sen de\ diapru/sion (Il. 8.227): properly, "going through" the ear, "piercing," like toro/s, diato/ros.
For w)= dai/mwn cp. on 185.
i(/la^os (sc. i)/sqi), as usually in Homer, etc., though i(/la_os also occurs (as Il. 1.583, Hymn. 5. 204, Hes. Op. 340, Aesch. Eum. 1040).
ga=| mate/ri, Attica: cp. 707 matropo/lei ta=|de. Plat. Rep. 414E dei= w(s peri\ mhtro\s kai\ trofou= th=s xw/ras e)n h(=| ei)si\ bouleu/esqai.
a)fegge\s, gloomy as the thunder-cloud.

sou= tu/xoimi is a certain correction. With e)naisi/w| (or -ou)...suntu/xoimi we must still understand soi/ (or sou=); for the version, "may I meet with a righteous man," gives a sense which is intolerably weak here.

a)/laston a)/ndr', Oedipus. With Homer, this adj. is always the epithet of pe/nqos or a)/xos, except in Il. 22.261 (Achilles), *(/ektor, mh/ moi, a)/laste, sunhmosu/nas a)go/reue, "Wretch, prate not to me of covenants,"—usu. taken as="thou whom I cannot forget (or forgive)," though others render "madman" (as if connecting the word with the rt of a)lu/w). It is simplest to suppose that the epithet of the act (537, 1672) is transferred to the agent,— the doer of a)/lasta being called a)/lastos in the general sense of "wretch," "accursed one."

i)dw\n, since, in the old Greek belief, even casual association with a polluted man was perilous: Antiph. or. 5 § 82 polloi\ h)/dh a)/nqrwpoi mh\ kaqaroi\ xei=ras h)\ a)/llo ti mi/asma e)/xontes suneisba/ntes ei)s to\ ploi=on sunapw/lesan meta\ th=s au(tw=n yuxh=s tou\s o(si/ws diakeime/nous ta\ pro\s tou\s qeou/s. Cp. Aesch. Th. 597 ff., Eur. El. 1354, Xen. Cyr. 8.1.25, Hor. Carm. 3. 2. 26.

a)kerdh= xa/rin meta/sx., have for my portion an unprofitable recompense (in return for the sympathy shown to Oed.); cp. Aesch. PV 544 a)/xaris xa/ris ("a thankless favour"), Soph. Ai. 665 a)/dwra dw=ra. Pind. Ol. 1.54 a)ke/rdeia=disaster (with a similar euphemism).
In the verb, meta/ here="along with Oedipus," "as my share in his curse": xa/rin is acc., not gen., because it denotes the share, not the thing shared.

mete/xw takes (1) gen. of thing shared, (2) acc. of share, (3) dat. of partner: but when (3) is present, (2) is usu. absent, unless equality is affirmed or denied, as Xen. Cyr. 7.2.28 eu)frosunw=n pasw=n e)moi\ to\ i)/son metei=xe. Hiero 2. 7 tou/tou (tou= kakou=) plei=ston me/ros oi( tu/rannoi mete/xousin. In Aristoph. Pl. 1144 ou) ga\r metei=xes ta\s i)/sas plhga\s e)moi/, the dat. depends on i)/sas, not on the verb: "you did not get for your share the same number of blows as I." (Cp. Dein. or. 1 § 54 to\ pe/mpton me/ros ou) metei/lhfe tw=n yh/fwn.) The peculiarity here is only in the use of the acc. alone, without a gen. (as th=s a)ra=s).

kixh/setai with gen., on the analogy of tugxa/nein. Elsewhere kixa/nw always governs acc. We might take e)myu/xou … mou (sc. o)/ntos, cp. 83) kai\ katorqou=ntos as gen. absol., but this is less probable.

katorqou=ntos intrans., fre/na acc. of respect: cp. e)c o)rqh=s freno/s, O. T. 528. The intrans. katorqo/w usu. ="to succeed" (Thuc. 6.12 h)\ katorqw/santas,...h)\ ptai/santas), but also "to be right or correct," as Plat. Legg. 654C o(\s a)\n th=| me\n fwnh=| kai\ tw=| sw/mati mh\ pa/nu dunato\s h)=| katorqou=n (in song and dance). The transitive katorqo/w="to bring anything to a successful end" (though, in such cases, the acc. might often be one of respect, and the verb intrans.), or "to make one successful" (El. 416).

e)mfu=nai freni/. Schol.: ti/ to\ pisto\n qe/leis e)mbalei=n th=| freni\ e)kei/nou, th=| tou= *qhse/ws dhlono/ti; a)nti\ tou=, ti/ bou/lei piqano\n a)nakoinw/sasqai tw=| *qhsei=; This proves that freni/ is at least as old as the ancient scholia in L, and also that the schol. had either e)mfu=nai, or, as Herm. infers from e)mbalei=n, e)mfu=sai. Many recent critics have held that freni/ has come in from 1487. So far as the mere repetition is an argument, we must be cautious in applying it: cp. 70 f., and n. on 554. The sense must be either:— "And what is the pledge which thou wouldst have fixed (1) in his mind?"— i.e. "What is it that thou wouldst tell him in confidence, under his pledge of secrecy?"—or else (2) "in thy mind?"—i.e. "what promise wouldst thou obtain from him before death?" Here (2) is recommended by the fact that the frh/n is then the same in both vv. Nor is the reply of Oed. (1489) inconsistent with it; since the fulfilment of his promise (580) to Theseus involves a pledge from Theseus to keep the secret (1530). It is, of course, possible that Soph. wrote e)mfh=nai ce/nw|, or the like: but the vulgate is at least defensible.
For the pause in sense after eu)=, cp. 52, 288, 610, El. 1036, Aesch. Eum. 87.
telesfo/ron xa/rin, a requital (1484) fraught with fulfilment (of my promise).

sfin is most naturally taken here, with the schol., as=au)tw=|, seeing that vv. 1486 f. refer to Theseus alone; though it is tenable as=au)toi=s, i.e. Theseus and his people. The evidence for sfin as dat. sing. is slender; but in Hom. Hymn. 19.19 su\n de/ sfin ought to mean su\n *pani/, and in Hymn. 30. 9 we have
bri/qei me/n sfin a)/roura fere/sbios, h)de\ kat' a)grou\s
kth/nesin eu)qhnei=, oi)=kos d' e)mpi/platai e)sqlw=n, where sfin should refer to o( d' o)/lbios shortly before, and the subject to eu)qhnei= seems clearly to be the man, not a)/roura. As to Aesch. Pers. 759, it is a case exactly parallel with ours here: i.e. sfin would most naturally refer to Xerxes alone, but might refer to Xerxes and his advisers (toi=s protreyame/nois schol.). In Pind. Pyth. 9.116, again, sfin might mean Antaeus and his family. Lycophron 1142 seems to have meant sfi for au)tw=|, as the schol. thought. On the whole, it appears unsafe to deny that poetry sometimes admitted the use.
tugxa/nwn=o(/te e)tu/gxanon (w(=n h)/|thsa), cp. 579 ff. The absol. use is made easier by a)nq' w)=n e)/pasxon eu)=.

ei)/t' a)/kra … i(kou=. On this corrupt passage, see Appendix. Reading a)/kra | peri\ gu/al) for a)/kran | e)pi\ gu/alon, I take the sense to be: "or if (ei)/t)), in the furthest recesses of the glade, for the honour of the Poseidonian sea-god, thou art hallowing his altar with sacrifice, (yet) come." The precinct of Poseidon at Colonus was large enough for an ecclesia to be held within it (Thuc. 8.67). It included the a)/lsos and nao/s mentioned by Paus. I. 30 § 4. (See Introd.) The word gu/alon, "a hollow," was oft. used in the plur. of hollow ground, valleys, or dells: cp. Aesch. Supp. 550
*lu/dia/ t' a)/g gu/ala
kai\ di' o)rw=n *kili/kwn. It would apply to the depressions between the gentle eminences of this sternou/xou xqono/s (691),—as e.g. between the two neighbouring knolls at Colonus (cp. 1600). a)/kra peri\ gu/ala means that the altar of Poseidon is in the part of the large te/menos furthest from the Chorus. When Theseus left the scene (1210), his purpose was to send the suppliant Polyneices from this same altar to Oedipus (cp. 1349). The Chorus surmise that Theseus may have stayed at the altar to complete his interrupted sacrifice (888).
In 1491 ei)/t) should perh. be ei)/g), but is intelligible if we suppose the thought to be,—Come (if thou art near, and at leisure),—or if thou art sacrificing, nevertheless quit the altar, and come.

bou/quton proleptic with a(gi/zwn; to sacrifice on the altar is to "hallow" it. Cp. Aristoph. Av. 1232
mhlosfagei=n te bouqu/tois e)p' e)sxa/rais
knisa=n t' a)guia/s.
e(sti/an= bwmo/n (888, 1158): Aesch. Th. 275 mh/loisin ai(ma/ssontas e(sti/as qew=n.

*poseidwni/w| qew=|=*poseidw=ni, not really like o( *bakxei=os qeo/s (O. T. 1105), "the god of *ba/kxoi" (cp. 678), but somewhat similar to the Homeric bi/h *(hraklhei/h, etc. Perhaps *poseidwni/an (with e(sti/an): cp. Pind. N. 6. 46 *poseida/nion a)\n te/menos.

e)pacioi=: lit. "he deems thee, thy city, and thy friends worthy (of a recompense),—that he should make a due return, after receiving benefits." The constr. is of the same class as xrh/|zw sto/matos (instead of sto/ma) prosptu/casqai (Eur. Med. 1399), i.e. the inf. is added epexegetically, outside of the construction with the principal verb (cp. 752 a(rpa/sai, 1212 zw/ein). This is, however, a peculiarly bold example, since we should have expected dikai/as xa/ritos. Against the conject. soi kai\ poli/tais kai\ fi/lois, remark that the strophic v. (1482) has no spondee.

po/lisma in Attic prose usu. implies a town of the smaller kind, as Thuc. 4.109 (of Thracian tribes) kata\ de\ mikra\ poli/smata oi)kou=si. But Eur. Med. 771 has a)/stu kai\ po/lisma *palla/dos, "the town and stronghold of Pallas" (Athens), Bacch. 919 po/lism' e(pta/stomon (Thebes): so it is used of the grand Cloud-city (Aristoph. Av. 553, 1565): and Her. applies it to Ecbatana (1. 98).
paqw/n does not require us to supply anything: it is strictly, "for treatment received,"
xa/rin sufficing to mark that this treatment was good. Cp. 1203.

div3.head: 1500-1555: Fifth episode
