div3.p: h)xei=tai is probably pass., as we find h)xw= go/ous, u(/mnon, etc. (The midd. occurs in Pind. fr. 53. 18 a)xei=tai *seme/lan...xoroi/.)

safh\s would ordinarily have been repeated in the second clause (cp. 5); but the equivalent e)mfanh\s takes its place: cp. O. T. 54 a)/rceis...kratei=s: Ant. 669 kalw=s...eu)=: also El. 986 f.: Ai. 647, 1323. The two adjectives could not be contrasted.
a)stw=n is a certain correction of au)tw=n, which, as="you yourselves," would be very awkward after u(mw=n and koino/s.

mh/ tis: "Can it be some thunderbolt of Zeus, or the rushing onset of some hail-storm (that has scared you)?" —e)ce/plhcen u(ma=s, or the like. Theseus must, of course, be supposed to have heard the thunder which was pealing a few moments before; the doubt implied by mh/ is merely as to whether the blunder is the cause of the summons.
o)mbri/a xa/laza, hail falling in a shower: cp. O. T. 1279 o)/mbros xala/zhs (n.).

e)pirra/casa, from e)pirra/ssw, which is either (1) trans., "to dash one thing against another," as O. T. 1244 pu/las...e)pirra/cas), "having dashed the doors together" at her back: or (2) intrans., as here, "to dash or burst on one": so with dat. Diod. 15. 84 toi=s *mantineu=sin...e)pe/rracen, "he dashed upon" them.
toiau=ta: "for one might forebode anything when the god sends such a storm as this" (on dioshmi/ai see n. to 95):—a courteous way of hinting that their alarm was not unnatural.
poqou=nti prou)fa/nhs: cp. O. T. 1356 qe/lonti ka)moi\ tou=t' a)\n h)=n, n.: Il. 12.374 e)peigome/noisi d' i(/konto.

kai/ soi qew=n: "and some god (cp. 1100) hath ordained for thee the good fortune of this coming": tu/xhn … o(dou=, a fortune belonging to (connected with) it.—The MS. qh=ke was a mere blunder caused by transposition. As to the occasional omission of the syllabic augment in tragic r(h/seis, see on O. T. 1249. Cp. above, 974.

r(oph\ bi/ou moi, the turn of the scale (momentum) for my life,—the moment which is to bring it down to death. Cp. O. T. 961 smikra\ palaia\ sw/mat' eu)na/zei r(oph/ (where see n.): Eur. Hipp. 1162
*(ippo/lutos ou)ke/t' e)/stin, w(s ei)pei=n e)/pos:
de/dorke me/ntoi fw=s e)pi\ smikra=s r(oph=s, "but his life still hangs in the trembling scale."
kai\ qe/lw qanei=n mh\ yeu/sas se po/lin te th/nde (tou/twn)

a(/per cunh/|nesa, "and I wish to die without having defrauded thee and this city of the things on which I agreed." For the constr. of yeu/sas cp. on 1145, and for the chief stress on the partic., 1038: for cunh/|n., Xen. Cyr. 4.2.47 tau=ta sunh/|noun, they agreed to these terms.

e)n tw=| de\ kei=sai: usu. explained, "And on what sign of thine end dost thou rely?" But kei=mai e)/n tini (see on 247)="to be situated in a person's power": an analogous use of kei=mai here would give us, "on what sign doth thy fate depend?" In Tr. 82, however, we have e)n ou)=n r(oph=| toia=|de keime/nw|: and, if the text be sound, kei=sai has (I think) a like sense here: lit., "at what sign of thy fate art thou in suspense?" The phrase is thus virtually equivalent to e)n ti/ni r(oph=| kei=sai;—the tekmh/rion itself standing for the crisis which it marks. The phrase seems to me possible (for our poet), but slightly suspicious. We might conjecture kai\ tw=| pe/peisai: cp. Eur. Hel. 1190
e)nnu/xois pepeisme/nh
ste/neis o)nei/rois. (To the obvious kei=tai sou=, so/n, or soi/...tekmh/rion, the objection is the phrase e)n tw=| kei=tai.)

au)toi\ with kh/rukes: the gods herald their own interposition in his fate. No ma/ntis, but Heaven itself, gi gives the warning. Cp. Bekker Anecd. 5. 14 au)tokh=ruc: o( mh\ di' e(te/rwn a)lla\ di' e(autou= khrukeu/wn. Eur. Suppl. 589 (Theseus says that he will march on Thebes) au)to\s si/dhron o)cu\n e)n xeroi=n e)/xwn, | au)to/s te kh=ruc.

yeu/dontes ou)de\n shma/twn prok., "disappointing me in no way (ou)de\n" adv., cp. 1145) of the signs appointed beforehand (94): as Her. 2.38 (of the Apis) ei) kaqarh\ (h( glw=ssa) tw=n prokeime/nwn shmhi/wn, the marks appointed by sacred law.
With the conjecture sh=ma tw=n, the sense is, "falsifying no sign of those appointed," a less usu. sense of yeu/dw, for which see Ant. 389 n.

The usual order would be ai( polla\ diatelei=s brontai/, "the long-continued thunderings." But an adj. or partic. is sometimes thus placed after the subst., when the art. and an adv. (or adverbial phrase) stands before it: cp. O. T. 1245 to
 h)/dh *la/i+on pa/lai nekro/n =to
 h)/dh pa/lai nekro
 *l., the already long-dead L.: where see n.

polla\= "very," with the adj.: cp. Ant. 1046 xoi( polla\ deinoi/: Ph. 254 w)= po/ll' e)gw\ moxqhro/s: El. 1326 w)= plei=sta mw=roi: Il. 11.557 po/ll' a)e/kwn.—The answer is framed as if Theseus had said, poi=a de\ shmei=a e)fa/nh tw=nde; If Reiske's dhlou=si (which Wecklein receives) is to be admitted, we must view L's ai( pollai\ as a mere gloss suggested by diatelei=s and conformed to ta\ polla/ te. This, however, seems very improbable, since (a) the article ta\ with be/lh recommends the art. with brontai\, and (b) the reiterated polla\ is effective.

stra/yanta. stra/ptw is not extant in classical Attic, but occurs in Apollonius Rhodius (2nd cent. B.C.) and Oppian (2nd cent. A.D.), also in an Orphic hymn of uncertain date, and in the Anthology. In cases of this kind we should always recollect how incomplete is our knowledge of the classical Attic vocabulary, and allow for the likelihood that the learned Alexandrian poets had earlier warrant for this or that word which, as it happens, we cannot trace above them. (Cp. on a)kore/statos, 120.) With a)stra/ptw and stra/ptw, cp. a)steroph/ and steroph/, a)spai/rw and spai/rw, a)stafi/s and stafi/s, a)/staxus and sta/xus, and many other instances in which the longer form and the shorter both belong to the classical age.

skh/yanta (Forster) is much less forcible: the thought is of the lightningflash breaking forth as a sign in the sky (fle/gei, 1466), rather than of its descent on earth: and this word would hardly have passed into the MS. stre/yanta.
xeiro\s th=s a)nikh/tou, gen. of point whence with str. (O. T. 152 *puqw=nos...e)/bas) rather than possess. gen. with be/lh.
qespi/zonq': as Oed. had predicted trouble from Thebes at a time when Theseus thought it impossible (606 ff.); Creon had fulfilled the prediction, and had even hinted at future war (1037).
yeudo/fhma: cp. O. T. 723 fh=mai mantikai/: ib. 43 fh/mhn=a message from a god (n.).

soi ethic dat., th=|de po/lei dat. of interest; which thou shalt have stored up for Athens. The ethic dat. is often combined with another, as [Eur.] Rhes. 644 e)xqrw=n tis h(mi=n xri/mptetai strateu/mati, we have some foeman approaching our camp. The v.l. sh=| te came of not seeing this.
gh/rws a)/lupa: see on 677 a)nh/nemon...xeimw/nwn.

xw=ron … e)chgh/somai, show the way to the place: the literal notion being blended with that of expounding (as the e)chghtai/ expounded the sacred law). Cp. Her. 3.4 e)chge/etai...th\n e)/lasin, expounds the route for the march.

a)/qiktos, pass., as always in Attic (though O. T. 969 a)/yaustos e)/gxous="not touching"): Tr. 685 a)kti=no/s t' a)ei\ | qermh=s a)/qikton. The act. sense, "not touching," occurs later (Callim. Hymn. Dian. 201).

tou=ton refers to xw=ron, the place where he was to "die," i.e. disappear. This place is accurately described at 1590. It was the grave (1545) that was to remain secret. But here, by a slip, the poet identifies them (see Introd.). We should not change tou=ton to tu/mbon. — Note how Soph. uses the vagueness of the local legend as to the grave. Secrecy was imposed by the dying breath of Oed. himself. The descent of the secret in the line of the Attic kings would serve to explain any esoteric knowledge on the subject which, in the poet's time, may have been claimed by a gens of hereditary priests.
mh/q' ou(= ke/keuqe: neither where (precisely) it is concealed, nor (even) whereabouts it is situated.

w(/s soi … tiqh=|. Like tou=ton in 1522, o(/de refers to xw=ron (1520), "this spot"; it is not for a)nh\r o(/de (450). For pro\ cp. Thuc. 1.33 h(\n u(mei=s a)\n pro\ pollw=n xrhma/twn kai\ xa/ritos e)timh/sasqe du/namin u(mi=n prosgene/sqai, au(/th pa/restin au)tepa/ggeltos. (Not, "against many shields etc.," as Xen. Anab. 7.8.18 o(/pws ta\ o(/pla e)/xoien pro\ tw=n toceuma/twn, "that they might have their shields to screen them from the arrows.") Cp. O. T. 218 n.

doro/s t' e)paktou=. As the hoplite was armed with a do/ru no less than with a shield, there is no contrast here between infantry and cavalry, but only between citizens and foreign allies. Cp. Isocr. or. 10 § 37 ou)d' e)paktw=| duna/mei (foreign mercenaries) th\n a)rxh\n diafula/ttwn, a)lla\ th=| tw=n politw=n eu)noi/a| doruforou/menos.—The old v.l. geitonw=n, "being near you," would be weak: as to the form, geitone/w is classical, though Attic prose preferred geitnia/w.

Others join a)lkh\n … geito/nwn, "a defence against neighbours" (the Thebans, 1534), but, though the objective gen. is quite correct (see on O. T. 218), the order of the words makes it hardly possible to disjoin geito/nwn from doro/s t' e)paktou=.

a(\ d' e)ca/gista, "but as to things which are banned" (which cannot be uttered without impiety). Cp. Aeschin. or. 3 § 113 oi( *lokroi\ oi( *)amfissei=s...to\n lime/na to\n e)ca/giston kai\ e)pa/raton pa/lin e)tei/xisan: "the harbour which was banned and accursed,"—the Amphictyons having pronounced an a)ra/, which said of the transgressor, e)nagh\s e)/stw (ib. § 110). The verb occurs Aesch. Ag. 641 pollou\s de\ pollw=n e)cagisqe/ntas do/mwn, many "devoted to death" out of many houses. a(gi/zw=to make a(/gios (1495): e)cagi/zw= to devote to avenging gods (cp. e)cosio/w, to dedicate), rather than (as some explain it) "to de-consecrate."

mhde\ kinei=tai lo/gw|, "and such things as (mhde/" of the class, cp. 73) are not to be touched upon in speech (see on 624 ta)ki/nht' e)/ph). Nauck proposed dei= kinei=n, but the pres. kinei=tai expresses what fate has decreed (Ph. 113 ai(rei=).
maqh/sei, by sight as well as by hearing: see 1641, 1650.
sw=|ze, "guard them," — not merely, "remember" them, a sense peculiar to the midd. sw/|zomai (Plat. Theaet. 153 B, etc., n. on O. T. 318). Cp. Ant. 1113 no/mous | … sw/|zonta ("observing").
a)fiknh=|: L's a)fi/kh| is of course impossible, the i of the aor. being long only in the indic. (cp. 1495).

tw=| proferta/tw| mo/nw|:
but to one,
Thy chiefest (Whitelaw), which well gives the vagueness of the phrase. While the hereditary monarchy lasted, the profe/rtatos would, in fact, be the king's eldest son: afterwards, it would be the man whose place in the State made him the proper guardian of the secret. The poet chose a phrase which would cover priestly tradition. I would not, then, change mo/nw|, with Nauck, to go/nw|. In fr. 401 h)= ga\r fi/lh )gw\ tw=nde tou= proferte/rou, the sense "elder" is possible, but not certain. Hes. Scut. 260 has tw=n ge me\n a)lla/wn proferh/s t' h)=n presbuta/th te, where the second adj. helps the first; Plat. Euthyd. 271 B has proferh/s, "wellgrown," of a youth, as opp. to sklhfro/s, "slight." Hom. has only profere/steros, never of age. The nearest parallel to our passage is Hes. Th. 361 proferesta/th e)sti\n a(pase/wn, foremost among the daughters of Oceanus is Styx; and at 777 she is called presbuta/th. So, here, the word suggests seniority, but without excluding pre-eminence of other kinds.
a)dh=|on contr. for a)dh/i+on, "unravaged," from dh/i+os (dh=|os Theogn. 552, always Dor. da/i+os in trag.), "ravaging" (√*d*av, whence dai/w, to kindle):

spartw=n a)p' a)ndrw=n, "on the part of," "from the quarter of" the Thebans. For a)po/, cp. Plat. Phaedo 83B ou)de\n tosou=ton kako\n e)/paqen a)p' au)tw=n. Schaefer's u(po/ is admissible (Plat. Rep. 366A a)zh/mioi...u(po\ qew=n): but a)po/ is fitter here as including all peril from that region. When Cadmus was founding Thebes, he required water from a well guarded by a dragon, the offspring of Ares. He killed the dragon, and sowed its teeth in the ground. Armed men sprang up, who slew each other, all save five. These five, of whom Echion was chief, became the ancestors of the Cadmeans. Cp. Ant. 1123
par' u(grw=n
*)ismhnou= r(ei/qrwn, a)gri/ou t'
e)pi\ spora=| dra/kontos. Pind. fr. 6 h)\ *ka/dmon, h)\ spartw=n i(ero\n ge/nos a)ndrw=n.

ai( de\ muri/ai po/leis, justifying his hint of possible danger from Thebes. "Most cities are apt (gnomic aor.) to enter on aggression with a light heart (r(a|di/ws), even though their neighbour is wellbehaved." Cp. what he said of the Thebans in 619 f., where e)k smikrou= lo/gou answers to r(a|di/ws here. So the schol.:— ka)\n dikai/ws tis politeu/htai, pollai\ po/leis a)di/kws e)pe/rxontai.

Those who suspect ai( muri/ai should observe that Greek writers often use this phrase when they wish to express the notion of many probabilities against one. Cp. Her. 8.119 e)n muri/h|si gnw/mh|si mi/an ou)k e)/xw a)nti/coon, "among ten thousand opinions I have not one against me": i.e. not one man in 10,000 would dispute it. Xen. Anab. 2.1.19 e)gw/, ei) me\n tw=n muri/wn e)lpi/dwn mi/a tis u(mi=n e)sti swqh=nai polemou=ntas basilei=, sumbouleu/w mh\ paradido/nai ta\ o(/pla: "if among the ten thousand forebodings (which the situation might suggest) there is one chance of your escape," etc. So, of "facing fearful odds," Eur. fr. 588
ei)=s toi di/kaios muri/wn ou)k e)ndi/kwn
kratei=. And so here ai( muri/ai is something more than a mere synonym for ai( pollai/. It suggests this notion:—"Be Athens never so just, there are countless chances to one that Thebes will some day attack it." (In citing Aeschin. or. 2 § 157 Blaydes has not noticed that tou\s muri/ous *)arka/dwn means the Pan-Arcadian mu/rioi, not muri/oi: cp. Grote c. 78, x. 317.)

ka)
 eu)= tis oi)kh=|: cp. Plat. Rep. 423A e(/ws a)
 h( po/lis soi oi)kh=| swfro/nws. (It might also be transitive, "governs," sc. th
 po/lin.) A compliment to Theseus and to Athens is implied: cp. 1125.

Others explain:—(1) "The majority of cities, even though one governs them well, are prone to outrage": i.e. if you divulge the secret to the Athenians, it may be abused to the hurt of the State. A modification of this view is that kaqu/brisan refers to overweening confidence inspired at Athens by the new a)lkh/. Theseus must still be watchful. (2) "The cities, with their multitudes (muri/ai"), are prone to outrage,—still referring to the Athenians. But for this sense we should at least need Wecklein's oi( de\ muri/oi po/lews.—Blaydes thought of ai( de\ mwri/as ple/ai: better would be oi( de\ mwri/as ple/w| (Ai. 1112, 1150): but neither this, nor anything with ku/rios, is either needful or probable.

ga\r refers to r(a|di/ws. "(Outrage is lightly committed), for the gods are late, though they are sure, in visiting sin," and so the hope of present impunity emboldens the wicked. See 1370. The remark is general, but Oed. is thinking especially of his unnatural sons; the divine vengeance has long been delayed, but is now at hand. Cp. Orac. Sibyll. 8. 14 o)ye\ qew=n a)le/ousi mu/loi, a)le/ousi de\ lepta/. Longfellow, "Retribution": "Though the mills of God grind slowly, yet they grind exceeding small" (from the German of F. von Logau, Sinngedichte 3. 2. 24). Hor. Carm. 3. 2. 32 pede Poena claudo.

eu)= me
 o)ye\ d). When two clauses are co-ordinated by me/n and de/, if we wish to subordinate one to the other we must take care that the subordinated clause is that which has me/n. Thus here:—"late, though surely." "Surely, though late," would be o)ye\ me
 eu)= de/. So O. T. 419 (n.) ble/ponta nu=n me
 o)/rq', e)/peita de\ sko/ton,=sightless then, though seeing now. It is the necessity of giving the chief emphasis to o)ye/, not to eu)=, that decides the true relation of this verse to the preceding.
ta\ qei=) a)fei/s, having set religion at nought: cp. O. T. 910 e)/rrei de\ ta\ qei=a.

mai/nesqai, the madness of passions which are no longer controlled by religion,—as the frenzy of ambition (371), and of hatred (1392).—I do not suppose that the poet directly alludes to any contemporary event; but we may surmise that, when he wrote these lines, he had in his thoughts the daring outrage on religion at Athens in 415 B.C.,—the partial impunity of its authors (including Alcibiades),—and the tremendous disasters of the city two years later. Cp. O. T. p. xxx, 886 n.

o(\ mh\ su\...bou/lou paqei=n, referring to ta\ qei=) a)fei/s etc. To divulge the e)ca/gista (1526) would be a)fei=nai ta\ qei=a. The next verse turns off this light reminder by adding that Theseus does not require it. "Well (ou)=n), thou knowest such things, without my precepts." Thuc. 2.43 w)feli/an, h(\n a)/n tis pro\s ou)de\n xei=ron au)tou\s u(ma=s ei)do/tas mhku/noi: ib. 36 makrhgorei=n e)n ei)do/sin ou) boulo/menos: Il. 10.250 ei)do/si ga/r toi tau=ta met' *)argei/ois a)goreu/eis. Cp. on 1038.
xw=ron: cp. 644.

tou)k qeou= paro/n: "that which has come from the god," (cp. 1694 to\ fe/ron e)k qeou=,)—the summons as conveyed both by the storm and by an inward prompting. Matthiae's ptero/n (97) would be less mysterious, and therefore, in this context, less solemn.

mhd' e)/t' e)ntrepw/meqa, "nor longer hesitate," o)knw=men, me/llwmen. e)ntre/pesqai (1) "to turn about": (2) "to give heed to," with gen., as O. T. 724: (3) then, absol., "to feel a scruple or misgiving," to hesitate, as here. Intelligible as the third use is, this is perh. the only clear example of it in classical Attic: but cp. Polyb. 31. 12 (with ref. to Demetrius son of Seleucus urging his claims before the Roman Senate), e)netre/ponto me
 a(/pantes a)kou/ontes e)n e(autoi=s, koinh=| ge mh
 e)/doce th=| sugklh/tw| to
 me
 *dhmh/trion katasxei=n, i.e. "they all felt some compunction in their own minds,"—some misgiving as to the fairness of their conduct. The hesitation which Oed. deprecates is that which the others might feel in acknowledging that the hour of his end had come.—The schol. wrongly took e)ntrep. in its first sense, "look behind us": a)nti\ tou= e)pistrefw/meqa: *(/omhros: e)ntropalizo/menos.

—1555 A more splendid dramatic effect than Sophocles has created here could hardly be conceived. Hitherto, throughout the play, Oedipus has been strongly characterised by that timidity in movement, and that sense of physical dependence, which are normal accompaniments of blindness. (Cp. 21, 173 ff., 495 ff., 1206, etc.) Now, suddenly inspired by the Unseen Power which calls him, he becomes the guide of his guides. Now it is they who shrink. Eager and unfaltering, the blind man beckons them on. And so he finally passes from the eyes of the spectators.
kaino/s, of a novel kind, "in strange wise": cp. Plat. Euthyd. 271 B kainoi/ tines...sofistai/... kai\ ti/s h( sofi/a;

th=|d), w(=de, th=|de, lit., "this way,— hither,—this way";—marking that he is already sure of his path. The number of forms from o(/de in this v. and 1546 is curious, but it is evident that the natural distribution of emphasis in speaking would avoid an unpleasing effect.

o( pompo\s: Ai. 831 kalw= d' a(/ma | pompai=on *(ermh=n xqo/nion eu)= me koimi/sai: hence yuxopompo/s (Diod. I. 96): Hor. Carm. 1. 10. 17 Tu pias laetis animas reponis Sedibus. He was also the guide of the living on errands of danger or guile (El. 1395, Ph. 133 *(e. o( pe/mpwn do/lios).

h(/ te n. qeo/s: Persephone: Ant. 893
w(=n a)riqmo\n e)n nekroi=s
plei=ston de/dektai *perse/fass' o)lwlo/twn.

fw=s a)fegge/s, light which, for the blind, is no light: cp. "darkness of life" in Tennyson's lines quoted on 33: sko/ton ble/pein, e)n sko/tw| o(ra=n (O. T. 419), 1273). The dying bid farewell to the sunlight, as Ai. 856
se\ d), w)= faennh=s h(me/ras to\ nu=n se/las
… prosenne/pw
panu/staton dh/. So here the blind man, for whom light has long been changed to darkness, bids farewell to his memory of it.

pro/sqe, before he blinded himself (cp. O. T. 1183). The full thought is,— "Once I saw thee, but for long I have only felt thee, and now I feel thee for the last time." Whitelaw cp. Par. Lost 3. 21,
Thee I revisit safe,
And feel thy sovran vital lamp; but thou
Revisit'st not these eyes. And Lear 4. 1. 23
Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
I'd say I had eyes again.

to\n teleutai=on bi/on is most simply taken (1) as="the last part of my life," its close, as (e.g.) Il. 6.40 e)n prw/tw| r(umw=|=at the end of the pole. He is going "to hide the close of his life with Hades" (par' *(/aidhn since motion is implied), not merely because he is about to quit life, but because he is destined to quit it by a strange passing not beheld of men.—(2) We might also take teleutai=on as proleptic adj. with art. (see on 1089 to\n eu)/agron): "to hide my life, so that it shall be ended." I prefer (1).
au)to/s te: cp. on 488. Theseus and his realm are identified, as 308 f., 1125, 1496.
pro/spoloi, like o)pa/ones (1103). Here his Attic lieges generally seem meant, rather than his followers from Athens as opposed to the Coloniates (1066). So 1496 se kai\ po/lisma kai\ fi/lous.
ka)p' eu)praci/a|: "and in your prosperous state,"
e)pi/ expressing the attendant condition (as it denotes the terms of a treaty): cp. El. 108 e)pi\ kwkutw=|...
div3.l: ...h)xw\...profwnei=n: Ant. 759 e)pi\ yo/goisi denna/zein: Aesch. Eum. 1047 o)lolu/cate nu=n e)pi\ molpai=s: Thuc. 7.81 § 5 e)p' eu)pragi/a| h)/dh safei= ("when success was now assured").
div3.p: me/mnhsqe, imper., not memnh=|sqe, optat.: for this depends on them, but their weal (eu)d. ge/noisqe) on the gods.
eu)tuxei=s a)ei/: (remember me), for your lasting welfare. If they duly revere his memory, their good-fortune will abide.

div2.head: 1556-1578: Fourth stasimon
div2.p: Fourth stasimon. Strophe 1556—1567=antistr. 1568—1578. See Metrical Analysis.—"May Persephone and Pluto suffer Oedipus to pass painlessly to the place of the dead. May the Erinyes and Cerberus spare to vex his path. Hear us, O Death."

div3.p: ei) qe/mis e)sti: a propitiatory address, since Pluto and the other xqo/nioi qeoi/ are stern to human prayers. So Hades is di/xa paia/nwn (Eur. I. T. 185), a)mei/lixos h)d' a)da/mastos (Il. 9.158). Hor. Carm. 2. 14. 5 Non si tricenis, quotquot eunt dies, Amice, places illacrimabilem Plutona tauris.

ta
 a)fanh= qeo
, Persephone (1548), an unusual title, perhaps suggested by the literal sense of *(/aidhs: cp. Pind. fr. 207 *tarta/rou puqmh
 pie/zei s' a)fanou=s: Aesch. Th. 859 ta
 a)na/lion | pa/ndokon ei)s a)fanh= te xe/rson (the nether-world).

e)nnuxi/wn a)/nac (Tr. 501 to\n e)/nnuxon *(/aidan), suggested by Il. 20.61 a)/nac e)ne/rwn *)ai+dwneu/s. This poetically lengthened form of *(/aidhs (trisyllabic only here) occurs also Il. 5.190 *)ai+dwnh=i+ proi+a/yein, Hes. Theog. 913, and oft. in later poets. A stream of the Troad on Mt Ida was called *)ai+dwneu/s from its disappearing into the ground, Paus. 10.12.3 f.

li/ssomai=e)c a)/ntrwn in the antistrophe (1571): but, since the first syll. of a)/ntrwn is "irrational," i.e. a long syllable doing duty for a short, the normal choree lisso is defensible. (See Metr. Analysis.) Dindorf's li/sswmai, which he calls a "modestior subiunctivi usus" (i.e. "permit me to pray"), will certainly not stand. The schol. had in his text di/dou moi,—not instead of li/ssomai, but (as his words show) in addition to it. As the construction of li/ssomai was clear enough, di/dou moi would rather seem to have been a gloss on some other imperat. with moi. Possibly neu=so/n moi (cp. Ph. 484 neu=son,... pei/sqhti: Pind. P. 1. 71 neu=son, *kroni/wn) which may have been current as a v.l. for li/ssomai.

L gives mh/t' e)pipo/nw (sic) mh/t' e)pibaruaxei=. While this verse is certainly corrupt, the antistrophic verse (1572) seems to afford firmer ground in the words fu/laka par' *(/aida|. These three words, at least, have every appearance of genuineness; and they tally metrically with e)pi\ barua_xei=. That the latter is Doric for baruhxei= is confirmed by the fact that the schol. actually uses the latter form in his note; cp. 1663 ou) stenakto/s. Brunck's a)da/maton (for MS. a)da/maston) being certain in 1572, the question then is:—How are the words mh/t' e)pipo/nw mh/t) to be so corrected that they shall metrically answer to a)da/mato_n? The absence of the i subscript agrees with the hypothesis of an original mht' e)pipo/nws. If, with Wecklein, we regard this as having been a gloss on a genuine a)/pona (adv. neut. pl., 319), and read a)/pona mhd' e)pi\ baruaxei=, an exact correspondence is obtained, without further change in the strophe, and without any change in the antistrophe. The sense is also clear.—In the Appendix other views are given.

e)pi\ baruaxei= … mo/rw|: for the prep. (="with") see on 1554. This prayer to Pluto needed the preface ei) qe/mis (1556), since he stenagmoi=s kai\ go/ois plouti/zetai (O. T. 30). Cp. Aesch. Th. 915
do/mwn ma/l' a)xa\n e)s ou)=s prope/mpei
dai+kth\r go/os.
e)canu/sai, reach: Ai. 607 a)nu/sein... *aidan: Ant. 804 to\n pagkoi/thn...qa/lamon
div3.l: ...a)nu/tousan. Eur. Or. 1684 lamprw=n a)/strwn po/lon e)canu/sas.

div3.p: pagkeuqh=, as Hades is pa/ndokos (n. 1556), polude/gmwn (H. Hymn. 5. 31), pagkoi/tas (Ant. 810), polu/koinos (Ai. 1193).
pla/ka (1577, 1681), a plain: cp. the lugentes campi of Vergil's Inferno (Aen. 6. 441).

The traditional text, pollw=n ga\r a)\n kai\ ma/tan phma/twn i(knoume/nwn, is usu. understood; "for, whereas sorrows were coming upon him in great number and without cause (kai\ ma/tan), a just god may now lift him up once more."

In this there are two difficulties. (1) i(knoume/nwn is thus the partic. of the imperf.,=e)pei\ i(knei=to. But manifestly the partic. ought here to have a pres. sense, "are coming on him." When the pres. partic. (or inf.) serves for the impf., there is usually something in the context which prevents too great ambiguity, as is the case in 1587 (parw/n), and O. T. 835 tou= paro/ntos, where see n. Cp. Xen. Anab. 5.8.1 *cenofw=ntos kathgorhsa/n tines fa/skontes pai/esqai (=o(/ti e)pai/onto) u(p' au)tou=, kai\ w(s u(bri/zontos (=o(/ti u(/brize) th\n kathgori/an e)poiou=nto. Dem. or. 20 § 119 tau=ta au)toi/ te poiei=te...kai\ tou\s progo/nous o)rgi/zesqe e)a\n mh/ tis fh=| poiei=n (=o(/ti e)poi/oun).

(2) ma/tan is strange in the sense "without cause" as="undeservedly." Another proposed version, "without any good result so far," seems inadmissible. Nor can the sense be "wildly" (temere). Hence there is ground for suspecting

kai\ ma/tan. Buecheler's pollw=n ga a)ntallaga
 phma/twn is brilliant, though the word occurs only in glossaries, and is slightly prosaic, as properly meaning "barter." But it leaves the blot i(knoume/nwn. I would suggest i(knou/menon, and, for a)
 kai\ ma/tan, au)= (or a)
) te/rmat' a)
: "now that he is coming to the goal of many sorrows." So the pl. El. 686 dro/mou...ta\ te/rmata. A doubled a)/n would not be unsuitable here, as expressing earnest hope; but au)=, which MSS. often confuse with a)/n, would well mark the turning-point: and for its combination with pa/lin cp. 1418.—Another possibility would be pollw=n ga a)
 a)llaga
 phma/twn i(knou/menon (cp. O. T. 1206 a)llaga=| bi/ou), or i(knoume/nan as="due": so oft. o( i(knou/menos xro/nos, h(liki/a, etc.

The MS. se is possible; but Reiske's sfe has very strong probability. Campbell says, "the apostrophe gives liveliness to what would otherwise be a frigid sentiment": but would it be so frigid? Changes to, and from, apostrophe are certainly not rare in choral odes; but this would (to my mind) be a somewhat harsh example;—quite different, e.g., from O. T. 1201, where see n. on 1197.
au)/coi, "uplift," raise to honour: cp. O. T. 1092 (n.), Tr. 116 (n. on 1453 f.).
xqo/niai qeai/: schol. *)erinu/es. Hardly Demeter and Persephone (683), who would not be thus associated with the fell Cerberus.

sw=ma/ t): the periphrasis suggests a more vivid image of the dread monster: cp. Tr. 508 fa/sma tau/rou: Verg. Aen. 6. 289 et forma tricorporis umbrae (Geryon). Eur. Phoen. 1508 *sfiggo\s a)oidou= sw=ma: Her. Fur. 24 trisw/maton ku/na.

a)nika/tou is sound, since the long penult. (=qe of qeo/n 1556) is an "irrational" syllable. Meineke's a)maima/kou is an unexampled form of a)maima/ketos. Cp. Tr. 1097
to/n q' u(po\ xqono\s
*(/aidou tri/kranon sku/lak', a)pro/smaxon te/ras. Homer mentions "the dog of Hades" only in reference to Eurystheus sending Heracles e)c *)ere/beus a)/conta ku/na stugerou= *)ai+/dao (Il. 8.368, Od. 11.625). The name Cerberus occurs first in Hes. Th. 311, where he is the offspring of Typhaon and Echidna, and has fifty heads: Horace makes him centiceps, Carm. 2. 13. 34. *kerbe/rioi was used (at least in comedy) as=*kimme/rioi, but the connection with e)/rebos is doubtful.

It seems clear that the fasi\ after pu/laisi in the MSS. is an interpolated gloss on lo/gos e)/xei. If fasi\ were genuine, it must go with eu)na=sqai only, knuzei=sqai depending on lo/gos e)/xei: a construction awkward beyond example. Bellermann seeks to avoid this by pointing thus,
fasi\ poluce/stois:
eu)na=sqai etc., supplying ei)=nai with fasi/: but this is even worse. The long delay of lo/gos e)/xei brought in the gloss.—In the MS. poluce/stois the long penult.=a^n of a)/nac (1559). Even if we assume an "irrational" syllable (¯ for ˘), the sense seems fatal. "Of polished stone" is surely not a good epithet for the Gates of Hell.

poluce/nois appears certain: cp. Aesch. Suppl. 157
to\n polucenw/taton
*zh=na tw=n kekmhko/twn
i(co/mesqa su\n kla/dois
a)rta/nais qanou=sai. See above on pagkeuqh= (n. 1561 ff.), and cp. Ant. 893 in n. on 1548.

While knuza=sqai is the form recommended by the analogy of like words for the sounds of animals (blhxa/omai, muka/omai, u(la/omai, etc.), knuzei=sqai has L's support, and also seems better just after eu)na=sqai. If right here, it is, however, much the rarer form of the two.
e)c a)/ntrwn: Verg. Aen. 6. 417 Cerberus haec ingens latratu regna trifauci Personat, adverso recubans immanis in antro. — Immania terga resolvit Fusus humi, totoque ingens extenditur antro.

fu/laka. Hes. Th. 767
e)/nqa qeou= xqoni/ou pro/sqen do/moi h)xh/entes …
e(sta=sin: deino\s de\ ku/wn propa/roiqe fula/ssei. He fawns on those who enter:
e)celqei=n d' ou)k au)=tis e)a=| pa/lin, a)lla\ dokeu/wn
e)sqi/ei o(/n ke la/bh|si pule/wn e)/ktosqen i)o/nta.

lo/gos … e)/xei, transitive, like Pind. P. 1. 96 e)xqra\ *fa/larin kate/xei...fa/tis, rather than intransitive like o( lo/gos kate/xei ("the report prevails that...") Thuc. 1.10 § 2. Cp. Paus. 9. 3 § 9 manteu/esqai de\ ta\s nu/mfas to\ a)rxai=on au)to/qi e)/xei lo/gos.
to/n (as relat.) is more probable than o(/n after the vowel: cp. O. T. 199 e)/rxetai: | to/n, w)= ta=n purfo/rwn.

*ga=s pai=. This cannot mean Pluto, who was the son of Cronus and Rhea; nor Cerberus (usu. called son of Typhaon and Echidna), unless with Nauck we change to/n to do/s. Thanatos is not elsewhere thus described, (in Hes. Th. 211 he is the son of *nu/c, no father being named,)—but is probably meant here. The invocation in 1578 is certainly addressed to him.

The MSS. have e)n kaqarw=| bh=nai. "And I pray that he (Cerberus) ...may leave a clear path for the stranger," as he passes to Hades. bh=nai e)n kaqarw=| tw=| ce/nw| must mean strictly, "to go on to clear ground for the stranger," i.e. to pass to ground which he will not traverse, leaving his path clear. e)n kaqarw=| is thus virtually equivalent to e)kpodw/n. Madvig's e)k kaqarou= is proleptic:—"go out of the path, so as to leave it clear." Cp. Pind. Ol. 6.23
keleu/qw| t' e)n kaqara=|
ba/somen o)/kxon: Her. 1.202 (of a river) r(e/ei dia\ kaqarou= (through an open country, where its course is not checked). So Il. 8.491 e)n kaqarw=|, in a clear space. I suspect the text to be unsound, but the data are inadequate for its certain correction. Two views are possible. (1) to/n in 1574 may be corrupt. If (e.g.) Hartung's to/d' were read, the sense would be:— "This is my prayer for the stranger..., that he may move in a clear path." Such a view best suits the natural sense of e)n kaqarw=| bh=nai. (2) to/n may be sound, while e)n kaqarw=| may have supplanted something like e)k kaqo/dou. Or bh=nai may have come (e.g.) from fqh=nai: "I pray for the stranger that he speed safely past Cerberus to clear ground."
pla/kas: see on 1564.
to\n ai)e/nupnon, Death, the giver of the a)te/rmona nh/greton u(/pnon (Moschus 3. 105): in contrast with his brother who lu/ei pedh/sas (Ai. 676).

div2.head: 1579-1779: Exodus
div2.p: Exodos. The passing of Oedipus is told. His daughters make lament. Antigone prays of Theseus that he send them to Thebes, if haply they may avert the coming strife of their brothers; and he promises to do so.

div3.p:
cuntomw/taton (neut. as adv.) is the best correction of the MS. cuntomwta/tws. A few such forms in -ws have MS. authority in good writers, though they are mostly comparatives, as bebaiote/rws, e)rrwmeneste/rws (Isocr.), kallio/nws, safeste/rws, etc. In Eur. Suppl. 967 ghra/skw dusthno/tatos | ou)/t' is corrected by Reiske to dusthnota/tws, which metre commends: but this is an almost isolated example. There is thus a strong presump tion in favour of the ordinary form where, as here, it can easily be restored.—Wecklein reads cuntomwta/twn: "I would hit on the briefest mode of speech."—Cp. O. T. 1234
o( me\n ta/xistos tw=n lo/gwn ei)pei=n te kai\
maqei=n, te/qnhke qei=on *)ioka/sths ka/ra.
le/cas … o)lwlo/ta: cp. O. T. 463 ei)=pe... tele/santa, n.

a(\ d' h)=n ta\ praxqe/nt). a(\= a(/tina: see on 1171. "But as to what the occurrences were, neither is the tale possible for me to tell in brief compass, nor (were) the events (brief) which happened there": sc. ou)/te (braxe/a h)=n) ta)/rg). That is, resolving the parataxis with ou)/te — ou)/te:—"But as to what occurred, the tale cannot be briefly told, as neither were the occurrences themselves brief."
o( mu=qos ou)k e)n braxei= pa/restin would have sufficed: fra/sai (epexeg. inf.) further defines pa/restin.

The MS. words to
 a)ei\ (or ai)ei\) certainly conceal a fault, which is perhaps very old. We cannot supply xro/non ("for ever"). Nor do I see how to
 a)ei\ bi/oton could mean, "the life of all his days" ("What life, life-long, was his," Whitelaw). The schol. gives nothing better than a fatuous interpretation of to
 a)ei\ bi/oton as to\ makro
 gh=ras. The first question is whether the fault is confined to a)ei/. (1) If so, to/n being sound, a)ei/ (a) may conceal another adv., or an adj.: as a)/rti, a)/bion, ai)no/n, a)lao/n, a)tuxh=. Of these a)lao/n is perh. least unsatisfactory. It should not be too hastily assumed that the poet would have shunned a fourfold -on. Or (b) a)ei/ may have arisen from some ancient mutilation of a)/ndra. The very simplicity of kei=non to
 a)/ndra has a solemnity which is not unfitting here; and to my mind this solution has greater probability than perhaps many would concede to it at first sight. (2) If to/n is corrupt, then there are these possibilities. (a) to
 a)ei/ may conceal one word, such (e.g.) as pa/noizun, "all-wretched," Aesch. Cho. 49. (b) to/n may have been inserted to supply a lost syllable: though against this is the fact that our MSS. often tolerate lame trimeters. This view suits (e.g.) e)kei=non a)/rti, or Hermann's kei=no/n g' e)saiei/ (to which, however, the g' is fatal). (3) It is vain to speculate on the possibility of corruptions extending beyond to
 a)ei/. The words bi/oton e)cepi/staso and kei=non (or e)kei=non) are prima facie sound. Thus (e.g.) to suggest e)kei=non e)cepi/stas' ei)saei\ bi/on would be unwarrantable. We seek to amend, not to re-write.
a)po/nw|, as they themselves had just prayed for him. Cp. the prayer of Ajax to Hermes Chthonios that he may die a)sfa/dastos (Ai. 833).
tou=t' … h)/dh means, "here we come to the point which is indeed (kai\) worthy of wonder": cp. Plat. Symp. 204B dh=lon dh\...tou=to/ ge h)/dh kai\ paidi/, o(/ti, etc.

u(fhghth=ros is supported against u(f' h(ghth=ros (a) by such examples as 83, w(s e)mou= mo/nhs pe/las, (b) by the fact that the compound with u(po/ is suitable where, as here, the sense is that no one so much as hinted or indicated the way. Cp. Plat. Crito 54E pra/ttwmen tau/th|, e)peidh\ tau/th| o( qeo\s u(fhgei=tai. So O. T. 966 w(=n u(fhghtw=n ("on whose showing"): ib. 1260 w(s u(fhghtou= tinos.

katarra/kthn (from r(a/ssw to strike hard, or dash, cp. 1503), lit. "dashing or rushing down"; Strabo 10. 640 thrh/sas katarra/kthn o)/mbron: here, of a cleft descending abruptly into the ground. Strabo applies the word to the cataracts of the Nile (called kata/doupoi by Her.): in this sense it is usu. spelt with one r, as if from katara/ssw: so Lucan 10. 317 praecipites cataractae. Cp. Plut. Mor. 781 E oi)/khma qu/ran e)/xon e)pirrakth/n, a room with a trap-door in it: so too Arat. 26 qu/ra| katarrakth=|. The v.l. katafra/kthn (Suidas) is worthless.

xalkoi=s ba/qroisi. Il. 8.13
e)s *ta/rtaron h)ero/enta,
th=le ma/l', h(=xi ba/qiston u(po\ xqono/s e)sti be/reqron,
e)/nqa sidh/reiai/ te pu/lai kai\ xa/lkeos ou)do/s. Hes. Theog. 811
(of Tartarus) e)/nqa de\ marma/reai/ te pu/lai kai\ xa/lkeos ou)do/s,
a)stemfh/s, r(i/zh|si dihneke/essin a)rhrw/s,
au)tofuh/s: "a brazen threshold, immoveable, fixed in the earth by roots without a break, of natural growth," i.e. not wrought by human hands. The rift or cavern at Colonus, from which the adjoining region took the name of the xalkou=s o)do/s (see on 57), was locally supposed to be connected with the "brazen threshold" below by brazen steps reaching down into the under-world. The stress laid on the xalkoi=s ba/qroisi here, and the name "Brazen Threshold" itself, rather suggest that the myth was visibly symbolised by some artificial steps made at the top of the steep rift.
gh=qen, as Od. 13.163 la=an e)/qhke kai\ e)rri/zwsen e)/nerqen (Poseidon petrifying the Phaeacian ship).

polusxi/stwn. Several paths converged at the katarra/kths o)do/s. Oedipus halted (e)/sth) near the o)do/s, i.e. just before the path which he was following met the others. We are reminded, perhaps designedly, of that sxisth\ o(do/s in Phocis at which the misfortunes of his early manhood began (O. T. 733).

koi/lou … krath=ros. (1) Schneidewin takes this to mean a large brazen vessel set in a rift of the ground, over which Theseus and Peirithous slew the victims when they made their pact (o(/rkia e)/tamon). He cites Eur. Suppl. 1201, where Theseus is directed thus to make a covenant with Adrastus; the throats of nine sheep are to be cut over a bronze tri/pous, and the terms of the pact (o(/rkoi) are then to be graven in its basin (tri/podos e)n koi/lw| ku/tei). (2) The schol., whose view is more likely, understands a basin or hollow in the rock: koi/lou pe/las krath=ros: tou= muxou=: ta\ ga\r koi=la ou(/tws e)ka/loun e)k metafora=s: o(/qen kai\ ta\ e)n th=| *ai)/tnh| koilw/mata krath=res kalou=ntai. Cp. Arist. De Mundo 6 tw=n e)n *ai)/tnh| krath/rwn a)narrage/ntwn. Plat. Phaedo 111D says of the subterranean cavities, suntetrh=sqai/ te pollaxh=|...kai\ dieco/dous e)/xein, h(=| polu\ me\n u(/dwr r(ei=n e)c a)llh/lwn ei)s a)llh/lous w(/sper ei)s krath=ras. The scholiast adds:—le/gei di' ou(= (sc. muxou=) katabh=nai fasi\ th\n *ko/rhn a(rpagei=san. That is, the schol. took this krath/r or muxo/s in the rock to be the actual cavity in which the katarra/kths o)do/s began. In each case the krath/r was close to the o)do/s.

*qhse/ws. Theseus went down to Hades with Peirithous, king of the Thessalian Lapithae, to help him in carrying off Persephone. Both heroes were made prisoners by Pluto. Theseus was afterwards delivered by Heracles, when sent by Eurystheus to capture Cerberus. According to another version, adopted by Eur. in his *peiri/qous, Heracles delivered Peirithous also.

*peri/qou. Elsewhere in extant classical literature the form is *peiri/qoos or (Attic) *peiri/qous. But a form *peri/qous is sufficiently attested by the name of the Attic deme of which this hero was eponymus. Harpocr. *periqoi=dai: dh=mo/s e)sti th=s *oi)nhi+/dos. Aeschin. or. 1 § 156 *periklei/dhn to\n *periqoi/dhn: and so [Dem.] or. 50 § 41. Eustathius (101. 3) notices both forms, and Dindorf ascribes *peri/qoun to the Paris MSS. of Georgius Syncellus (the Byzantine chronographer, 800 A.D.), p. 299. 11: vases and inscriptions also give it. There is no need, then, to write *peiri/qou *qhse/ws te, as Blaydes does.

kei=tai … cunqh/mata: schol. oi(=on u(pomnh/mata th=s pi/stews h(=s e)/qento pro\s a)llh/lous: i.e. he understood by kei=tai some visible memorial. This seems clearly right. The local belief probably pointed to characters or marks on the rock. See the schol. on Aristoph. Eq. 785 e)/sti de\ kai\ a)ge/lastos pe/tra kaloume/nh para\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, o(/pou kaqi/sai fasi\ *qhse/a me/llonta katabai/nein ei)s *(/a|dou. Leake (Demi I. 635) conjectured that this pe/tra may have marked the place (xwri/on) mentioned by Paus. 1.18.4 as near the temple of Sarapis, S.E. of the acropolis, e)/nqa *peiri/qoun kai\ *qhse/a sunqeme/nous e)s *lakedai/mona kai\ u(/steron e)s *qesprwtou\s stalh=nai le/gousin. But the expeditions named there are distinct from the descent to Hades with which the schol. connects the pe/tra. And, wherever this a)ge/lastos pe/tra was, there must have been a cavern suggestive of the descent to Hades. The schol.'s phrase, para\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, would cover Colonus.

Others understand: "where the compact has been made" (kei=tai=pf. pass. of ti/qhmi),—a lively way of saying, "was made," e)te/qh: but this is improbable.— Wecklein conjectures *peri/qw| kalei=tai: "where men say that the compact of Th. with P. was made": the dat. as Tr. 668 tw=n sw=n *(hraklei= dwrhma/twn: the verb as Simonides fr. 107 e)/nqa kalei=tai...*)arte/midos...te/menos. (Cp. on O. T. 1451.) This idiom, however, elsewhere always refers to places, not to acts.

(1) With L's e)f) ou(=: "At which (the krath/r") he halted, midway between the other objects. Cp. Il. 22.153 e)/nqa d' e)p' au)ta/wn plunoi\ eu)re/es e)ggu\s e)/asin, at the springs. With e)f), L's me/sou is possible; "at which, midway as it is." (2) With Brunck's a)f) ou(=, it becomes necessary to read me/sos. The krath/r is then one of four points from which the point denoted by me/sos is measured. The second a)po/ may be taken with a)xe/rdou also: cp. O.T. 734, 761.
me/sos usu. takes a simple gen. of the extremes, and is not elsewhere found with a)po/, but the latter is natural (Plat. Parm. 145 B to/ ge me/son i)/son tw=n e)sxa/twn a)pe/xei).

tou= te *qoriki/ou pe/trou. It was from Thoricus (Apollod. 2. 4. 7) that "radiant Eos caught up Cephalus to the gods" (Eur. Hipp. 455). Hence the name of that place may have been associated in the Athenian mind with the idea of removal to another world. *qoriko/s (so Her., Xen., etc.: *qo/rikos schol.) was a town and deme of Attica, belonging to the tribe *)akamanti/s, on the S.E. coast, about 6 miles N. of Sunium, and 42 S.E. of Colonus. It was reckoned among the twelve towns of the old Attic dodecapolis, and, to judge by the ruins, was a considerable place down to late times (Leake, Demi II. 17—22). If *qoriki/ou is unsound, the familiarity of *qori/kioi as a deme-name may have suggested it. Schneidewin's trikoru/fou rests on the schol. to 57: kai/ tis tw=n xrhsmopoiw=n fhsi/:
*boiwtoi\ d' i(/ppoio potistei/xousi *kolwno/n,
e)/nqa li/qos trika/ranos e)/xei kai\ xa/lkeos ou)do/s. But, if *qoriki/ou came from trikoru/fou, the genuine word must have been well-nigh obliterated.

koi/lhs t' a)xe/rdou: schol. th=s to\n puqme/na e)xou/shs u(po/kenon, sape/nta. The wild pear gave its name to the Attic deme *)axerdou=s (*)axerdou/sioi); as in its other form, a)xra/s, to *)axradi/nh, the E. quarter of Syracuse. If, as the schol. states (n. 1593), the local myth placed the rape of Persephone here, this old tree may have been pointed out as the spot whence she was snatched. An e)rineo/s (wild figtree) by the Cephisus was connected with a like legend (Paus. 1.38.5). A wild olive-tree (ko/tinos) at Troezen was associated with the disaster of Hippolytus (2. 32. 10), as the strepth\ e)lai/a at Epidaurus (see on 694) with Heracles.

ka)po\ lai+/nou ta/fou. Dobree's kau)tolai+/nou ("of natural rock," cp. on 192) is more ingenious than probable. Cp. Eur. Helen 962 to/nde la/i+non ta/fon: El. 328 mnh=ma la/i+non patro/s. The la/i+nos ta/fos is opposed to a tu/mbos of earth or a la/rnac of wood (Thuc. 2.34): it would commonly denote an oblong monument with a flat slab (tra/peza) on top, the sides being sometimes sculptured.

The power and beauty of this passage are in no way lessened for us because we know nothing of the basin or the stone, the tree or the tomb. Rather it might be said that the very fact of our ignorance illustrates the spirit in which these details are introduced. Their significance is essentially local: tau=ta gnw/rima toi=s e)gxwri/ois (schol.). They show us how the blind man, who had never been at Colonus before, placed himself at precisely the due point in the midst of its complex sanctities. The god made him as one who had the most intimate and minute knowledge of the ground.
e)/luse, as Tr. 924 lu/ei to\n au(th=s pe/plon: while the midd. in Il. 17.318 lu/onto de\ teu/xea refers to Greeks stripping Trojans.
duspinei=s: cp. 1258. He prepares to put on the garb of the dead.

r(utw=n (r(e/w), flowing, e)c a)eiru/tou krh/nhs (469). Cp. Theophr. Causs. Plantt. 2. 6. 3 (with ref. to correcting the properties of water by mixing different kinds), di' o(\ polla/kis a)
 a(rmo/seie lepto
 kai\ kaqaro
 mh\ kaqarw=| kai\ paxei=, kai\ freatiai=on namatiai/w| (well water with river water), kai\ r(uto
 kai\ o)/mbrion (spring or rain water) limnai/w| kai\ a(plw=s stasi/mw|.
They go to a hillock a little way off, on which was a shrine of Demeter Euchloös. See map in Introd.

eu)xlo/ou, as protecting the young green corn and other young vegetation (xlo/h), Paus. 1.22.3 e)/sti de\ (at Athens) kai\ *gh=s kourotro/fou kai\ *dh/mhtros i(ero\n *xlo/hs. She was associated with *gh= kourotro/fos and with Apollo in the *xlo/eia held on 6th Thargelion (latter part of May). Other names given to Demeter as protectress of crops, etc., expressed the ills which she averted, as kau=stis, a)zhsi/a (parcher), e)rusi_/bh (mildew), e(lh/ghris (popularly referred to ei(/lh, sunshine, but doubtful).

proso/yion, not found elsewhere, is read by L and Suidas. "The hill of Demeter, in full view": rather than, "the hill looking on Demeter." The act. sense is possible (Ph. 1040 qeoi/ t' e)po/yioi), but the other seems better here: cp. Ant. 1110 o(rma=sq'...ei)s e)po/yion to/pon.

)po/reusan and po/reusan are alike admissible in this r(h=sis (cp. 1606 ff.), but the former seems preferable on the general principle of not multiplying omissions of augment without necessity. (Cp. Tr. 560 misqou= )po/reue.) "Brought this behest," i.e. the water for which he had asked. Eur. Phoen. 984 *m*e*n. xrhma/twn de\ ti/s po/ros; | *k*p. e)gw\ poreu/sw xruso/n. Cp. on 1458 po/roi.
taxei= su\n xr.: cp. 885: Tr. 395 su\n xro/nw| bradei= molw/n.
loutroi=s, as the dead were washed: Lucian De Luctu 11 meta\ tau=ta de\ lou/santes au)tou\s...proti/qentai. So Ai. 1405 loutrw=n o(si/wn (for the dead Ajax).

h(=| nomi/zetai, as the dead were usually dressed for burial, i.e. in white. Artemidorus Oneir. 2. 3 a)ndri\ de\ nosou=nti leuka\ e)/xein i(ma/tia qa/naton proagoreu/ei, dia\ to\ tou\s a)poqano/ntas e)n leukoi=s e)kfe/resqai.

panto\s … drw=ntos. (1) Usu. explained:—"when he had content of all service," i.e. when his daughters had done for him all that he wished. Then pa=n drw=n will be "every activity" of attendants: cp. the Homeric drhsth=res, drh/steirai, of servants, Od. 10.349 etc. (2) A better view is: "when of doing all he had content" (as Whitelaw), when pa=n drw=n is his own activity. Cp. to\ boulo/menon th=s gnw/mhs and similar phrases (see on 267): also Thuc. 1.142 e)n tw=| mh\ meletw=nti, "in the absence of practice." As to Tr. 196 to\ ga\r poqou=n e(/kastos e)kmaqei=n qe/lwn,—where to\ poqou=n used to be explained as "the desire within him,"—it is now generally held to be corrupt (E. Thomas conjectures ta\ ga\r poqei/n)). But the absence of the art. makes pa=n drw=n a bolder expression than any of these; nor can the adverbial e)n a)mei/bonti, "alternately," (Pind. N. 11. 42) be properly compared. I suspect, then, that the text is corrupt. To Mekler's conjecture (see cr. n.) the obstacle is e)/drwn instead of e)/drasan. The obvious e)/rwtos ("desire") should not be too lightly rejected: cp. 436.
a)rgo\n, neglected: see on O. T. 287.
ktu/phse: for the omission of the augment, see on O. T. 1249.

*zeu\s xq.: Il. 9.457 *zeu/s te kataxqo/nios kai\ e)painh\ *persefo/neia. At Corinth Pausanias saw three images of Zeus, one being *xqo/nios, another *(/uyistos, the third nameless (2. 2. 8). The Zeus Chthonios was a benevolent Pluto, associated with Demeter in the prayers of the husbandman (Hes. Op. 465).

ou)d' a)ni/esan, "did not remit" (cp. a)nie/nai fulakh/n, a)/skhsin, e)/xqran, etc.); not, "did not send up" (as in O. T. 1277, a different context). klauqmo/s was commonly associated with kommo/s (planctus) and go/os. If Soph. had meant otherwise, he would have added another verse with a)lla/.
pammh/keis, very loud: see on 489.
e)cai/fnhs, because they burst into their wail when the sudden peal of thunder was heard.
pa/nta ta)ma/, all that concerns my earthly life.
th\n duspo/n.: cp. 509: Aesch. Pers. 515 w)= duspo/nhte dai=mon.
a)mf' e)moi\: cp. El. 1143 quoted on 345;
trofh/n, ib. and 352.
sklhra\n, in appos.; cp. 1173.
a)lla\ … ga\r, "but (I need not speak of hardship), for":="but indeed": cp. on 988.
e(/n … e)/pos, "one word," viz. filei=n. Cp. Ant. 53 mh/thr kai\ gunh/, diplou=n e)/pos. (This is better than "one saying," i.e. reflection.)
lu/ei, cancels.

thtw/menai: cp. on 1200.— The simplest view of the MS. to\ loipo
 h)/dh bi/oton dia/ceton is Elmsley's, that bi/oton was written by a mistake for to
 bi/on. (The error here affords no ground for suspecting bi/oton in 1584.) But tou= bi/ou (Suidas) is equally possible: cp. O. T. 1487 noou/menos ta\ loipa\ tou= pikrou= bi/ou. The constr. to
 loipo
...tou= bi/ou would be a rare one: Dem. or. 15 § 16 pro\s to
 loipo
 tou= xro/nou, Xen. Cyr. 4.5.1 tou= si/tou...to
 h(/misun: so h( pollh\ th=s gh=s, etc.
e)p' a)llh/l. a)mfik.: i.e. each of the daughters had twined her arms about her father, while he had also embraced them. Cp. Od. 8.523 w(s de\ gunh\ klai/h|si fi/lon po/sin a)mfipesou=sa.
lu/gdhn from lu/zw, singultare. Anthol. Pal. 15. 28. 3 lige/ws o)lofu/reto mh/thr, | lu/gdhn, i(stame/nh.

siwph/, a moment of absolute stillness, after the wails had subsided. Job iv. 15 "Then a spirit passed before my face; the hair of my flesh stood up. It stood still, but I could not discern the appearance thereof; a form was before mine eyes: there was silence, and I heard a voice."

tino\s: Eur. Andr. 1147
pri\n dh/ tis a)du/twn e)k me/swn e)fqe/gcato
deino/n ti kai\ frikw=des.

qw/u+cen au)to/n. Porson on Eur. Phoen. 5 wished to read qew=n e)qw/u+c) (omitting au)to/n). But the change is unnecessary, if occasional omission of the augment is conceded to such r(h/seis as this: cp. 1606. qwu+/ssw denotes a loud, urgent cry (cp. Eur. Hipp. 219 kusi\ qwu+/cai): here with acc. of the person called.
pa/ntas, subject to sth=sai. For this phrase, instead of pa=si sth=nai tri/xas, see on 150 futa/lmios. Cp. 1464.
fo/bw| is causal dat. with sth=sai, rather than modal dat. with dei/santas, so that we should not compare Tr. 176 fo/bw|... tarbou=san: O. T. 65 u(/pnw| g' eu(/donta.
e)cai/fnhs, though it has come in 1623 (and 1610): see on 554.

polla\ pollaxh=|, "with repeated and manifold calling." There seems to be no genuine instance of pollaxh=| meaning simply polla/kis. It is always "by many routes" (as Xen. Anab. 7.3.12), "in many ways" (Her. 6.21), or "on many grounds" (id. 1. 42). The phrase here, then, cannot mean "loudly (polla/) and often": nor can it be merely, "again and again." But pollaxh=| need not refer to different forms of words. It is enough to understand it of varying tones in which the name was sounded, or of the voice seeming to come from different points at successive moments.

It is strange that a modern critic should have thought this "alienissimum a divina maiestate" (Schaefer). He must have forgotten that a divine summons had already been thrice repeated when "the LORD came, and stood, and called as at other times, Samuel, Samuel."

w)= ou(=tos. So the goddess Athena, calling Ajax to come forth from his tent; Ai. 71 ou(=tos, se\ to\n ta\s etc.: 89 w)= ou(=tos, *ai)/as, deu/tero/n se proskalw=, where *ai)/as is voc. (ib. 482), as *oi)di/pous here (cp. 461).

ou(=tos ("Ho there!"), thus used, implies that the person addressed is not duly heeding the speaker; here it helps to express impatience. So, when Medea turns her face away from Jason's smooth words, he cries to her, au(/th, ti/ xlwroi=s dakru/ois te/ggeis ko/ras; etc. (Med. 922). There is nothing of roughness in the phrase, except in the particular combination ou(=tos su/ (O. T. 532, 1121: Eur. Hec. 1280).
xwrei=n: cp. the emphatic place of dei=cai, O. T. 278. Nauck's me/llomen; | xw/rei: by the change to the singular number, breaks the companionship of Oedipus with the Unseen.

ta)po\ sou= adv., bradu/netai pass. impers.: delay is made on thy part. Cp. Eur. Tro. 74 e(/toim' a(\ bou/lei ta)p' e)mou=: Ar. Plut. 100 a)/feton me nu=n: i)/ston ga\r h)/dh ta)p' e)mou= (for in both places it is a)po/ rather than e)pi/). Cp. 293.

oi(, ethic dat., "for him," as a grace to him: cp. 81. The enclitic almost adheres to molei=n, while gh=s is naturally drawn to a)/nakta: thus the two monosyllables in the 3rd foot do not hurt the rhythm.—Theseus, with attendants, had followed Oed. to the o)do/s (see 1589), but had remained apart while the daughters ministered to their father (1598—1603). He is now summoned to approach them.

o(rki/an, the conjecture of P. N. Papageorgius, is the best emendation of the certainly corrupt a)rxai/an. It gives exactly what we need, viz. such an epithet for pi/stin as marks the special solemnity of the pledge. Cp. Plat. Legg. 843A fili/an te kai\ e)/xqran e)/norkon. The occurrence of o(/rkios in 1637 cannot be made an objection (cp. 544 n.); on the contrary, it rather confirms o(rki/an here. Theseus did just what Oedipus asked.

a)rxai/an has been explained as follows: —(1) "Thy right hand, that time-honoured pledge." I agree with Campbell and Bellermann that this is the best version: indeed, I should be disposed to say, the only sound one. But in such a context we surely want something more than so general an epithet. (2) Thy pledge, "which some day will be old," i.e. which you are sure to observe permanently. Herm. supports this extraordinary "prolepsis" by Aesch. Ag. 579, where, however, a)rxai=on ga/nos is rather, "the traditional ornament" of temples (spoils): unless we should read (do/mois) a)rxai/ois. (3) "A pledge of such good faith as you have always observed" (fides perpetuo apud te usu sacrata, Ellendt). (4) A modification of the last view refers a)rxai/an to v. 631, as="the pledge given at the beginning (of our intercourse)." It is impossible to accept any one of these interpretations.

(1) Two other conjectures claim notice. a)rqmi/an (Wecklein)="in a friendly compact." Cp. Od. 16.427 oi( d' h(mi=n a)/rqmioi h)=san, "they were in amity with us." In Ph. 1132 Erfurdt has restored a)/rqmion (as ="trusty comrade") for a)/qlion. But this epithet does not strengthen pi/stin. (2) a)rki/an (L. Schmidt)="sure." The only support for this is the epic phrase misqo\s a)/rkios (Il. 10.304, Od. 18.358, Hes. Op. 368).

e(kw/n, "if thou canst help it": cp. Plat. Prot. 345D o(\s a)
 e(kw
 mhde
 kako
 poih=|: in prose more often with ei)=nai added, as Symp. 214 E e(kw
 ga ei)=nai ou)de
 yeu/somai: almost always in sentences which contain or imply a negative: but Her. 7.164 has e(kw/n te ei)=nai kai\ deinou= e)pio/ntos ou)deno\s...kataqei\s th
 a)rxh/n.
me/llh|s, sc. telei=n:

fronw=n eu)=, "wishing them well." Cp. O. T. 1066 kai\ mh\n fronou=sa/ g' eu)= ta\ lw=|sta/ soi le/gw. "To do all that, as their well-wisher, thou seemest likely (to do) with advantage to them." As a well-wisher will do his best,
eu)= fronw=n thus practically means, "to the best of thy judgment"; but that is not the first sense of the words.

ou)k oi)/ktou me/ta, without making lamentation,—controlling his feelings in presence of the afflicted girls. Vauvilliers: "oi)=ktos" hic est quod nos Galli dicimus foiblesse. Cp. Plat. Phaedo 117C kai\ h(mw=n oi( polloi\ te/ws me\n e)pieikw=s oi(=oi/ te h)=san kate/xein to\ mh\ dakru/ein, w(s de\ ei)/domen pi/nonta/ te kai\ pepwko/ta, (that Socrates had drunk the hemlock,) ou)ke/ti, a)ll' e)mou= ge bi/a| kai\ au)tou= (in spite of myself) a)stakti\ e)xw/rei ta\ da/krua. If the men of the old Greek world were more easily moved to tears than modern men, at least they knew very well when a man is bound to repress his emotion, if he can. Why, then, obliterate a noble touch by changing oi)/ktou—as Wecklein does with Wex and Bothe — to the wretchedly feeble o)/knou?
o(/rkios: Ant. 305 o(/rkios de/ soi le/gw: Ph. 811 ou) mh/n s' e)/norkon a)ciw= qe/sqai.

a)maurai=s, "dark," not guided by eyes: cp. 182 a)maurw=| | kw/lw|. Not "feeble" (1018), for no increase of physical weakness is among the signs that his end is near: rather is he lifted above his former helplessness (1587).

tla/sas … to\ gennai=on freni\, "ye must make a brave effort of the mind, and depart": to\ gennai=on, acc. governed by tla/sas. It might also be adv., like ka/mnonti to\ kartero/n Theocr. 1. 41, but an absolute use of tla/sas seems slightly less probable here.

freni\, in or with it. L's fe/rein is conceivably genuine, but in that case to\ gennai=on can hardly be so. Bellermann combines them by rendering, "that which it is noble to bear." This will not serve: nor yet this, "to bear what is noble." Wecklein suggests tre/fein: "having brought yourselves to cherish fortitude." But since the effort demanded is one of moral courage, I do not see why the addition of freni/ to tla/sas should offend.
a(\ mh\: "such things as 'tis not lawful," etc.: cp. 73.
fwnou/ntwn, masc.

o( ku/rios, the master, he who has control of all; since to him alone the e)ca/gista (1526) are to be confided. The word has a further fitness here, since the maidens had been committed to the care of Theseus (cp. n. on O. T. 1506).
ei)shkou/samen, simply "heard" (rather than "obeyed"), as Ant. 9, Ai. 318, Tr. 351, 424.—Wecklein suggests fwnh/sanq' o(/t), with omission of a)stakti\... ste/nontes.
cu/mpantes, the attendants of Theseus, who had remained apart when their master was summoned to approach Oedipus (1630).
a)stakti\: see on 1251.

e)capei/domen. This compound occurs only here, but is not intrinsically more questionable than the Homeric e)capobai/nw, e)capodu/nw, etc. While e)cora=n="to see at a distance" (used in pass. by Eur. Her. 675 etc.), a)fora=n alone usu. =merely "to regard": hence the double compound is really less pleonastic than those just mentioned. So e)kprotima=n occurs only in Ant. 913.

to
 a)/ndra to
 me
: "we saw Oedipus,—him, I say,— no longer present anywhere, but Theseus, etc." The to
 me
 comes in, by an afterthought, to prepare the distinction: cp. Od. 1.115
ei) poqen e)lqw

mnhsth/rwn tw=n me
 ske/dasin kata\ dw/mata qei/h,
timh
 d' au)to\s e)/xoi: "make a scattering of the wooers,—those men there,—in the house, but himself have honour," etc.
au)to\n, "alone": Aristoph. Ach. 504 au)toi\ ga/r e)smen ou(pi\ *lhnai/w| t' a)gw/n (citizens without foreigners): cp. O. T. 221 n.
o)mm. (object. gen.)
e)pi/skion, predicative, w(/ste e)piskia/zein ta\ o)/mmata.

a)nte/xonta, holding over against, from the primary sense of a)nti/: so with dat. (o)/mmasi) Ph. 830. —Perhaps nothing else in Greek literature leaves on the mind an impression so nearly akin to that of the awful vision in Job (iv. 15, 16).

gh=n te … kai\ … *)/olumpon. Theseus bows down and kisses the earth, then suddenly rises, and with upturned face stretches forth his hands towards the sky. The vision which he had just seen moved him to adore both the xqo/nioi and the u(/patoi. This touch is finely conceived so as to leave the mystery unbroken. Cp. Ph. 1408 stei=xe prosku/sas xqo/na: Ant. 758 to/nd' *)/olumpon (the heaven above us).
e)n tau)tw=| lo/gw|, "in the same address (or prayer)," i.e. one immediately after the other: not, "on the same account."
e)ce/pracen, like dieirga/sato, diexrh/sato, confecit, "took his life"; cp. Eur. Hec. 515 pw=s kai/ nin e)cepra/cat); "how indeed did ye take her life?"

ponti/a qu/ella kinhqei=sa, "a whirlwind from the sea, suddenly aroused,"—so as to sweep inland on Colonus, and snatch him out of men's sight. For the locative force of ponti/a as=ponto/qen, cp. on 119 e)kto/pios. Cp. Il. 6.345
(Helen's wish) w(/s m' o)/fel' h)/mati tw=| o(/te me prw=ton te/ke mh/thr
oi)/xesqai profe/rousa kakh\ a)ne/moio qu/ella
ei)s o)/ros h)\ ei)s ku=ma polufloi/sboio qala/sshs.
pompo/s: cp. 1548.

h)\ to\ nerte/rwn gh=s ba/qron, the nether world on which the upper world rests. gh=s ba/qron, earth's firm floor, rocky base: cp. Milton, "Hymn on the Nativity," And cast the dark foundations deep. So Ai. 860 e(sti/as ba/qron is the ground on which the home stands.

a)lu/phton, the MS. reading, is incomparably better than the variant a)la/mpeton, which I believe to have been merely one of those conjectures in which the old transcribers and commentators sometimes indulged. By a)lu/phton the poet meant, "without pain" (to Oed.); though it does not follow that he used the word with definite consciousness of an active sense. Cp. Ph. 687 a)mfiplh/ktwn r(oqi/wn, the billows that beat around him: O. T. 969 a)/yaustos, "not touching," etc. (ib. 885 a)fo/bhtos, "not fearing," is not properly similar, since e)fobh/qhn was deponent). Plat. Legg. 958E ta\ tw=n teteleuthko/twn sw/mata ma/lista a)luph/tws toi=s zw=si... kru/ptein, to bury the dead with least annoyance to the living. The passive sense, "not pained,"—i.e., where all earthly pain is over,—seems less suitable. Pollux 3. 98 says, *pla/twn de\ kai\ a)lu/phtos e)/xei, w(/sper kai\ *sofoklh=s a)lu/phton: where, since Plat. has the word only in the place just cited, a)lu/phtos should perh. be a)luph/tws. The second ref. seems to indicate this passage, rather than Tr. 168 zh=n a)luph/tw| bi/w|, and, if so, proves the existence of the reading as early at least as c. 160 A.D.
a)la/mpeton (instead of a)lampe/s) is not attested for the classical age, though it occurs in later poetry (Anthol. P. 9. 540, etc.), as does also a subst. lampe/ths.

ou) stenakto\s, "not with wailing." Some assume a definitely active sense, "not wailing"; see last n., and add mempto/s "blaming" (Tr. 446). Others make it definitely passive, "not bewailed." The thought is that his end was "not accompanied by stenagmoi/", and the poet probably meant to suggest both ideas. Cp. on swth/rion 487.
su\n no/sois: cp. O. T. 17 su\n gh/ra| barei=s.

a)lgeino\s, associated with a)/lgos, here as feeling, not as causing, it: thus only here. Analogous is Pind. Ol. 1.26 kaqarou= le/bhtos, the cauldron of cleansing, where Fennell cp. Theocr. 24. 95 kaqarw=| de\ purw/sate dw=ma qeei/w|.

ei) de\ mh\ dokw=, "But if I seem not to speak with understanding" (i.e. if my narrative is thought incredible and foolish), "I would not crave belief from those to whom I seem not sane."—ou)k a)\n parei/mhn. pari/emai="to win over to one's own side," and so either (1) with gen. of pers., Plat. Rep. 341B ou)de/n (adv.) sou pari/emai, I ask no favour, no mercy, from you: or (2) with acc. of pers., Legg. 742 B pare/menos...tou\s a)/rxontas a)podhmei/tw, "when he has persuaded the rulers,"—obtained their permission: so again ib. 951 A. Here it seems better to understand tou/twn than tou/tous. He scorns to deprecate their unbelief. Eur. Med. 892 parie/mesqa (I crave pardon) kai/ famen kakw=s fronei=n.—His closing words mark his own profound belief in the reality of what he has seen. Cp. El. 550
ei) de\ soi\ dokw= fronei=n kakw=s
gnw/mhn dikai/an sxou=sa, tou\s pe/las ye/ge. Ai. 1038
o(/tw| de\ mh\ ta/d' e)sti\n e)n gnw/mh| fi/la,
kei=no/s t' e)kei=na sterge/tw, ka)gw\ ta/de. Ant. 469
soi\ d' ei) dokw= nu=n mw=ra drw=sa tugxa/nein,
sxedo/n ti mw/rw| mwri/an o)fliska/nw. To the ancient Greek, who enjoyed discussion, there was something peculiarly impressive in declining it.
xoi( prope/my.: meaning Theseus (295 n.), though the plur. might also be explained of Theseus with his attendants (1646).
a)sh/mones=a)/shmoi, only here.

div2.head: 1670-1750: Commos
div2.p: 1st str. 1670 —1696=1st antistr. 1697—1723. 2nd str. 1724—1736=2nd antistr. 1737—1750. See Metrical Analysis.

div3.p: ai)ai=, feu=. To delete feu= here seems a less probable remedy than to supply toi in 1697, where the neighbourhood of kai\ may have caused its loss.

e)/stin e)/sti nw=|n dh/. The passage is simple if it is only remembered that ou) to\ me/n, a)/llo de\ mh/ is an adverbial phrase, equivalent to pantelw=s. "It is indeed for us twain in no incomplete sense to bewail the accurst blood of our father which was born in us, hapless that we are." While he lived, they suffered with him. Now, his fate has snatched him from them in strange and terrible sort, leaving them destitute.

ou) to\ me/n, a)/llo de\ mh/ (mh/, instead of ou), because it goes with the inf. stena/zein), "not in one respect merely, with the exception of some other"; not merely partially. This phrase is frequent where the notion of completeness or universality is to be brought out with greater emphasis than would be given by the mere use of pa=s or like words. Aesch. Pers. 802 sumbai/nei ga\r ou) ta\ me\n ta\ d' ou)/, i.e. "for our disasters are complete." Her. 1.139 ou) ta\ me/n, ta\ d' ou)/, a)lla\ pa/nta o(moi/ws: so id. 2. 37: Phocylides fr. 1 *le/rioi kakoi/, ou)x o( me/n, o(\s d' ou)/, | pa/ntes: Eur. Phoen. 1641
ou) ga\r to\ me/n soi baru\ kakw=n, to\ d' ou) baru/,
a)ll' ei)s a(/panta dustuxh\s e)/fus, pa/ter: Plat. Rep. 475B, etc. The idiom strikingly illustrates three tendencies of Greek; (1) love of antithesis, (2) love of parataxis, (3) the tendency to treat whole clauses as virtually adverbs (cp. ou)k e)/sq' o(/pws ou), oi)=d' o(/ti, etc.).
e)/mfuton, "planted in us at our birth": whereby they are sharers in the hereditary a)ra/ on the Labdacid race.
a)/laston: cp. on 1482.
ai(=ma, as kinsfolk are of the same "blood": cp. Eur. Phoen. 246 koino\n ai(=ma, koina\ te/kea: O. T. 1406 ai(=m' e)mfu/lion, an incestuous kinship.
w(=|tini, dat. of interest, for whom: cp. 508 toi=s tekou=si ga\r | ou)d' ei) ponei= tis. As making the sense of po/non clearer, the dat. is preferable to the nom. dual, w(/tine (Badham).
to\n polu\n: for the art. cp. on 87.
e)n puma/tw|, "at the last," i.e. "at his death," as opp. to a)/llote me/n, i.e. "during his life."

a)lo/gista, things which baffle logismo/s, things which transcend human reason. As i)do/nte shows, the reference is to the mysterious manner of their father's death, while paqou/sa marks their loss by that death.

paroi/somen can only be explained with Hermann, as="we shall bring forward," "allege." "And we shall have to tell of things baffling reason, as seen and suffered by us at the end." This will seem less strained, I think, if we observe that Antigone need not be supposed to know of the Messenger's narrative. She may believe that she is bringing the Chorus the first intelligence of the event; and, if so, a)lo/gista paroi/somen would be no unsuitable preface. This view agrees with the next words of the Chorus, who ask ti/ d' e)/stin; as if uncertain what she means; and be/bhken; as if they did not know that Oedipus was gone. They do not wish to check the flow of her sorrow, to which utterance will be a relief. Cp. Eur. I. A. 981 ai)sxu/nomai de\ parafe/rous' oi)ktrou\s lo/gous, "advancing a plea to pity" (unless "bringing in" be preferable). Her. 9.26 kai\ kaina\ kai\ palaia\ parafe/rontes e)/rga, "citing" (as claims).—We cannot render paroi/somen "we shall suffer beside" (over and above our former sufferings), since the reference is to the fact of their bereavement, not to its prospective consequences.—Though the phrase is certainly strange, yet the defence indicated above may at least avail in arrest of judgment. If paroi/somen were to be altered, I should be disposed to suggest e)pera/samen ("we have gone through," cp. pera=n ki/ndunon etc.). The more obvious a)/por' oi)/somen and a)porh/somen are barred by the context.

i)do/nte kai\ paqou/sa. The difficulty is to explain how, if paqo/nte originally stood here, it was changed in the MSS. to paqou/sa, when i)do/nte (which metre requires) was more likely to cause an opposite change. I therefore leave paqou/sa in the text. And it is important to notice that a similar combination of forms (both attested by metre) occurs in an Attic inscription of about the second cent. B.C., edited by Kaibel, Epigr. 1110:
leukoi=sin fa/ressi kaluyame/na xro/a kalo\n
a)qana/twn meta\ fu=lon i)/ton prolipo/nt' a)nqrw/pous
*ai)dw\s *eu)nomi/h te.— Cp. Eur. Andr. 1214 w)= kaka\ paqw\n i)dw/n te.—See Appendix.

The Chorus ask, "And what is it?" She replies, e)/stin me
 ei)ka/sai, "we may conjecture" (to\ de\ safe\s ou)dei\s oi)=de). Cp. Eur. fr. 18 doca/sai e)/sti, ko/rai: to\ d' e)th/tumon ou)k e)/xw ei)pei=n. So 1656 mo/rw| d' o(poi/w| kei=nos w)/let' ou)d' a)
 ei(=s | qnhtw=n fra/seie. Better thus than, "you can guess."—The MS. ou)k e)/stin me
="we cannot conjecture." (Not, "I can liken my grief to no other," as Bellermann: schol. ou)de\ ei)ko/na e)/xw labei=n tou= pa/qous.)
ou)k requires us to omit me/n or else to alter v. 1704, where see n.

w(s ma/list' a)\n e)n po/qw| la/bois, as thou mightest most desire (that he should pass away). lamba/nein ti e)n po/qw|, to take a thing into one's desires, to conceive a wish for it; cp. Ant. 897 e)n e)lpi/sin tre/fw: e)n o)rgh=| e)/xein tina/ (Thuc. 2.21). For lamba/nein of mental conception, cp. 729.—The MS. ei) (for e)n) seems a mere mistake. The construction w(s ma/lista a)\n po/qw| la/bois, ei) (la/bois) is intolerable here.
ti/ ga/r, o(/tw|: "How else, when he," etc. For the causal use of the relat. see on 263.

mh/t' *)/arhs mh/te po/ntos. His death was sudden, yet not violent. Death in battle and death by drowning are taken as types of the death which is both sudden and violent. Schol.: w(=|tini mh/te po/lemos mh/te no/sos e)ph=lqen. This certainly looks as if he read something else than po/ntos. Cp. Ant. 819
ou)/te fqina/sin plhgei=sa no/sois
ou)/te cife/wn e)pi/xeira laxou=s'. Hence the conjecture nou=sos, a form which the Attic poets nowhere use. Wecklein's pureto\s is too specific (as if one said, "neither the War-God, nor typhoid").
I think that I can suggest the true solution. The schol.'s no/sos was a paraphrase of po/nos, a corruption of po/ntos which actually appears in the Vatican MS. here.
a)/skopoi … pla/kes, the "viewless fields" of the nether world (cp. on 1564).

fero/menon, pass., is clearly right, "borne away," helping e)/maryan to express sudden and swift disappearance. Plat. Phaedo 98B a)po\ dh\ qaumasth=s e)lpi/dos... w)|xo/mhn fero/menos, "from what a summit of hope was I hurled headlong": Rep. 496 D e)n xeimw=ni koniortou= kai\ za/lhs u(po\ pneu/matos ferome/nou. The midd. fero/menai, as "carrying off to themselves," would be somewhat strange, and also much less forcible.
o)leqri/a nu\c: cp. O. T. 1222 katekoi/mhsa tou)mo\n o)/mma, I have closed my eyes (as in death),—said, as here, in despairing grief.

a)pi/an ga=n, some distant land, the Homeric )a^pi/h gai/h (Il. 1.270 etc.). If the regular quantity, )a^pi/an, is to be kept here, we must read to/son, with Arndt, for toso/nd), in 1712. But toso/nd) is there confirmed by metre (see Metrical Analysis). In this word a_ is not found elsewhere. But, by a converse license, *)api/a (see on 1303) had sometimes a^ in later epos; and if, in poetical usage, the quantity of *)api/a could thus be affected by association with a)pi/h, it is conceivable that the influence should have been reciprocal.
a)lw/menai with acc. of space traversed, as Ai. 30 phdw=nta pedi/a.
du/soiston, not -ou, since bi/ou — trofa/n form one notion; cp. Ant. 793 nei=kos— a)ndrw=n cu/naimon.
kata\ … e(/loi=kaqe/loi: so 1709 a)na\...ste/nei (cp. O. T. 199 n.).
fo/nios here="deadly," in a general sense, as O. T. 24 (n.) foini/ou sa/lou (of the plague).

In this and some following passages the correspondence of strophe and antistrophe has been disturbed by interpolations, and also omissions, in the MSS. A kommo/s of this kind was peculiarly liable to corruption by the actors, and that has doubtless been one of the causes at work. (Cp. on 1737.) At some points it is now impossible to restore the text with certainty; but the whole extent of the mischief is small. In dealing with such points we can only use caution, and clearly recognise the doubtful nature of the ground.—On this passage, see note in Appendix.

The words patri\ cunqanei=n geraiw=| are not suspicious in themselves (though Nauck demurs to calling a dead man gerai/os); but they are in metrical excess of 1715 f. Now, if cunqanei=n geraiw=| is omitted, patri/ must go also, or else be altered. For e(/loi patri/ could not mean "take for" (i.e. to join) "my father." I prefer to leave patri\ cunqanei=n geraiw=|, and to suppose a lacuna after 1715. The sense is: "may deadly Hades lay me low (kaqe/loi"), so that I may share the death of mine aged sire. Cp. Ai. 516
kai\ mhte/r' a)/llh moi=ra to\n fu/santa/ te
kaqei=len *(/aidou qanasi/mous oi)kh/toras.
g' o( me/llwn is struck out by some. But it suits the sense, and it also fits the antistrophic metre, if in 1718 we add ta\s (with Hermann) before patro/s, —an addition probable in itself.

The MSS. give to\ fe/ron e)k qeou= kalw=s fe/rein xrh/. There has certainly been an interpolation, equivalent to uu-. (1) Some reject the words fe/rein xrh/. Then to\ fe/ron e)k qeou= kalw=s must be taken with fle/gesqon: "As to the fortune sent by heaven for your good, be not too passionate in grief" (pass.): or, if with Herm. the verb is made midd., "do not inflame the trouble sent for your good" (cp. the act. in Ai. 196 a)/tan ou)rani/an fle/gwn). So, if the MS. mhd' a)/gan is kept, mhd' ="do not on your part" (Herm., "etiam non debet vos tam vehementer urere"). But mhde\n a)/gan or mhd' e)/t' a)/gan (see cr. n.) gives in this case a clearer sense. (2) Wecklein, with whom I agree, rejects kalw=s and xrh/, keeping fe/rein. Then to\ fe/ron e)k qeou= fe/rein="bear the fate from heaven," the inf. standing for imperat., a use fitting in such a precept (O. T. 1529). The origin of the interpolated words is thus clear: xrh/ explained the use of the inf., while kalw=s was meant to fix the sense of fe/rein, lest to\ fe/ron should obscure it.
to\ fe/ron e)k qeou=,=the fortune from the god.

to\ fe/ron in this sense admits of two explanations. (1) "That which brings" good or evil. This view seems confirmed by the analogy of fors, fortuna (ferre): Ter. Ph. 1. 2. 88 quod fors feret, feremus: Cic. Att. 7. 14 ut fors tulerit, etc. (2) "That which carries" or "leads" us forward, in a course which we cannot control (cp. h( o(do\s fe/rei e)kei=se, and like phrases). This view might seem to be supported by the epigram of Palladas (c. 400 A.D.) in Anthol. P. 10. 73
h(=| to\ fe/ron se fe/rei, fe/re kai\ fe/rou: ei) d' a)ganaktei=s,
kai\ sauto\n lupei=s, kai\ to\ fe/ron se fe/rei: "as Fortune bears thee on, bear, and be borne; but if thou chafest, thou vexest thine own soul, and (none the less) she bears thee on." There, however, se fe/rei is said for the sake of a play on the word, and hardly warrants an inference as to the way in which to\ fe/ron was usually understood.—The conjecture to\ paro\n (cp. 1540) would be plausible only if there were reasons for thinking that to\ fe/ron in this sense was a phrase of postclassical date.

The MS. mhd' a)/gan ou(/tw answers to lh/gete tou=d' in 1722. The question is, Are we (1) to compress the former, or (2) to expand the latter? Dindorf and others prefer (1), and so eject ou(/tw, reading mhd' e)/t' (or mhde\n) a)/gan,=lh/gete tou=d'. This view agrees with the metre, and is adopted by Heinrich Schmidt (see Metr. Analysis). If, on the other hand, ou(/tw is kept here, then Hermann's lh/get' <h)/dh> tou=d' is the simplest supplement in 1722. For Wecklein's conjecture lh/get' <ai)nou=> tou=d' (Ars Soph. emendandi p. 81), it may be said that nou= might have dropped out before tou=: cp. Ai. 706 ai)no\n a)/xos.
ou)/toi kata/mempt' e)/bhton, "ye have fared not blameably": ye cannot justly complain of the destiny which has removed your father, in old age, by a painless death (cp. 1678).
kata/mempta, neut. pl. as adv.: cp. on 319.

bai/nein does not occur elsewhere in a strictly similar use, for we cannot compare the perf. eu)= bebhkw/s (El. 979) as="placed well," "prosperous." But there is at least some analogy in such figurative uses of it as Eur. Her. 625 a( d' a)reta\ bai/nei dia\ mo/xqwn, the path of virtue lies through troubles; H. F. 630 w(=d' e)/bht' e)pi\ curou=; "had ye come into such peril?" Ph. 20 so\s oi)=kos bh/setai di' ai(/matos, "will pass through deeds of blood":—where a certain course of fortune is expressed. Indeed, the metaphor is so easy and natural as hardly to demand special warrant in the case of bai/nw: e.g. O. T. 883 ei) de/ tis u(pe/ropta xersi\n h)\ lo/gw| poreu/etai ("walks haughtily"). I hold, then, that no suspicion of the text can fairly be founded on e)/bhton.

But the scholium in L is:—ou)/toi kata/memptos e)/bh: ou)k e)n toi=s toiou/tois e)/stai [Elmsley e)ste\] w(/ste katame/mfesqai: h)/toi w(s a)
 e)pikoufi/zontos au)tai=s th
 sumfora
 tou= basile/ws (Theseus). h)\ oi(=on, ou)k e)n xei/roni nu=n u(mi=n e)/stai ta\ pra/gmata. Does the lemma point to another reading? I do not think so. Papageorgius points out (Krit. und palaeogr. Beiträge z. d. alt. Sophoklesscholien, p. 59) that e)/bh was probably a mere slip, by the scholiast who copied the old scholia into L, for e)/bht (e)/bhton), while kata/memptos was a like error for katame/mptws. On the strength of this schol., however, (1) Nauck conjectured ou)/toi kata/memptos ai)=sa: (2) Hartung, ou)/toi kata/mempt' e)/bh ga/r: (3) M. Schmidt, ou)/toi kata/mempt' a)pe/sbh, which Wecklein adopts, citing Bekk. Anecd. 422 a)pe/sbh: e)sbe/sqh h)\ e)pau/sato, te/qnhken. But the word would ill suit the swift passing of Oed.: it rather suggests a gradual extinction of life: cp. Eur. Med. 1218 (after a long deathagony) xro/nw| d' a)pe/sbh kai\ meqh=x' o( du/smoros | yuxh/n.
< toi>: see on 1670.

a)/r' h)=n. The impf. of new perception: "there was such a thing, then" (all the time), though I did not know it before: Ph. 978 o(/d' h)=n a)/ra | o( cullabw/n me: Eur. fr. 807 me/giston a)=r' h)=n h( fu/sis: Plat. Gorg. 508C a(\ *pw=lon ai)sxu/nh| w)/|ou sugxwrei=n, a)lhqh= a)/ra h)=n, "were true all the time." (Distinguish the impf. of previous admission: ib. 478 C ou)...tou=t' h)=n eu)daimoni/a, "happiness, we agreed, was not this.")

The MS. to\ fi/lon fi/lon can only mean: "that which is in no way to\ fi/lon" (was) fi/lon. But the article is unendurable here, making her say, in effect, that her former duty was not the ideal of what is pleasant. It came in to patch the metre, when h)=n had dropped out. For mhdama/ instead of ou)dama/ cp. 73: for the neut. pl. form, 1104.
to\n= au)to/n: cp. 742.
w)= fi/los: for the nom. cp. on 185.
Join to\n a)ei\ kata\ ga=s sko/ton, the eternal darkness beneath the earth: there is no warrant for to\n a)ei/ with ellipse of xro/non as="for ever" (cp. 1584).

ei(me/nos: Pind. N. 11. 15
qnata\ memna/sqw periste/llwn me/lh,
kai\ teleuta\n a(pa/ntwn ga=n e)piesso/menos: Xen. Cyr. 6.4.6 e)pomnu/w...bou/lesqai a)\n...gh=n e)pie/ssasqai ma=llon h)\ zh=n.
