ou)de/ g' e)/nerq' is Wecklein's correction of the corrupt ou)de\ ge/rwn. In Linwood's ou)de\ ga\r w(\s (which Hartung and Blaydes adopt), ga/r will refer to her addressing him as w)= fi/los (1700). We might also conjecture ou)d' e)kei= w)\n, "not even in that other world" (Ai. 1372 ka)kei= ka)nqa/d' w)/n): for the hiatus cp. 1720 a)ll' e)pei\ o)lbi/ws.

ou)de\ ge/rwn yields no intelligible sense. (1) "Even though thou wast old at the time of thy death." (2) "Even though thou art old in Hades,"—the dead being supposed to remain such as they were at the time of death. (3) "Even when they memory is old"—i.e. after the lapse of years. This last is untenable: while neither (1) nor (2),—which Campbell blends by rendering "Even old as thou wast (or art),"—seems appropriate. She could hardly say that they would still love him though he had been so long with them, and had died at a ripe age.

The first e)/pracen is itself an argument for the second. A simple repetition is more fitting than e)ce/pracen. Cp. on 1677. Cp. Ai. 966
e)moi\ pikro\s te/qnhken h)\ kei/nois gluku/s,
au(tw=| de\ terpno/s: w)=n ga\r h)ra/sqh tuxei=n
e)kth/saq' au(tw=|, qa/naton o(/nper h)/qelen.
eu)ski/aston: cp. on 406. Pind. P. 11. 21 *)axe/rontos a)kta\n par' eu)/skion.

pe/nqos … a)/klauton: lit. "he did not leave behind him a mourning unhonoured by tears,"—i.e. he is duly mourned by weeping friends, as the spirits of the dead desired. Solon fr. 21
mhde/ moi a)/klautos qa/natos mo/loi, a)lla\ fi/loisin
poih/saimi qanw\n a)/lgea kai\ stonaxa/s.

In to/d' e)mo\n o)/mma dakru=on a)naste/nei (tmesis, 1689) se, it is truer to regard e)mo\n o)/mma as a periphrasis for e)gw/ than a)naste/nei as a mere synonym for "mourns." Cp. Ai. 139 pefo/bhmai | pthnh=s w(s o)/mma pelei/as, ib. 977 w)= fi/ltat' *ai)/as, w)= cu/naimon o)/mm' e)moi/.
to\ so\n a)/xos, grief for thee: cp. 419 n.
a)fani/sai, do away with, overcome (not, "conceal").
to/son, Arndt's correction of toso/nd), would give us the normal )a^pi/an in 1685 (n.).

w)/moi is Wecklein's correction of i)w\ mh/. That mh/ was an error for moi had already been surmised by some old corrector (see cr. n.). Hermann defended mh/ by taking it with e)/xrh|zes as="would that thou hadst not wished"—an unheardof construction (cp. on 540). He took e)/rhmos w(=de/ … moi as="lonely, just as thou wast, for me,"—i.e. in his wanderings before he had found Attic friends; since, if he had died while still alone with her, she could have given him burial herself.—With w)/moi render:—"Ah me, it was thy wish to die in a strange land (and so far thy death is well): but thus (by this manner of death) thou hast died forlorn in regard to me" (moi ethic dat.). She means, "I have had no opportunity of rendering thee the due rites, and now I do not know the place of thy grave, so as to make the e)nagi/smata" at it. Hence her passionate desire to find his grave (1724 ff.), which Theseus with difficulty allays by reminding her of his solemn promise (1760). The preparatory offices rendered at 1602 f. could not be viewed as taking the place of a daughter's tribute to the dead. Like 1410, this trait serves to recall the special manifestation of her piety in the earlier play.—Not merely:—"It was your wish; but it was sad for me to see you die forlorn,"—i.e. in exile. Though e)pi\ ce/nhs, he was not in this sense e)/rhmos,—he who, in his own words, had "Athens and all her people" for his friends (772).—Cp. 1705 a)=s e)/xrh|ze...e)/qane. The repetition of one phrase in no way justifies Dindorf's rash hypothesis of interpolation here (see cr. n.). Here, the wish is connected with a painful thought; there, with a soothing one. Mention of the wish itself might most naturally recur in a lament.

Cp. 1735 au)=qis w(=d' e)/rhmos a)/poros. Almost all critics are now agreed that the words e)/rhmos a)/poros were borrowed thence, to supply a gap here. But opinions differ as to whether we should here retain au)=qis, or w(=d', or both. I retain both. See Metrical Analysis, and Appendix on 1690.

e)/luse to\ te/los … bi/ou, lit., "closed the end of life," a pleonasm which blends e)/luse bi/on and a)fi/keto to\ te/los bi/ou: so Eur. El. 956 te/los ka/myh| bi/ou instead of the simple ka/myh|s bi/on (Helen. 1666). The phrase lu/ein bi/on occurs Eur. I. T. 692, katalu/ein bi/oton Suppl. 1004.
lh/gete: cp. on 1694.

kakw=n dusa/lwtos, hard for calamity to capture. Every mortal is an easy prey to misfortune. The gen. as 1519: Ai. 910 a)/fraktos fi/lwn, Ant. 847 fi/lwn a)/klautos, ib. 1034 mantikh=s | a)/praktos. In prose a prep. would usu. be added, as Xen. Ages. 8. 8. 8 tei/xh a)na/lwta...u(po\ polemi/wn. — Cp. Shaksp. Hen. VI. Pt. iii. 1. 4. 115 "their woes, whom fortune captivates."

pa/lin … suqw=men, hasten back (601) to the neighbourhood of the katarra/kths o)do/s (1590).—w(s ti/ r(e/comen; w(s with the fut. indic., depending on suqw=men, is the object-clause after a verb implying effort: Xen. Cyr. 3.2.13 w(s de\ kalw=s e(/cei ta\ u(me/tera, e)moi\ melh/sei. With the fut. indic., however, o(/pws is much commoner than w(s.

The MS. text of this verse does not answer metrically to 1739. Bergk and Gleditsch alter both verses (see cr. n.). Hermann, whose remedy is simplest, leaves this v. intact, and in 1739 reads *x*o. kai\ pa/ros a)pe/fuge *a*n. ti/; See n. there.
ta\n xqo/nion e(sti/an, the home, resting-place, in the ground (1763 qh/ken i(era/n). Oedipus had himself spoken in her hearing of the i(ero\s tu/mbos (1545) where he was to rest.
qe/mis … ta/d': cp. 883: O. T. 1329.
mw=n ou)x o(ra=|s; dost thou not see for thyself that it cannot be?—since Oedipus solemnly forbade it (1529, 1640).
mw=n ou) is a strong nonne? (Aesch. Suppl. 417, Eur. Med. 733, Plat. Polit. 291D, etc.).
e)pe/plhcas, sc. moi: "what is this reproof of thine to me?"
kai\ to/d) still depends on ou)x o(ra=|s;
ma/l' au)=qis: cp. 1477.
e)/pitne, impf., must be either (1) "was appointed to perish," or (2) "was perishing" when we last saw him. (2) seems best.

di/xa te panto/s, "apart from all": i.e. without any eye-witness (save Theseus).—Better thus than, "in a manner different from all other men."—Ismene opposes her sister's desire as (1) unlawful, and (2) impossible.

a)/ge me. "Lead me (to the spot where we last saw our father), and then slay me also." In e)pena/ricon the prep.= "in addition" (i.e. to my father). Not, "slay me at his grave" (Eur. Hec. 505 ka)/m' e)pisfa/cai ta/fw|). She could not intend this after Ismene's words a)/tafos e)/pitne, to which she had been attentive. Cp. Ismene's wish, 1689.

The MS. poi= dh=t)...e(/cw has been defended in two ways, neither of which is satisfactory: (1) by an ellipse of molou=sa: (2) as="until when?" As in 383 (n.) we should read o(/pou for o(/poi, and in 335 (n.) pou= for poi=, so here I feel sure that pou= is right. It suits the sense better than the v.l. ph=|, besides being closer to the MSS. The v.l. a)/cw, (which would justify poi=,) is plainly a mere corruption of e(/cw.
au)=qis, lit., "now again," i.e. after this new turn in our unhappy fortunes.

In these verses the utterances usually assigned to Antigone all turn on her anxiety as to a refuge, and her desire to return to Thebes. Such feelings, at this moment, are more in harmony with the character of Ismene (cp. 1735). Antigone is at present absorbed in the yearning to visit her father's tomb, or at least the spot where she last saw him alive (1724). When Theseus appears, it is this wish which she instantly presses on him. Only when it has been put aside does she think of a return to Thebes (1769).

Ought we, then, to read *i*s. for *a*n. throughout vv. 1737—1750? This has been suggested by Bergk. I may observe that the Laur. MS. leaves the question open. At 1730 it has *a*n. before ti/ to/d' e)pe/plhcas. After that, there is no indication of any person, but only short lines (-), until at 1741 *a*n. again stands before fronw=. The next words, ti/ dh=q' etc., have *x*o. before them: but after that no person is indicated till 1751, where *x*o. (instead of *q*h.) is erroneously placed before pau/ete.

I am disposed to think that Sophocles wrote the words for Ismene, but that the fourth-actor difficulty had led to a fluctuation of stage-practice, which helps to account for the ambiguity of the MS. tradition. See the note on the Dramatis Personae. If the part of Ismene, after v. 509, was ever taken by a kwfo\n pro/swpon, there may then have been a wish to keep her part in this scene as small as possible. Similarly at 1689 ff. there is a doubt as to which sister ought to have the words ou) ka/toida...biwto/s.
fu/gw: cp. on 170.

The MS. a)pefeu/geton is most simply corrected to a)pefu/geton. But then we must either (1) add ti/ dh/, and expand v. 1726, as Bergk and Gleditsch do (cr. n. ad l.): or (2), leaving v. 1726 intact, suppose that vv. 1739, 1740 are spoken by the Chorus without any interpellation by Antigone. This, however, is improbable, and also injurious to the point of v. 1740. Further, with a)pefu/geton, v. 1740 has a construction which makes the order of the words harsh, viz.: —"Ye escaped,"

to\ mh\ ta\ sfw=|n pi/tnein kakw=s, "so that your affairs should not fall out ill" (Xen. Anab. 1.3.2 *kle/arxos mikro\n a)pe/fuge mh\ katapetrwqh=nai). I therefore incline to Hermann's a)pe/fuge *a*n. ti/; "Long ago there was an escape"— *a*n. "For what?" [lit. "what escaped?"]— *c*h. "For your fortunes, from falling out ill." The merits of this reading are:—(1) it leaves v. 1725, which seems quite sound, unaltered: (2) by making ta\ sfw=|n nom. to a)pe/fuge, it smooths v. 1740. It may be added that, with a)pefu/geton, v. 1740 is somewhat pointless, since the mere allusion in ta\ sfw=|n to Creon's attempt is too vague to answer Antigone's ti/; ("what did we escape?"). Most "escapes" are escapes from "one's affairs falling out ill."

fronw=, I am conscious of that, —"I know it well,"—in quick and grateful response to their allusion. Theseus and the men of Attica had indeed rescued her and her sister in their extremity. Not, "I am thinking...," for (a) the question ti/ dh=q' refers back to her poi= fu/gw; and (b) some acknowledgement was due to their reminder.—The MS. u(pernoei=s, as Hermann saw, is corrupt. The compound, which occurs only here, could not mean (1) "why art thou too anxious?" (Wunder): nor (2) "what further hast thou in thy thoughts?"—Hermann's u(pennoei=s is a compound used by Aelian Var. Hist. 4. 8 as="to have a secret thought or purpose." But the word seems scarcely appropriate in regard to thoughts which, far from hiding, she is in the act of uttering. Graser's o(/per noei=s is so far closer to the MSS. that u for o would be an easier mistake than r for n.

o(/pws molou/meq': "how we are to return to Thebes, I know not":—for Oedipus had predicted that both her brothers would soon fall in the war (1373), and Creon, the next heir to the throne, was no friend. This continues the thought poi= fu/gw; (1737). The interposed words of the Chorus did not touch her difficulty.
mhde/ ge ma/teue: "No, (thou canst not return to Thebes,) nor seek to do so,"—but stay in Attica under the protection of Theseus.
mo/gos e)/xei, sc. h(ma=s.

e)pei=xe, "bore hardly on you," sc. u(mi=n or e)f' u(ma=s: for mo/gos e)pei=xen u(ma=s would mean, "restrained you." The MS. e)pei/ doubtless arose from a contraction of e)pei=xe. The sense of e)ph/|ei, "was coming on you," would be less apt; and the preceding e)/xei also confirms e)pei=xe.

tote\ me\n … u(/perqen. Whitelaw: "Oh then past cure, but worst is now grown worse." The neut. plur. is most simply taken as adverb (319), referring to mo/gos e)pei=xe: though we might also construe, a)/pora (h)=n ta\ h(me/tera).
tote\ me\n … tote\ de/, "at one time" (i.e. while Oed. lived)... "at another time" (i.e. now that he is dead).
u(/perqen, hyperbolic, since a)/pora already="hopeless": cp. fr. 188 w)= pa=n su\ tolmh/sasa kai\ pe/ra, gu/nai.
pe/lagos, without kakw=n or the like, is excused by the familiarity of this metaphor in Greek: cp. on 663.

feu=, feu=. Dindorf substitutes ai)ai=, because he supposes the latter to have generated the nai\ nai/ which, with the words cu/mfhmi kau)to/s, he ejects (see cr. n.). But so common a form as ai)ai= was not very likely to be thus corrupted. It is simpler to suppose that the ejected phrase was a mere interpolation, perhaps due to actors.

e)lpi/dwn ga\r e)s ti/n): lit., "(we may well ask whither we are to go,) for towards what remaining (e)/ti) hope of (all possible) hopes is fate now urging us?" What hope now remains for us, in the course on which we are driven? For e)/ti, which here is virtually equiv. to an adj. loiph/n, cp. 865 th=sde th=s a)ra=s e)/ti.

e)lpi/dwn in its good sense, rather than neutral or sinister ("bodings"): cp. El. 958
poi= ga\r menei=s r(a/|qumos, e)s ti/n' e)lpi/dwn
ble/yas' e)/t' o)rqh/n

div3.head: 1751-1779: Closing episode
div3.p: qrh=non, not qrh/nwn, is clearly right. The 2nd per. sing. imper., pau=e, is the only part of pau/w which is used intransitively by the classical Attic writers,—being, in fact, an exclamation (like our "stop!"), though sometimes joined with a gen. (pau=e tou= lo/gou, Aristoph. Ran. 580). No weight can be given to the fact that L has qrh/nwn here, since it has it also in 1778 (see cr. n.).

cu/n' a)po/keitai for the MS. cu^napo/keitai is (I think) right. The literal sense is:— e)n oi(=s ga\r "for in a case where" (neut. pl.), xa/ris h( xqoni/a "the kindness shown by the xqo/nioi," cu/n' a)po/keitai "is stored up as a common benefit" (cuna/, neut. pl. as adv.),—common, namely, to Oedipus and the Athenians. That is:—"By the death of Oedipus, the Powers below have given him the everlasting rest which he desired, and us the abiding safeguard which he promised" (i.e. his grave). To mourn here would be to provoke the deities who have ordered all things well for him and for us.—

a)po/keitai, is laid up in store: cp. [Dem.] or. 23 § 42 to\ th=s suggnw/mhs w)fe/limon...o(/tw| pote\ tw=n pa/ntwn a)po/keitai a)/dhlon o)/n, it being uncertain for whom the benefit of compassion is laid up,—i.e., who may need to draw upon it. Dem. or. 18 § 198 o(/tw| ta\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn a)tuxh/mata e)neudokimei=n a)pe/keito, "a man to whom the disasters of his countrymen were a fund of material for self-glorification." In the literal sense, Xen. Anab. 2.3.15 au)tai\ de\ ai( ba/lanoi tw=n foini/kwn, oi(/as me\n e)n toi=s *(/ellhsin e)/stin i)dei=n, toi=s oi)ke/tais a)pe/keinto, ai( de\ toi=s despo/tais a)pokei/menai h)=san.

For cuna/ (adv.) cp. Ant. 546 mh/ moi qa/nh|s su\ koina/, along with me: Ai. 577 ta\ d' a)/lla teu/xh koi/n' e)moi\ teqa/yetai.—The schol. found the passage a)safe/s, but saw part of the general sense: ne/mesis ga/r e)sti tou=ton qrhnei=n w(=| ta\ th=s teleuth=s kata\ xa/rin a)pe/bh. See Appendix.

ne/mesis ga/r, sc. penqei=n e)sti/: it is provocative of divine anger to mourn, as if insensible of the divine beneficence. Il. 14.80 ou) ga/r tis ne/mesis fuge/ein kako/n, "'tis no matter for indignation that one should flee from ill": Od. 1.350 tou/tw| d' ou) ne/mesis...a)ei/dein: Arist. Rhet. 2.9.11 e)a\n ou)=n a)gaqo\s w)\n mh\ tou= a(rmo/ttontos tugxa/nh|, nemeshto/n: where, however, the ne/mesis is human, not, as here, divine. Cp. El. 1467 ei) d' e)/pesti ne/mesis, ou) le/gw (in revoking words which might offend the gods).
ti/nos … xrei/as, "for what request,"—depending on the idea of deo/meqa, xrh/|zomen, implied in prospi/tnomen:
a)nu/sai (sc. au)th/n), epexegetic inf., "so that ye should obtain it": cp. 1211 (n.).—For the use of xrei/as, cp. O. T. 1435 kai\ tou= me xrei/as w(=de liparei=s tuxei=n;
au)tai\, with our own eyes (instead of merely hearing that it exists).

The MS. words kei=se molei=n, which I omit, were almost certainly a gloss upon a)ll' ou) qemito/n. If we keep them, then we must add something more, so as to make an anapaestic dimeter (see cr. n.). Campbell defends a)ll' ou) qemito\n kei=se molei=n as a paroemiac; but it is not such. In a paroemiac the penultimate syllable is necessarily long (as if here we had kei=s' e)lqei=n).
a)pei=pen, forbade, takes mh/ after it, as is usual (cp. O. T. 236 a)paudw= ...mh/); Aeschin. or. 1 § 138 tau=ta toi=s dou/lois a)pei=pon mh\ poiei=n.

mh/t' e)pifwnei=n … qh/khn must be carefully distinguished from e)pifwnei=n qh/kh|. The former must mean strictly (not, "to utter over the grave," but) "to approach the grave with utterance,"—the notion being that of invading the secret silence around it. Invocations and prayers to the dead were often made aloud at a grave: Eur. Helen 961
le/cw ta/d' a)mfi\ mnh=ma sou= patro\s po/qw|:
w)= ge/ron, o(\s oi)kei=s to/nde la/i+non ta/fon, etc.—The alternative is to take e)pifwnei=n as="mention to another": but this is unfitting, since Theseus alone knows the place.

If mhdeni\ were substituted for mhde/na, this would give a much easier sense; but then Theseus must be the subject to both infinitives:—"he forbade me to approach, ...or to tell." According to Greek ideas, however, Theseus, at least, ought occasionally to visit the grave with e)nagi/smata: and in fact the rendering of such honours is implied by the provision that the place of the grave should always be known to one person (1531). I therefore keep mhde/na.
qh/khn i(era/n: cp. 1545. Thuc. 1.8 tw=n qhkw=n a)naireqeisw=n o(/sai h)=san tw=n teqnew/twn e)n th=| nh/sw|.

kalw=s with pra/ssonta (not with e(/cein), "in a seemly manner," "duly" (Lat. rite): cp. 617: O. T. 879 to\ kalw=s d' e)/xon | po/lei pa/laisma. The fact that pra/ssonta kalw=s usually meant "faring well" is no objection. The ancient Greek instinct for words was remarkably free from bondage to phrases. Cp. Ant. 989 n.
a)/lupon: an echo of the expression used by Oed. (1519). Why change it to a)dh=|on (1533, Nauck), or a)/sulon (Wecklein)?

tau=t' ou)=n: "These things, then, (ou)=n, according to the injunctions of Oedipus,) I was heard to promise by the god," etc. tau=t) is short for "the promise to do these things," as if u(pisxnoume/nwn stood with h(mw=n. For e)/kluen with both gen. and acc. cp. O.T. 235.
dai/mwn: the Divine Power that called Oedipus away (1626).
pa/nt' a)i+/wn: cp. 42. The a of a)i+/w short, as in 240 and Ph. 1410: whereas it is long in 181, 304, Ai. 1263.

*dio\s *(/orkos, as the servant of Zeus. Hes. Op. 803
e)n pe/mpth| ga/r fasin *)erinu/as a)mfipoleu/ein
*(/orkon geino/menon, to\n *)/eris te/ke ph=m' e)pio/rkois. This personified Horkis is a deity who witnesses an oath, and punishes perjury (Hes. Theog. 231). He is the son of Eris, because strife gives birth to treaties; he is attended at his birth by the Erinyes, because they avenge broken faith. And he is the servant of Zeus, because *zeu\s *(/orkios is the supreme guardian of good-faith — represented in the bouleuth/rion at Olympia by a Zeus with lightnings in both hands, —the most terrible, Pausanias says, that he knew: pa/ntwn o(po/sa a)ga/lmata *dio\s ma/lista e)s e)/kplhcin a)di/kwn a)ndrw=n (5. 24. 9)
kata\ nou=n. Ar. Eq. 549 kata\ nou=n pra/cas: so oft. kata\ gnw/mhn.
ta/d' … tau=t': cp. on 787.

ta=s w)gugi/ous: a specially fit epithet, since the mythical *)wgu/ghs was represented (in one legend at least) as son of Boeotus, and first ruler of Thebes (Paus. 9.5.1). Another legend connected him with Attica (Paus. 1.38.7). The trait common to the two legends is a great inundation which happened in his reign. The adj. is applied by Aesch. to Thebes (Th. 321 po/lin w)gugi/an, Pers. 37 ta/s t' w)gugi/ous *qh/bas), and also to Athens (Pers. 974). The Attic poets used it in the general sense of "very ancient," as Phil. 142 kra/tos w)gu/gion, "royalty inherited from of old."

i)o/nta, a pres., not fut., partic. (O. T. 773 n.), "coming on them": El. 374 kako
...ei)s au)th
 i)o/n: Plat. Legg. 873E para\ qeou=...be/los i)o/n. So Ant. 185 th
 a)/thn o(rw=n | stei/xousan a)stoi=s.
o(mai/mois: see on 330.

Antigone suggests that she and Ismene may yet be in time to plead with their two brothers, and so to avert the doom of mutual destruction pronounced on them by their father (1373). Thus the close of this drama is linked by the poet with the beginning of his earlier Antigone, which opens at a moment just after the deaths of the brothers. The sisters are then living at Thebes, where Creon has succeeded to the throne. An additional pathos is lent to Antigone's part there by the suggestion here of a previous intercession. In Aesch. Theb. it is the Chorus (of Theban maidens) that endeavours to dissuade Eteocles from going to meet his brother (677 ff.): in Eur. Phoen. it is their mother Iocasta who seeks to reconcile them (452 ff.).

After ou) in 1776 the MS. ga/r must be struck out, as Hermann saw, so that the anapaests spoken by Theseus may end with a paroemiac. When anapaests spoken by the Chorus close a tragedy, these always form a system separate from the anapaests (if any) which precede them. This was plainly necessary, in order to avoid an unduly abrupt ending. But if we point thus:— pro\s xa/rin: ou) dei= m' a)poka/mnein, the asyndeton has a crude effect. Hence, placing only a comma after pro\s xa/rin, we should render:— "Not only will I do these things, but in all things which I am likely to do for your advantage (etc.) I must not wax weary." The sentence begins as if the constr. was to be dra/sw kai\ ta/de kai\ pa/nta. But the new verb added at the end requires pa/nta to be acc. with a)poka/mnein. (Cp. on 351.)

o(po/s' a)
 seems slightly preferable to o(/sa g' a)
 as a correction of the MS. o(/s' a)
 (or o(/sa a)
), because the qualification which g) would imply is sufficiently provided for by pro/sfora etc.: cp. 1634
telei=n d' o(/s' a)

me/llh|s fronw=n eu)= cumfe/ront' au)tai=s a)ei/.

pra/ssein, pres. inf. with me/llw, as in eight other places of Sophocles. He has the fut. inf. with it ten times, including O. T. 967, where the MS. ktanei=n, if sound, would be the only instance of the aor. inf. with me/llw in Soph.; but there the fut. ktenei=n is clearly right. Where me/llw means "to delay," the pres. inf. is naturally preferred: cp. 1627: O. T. 678 ti/ me/lleis komi/zein do/mwn to/nd' e)/sw;
pro/sfora/ q' u(mi=n, kai\ pro\s xa/rin tw=| kata\ gh=s: at once for your advantage, and to the gratification of the dead.
pro/sfora, "suitable" for a given purpose, and so "useful,""profitable": so often in Attic prose, as Thuc. 1.125; 2. 46, 65; 7. 62.
pro\s xa/rin: cp. O. T. 1152 n.

e)/rrei is justified by the sudden and swift removal of Oedipus, as O. T. 560 a)/fantos e)/rrei, he hath been swept from men's sight. In El. 57 tou)mo
 w(s e)/rrei de/mas | flogisto
 h)/dh, it is little more than oi)/xetai. More commonly e)/rrein implies either an evil end, or at least some feeling of contempt on the speaker's part, as Eur. Suppl. 1112
ou(\s xrh=n, e)peida
 mhde
 w)felw=si gh=n,
qano/ntas e)/rrein ka)kpodwn ei)=nai ne/ois. Wecklein regards the words o(\s ne/on e)/rrei as a spurious addition (Ars Soph. em. p. 81).

a)poka/mnein, "to cease from labouring," can take an acc. of the labour avoided: hence pa/nq' in 1773 need not be merely acc. of respect. Xen. Hellen. 7.5.19 po/non...mhde/na a)poka/mnein, "to flinch from no toil." Also with inf., Plat. Crito 45B mh\ a)poka/mh|s sauto\n sw=sai, "do not abandon the effort to save yourself." So e)kka/mnw, Thuc. 2.51 ta\s o)lofu/rseis tw=n a)pogignome/nwn...e)ce/kamon, "were worn out by the lamentations of the dying." For the form of the sentence cp. Plat. Rep. 445B e)peidh\ e)ntau=qa e)lhlu/qamen, o(/son oi(=o/n te safe/stata katidei=n o(/ti tau=ta ou(/tws e)/xei, ou) xrh\ a)poka/mnein. For this force of a)po/ cp. a)palge/w, a)panqe/w, a)poze/w, a)pokhdeu/w, a)polofu/romai.
a)ll) introduces the final words of comfort which the elders of Colonus address to the Theban maidens; cp. 101.
a)popau/ete, no less than the following verb, governs qrh=non: cp. on 1751.

Though the neut. pl. plei/w alone is sometimes adverbial, there seems to be no instance of e)pi\ plei/w as=e)pi\ ple/on: indeed, such a phrase is hardly conceivable. e)pi\ must therefore belong to e)gei/rete: for the tmesis cp. on 1689.

e)/xei … ku=ros, lit., "have validity," = keku/rwtai, sancta sunt. Cp. El. 919 pollw=n...ku=ros...kalw=n ("sanction of"), Aesch. Suppl. 391 ou)k e)/xousi ku=ros...a)mfi\ sou=, "authority over thee." — Two meanings are possible: (1) "These promises of Theseus are certain to hold good": or, more generally, (2) "These events have assuredly been ordained past recall" (by the gods). Most commentators prefer (1). But (2) seems more fitting at the conclusion. The last soothing words of the Chorus convey a precept of resignation to the divine will.

Fr. Ritter rejects the last three verses, as he rejects the choral clausulae of all the other six plays (Philol. XVII. 422-436): cp. O. T. 1524 cr. n. Here, at least, there is not a shadow of ground for the suspicion. It did not require a Sophocles to write vv. 1777-1779, but the burden of proof rests with those who deny that he wrote them.
